synonyms: Aerospace Studies I (Air Force Mission and Organization)
AEST-100B.title: Aerospace Studies I (Air Force Mission and Organization)
AEST-100B.description: Organization and function of NORAD; Tactical Air, Military Airlift, Systems, Logistics, Air Training, and Communications Commands; Army, Navy, Marines; Reserves; Separate Operating Agencies.

AEST-110B.title: Leadership Laboratory I
AEST-110B.description: Introduction to the military experiecne focusing on customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and the environment of an Air Force Officer. Graded CR/NC.

AEST-200B.title: Aerospace Studies II (Air Force History)
AEST-200B.description: Development of aerospace power since WWII; emphasis on international confrontations involving the U.S.; communications skills.

AEST-210B.title: Leadership Laboratory II
AEST-210B.description: Introduction to the military experience focusing on customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and the environment of an Air Force Offficer. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Aerospace Studies III (Air Force Management and Leadership)
AEST-300B.title: Aerospace Studies III (Air Force Management and Leadership)
AEST-300B.description: Air Force management fucusing on the new manager in the Air Force milieu. Emphasis on communication skills peculiar to the Air Force.

AEST-310B.title: Leadership Laboratory III
AEST-310B.description: Practical introduction to Air Force leadership focusing on military communicative skills, group dynamics, and application of theories of leadership and management. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Aerospace Studies IV (National Security Forces in Contemporary American Society)
AEST-400B.title: Aerospace Studies IV (National Security Forces in Contemporary American Society)
AEST-400B.description: (AEROSPACE STUDIES IV - NATIONAL SECURITY FORCES IN CONTEMPORARY AMERICAN SOCIETY - Military professionalism and the context in which defense policy is formulated and implemented; national security policy, political/social constraints, and military justice.

AEST-410B.title: Leadership Laboratory IV
AEST-410B.description: Advanced Air Forcer leadership experience forcusing on the practical development of the Air Force officer through command and staff positions within the Cadet Corps. Graded CR/NC.

AEST-420B.title: Leadership Laboratory V
AEST-420B.description: Advanced leadership experiences for AFROTC continuing cadets. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Elective Courses in English as a Second Language for International Students
ALI-103.title: Elective Courses in English as a Second Language for International Students
ALI-103.description: Specialized tutorial classes in listening, speaking, reading, or writing. A maximum of 4 units may be counted toward a degree. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Elementary English as a Second Language for International Students
ALI-200.title: Elementary English as a Second Language for International Students
ALI-200.description: Required for international students assessed to be at the beginning level by the International Student English Exam (ISE) or by the completion of a lower level ALI course.

synonyms: Low Intermediate ESL (I) for International Students
ALI-210.title: Low Intermediate ESL (I) for International Students
ALI-210.description: Required for international students assessed to be at the low intermediate level by the International Student English Exam (ISE) or by the completion of a lower level ALI course. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: High Intermediate ESL for International Students
ALI-220.title: High Intermediate ESL for International Students
ALI-220.description: Required for international students assessed to be at the high intermediate level by the International Student English Exam (ISE) or by the completion of a lower level ALI course. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Oral Skills for International Graduate Students in Science and Technology
ALI-230.title: Oral Skills for International Graduate Students in Science and Technology
ALI-230.description: Required for international students assessed to be at the intermediate level in oral skills by the International Student English Exam (ISE) or by the completion of a lower level ALI course.

synonyms: Writing Skills for International Graduate Students in Science and Technology
ALI-231.title: Writing Skills for International Graduate Students in Science and Technology
ALI-231.description: Required for international students assessed to be at the intermediate level in writing skills by the International Student English Exam (ISE) or by the completion of a lower level ALI course.

synonyms: Advanced English as a Second Language for International Students
ALI-240.title: Advanced English as a Second Language for International Students
ALI-240.description: Required for students assessed to be at the advanced level by the International Student English Exam (ISE) or by the completion of a lower level ALI course.

ALI-258.title: Writing Workshop
ALI-258.description: Required for international students assessed by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or by completion of a lower level ALI course to be at the post-advanced level in all skills except writing. Graded CR/NC.

ALI-259.title: Oral Skills
ALI-259.description: Required for international students assessed by the International Student English Examination (ISE) or by completion of a lower level ALI course to be at the post-advanced level in all skills except speaking. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Oral Skills for International Teaching Assistants
ALI-270.title: Oral Skills for International Teaching Assistants
ALI-270.description: Classroom interaction skills for International Teaching Assistants, with a focus on the language needed to lead discussions and make presentations. Open to International Teaching Assistants only.

synonyms: Language Tutorial for International Teaching Assistants
ALI-271.title: Language Tutorial for International Teaching Assistants
ALI-271.description: Individualized tutorial on the language and oral skills used by International Teaching Assistants in the performance of his or her duties. Based on observation and feedback. Open to International Teaching Assistants only.

AMST-100O.title: Off Campus Studies
AMST-100O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution appears as a section title on USC transcript.

synonyms: Race and Class in Los Angeles
AMST-101.title: Race and Class in Los Angeles
AMST-101.description: Analysis of race and the economic, political, gender, and social dimensions of contemporary Los Angeles including topics such as residential segregation, economic inequality, and city politics.

AMST-133.title: Religions of Latin America
AMST-133.description: Examines the diverse and complex religious traditions of Latin America.

AMST-202.title: Interethnic Diversity in the West
AMST-202.description: Introduction to community, culture, and ethnicity within the Western United States with emphasis on African American, Asian American, and Chicano/Latino cultures and social patterns. Recommended preparation: AMST 301.

AMST-274.title: Exploring Ethnicity Through Film
AMST-274.description: Examination of the constructions of American ethnicity/race in film.

synonyms: America, the Frontier, and the New West
AMST-301.title: America, the Frontier, and the New West
AMST-301.description: Introduction to an interdisciplinary study of American political, cultural and social life with a particular emphasis on the Western United States as a region. Recommended preparation: HIST 200, ENGL 263

AMST-328.title: Asian American Politics
AMST-328.description: Examines political attitudes, behavior and participation of Asian Americans in diverse U.S. society.

synonyms: Junior Seminar in American Studies and Ethnicity: Theories and Methods
AMST-350.title: Junior Seminar in American Studies and Ethnicity: Theories and Methods
AMST-350.description: Advanced study in interdisciplinary theories and methods for analyzing race and ethnicity in the United Stes, including a comparative study of topics such as inequality, gender, and class.

AMST-365.title: Leadership in the Community -- Internship
AMST-365.description: 8-10 hours per week in a community-based internship plus 2 hour class discussion. Theoretical and practical issues associated with community leadership.

AMST-373.title: History of the Mexican American
AMST-373.description: Racial and cultural background of Mexico; immigration and conquest; the Mexican in California and the southwest; the rise of contemporary Mexican-American consciousness.

AMST-378.title: Introduction to Asian American History
AMST-378.description: Comparative examination of the social, economic, and political experiences of Asian immigrants and their descendants in the U.S., 1840s-present.

AMST-380.title: American Popular Culture
AMST-380.description: Rise of popular culture (sports, amusment parks, movies, and televsion) and its significance in American society from mid 19th century to the present.

AMST-392.title: Undergraduate Research Methods
AMST-392.description: Examines processes of scholarly research; quantitative and qualitative research methods; faculty mentorship; experiential learning; research proposal writing; careers in research. Sophomore or junior standing in the major. Departmental approval. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Racial and Ethnic Relations in a Global Society
AMST-432.title: Racial and Ethnic Relations in a Global Society
AMST-432.description: Examination of race/ethnic relations with U.S. and selected countries from a global perspective, causes and social effects of globalization on people's lives and on U.S. attitudes and political policies.

AMST-442.title: American Literature, 1920 to the Present
AMST-442.description: American poetry, fiction, and drama since World War I with special attention to Eliot, Frost, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, O'Neill, Stevens, Faulkner, and Nabokov.

AMST-449.title: Asian American Literature
AMST-449.description: Survey of Asian American literature from the earliest time to the present; development of prose, poetry, and novel.

AMST-490.title: Directed Research
AMST-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

synonyms: Senior Seminar in American Studies and Ethnicity
AMST-498.title: Senior Seminar in American Studies and Ethnicity
AMST-498.description: Capstone course for majors, highlighting interdisciplinary study of race and ethnicity in a comparative context.

AMST-590.title: Directed Research
AMST-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the program. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Interdisciplinary Research Seminar in Race and Ethnicity
AMST-660.title: Interdisciplinary Research Seminar in Race and Ethnicity
AMST-660.description: Explores issues of conducting interdisciplinary research in race and ethnicity and guides students through the design and completion of a journal-quality research paper. Recommended preparation: graduate reading course in race and ethnicity

synonyms: Interdisciplinary Research Seminar on Los Angeles
AMST-670.title: Interdisciplinary Research Seminar on Los Angeles
AMST-670.description: Introduces students to issues of urban-based research concerning Los Angeles and guides students through the design and completion of a journal-quality research paper. Recommended preparation: graduate reading course on Los Angeles

synonyms: Interdisciplinary Research Seminar in Cultural Studies
AMST-680.title: Interdisciplinary Research Seminar in Cultural Studies
AMST-680.description: Explores theoretical approaches to cultural studies as an interdisciplinary field and guides students through the design and completion of a journal-quality research paper. Recommended preparation: graduate reading course in cultural studies

AMST-790.title: Research
AMST-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

AMST-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

AMST-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

AMST-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

AMST-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

AMST-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AMST-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ANTH-100O.title: Off-Campus Studies
ANTH-100O.description: Coursework taken off campus. Title of Course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

ANTH-101.title: Body, Mind and Healing
ANTH-101.description: The body, illness and healing from a cultural perspective, including comparative studies of folk healing systems, curing rituals and Western biomedical practices.

synonyms: Native Peoples of Mexico and Central America
ANTH-140.title: Native Peoples of Mexico and Central America
ANTH-140.description: An exploration of the nature and contributions of pre-Columbian high civilizations (Maya, Aztecs, etc.) and their descendants as they resist and assimilate to the modern world.

ANTH-200.title: The Origins of Humanity
ANTH-200.description: The foundations of the human species. Examination of scientific evidence from Darwinian theory, primate behavior, fossils, and the behavior of modern people.

synonyms: The Changing Pacific: Culture, History and Politics in the New South Seas
ANTH-235.title: The Changing Pacific: Culture, History and Politics in the New South Seas
ANTH-235.description: Current social and political developments in the South Pacific analyzed from the perspective of the historical relationship between indigenous cultures and the West.

ANTH-263.title: Exploring Culture Through Film
ANTH-263.description: Concepts of social anthropology using filmic representations of societies throughout the world in contrast to written ethnography.

ANTH-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
ANTH-300O.description: Courseork taken off campus. Title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

ANTH-310.title: Archaeology of the Americas
ANTH-310.description: Precolumbian culture from early hunters to the Spanish conquest in major geographical areas of Mexico, Central America, Peru, or the United States.

synonyms: North American Indians in American Public Life
ANTH-316.title: North American Indians in American Public Life
ANTH-316.description: Role of American Indians in American public life from colonial times to the present; native American forms of government; relations between tribes and the U.S.

synonyms: Imaging Indians: From Warriors to Windtalkers
ANTH-317.title: Imaging Indians: From Warriors to Windtalkers
ANTH-317.description: An historical and anthropological overview of 500 years of the presentation of differing and, often, contradictory perceptions of Native American life and character in popular and academic media.

ANTH-326.title: Ethnography of European Culture
ANTH-326.description: Europe as a geographic area in terms of its linguistic, ethnic, racial, and cultural diversity; particular focus on peasant society and the Little Tradition.

synonyms: Culture, Gender and Politics in South Asia: Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, Nepal
ANTH-330.title: Culture, Gender and Politics in South Asia: Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, Nepal
ANTH-330.description: Examination of violence, identity, law, religion, nationalism, development, caste, kinship, gender, and the South Asian diaspora.

ANTH-336.title: Health, Gender and Ethnicity
ANTH-336.description: Cross-cultural notions of the body, health, and healing; historic and cultural variability of ideas of reproduction, birth, sexuality, mental illness, and disability.

ANTH-345.title: Politics, Social Organization, and Law
ANTH-345.description: Political and legal systems of primitive societies, social control, and structure.

synonyms: Family and Kinship in Cross-Cultural Perspective
ANTH-370.title: Family and Kinship in Cross-Cultural Perspective
ANTH-370.description: Comparative examination of family and kinship in tribal, peasant, and complex societies, emphasizing non-Western cultures, societal and normative consequences of forms and functions in family.

ANTH-371.title: Cross-Cultural Research on Urban Gangs
ANTH-371.description: Youth gang dynamics and their effects on American institutions. Comparative analysis of Asian-American, African-American, and Mexican-American gangs.

ANTH-385.title: Men and Masculinity
ANTH-385.description: Interdisciplinary examination of social, personal meanings of masculinity; variety of male experience by social class, race, sexuality, and age; emerging masculinities of the future.

ANTH-405.title: Evolutionary Medicine
ANTH-405.description: Evolutionary, cultural, and environmental factors in the emergence and existence of diseases; a Darwinian examination of illness in the human species.

ANTH-410B.title: Ethnographic Field Methods and Practicum
ANTH-410B.description: Survey of anthropological methods for acquiring and analyzing data. Implementation of the field project.

ANTH-440.title: History of Anthropological Theory
ANTH-440.description: Ideas about man, culture, and society which have formed the field of anthropology as a research discipline; present trends and problems.

ANTH-470.title: Multidisciplinary Seminar in Visual Anthropology
ANTH-470.description: Application of broadcast journalism, cinema, and anthropology to ethnographic filmmaking.

ANTH-472.title: Visual Techniques in Anthropology: Stills
ANTH-472.description: Visual techniques for data collection and analysis in anthropological research. Visual anthropology research using 35 mm. photography skills, fieldwork procedures, data analysis, and presentation formats.

ANTH-475.title: Ethnographic Film Analysis
ANTH-475.description: Analysis of film as a tool for investigating primitive and modern cultures and societies.

synonyms: Ethnographic Film Theory from an Historical Perspective
ANTH-476.title: Ethnographic Film Theory from an Historical Perspective
ANTH-476.description: Technologies and uses of, theoretical frameworks for, and the presentation styles of visual ethnographic materials are examined from an historical perspective.

ANTH-490.title: Directed Research
ANTH-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ANTH-590.title: Directed Research
ANTH-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded C/NC.

ANTH-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ANTH-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ANTH-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
ANTH-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ANTH-790.title: Research
ANTH-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum number of units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ANTH-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ANTH-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ANTH-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ANTH-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MS-101.title: Foundations of Officership
MS-101.description: Introduces students to issues and competencies that are central to a commissioned officer's responsibilities. Establish framework for understanding officership, leadership, and Army values followed and "life skills" such as physical fitness and time management.

MS-102.title: Basic Leadership
MS-102.description: Establishes foundation of basic leadership fundamentals such as problem solving, communications, briefings and effective writing, goal setting, techniques for improving listening and speaking skills and an introduction to counseling.

MS-201.title: Individual Leadership Studies
MS-201.description: Students identify successful leadership characteristics through observation of others and self through experiential learning exercises. Students record observed traits (good and bad) in a dimensional leadership journal and discuss observations in small group settings.

MS-202.title: Leadership and Teamwork
MS-202.description: Study examines how to build successful teams, various methods for influencing action, effective communication in setting and achieving goals, the importance of timing the decision, creativity in the problem solving process, and obtaining team buy-in through immediate feedback.

MS-302.title: Leadership and Ethics
MS-302.description: Examines the role communications, values, and ethics play in effective leadership. Topics include ethical decision-making, consideration of others, spirituality in the military, and survey Army leadership doctrine. Emphasis on improving oral and written communication abilities.

MS-402.title: Leadership and Management
MS-402.description: Study includes case study analysis of military law and practical exercises on establishing an ethical command climate. Students must complete a semester long Senior Leadership Project that requires them to plan, organize, collaborate, analyze, and demonstrate their leadership skills.

LING-100O.title: Off-campus Studies
LING-100O.description: Off-campus studies course; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

LING-110.title: In a Word
LING-110.description: Words as a gateway to the human mind. How words are stored, comprehended and retrieved. How words are constructed. Words and concepts. Words and social constructs. The processeing and the acquisition of words in normal and atypical children and adults.

LING-115.title: Language, Society, and Culture
LING-115.description: Discourse patterns among diverse social groups in institutional and interpersonal settings; interrelationships among language practices and gender, socioeconomic status, ethnicity; social structures and cultural values as reflected in language policies and practices.

LING-122.title: Arabic I
LING-122.description: Introduction to current Arabic; oral practice, hearing and reading comprehension; the grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression. Lecture, classroom drill, laboratory practice.

LING-150O.title: off-camous Studies
LING-150O.description: Off-campus studies course; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

LING-152.title: Arabic II
LING-152.description: Continuation of 122. Reading of simple Arabic prose, practice in pronunciation, the grammar essential for reading comprehension and writing. Lecture, classroom drill, and laboratory practice.

LING-155.title: Hindi II
LING-155.description: Continuation of LING 125. Reading of simple Hindi prose, practice in pronunciation, the grammar essential for reading comprehension and writing. Lecture, classroom drill and laboratory practice.

LING-210.title: Introduction to Linguistics
LING-210.description: Empirical study of the sounds and structures of human language; syntax and semantics; language change; linguistic universals.

LING-222.title: Arabic III
LING-222.description: Continuation of LING 152. Reading selections from Arabic newspapers and current prose, continued study of grammar for reading comprehension. Lecture and classroom drill.

LING-252.title: Arabic IV
LING-252.description: Reading of modern Arabic authors, review of grammar, composition, collateral reading.

LING-275.title: Language and Mind
LING-275.description: Language within cognitive science: speech physiology and acoustics, language acquisition, reading, language disorders, perception and mental representation of words, linguistic diversity, and computer analysis of speech.

LING-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
LING-300O.description: Off-campus studies course; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

LING-301.title: Introduction to Phonetics and Phonology
LING-301.description: A survey of topics in phonetics and phonology.

LING-402.title: Advanced Syntax
LING-402.description: Advanced study of topics in syntax.

LING-405.title: Child Language Acquisition
LING-405.description: Universal characteristics of child language; stages of acquisition of phonology, syntax, semantics; processes and dimensions of development; psychological mechanisms; communicative styles.

LING-410.title: Second Language Acquisition
LING-410.description: Theories of second language acquisition in children and adults; comparison of first and second language acquisition including psychological, social, and individual factors.

LING-485.title: Field Methodology
LING-485.description: Elicitation techniques and methodological principles; recording and analysis of phonological, syntactic, and semantic structures; practical approaches to procedures used in urban, rural, and "primitive" settings.

LING-490.title: Directed Research
LING-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

LING-497.title: Honors Thesis
LING-497.description: Writing of the honors thesis. Registration is restricted to honors students.

LING-505B.title: Seminar in Linguistics
LING-505B.description: Preparation and presentation of M.A./Ph.D. screening papers; discussion of student research.

LING-505C.title: Seminar in Linguistics
LING-505C.description: Colloquium for presentation and discussion of student research paper.

LING-527.title: Second Language Acquisition
LING-527.description: Concepts and issues in theoretical approaches to the study of non-primary language acquisition; e.g. linguistic and processsing universals, language transfer, language learnability, fossilization.

LING-531B.title: Phonology
LING-531B.description: Traditional views of phonology; generative phonology; current developments in phonological research and theory.

LING-535.title: Syntax and Grammatical Theory
LING-535.description: Principles and comparison of modern theories of grammar with special reference to syntax.

LING-536.title: Semantics
LING-536.description: Current linguistic approaches to the semantics of natural language; analysis of concepts of meaning and reference.

LING-538.title: Selected Topics in Romance Syntax
LING-538.description: Overview of selected topics in Romance Syntax within a comparative perspective and their contribution towards the understanding of a general theory of grammar.

synonyms: Topics and Issues in East Asian Linguistics
LING-561.title: Topics and Issues in East Asian Linguistics
LING-561.description: Descriptive and theoretical analyses of the grammers of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean; emphasis on comparative studies of these languages and English.

LING-579.title: Child Language Development
LING-579.description: Acquisition of grammatical, discourse, and conversational competence; strategies and structures.

LING-580.title: General Phonetics
LING-580.description: Familiarization with articulation, transcription, production, and acoustic analysis of the speech sounds found in the world's languages. Also speech technology, perception, and disorders. Includes laboratory exercises.

LING-590.title: Directed Research
LING-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

LING-595.title: Directed Readings
LING-595.description: Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

LING-632.title: Seminar in Phonetics
LING-632.description: Readings in phonetic theory and current research as the framework for a discussion-oriented class.

LING-790.title: Research
LING-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

LING-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

LING-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
LING-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

LING-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
LING-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

LING-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
LING-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ARCH-102B.title: Architectural Design I
ARCH-102B.description: Introduction to principles and processes; sequence of exercises emphasizing development of basic skills, ideas, and techniques used in the design of simplified architectural projects.

ARCH-106.title: Workshop in Architecture
ARCH-106.description: Introduction to the ways architecture is created and understood, for minors and nonmajors. Hands-on discussion and laboratory session with some drawing and model building. Not available for credit to architecture majors.

ARCH-114.title: Architecture: Culture and Community
ARCH-114.description: Introduction to ways architecture represents aspirations of culture, satisfies practical and spiritual needs, shapes the social and urban environments, and helps preserve the planet.

ARCH-202B.title: Architectural Design II
ARCH-202B.description: Continuing development of principles and processes: sequence of projects selected to broaden awareness of design issues at various scales in the urban context. Prerequisite: 102abL.

ARCH-205B.title: Building Science I
ARCH-205B.description: The process and communication of building design: physical building shell, systems for structure, enclosure, and space ordering.

ARCH-206.title: Shelter
ARCH-206.description: Introduction to issues, processes, and roles of the individual in relation to present and future shelter needs and aspirations.

ARCH-207.title: Computer Applications in Architecture
ARCH-207.description: Introduction for the non-programmer to the uses of the computer in architecture, including the application of existing programs and their implications for design. Lecture and laboratory. Overview and use of software types. (Duplicates credit in former ARCH 207a.)

synonyms: Materials and Methods of Building Construction
ARCH-211.title: Materials and Methods of Building Construction
ARCH-211.description: Basic considerations and design implications of the problem of determination of the materials and the construction details and processes for buildings.

ARCH-213B.title: Building Structures and Seismic Design
ARCH-213B.description: Investigation and design of structure systems : their resistance to seismic and wind forces and integration with architectural design for synergy of form and structure.

ARCH-214A.title: History of Architecture
ARCH-214A.description: History of building and cities, social, political, technical, formal, aesthetic dimensions in western and non-western traditions: antiquity through the Middle Ages.

ARCH-220.title: The Architect's Sketchbook
ARCH-220.description: The architect's sketchbook as a portable laboratory for perceiving and documenting space introduces the study of the built environment. On-site sessions develop drawing, observation, and visualization skills. Not for professional elective credit for architecture majors.

ARCH-270.title: Introduction to Architectural Studies
ARCH-270.description: Gateway course requirement for the B.S. in architectural studies introduces related fields using mentoring, readings, case studies and field trips.

ARCH-302A.title: Architectural Design III
ARCH-302A.description: Special integrative year including design issues relating to housing.

ARCH-302B.title: Architectural Design III
ARCH-302B.description: Special integrative year including design issues relating to housing.

ARCH-305B.title: Building Science II
ARCH-305B.description: The design of a building as a complex of interacting systems; relations of subsystems; influences of production and marketing on design.

ARCH-307.title: Digital Tools for Architecture
ARCH-307.description: Introduction for the non-programmer to the uses of the computer in architecture, including the application of existing programs and their implications for design. Management of computer systems. Lecture and laboratory. (Duplicates credit in former ARCH 207b.) Recommended preparation: ARCH 207 or equivalent computer experience.

synonyms: Design for the Luminous and Sonic Environment
ARCH-315.title: Design for the Luminous and Sonic Environment
ARCH-315.description: Ideas, problems, and computations related to the design of buildings in response to the luminous and sonic environment.

ARCH-316.title: Place and Culture
ARCH-316.description: (Study abroad programs only) Study of the relationships between places and culture through readings, lectures, discussion and weekly field trips.

ARCH-326.title: The Modern Movement in Architecture
ARCH-326.description: Major theories of modern architecture are presented by studying the work of masters such as: Gropius, Mies van der Rohe, Corbusier, and Kahn.

ARCH-363.title: Plant Material Identification: Horticulture
ARCH-363.description: Introduction to 300 species of plantings. Learn visual characteristics, nomenclature, cultural considerations, and design applications through visits to existing gardens.

ARCH-402A.title: Architectural Design IV
ARCH-402A.description: Selected areas of specialization; three projects chosen with advisement from a variety of studio offerings that concentrate on different areas of vital concern.

ARCH-402B.title: Architectural Design IV
ARCH-402B.description: Selected areas of specialization; three projects chosen with advisement from a variety of studio offerings that concentrate on different areas of vital concern.

ARCH-402C.title: Architectural Design IV
ARCH-402C.description: Selected areas of specialization; three projects chosen with advisement from a variety of studio offerings that concentrate on different areas of vital concern. Prerequisite: 302L.

synonyms: Topics in Modern Architecture in Southern California
ARCH-404.title: Topics in Modern Architecture in Southern California
ARCH-404.description: Investigation of modern architecture in Southern California within its cultural and historic contexts.

ARCH-405B.title: Building Science III
ARCH-405B.description: Design of building systems as an experimental process. Prereq: ARCH 305abL.

ARCH-407.title: Advanced Computer Applications
ARCH-407.description: Investigation of computer graphic applications, emphasizing the role of computers in helping designers create and communicate using color (rendering), form (modeling), and time (animation) and the implications of future technological advancements.

ARCH-411.title: Architectural Technology
ARCH-411.description: Architectural design considered as a technological problem; influence of technology on design; buildings as integrated sets of subsystems.

ARCH-415.title: Asian Architecture and Urbanism
ARCH-415.description: Overview of Asian architecture emphasizing that the built environment is as diverse as the histories and cultures that make up the region.

ARCH-416.title: Architecture and Urbanism in France
ARCH-416.description: Provides an understanding of the cities and buildings of France. Includes case studies as specific places, historical background for development of personal design theory. Open to architecture students (majors and minors) at 3rd year and above.

ARCH-422.title: Architectural Photography
ARCH-422.description: Perceiving and documenting the built environment through the perspective and frame of the camera. Abilities with 35mm and large format cameras, lighting, and black and white lab techniques will be developed. Recommended preparation: knowledge of 35mm camera

synonyms: Light, Color and the Character of Material
ARCH-423.title: Light, Color and the Character of Material
ARCH-423.description: Color theory, constructed drawings, constructed shadows, descriptive geometry, constructed perspective drawing, and layered wash techniques lead to experimentation with methods of representing materiality and construction in design projects.

ARCH-424.title: Field Studies in Architecture
ARCH-424.description: Field studies using direct observation, site recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by discussions and readings in architecture. Departmental approval. Recommended preparation: core curriculum

ARCH-425.title: Field Studies in Urbanism
ARCH-425.description: Field studies using direct observation, site recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by discussions and readings in urbanism. Departmental approval. Recommended preparation: core curriculum

ARCH-426.title: Field Studies in Tectonics
ARCH-426.description: Field studies using direct observation, site recordings/documentation, analysis and evaluation supplemented by discussions and readings in tectonics. Departmental approval. Recommended preparation: core curriculum

synonyms: Plant Materials Identification: California Plant Communities
ARCH-463.title: Plant Materials Identification: California Plant Communities
ARCH-463.description: Expand plant material vocabulary to include native plants of southern California. Emphasis on bio-engineering techniques for site design.

ARCH-465.title: History of Landscape Architecture
ARCH-465.description: Provides understanding of design of landscape in the Western world. Includes case studies on general and specific projects. Students develop personal theory of landscape design.

synonyms: Nature Landscape and Gardens in Non-Western Cultures
ARCH-466.title: Nature Landscape and Gardens in Non-Western Cultures
ARCH-466.description: Critical analysis and appreciation of landscape as cultural interpretation of nature and the representation of landscape as garden and public space in Asian, Islamic, and Pre-Columbian American civilizations. (Duplicates credit in former ARCH 366.)

ARCH-470.title: Architectural Studies Capstone Seminar
ARCH-470.description: Collaborative research project and research paper in an area of concentration. Senior standing.

ARCH-481.title: Furniture Design
ARCH-481.description: An investigation into 20th century furniture design and its relationships to architecture, art and design.

ARCH-490.title: Directed Research
ARCH-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ARCH-499.title: Special Topics
ARCH-499.description: Selected topics in various specialty areas of architecture.

ARCH-501.title: Comprehensive Studio Support and Enrichment
ARCH-501.description: Addresses curricular responsibilites in Comprehensive Studio concurrent with academic research, documentation and production of a written and illustrated paper on an architectural subject.

ARCH-502A.title: Architectural Design V
ARCH-502A.description: The final comprehensive architectural project under the guidance of a faculty advisor to demonstrate the architectural knowledge, skills and professional interests and goals. Graded IP.

ARCH-502B.title: Architectural Design V
ARCH-502B.description: The final comprehensive architectural project under the guidance of a faculty advisor to demonstrate the architectural knowledge, skills and professional interests and goals.

ARCH-505B.title: Graduate Architecture Design
ARCH-505B.description: Emphasis on comprehensive architectural design; attention to theories and skills appropriate for practice in contemporary urban conditions. Open to graduate architecture majors only. Recommended preparation: 6 semesters of architecture design

ARCH-507.title: Theories of Computer Technology
ARCH-507.description: Fundamental theories and meanings of computation as a technique in architectural design.

synonyms: Professional Practice: Legal and Economic Context
ARCH-521.title: Professional Practice: Legal and Economic Context
ARCH-521.description: The laws and regulations that affect architecture as well as building economics and financing.

ARCH-523.title: Professional Practice: Project Documentation
ARCH-523.description: Development of comprehensive project documentation, detailing, specifications, drawing formats and organizations.

ARCH-524.title: Professional Practicum
ARCH-524.description: Comparative studies of professional practice between U.S. firms and firms in other countries. Open to international upper-division undergraduate and graduate architecture students only. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Professional Practice: Legal and Economic Context Project Documentation
ARCH-526.title: Professional Practice: Legal and Economic Context Project Documentation
ARCH-526.description: Design methodology, typology programming, site analysis, budget formulation and pro-forma procedures. Office management, emphasizing professional service and professional ethics as well as project management focusing on the architect's responsibilities during construction.

ARCH-533.title: Urban Landscape Case Studies
ARCH-533.description: History of American architecture and urbanism from Prehistory to World War II examined in relation to European influences and indigenous developments.

synonyms: Materials and Methods for Landscape Architecture
ARCH-535A.title: Materials and Methods for Landscape Architecture
ARCH-535A.description: Introduction to materials of landscape construction, including plant species and planting design, site grading and drainage, surface and building materials and assemblies.

ARCH-542B.title: Landscape Architecture Design
ARCH-542B.description: Projects in complex urban settings; collaboration with students in related fields; emphasis on development of integrative schematic proposals as well as detailed open space design.

ARCH-551.title: Conservation Methods and Materials
ARCH-551.description: Concepts and techniques for building conservation including identification of treatments, recordation and research, material properties and behavior, building forensics, and implementation of preservation projects.

ARCH-552.title: Introduction to Historic Site Documentation
ARCH-552.description: Survey of basic guidelines and standards for documentation in historic preservation, including cultural resource surveys, historic structures reports and Historic American Building Survey and Historic American Engineering Record recordation.

synonyms: History of American Architecture and Urbanism
ARCH-553.title: History of American Architecture and Urbanism
ARCH-553.description: History of American architecture and ubanism from Prehistory to World War II examined in relation to European influences and indigenous developments.

synonyms: Architecture in the Urban Landscape: Comparative Theories
ARCH-563.title: Architecture in the Urban Landscape: Comparative Theories
ARCH-563.description: A comparative study of design theories of the physical, formal and spatial characteristics of historic city types from ancient to modern.

ARCH-590.title: Directed Research
ARCH-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ARCH-596.title: Building Science Thesis Preparation
ARCH-596.description: Exploration of topics leading to development of a thesis prospectus. Topics may be in the areas of building structures, seismic design, environmental control, passive and active energy, or other relevant topics.

ARCH-599.title: Special Topics
ARCH-599.description: Selected topics in various speciality areas of architecture.

ARCH-605A.title: Graduate Architecture Design
ARCH-605A.description: Development of advanced skills and theoretical knowledge about urban architectural issues: a series of projects emphasizing the interaction between general principles and local sites.

ARCH-605B.title: Graduate Architecture Design
ARCH-605B.description: Development of advanced skills and theoretical knowledge about urban architectural issues: a major urban project in Los Angeles.

ARCH-613.title: Seminar: Structures Research
ARCH-613.description: An overview of research topics in building structures; detailed investigation of selected major issues. Prerequisite: ARCH 513L

ARCH-615.title: Seminar: Environmental Systems Research
ARCH-615.description: A detailed examination of current issues in the thermal, acoustical and radiant environment; recent developments in criteria, systems, controls, design tools and simulations; an understanding of the relationships between environmental factors, economics, and architectural goals. Prerequisite: ARCH 515L.

synonyms: Historic Preservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH-691A.title: Historic Preservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH-691A.description: Introduction to, and exploration of, topics leading to the development of a thesis prospectus and directed research towards the completion of the master's thesis in historic preservation. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Registration restricted to Master of Historic Preservation students who have satisfactorily completed 12 hours of graduate course work and have permission of the Program Director. Graded IP/CR/NC.

synonyms: Historic Preservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH-691B.title: Historic Preservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH-691B.description: Introduction to, and exploration of, topics leading to the development of a thesis prospectus and directed research towards the completion of the master's thesis in historic preservation. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Registration restricted to Master of Historic Preservation students who have satisfactorily completed 12 hours of graduate course work and have permission of the Program Director. Graded IP/CR/NC.

synonyms: Historic Preservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH-691Z.title: Historic Preservation Thesis Preparation and Thesis
ARCH-691Z.description: Introduction to, and exploration of, topics leading to the development of a thesis prospectus and directed research towards the completion of the master's thesis in historic preservation. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Registration restricted to Master of Historic Preservation students who have satisfactorily completed 12 hours of graduate course work and have permission of the Program Director. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH-692A.title: Building Science Thesis
ARCH-692A.description: Research and thesis for the Master of Building Science degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH-692B.title: Building Science Thesis
ARCH-692B.description: Research and thesis for the Master of Building Science degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH-692Z.title: Building Science Thesis
ARCH-692Z.description: Research and thesis for the Master of Building Science degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH-693A.title: M.Arch. Thesis, Option I
ARCH-693A.description: Directed research option of M.Arch. degree. Credit on acceptance of research project. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH-693B.title: M.Arch. Thesis, Option I
ARCH-693B.description: Directed research option of M.Arch. degree. Credit on acceptance of research project. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH-693Z.title: M.Arch. Thesis, Option I
ARCH-693Z.description: Directed research option of M.Arch. degree. Credit on acceptance of research project. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ARCH-697Z.title: M.L.Arch. Thesis, Option II
ARCH-697Z.description: Field studies, and thesis for the Master of Architecture degree. Credit on acceptance of thesis.

ARCH-698A.title: M.L.Arch. Thesis, Option I
ARCH-698A.description: Directed research option for the M.L.Arch. degree. Credit on acceptance of research project. Graded IP/CR/NC.

AHIS-001.title: Web Site Authoring and Design
AHIS-001.description: This course focuses on the World Wide Web as a teaching tool. Students will construct a website as a final project, utilizing a hands-on computer laboratory. Not available for degree credit. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS-100.title: Introduction to Visual Culture
AHIS-100.description: The description and analysis of various forms of visual culture, including both mass media and "high" art representations, both Western and non-Western images.

synonyms: Art and Society: Renaissance to Modern
AHIS-121.title: Art and Society: Renaissance to Modern
AHIS-121.description: European art and its legacy in the Americas. Painting, sculpture, architecture and other visual media considered in relation to social and cultural history.

synonyms: Introduction to Asian Art: 1300 to the Present
AHIS-126.title: Introduction to Asian Art: 1300 to the Present
AHIS-126.description: A survey of the art and architecture of India, China, Korea, and Japan from 1300 to the present.

synonyms: Digging into the Past: Material Culture and the Civilizations of the Ancient Mediterranean
AHIS-201.title: Digging into the Past: Material Culture and the Civilizations of the Ancient Mediterranean
AHIS-201.description: A broad survey, covering some 8,000 years and focusing on the material culture of the ancient world in a historical and social context.

AHIS-300O.title: Off Campus Studies
AHIS-300O.description: Off-campus studies; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as section title.

AHIS-330.title: Medieval Art
AHIS-330.description: Introductory survey of art and architecture of Christianity from 300-1300; biblical themes and classical traditions; cultural and historical analysis of medieval art.

AHIS-344.title: Baroque Art
AHIS-344.description: Painting, sculpture and architecture in 17th century Europe, north and south. Recommended preparation: AHIS 121

AHIS-357.title: History of French Art 1860-1920
AHIS-357.description: (Paris semester only). Exploration of the main movements of late 19th and early 20th century French art using the resources of Parisian museums and monuments. Visits to Paris museums are an integral part of the coursework. Recommended preparation: familiarity with modern European history

synonyms: Myths, Arts, Realities: Visual Culture in California, 1849 to the Present
AHIS-364.title: Myths, Arts, Realities: Visual Culture in California, 1849 to the Present
AHIS-364.description: Diverse interpretations of "the California experience and lifestyle" in paintings, sculpture, photography, cinema, public art and popular culture of the last 150 years.

synonyms: Modern Art III: 1940 to the Present
AHIS-370.title: Modern Art III: 1940 to the Present
AHIS-370.description: Questions of social engagement and political address structure this examination of major movements in art since 1940.

AHIS-373.title: History of Photography
AHIS-373.description: Explores key moments in the history of photography from its invention to the present. Issues include modernity and mass culture; photography as a fine art; technologies of vision.

AHIS-385.title: Later Chinese Art
AHIS-385.description: A survey of Chinese painting from 900 to the present, emphasizing the role of painting within the context of Chinese intellectual history.

AHIS-400.title: Undergraduate Apprenticeship
AHIS-400.description: Independent work in art museums, galleries or institutes supervised by on-site professionals and USC faculty. Available to upper-division Art History majors only.

AHIS-449.title: History of Prints and Drawings
AHIS-449.description: Aspects of the history of the graphic arts; stylistic and technical considerations may both be included or specific areas stressed at the choice of the instructor.

AHIS-460.title: Studies in 18th and 19th Century Art
AHIS-460.description: In-depth exploration of specified topics within the area of 18th and 19th century art and architecture.

AHIS-469.title: Critical Approaches to Photography
AHIS-469.description: Selected problems in the history, theory and criticism of photography; recent scholarship considered in relationship to specific photographers and photographic images.

AHIS-490.title: Directed Research
AHIS-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

AHIS-494.title: Undergraduate Proseminar in Art History
AHIS-494.description: Historiography and methodology: introduction to techniques of research and writing. Required of all art history majors, preferably in junior year.

AHIS-495A.title: Undergraduate Honors Thesis
AHIS-495A.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member. Prereq: Consent of instructor.

AHIS-495B.title: Undergraduate Honors Thesis
AHIS-495B.description: Research and writing of original thesis under guidance of faculty member. Prereq: Consent of instructor.

AHIS-496.title: Paintings in the Prado Museum
AHIS-496.description: (Madrid Center only) From Romanticism through Goya in relation to European and Mediterranean antecedents using paintings in the Prado Museum. Field trips in conjunction with classwork.

AHIS-499.title: Special Topics
AHIS-499.description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of the history of art.

synonyms: Problems in the History and Theory of Collecting and Display
AHIS-501.title: Problems in the History and Theory of Collecting and Display
AHIS-501.description: Explores the history of patronage, collecting, and display in the private and the public spheres, (e.g., salons, galleries, museums, and international expositions).

AHIS-504.title: Museum Research Assistantship
AHIS-504.description: Working within an institution with a collection and reflecting, in class meetings, upon how collections are formed, shaped and used.

synonyms: Seminar in Arts of the Ancient Americas
AHIS-509.title: Seminar in Arts of the Ancient Americas
AHIS-509.description: In-depth exploration of a specified topic in the arts of the ancient Americas, which includes North, Central, and South America.

AHIS-520.title: Seminar in Modern Art
AHIS-520.description: In-depth exploration of a specified topic within the area of European art of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

AHIS-590.title: Directed Research
AHIS-590.description: Research leading to graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department.

AHIS-599.title: Special Topics
AHIS-599.description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of the history of art.

AHIS-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

AHIS-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
AHIS-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

PT-516.title: Principles of Disease
PT-516.description: Prinicples and mechanisms of genetics, immunology, infection, wound healing, and oncology. Lecture.

PT-530.title: Therapeutic Exercise
PT-530.description: Theoretical and practical principles for evaluation of exercise need and prescription of exercise programs, specifically for strength and balance. Emphasis on approaches for patients with musculoskeletal deficits.

PT-546.title: Neuropathology
PT-546.description: Pathology in the central and peripheral nervous systems that alter motor and sensory performance. Emphasis on loss of motion, excessive and involuntary movement disorders. Lecture.

PT-554.title: Analytical Anatomy
PT-554.description: Detailed kinesiologic analysis of axial, spine, head, neck, face and bulbar muscles. Lecture, laboratory and clinical demonstration.

PT-557.title: Professional Practice: Patient Perspective
PT-557.description: Examination of issues related to professional-patient relationships, culture, life styles, ethnicity, gender and age. Emphasis on communication within a patient care model.

PT-566.title: Disorders of the Musculoskeletal System
PT-566.description: Regional description of pathology and pathophysiological mechanisms of disorders of bone, connective tissue, and joints. Lecture, demonstration.

PT-569.title: Fundamentals of Neuroscience
PT-569.prereq_text: (PT-509 and PT-516 and PT-529 and PT-534)
PT-569.description: Detailed analysis of neurophysiologic mechanisms underlying normal and abnormal motor and sensory function. Lecture.

synonyms: Physical Examination and Differential Diagnosis in Patients with Medical Disorders
PT-573.title: Physical Examination and Differential Diagnosis in Patients with Medical Disorders
PT-573.description: Physical assessment and differntial diagnosis in common medical conditions. Emphasis on factors that influence phisical therapy or require referral back to the physician.

synonyms: Clinical Management of the Patient with Neurological Dysfunction
PT-581.title: Clinical Management of the Patient with Neurological Dysfunction
PT-581.prereq_text: (PT-509 and PT-516 and PT-521 and PT-529 and PT-534)
PT-581.description: Physical therapy theory and methods for intervention in neurological dysfunction. Lecture, laboratory. Neuroanatomy lab available.

PT-583.title: Clinical Electrophysiology
PT-583.description: Use of electrical currents to evaluate and treat musculoskeletal, neurological and wound disorders. Theory and practice. Lecture, laboratory.

PT-592.title: Capstone Project
PT-592.description: Synthesis of knowledge gained in the pursuit of DPT degree through a case study, a learning module for students or patients, a business plan for a unique form of health care delivery, or some other innovative concept.

synonyms: Residency in Advanced Clinical Physical Therapy
PT-595A.title: Residency in Advanced Clinical Physical Therapy
PT-595A.description: Residency open to students pursuing a Graduate Certificate in Orthopedic Physical Therapy or Neurologic Physical Therapy or the post-professional D.P.T. program. Graded CR/NC. Open to licensed physical therapists only.

synonyms: Residency in Advanced Clinical Physical Therapy
PT-595B.title: Residency in Advanced Clinical Physical Therapy
PT-595B.description: Residency open to students pursuing a Graduate Certificate in Orthopedic Physical Therapy or Neurologic Physical Therapy or the post-professional D.P.T. program. Graded CR/NC. Open to licensed physical therapists only.

synonyms: Residency in Advanced Clinical Physical Therapy
PT-595C.title: Residency in Advanced Clinical Physical Therapy
PT-595C.description: Residency open to students pursuing a Graduate Certificate in Orthopedic Physical Therapy or Neurologic Physical Therapy or the post-professional D.P.T. program. Graded CR/NC. Open to licensed physical therapists only.

synonyms: Residency in Advanced Clinical Physical Therapy
PT-595D.title: Residency in Advanced Clinical Physical Therapy
PT-595D.description: Residency open to students pursuing a Graduate Certificate in Orthopedic Physical Therapy or Neurologic Physical Therapy or the post-professional D.P.T. program. Graded CR/NC. Open to licensed physical therapists only.

PT-600A.title: Clinical Clerkship
PT-600A.description: Practical experiences in two or six week physical therapy manual skills, decision making, and professional behaviors. Graded CR/NC.

PT-600B.title: Clinical Clerkship
PT-600B.description: Practical experience in six week physical therapy manual skills, decision making, and professional behaviors. Graded CR/NC.

PT-600C.title: Clinical Clerkship
PT-600C.description: Practical experience in two week therapy psychomotor skills, decision making, and professional behaviors. Graded CR/NC.

PT-600D.title: Clinical Clerkship
PT-600D.description: Practical experience in two week physical therapy psychomotor skills, decision making, and professional behaviors. Graded CR/NC.

PT-600E.title: Clinical Clerkship
PT-600E.description: Practical experience in six week physical therapy psychomotor skills, decision making, and professional behaviors. Graded CR/NC.

PT-600Z.title: Clinical Clerkship
PT-600Z.description: Practical experiences in two or six week physical therapy manual skills, decision making, and professional behaviors. Graded CR/NC.

PT-605.title: Orthopedic Radiology
PT-605.description: Study of normal and pathologic skeletal radiographic examinations.

synonyms: Clinical Management of the Patient with Musculoskeletal Dysfunction
PT-621.title: Clinical Management of the Patient with Musculoskeletal Dysfunction
PT-621.description: Physical therapy theory and methods of evaluation and treatment of orthopedic dysfunction. Lecture, demonstration, laboratory. Dissection lab available.

PT-622.title: Advanced Management of Spinal Disorders
PT-622.description: Theoretical and practical foundations in orthopedic rehabilitation of spinal disorders with emphasis on differential diagnosis from systemic manifestations. Lecture, laboratory, case presentations. Open to licensed physical therapists only.

PT-623.title: Advanced Management of Extremity Disorders
PT-623.description: Theoretical and practical foundations in orthopedic rehabilitation of occupational, recreational and athletic disorders of the extremities; emphasis on differential diagnosis from systemic manifestations. Lecture, laboratory, case presentations. Open to licensed physical therapists only.

synonyms: Neurological Differential Diagnosis and Therapeutic Interventions
PT-624A.title: Neurological Differential Diagnosis and Therapeutic Interventions
PT-624A.description: Theoretical and practical foundations of clinical practice for specialization in neurologic physical therapy. a: Principles of neurologic differential diagnosis, mechanisms of neurorecovery, and rehabilitation of focal neurologic disorders covered.

synonyms: Neurological Differential Diagnosis and Therapeutic Interventions
PT-624B.title: Neurological Differential Diagnosis and Therapeutic Interventions
PT-624B.description: Theoretical and practical foundations of clinical practice for specialization in neurologic physical therapy. b: Emphasis on advanced skills in neurologic differential diagnosis and rehabilitation for complex neurologic disorders.

synonyms: Integrated Management of the Upper and Lower Extremities
PT-630.title: Integrated Management of the Upper and Lower Extremities
PT-630.description: Advanced evaluation and management of upper and lower extremity disorders and related movement dysfunction.

synonyms: Integrated Management of the Axial Skeletal System and Related Movement Disorders
PT-631.title: Integrated Management of the Axial Skeletal System and Related Movement Disorders
PT-631.description: Advanced assessment and management of axial skeletal dysfunctions and related movement disorders.

PT-632.title: Integrated Patient Management Seminar
PT-632.description: Integration of physical therapy management of complicated patients with concurrent musculoskeletal, cardiopulmonary and/or neurologic disorders.

PT-642C.title: Evidence Based Practice
PT-642C.description: Focus on evidence based decision making using patient perspectives to effect optimal functional outcomes.

PT-660.title: Advanced Clerkship with Academic Integration
PT-660.description: A 16-week clerkship consisting of a minimum of 24 hours per week in a part-time setting. Emphasis on the care of orthopedic, neurologic, pediatric or complicated medical conditions. Graded CR/NC.

PT-665.title: Advanced Clinical Clerkship
PT-665.description: A 16-week clerkship consisting of a minimum of 36 hours per week in a full-time setting. Emphasis on care of orthopedic, neurologic, pediatric or complicated medical conditions. Graded CR/NC.

BKN-550.title: Neurobehavioral Basis of Movement
BKN-550.description: Introduction to the neurobehavioral and neurobiological basis of movement. Review of information processing, neural basis of perception/action, motor systems, and higher cognitive function and behavior. Recommended preparation: biology and physiology

BKN-552.title: Physiological Basis of Voluntary Movement
BKN-552.description: Consideration of the neuromuscular and musculoskeletal physiology of voluntary movement.

BKN-559.title: Readings in Biokinesiology
BKN-559.description: Independent review and synthesis of papers appearing in the current literature.

BKN-567.title: Advanced Topics in Biomechanics
BKN-567.description: Advanced examination of motion-analysis techniques, applications and data interpretation. Magnetic tracking techniques, upper-extremity kinematics, energy/work/impulse concepts, intersegmental dynamics, and EMG muscle modeling are examined.

BKN-573A.title: Advanced Dissection Anatomy
BKN-573A.description: Advanced analysis of systems or structures with dissection. Emphasis on correlations with function.

BKN-573B.title: Advanced Dissection Anatomy
BKN-573B.description: Advanced analysis of systems or structures with dissection. Emphasis on correlations with function.

BKN-587A.title: Physiological Correlates of Therapeutic Exercise
BKN-587A.description: Responses of the physically handicapped to exercise. Emphasis on muscle, energy metabolism, body temperature, environment, endocrine considerations. Strengthening, training, endurance, and evaluation of performance.

BKN-590.title: Directed Research
BKN-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determnined by the department.

synonyms: Modeling the Motor System: An Introduction
BKN-617.title: Modeling the Motor System: An Introduction
BKN-617.description: Introduction of basic principles and models of the primate motor system. Emphasis on arm control.

BKN-672.title: Advanced Independent Study in Biokinesiology
BKN-672.description: Examination of selected mechanisms underlying normal movement and pathological movement. Study of methods used to investigate these mechanisms. Doctoral students only.

BKN-790.title: Research
BKN-790.description: Research leading to doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BISC-102.title: Humans and Their Environment
BISC-102.description: An examination of the physical and biological laws that influence agriculture, pollution, population dynamics (including humans), climate, biodiversity and ecosystem structure and function. Not available for major credit.

BISC-109.title: Special Laboratory II
BISC-109.description: Laboratory component for BISC 220 for entering freshmen or transfer students with advanced placement or equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

synonyms: The Nature of Human Health and Disease
BISC-150.title: The Nature of Human Health and Disease
BISC-150.description: The human organism; the nature of inherited and acquired diseases; the biological and societal basis for the AIDS epidemic; therapy, drug design and the future. Not available for major credit.

BISC-194.title: Freshman Colloquium II
BISC-194.description: A series of lectures and discussions at which faculty of the department introduce their research activities to students entering biology and related majors. Graded CR/NC.

BISC-212.title: Human Anatomy
BISC-212.description: Systemic human anatomy; morphological and embryological conditions contributing to the structures of the adult. Not available for major credit to biological sciences majors. Lecture, 3 hours; Demo, 3 hrs. Prerequisite: high school biology; recommended preparation: BISC 112L or BISC 113L or BISC 120L or BISC 121L.

synonyms: General Biology: Cell Biology and Physiology
BISC-220.title: General Biology: Cell Biology and Physiology
BISC-220.description: In-depth survey of key topics related to advances in our knowledge of cellular biology and physiology; cell composition/metabolism; gene action; organism structure and function. Recommended preparation: high school chemistry; BISC 120L or BISC 121L.

synonyms: Advanced General Biology: Cell Biology and Physiology
BISC-221.title: Advanced General Biology: Cell Biology and Physiology
BISC-221.description: Equivalent to 220L, but taught at a higher level for exceptionally well-prepared students. Admission to the course by departmental approval only.

synonyms: Brain, Mind, and Machines: Topics in Neuroscience
BISC-230.title: Brain, Mind, and Machines: Topics in Neuroscience
BISC-230.description: The structure and function of the mammalian brain including the role of the brain in regulating behavior, both in normal and diseased states; in relation to mind; and in comparison with machine forms of intelligence. Not available for major credit.

BISC-290.title: Introduction to Biological Research
BISC-290.prereq_text: 1 from (BISC-220 or BISC-221) and 1 from (BISC-120 or BISC-121) and 1 from (CHEM-105B or CHEM-115B)
BISC-290.description: Experience in basic techniques through supervised research in the research laboratory of a departmental faculty member. Graded CR/NC.

BISC-300.title: Introduction to Microbiology
BISC-300.description: Comparative approach to bacteria, Archaea and viruses; their structure, life cycles, geochemical activity, ecology and nutrition. Fundamentals of metabolism and microbial genetics. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 6 hours.

BISC-307.title: General Physiology
BISC-307.description: Physiological functions of the circulatory, digestive, endocrine, integuementary, musculoskeletal, nervous, respiratory, and urogenital systems in animals. Lecture, 3 hours; Laboratory, 3 hours.

synonyms: Multidisciplinary Seminar: Science, Technology and Society
BISC-321.title: Multidisciplinary Seminar: Science, Technology and Society
BISC-321.prereq_text: 1 from (BISC-120 or BISC-121 or BISC-220 or BISC-221) and 1 from (CHEM-105A or CHEM-115A) and 1 from (PHYS-135A or PHYS-151)
BISC-321.description: Builds upon a basic science background to provide students with an awareness of cutting edge scientific research, its technological applications and its societal ramifications. Not available for major credit.

BISC-330.title: Biochemistry
BISC-330.description: Basic biochemical principles; classes of molecules -- structure and function; cellular energetics.

synonyms: Ecology and the Natural History of California
BISC-369.title: Ecology and the Natural History of California
BISC-369.description: Marine, freshwater and terrestrial communities of California. Life histories, morphology, special evolutionary adaptations. Relationships between organisms and their biological-physical-chemical environment. Emphasis on field biology. Catalina semester only.

BISC-373.title: Conservation Biology
BISC-373.prereq_text: 1 from (BISC-220 or BISC-221) and 1 from (BISC-120 or BISC-121)
BISC-373.description: Biological principles underlying conservation including ecology, evolution, genetics and biogeography. Covers both marine and terrestrial environments, with special emphasis on island biology. Catalina semester only. Recommended preparation: BISC 320L; BISC 313 or BISC 325

synonyms: Applications of Molecular Biology to Medicine
BISC-410.title: Applications of Molecular Biology to Medicine
BISC-410.description: Advances and trends in the understanding, diagnosis, and treatment of human diseases. A mixture of lectures, seminars and resulting discussions by the students. Senior standing.

BISC-411.title: Cell Biology
BISC-411.description: The synthesis, transport and assembly of the complex structures that mediate eukaryotic cellular function. Electrical and biochemical mechanisms underlying intercellular communication.

BISC-419.title: Environmental Microbiology
BISC-419.description: Qualitative and quantitative appraisal of microbial activities in pure and contaminated environments; microbial community and its development; interspecific relationships; effects of microorganisms on their surroundings. Lecture 4 hours. Recommended preparation: BISC 300L

synonyms: Epilepsy to Ecstacy: Biological Basis of Neurological Disorders
BISC-423.title: Epilepsy to Ecstacy: Biological Basis of Neurological Disorders
BISC-423.description: Examination of various neurological disorders originating from developmental signaling and/or anatomical abnomalities.

BISC-435.title: Advanced Biochemistry
BISC-435.description: Macromolecular structure and function; enzymology; metabolic regulation. Lecture, 3 hours; discussion, 2 hours.

BISC-437.title: Comparative Physiology of Animals
BISC-437.prereq_text: 1 from (BISC-220 or BISC-221) and 1 from (BISC-120 or BISC-121)
BISC-437.description: Control of the internal environment of animals in relation to their external environment. Thermal regulation, osmoregulation, excretion, and ion balance. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 3 hours. Junior standing. Recommended preparation: two from BISC 313, BISC 320L, BISC 325 and BISC 330L

BISC-462.title: Seminar in Neurobiology
BISC-462.description: Topical seminar in neurobiology. Junior, senior or graduate standing.

BISC-478.title: Computational Genome Analysis
BISC-478.description: Introduction to and applications of algorithms and statistics to genome analysis. Analysis of physical and genetic maps, DNA sequencing, sequence comparisons, DNA chips.

BISC-480.title: Developmental Biology
BISC-480.description: Basic mechanisms of animal development are considered at different levels of analysis. Emphasis is on molecular, genetic, and cellular processes underlying vertebrate and invertebrate development. General concepts and evolutionary mechanisms are emphasized. Lecture, 3 hours; discussion, 2 hours.

BISC-483.title: Geobiology and Astrobiology
BISC-483.description: Relationships between microbiota and the earth environment including the hydrosphere, lithosphere and atmosphere, with consideration of the potential for life on other planets.

BISC-490.title: Directed Research
BISC-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

BISC-493.title: Honors Seminar
BISC-493.prereq_text: 1 from (BISC-220 or BISC-221) and 1 from (BISC-120 or BISC-121)

BISC-499.title: Special Topics
BISC-499.prereq_text: 1 from (BISC-220 or BISC-221) and 1 from (BISC-120 or BISC-121)
BISC-499.description: Lecture and discussion in specialized areas of the biological sciences. Students cannot register more than twice for this course. Junior standing. Recommended preparation: two from BISC 313, BISC 320L, BISC 325 and BISC 330L.

BISC-502B.title: Molecular Genetics and Biochemistry
BISC-502B.description: Current genetic and biochemical analysis of replication, recombination, mutagenesis, and repair. Fundamentals of transcription and regulation of gene expression. Recent applications of genetic engineering and genome analysis.

synonyms: Laboratory Techniques in Cellular and Molecular Biology
BISC-504.title: Laboratory Techniques in Cellular and Molecular Biology
BISC-504.description: Rotation of graduate students through molecular biology research laboratories to learn the major technological skills required in the field. Graded CR/NC.

BISC-510B.title: Integrative and Evolutionary Biology
BISC-510B.description: Current topics in integrative and evolutionary biology including genetics, natural selection, ecology with emphasis on higher order complex questions including form, function, and energy use throughout the life span.

BISC-520.title: Recent Advances in Neurobiology
BISC-520.description: Lectures on selected topics in neurobiology. Registration restricted to three semesters. Open to graduate students in departmental program only.

synonyms: Advanced Seminar in Molecular and Microbial Ecology
BISC-532.title: Advanced Seminar in Molecular and Microbial Ecology
BISC-532.description: Microorganisms dominate biological processes in the ocean. These species pose significant problems for estimating species diversity, abundance and activity. Examination of modern molecular biological approaches for analyzing aquatic microbial communities and their ecological roles.

synonyms: Advanced Seminar in Remote Sensing and Modeling
BISC-533.title: Advanced Seminar in Remote Sensing and Modeling
BISC-533.description: Modern oceanographic methods for making remote measurements of aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems using satellite imagery and other means. Integrating these data into models that describe ecosystem structure and enable interpretation of ecosystem function.

synonyms: Advanced Seminar in Population Genetics of Marine Organisms
BISC-534.title: Advanced Seminar in Population Genetics of Marine Organisms
BISC-534.description: An overview of the theory underlying population and quantitative genetics, with applications to marine systems. Basic evolutionary mechanisms (mutation, migration, drift, selection, nonrandom mating) and modern evidence for their roles in sturcturing genetic variation within and among marine populations.

synonyms: Advanced Seminar in Marine/Global N Cycle
BISC-536.title: Advanced Seminar in Marine/Global N Cycle
BISC-536.description: Biological processes in marine ecosystems strongly affect the cycling of important elements on our planet. Examination of the interplay between ocean biology and the cycling of carbon and nitrogen on a local, regional and global scale.

synonyms: Seminar in Integrative and Evolutionary Biology
BISC-549.title: Seminar in Integrative and Evolutionary Biology
BISC-549.description: Current topics in integrative and evolutionary biology.

BISC-577A.title: Computational Molecular Biology Laboratory
BISC-577A.description: Practical experience in computational molecular biology applications. Mathematical and statistical software packages relevant for genomic analysis. Retrieval and analysis of genomic data from databases.

BISC-584.title: Faculty Lecture Series
BISC-584.description: Multi-instructor course designed to introduce students to the breadth and depth of faculty interests within the MEB Section of Biological Sciences and the Natural History Museum.

BISC-585.title: Scientific Writing and Reviewing
BISC-585.description: Hands-on experience writing and reviewing scientific literature. The review process and participation in writiing and reviewing their own proposals.

BISC-590.title: Directed Research
BISC-590.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BISC-790.title: Research
BISC-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BISC-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

BISC-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

BISC-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

BISC-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

BISC-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
BISC-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PHYS-100.title: The Physical World
PHYS-100.description: The fundamentals of physics presented with emphasis on the structure and beauty of physical laws. Practical component will relate these laws to commonly encountered events. Not available for major credit.

PHYS-125.title: Physics for Architects
PHYS-125.description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics with emphasis on the application of physical principles to the problems of architecture. Lecture, 4 hours; laboratory, 3 hours.

PHYS-135A.title: Physics for the Life Sciences
PHYS-135A.prereq_text: 1 from (MATH-108 or MATH-125 or MATH-126 or MATH-226)
PHYS-135A.description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics emphasizing areas related to life sciences. Prerequisite for Biological Sciences, Medicine, Dentistry, Pharmacy. Lecture, 4 hrs.; Lab, 3 hrs.

PHYS-135B.title: Physics for the Life Sciences
