PHYS-135B.description: Fundamental laws and principles of physics emphasizing areas related to life sciences. Prerequisite for Biological Sciences, Medicine, Dentistry, and Pharmacy. Lecture, 4 hrs.; Lab, 3 hrs. (Duplicates credit in 105abLg and 125abL).

synonyms: Fundamentals of Physics I: Mechanics and Thermodynamics
PHYS-151.title: Fundamentals of Physics I: Mechanics and Thermodynamics
PHYS-151.description: Gateway to the majors and minors in Physics and Astronomy. Statics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies, conservation principles, gravitation, simple harmonic oscillators, thermodynamics, heat engines, entropy. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 3 hours.

synonyms: Fundamentals of Physics II: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS-152.title: Fundamentals of Physics II: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS-152.description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrical circuits, wave motion, sound waves, electromagnetic waves. Lecture, 4 hours; laboratory, 3 hours.

synonyms: Fundamentals of Physics III: Optics and Modern Physics
PHYS-153.title: Fundamentals of Physics III: Optics and Modern Physics
PHYS-153.description: Geometrical optics, interference, diffraction, special relativity, quantum mechanics, atomic physics, solid state physics. Lecture: 3 hours; Laboratory: 3 hours.

PHYS-161.title: Advanced Principles of Physics I
PHYS-161.description: Gateway to the majors and minors in Physics and Astronomy. Introductory treatment intended for well-qualified students. Dynamics of particles and rigid bodies, conservation laws, wave motion, thermodynamics, heat engines, entropy. Lecture, 4 hours; laboratory, 3 hours.

PHYS-163.title: Advanced Principles of Physics III
PHYS-163.description: Interference and diffraction of waves, special relativity, quantum mechanics, atomic physics, condensed matter physics, elementary particles. Lecture: 3 hours; Laboratory: 3 hours.

synonyms: The Physics and Technology of Energy: Keeping the Motor Running
PHYS-200.title: The Physics and Technology of Energy: Keeping the Motor Running
PHYS-200.description: Investigation of energy technologies, including development and implementation issues. Topics include the Industrial Revolution, electromagnetic induction, power transmission, combustion engines, fission and fusion. Not available for major credit.

PHYS-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
PHYS-300O.description: Off-campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as section title.

PHYS-316.title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
PHYS-316.description: First, second, and third laws; thermodynamic potentials, applications; distribution laws, kinetic theory, transport phenomena, specific heats.

PHYS-408B.title: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS-408B.description: b: Electromagnetic induction; AC circuits; Maxwell's equations.

synonyms: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and its Applications
PHYS-438A.title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and its Applications
PHYS-438A.description: Concepts and techniques of quantum mechanics; free and bound states, the hydrogen atom.

PHYS-473.title: Lasers and Optics Laboratory
PHYS-473.description: Introductory design/research laboratory in lasers and optics, which typically includes fiber optics, photonics, electro-optics, optical sensors, optical communication, optical signal processing and computing.

PHYS-490.title: Directed Research
PHYS-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

PHYS-493.title: Advanced Experimental Techniques
PHYS-493.description: Development of modern experimental techniques, including computer interface with data acquisition hardware and data analysis by software, applied specifically to experiments in modern physics. Emphasis on laboratory work with discussion of theoretical background. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 6 hours.

PHYS-500.title: Graduate Colloquium
PHYS-500.description: Topics of current research interest in physics and astronomy. Lectures directed to physics graduate students by faculty of the department and by outside speakers. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS-508A.title: Advanced Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS-508A.description: a: Electrostatics, boundary value problems, multiple expansions, microscopic models of matter, magnetostatics. b: Maxwell's equations, potentials and gauge transformations; electromagnetic waves; wave guides; electromagnetic radiation; special relativity.

PHYS-516.title: Methods of Computational Physics
PHYS-516.description: Introduction to algorithm development. Integration of ordinary differential equations; chaotic systems; molecular dynamics; Monte Carlo integration and simulations; cellular automata and other complex systems. Recommended preparation: ability to program in C or C++

PHYS-520.title: Methods for Complex Systems
PHYS-520.description: Probabilities, random walks, generalized central limit theorems, probabilities in thermodynamics, critical phenomena, self organized criticality, phenomenology of catastrophes, dynamical systems and examples from outside physics.

PHYS-530.title: Relativity
PHYS-530.description: Fundamentals of the special theory and applications to classical and quantum physics; the principle of equivalence; tensor analysis and Einstein's theory of gravitation; relativistic cosmology. Recommended preparation PHYS-504a and 508a

PHYS-540.title: Solid State Physics
PHYS-540.description: Fundamental concepts and techniques in solid state physics; electron gas at metallic densities; semiclassical transport; crystallography; band structure; phonons; screening; superconductivity; magnetic ordering. Recommended preparation PHYS-518a and 558a

PHYS-558A.title: Quantum Mechanics
PHYS-558A.description: a: General formulation of quantum mechanics with applications; theory of measurement; exactly solvable problems; angular momentum formalism.

PHYS-566.title: Neural Network Self-Organization
PHYS-566.description: Differential equations for network pattern formation. Dynamic link architecture. Simulation of brain organization processes (retinotopy, orientation columns) and face recognition by elastic matching. Recommended preparation: CSCI 564 and either MATH 225 or MATH 245.

PHYS-590.title: Directed Research
PHYS-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS-640.title: Advanced Condensed Matter Physics
PHYS-640.description: Magnetism, magnons; superconductivity; transport phenomena; many-body effects; interacting electron gas; Hartee-Fock theory; neutron and x-ray scattering; and other selected topics. Recommended preparation PHYS 540 and PHYS 558b.

PHYS-668.title: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
PHYS-668.description: Relativistic wave equations; second quantization of Klein-Gordon, Dirac, and Maxwell fields; applications in quantum electrodynamics and condensed matter physics. Recommended preparation: PHYS-558b.

PHYS-692.title: Internship
PHYS-692.description: Field application of physics in a business or industry setting; part-time employment. Project to be jointly defined by student, employer and professor. Open to M.S., Physics for Business Applications degree candidates only.

PHYS-710.title: Selected Topics in Experimental Physics
PHYS-710.description: Course content will vary yearly with current interest. Topics covered may include superconducting quantum interference devices, scanning tunneling microscopy, and laser cooling and trapping of single atoms.

PHYS-720.title: Selected Topics in Theoretical Physics
PHYS-720.description: Course content will vary yearly with current interest. Topics covered may include field theory, many body theory, Green's functions, dispersion theory, and group theory.

PHYS-730.title: Selected Topics in Particle Physics
PHYS-730.description: Various advanced phases of particle physics. Content will vary yearly; emphasis on superstring theories, advanced topics in quantum gravity, and field theory. Recommended preparation: PHYS-678.

PHYS-750O.title: Off Campus Studies
PHYS-750O.description: Coursework taken on campus at Caltech as part of the Caltech-USC cross-registration program. Graded CR/NC.

PHYS-790.title: Research
PHYS-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ASTR-100.title: The Universe
ASTR-100.description: Survey of the universe: planets, satellites, comets, stars, nebulae, galaxies. Practical component includes planetary observations and dark-sky field trip. Not available for major credit.

ASTR-104.title: Special Laboratory
ASTR-104.description: Laboratory component for ASTR 100Lxg for transfer students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution. For transfer students only. Departmental approval. Graded CR/NC.

ASTR-420.title: Galaxies and Cosmology
ASTR-420.description: Galaxies and clusters of galaxies: their content, structure, dynamics, distribution, and motions; observational cosmology. Prerequisite: PHYS 153L or PHYS 163L

ASTR-490.title: Directed Research
ASTR-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

NEUR-490.title: Directed Research
NEUR-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Departmental approval.

NEUR-525.title: Advanced Neurosciences II
NEUR-525.description: Sensory and motor systems, cognitive neuroscience, behavioral systems, computational neuroscience.

BAEP-423.title: Management of Small Businesses
BAEP-423.description: Strategic, organizational and human issues facing the small business; influence of the founder's personality, managing growth, competitive strengths and weaknesses are covered.

BAEP-450.title: Fundamentals of Entrepreneurship
BAEP-450.description: Starting and managing one's own business: developing a viable concept, organizing the enterprise, market and financial planning, and controlling the organization. Not available to Entrepreneurship Program majors, undergraduate or graduate.

BAEP-451.title: The Management of New Enterprises
BAEP-451.description: Development of analytical and conceptual skills in entrepreneurship and venture management.

BAEP-452.title: Cases in Entrepreneurship
BAEP-452.description: Case analysis of problems encountered in the management of new enterprises.

BAEP-453.title: Venture Management
BAEP-453.description: Design and application of organization structures and systems in management of new ventures.

BAEP-454.title: The Entrepreneurial Business Plan
BAEP-454.description: Development of a detailed plan for starting and owning an enterprise.

BAEP-460.title: Seminar in Entrepreneurship
BAEP-460.description: The intimate issues of entrepreneurship. Internalization of the key decisions that an individual needs for creating and building the entrepreneurial organization.

BAEP-549.title: Initiating New Ventures
BAEP-549.description: Moving beyond the business plan; identifying individual and organizational leadership skills needed to move a venture forward; "how-to" portion of establishing an enterprise.

BAEP-551.title: Introduction to New Ventures
BAEP-551.description: Study and development of analytical and conceptual skills in the management of new enterprises and new ventures within large organizations. (Duplicates credit in BAEP 550 and GSBA 586.

BAEP-552.title: Cases in Feasibility Analysis
BAEP-552.description: Study of analytical techniques used to evaluate business concepts and new business development.

BAEP-554.title: The New Venture Business Plan
BAEP-554.description: Creation of an operating plan for starting or managing fast-growing ventures.

BAEP-557.title: Technology Commercialization
BAEP-557.description: Focus of the course is on the identification, evaluation and commercialization of new technologies. Emphasis will be placed on the legal, financial and marketing aspects of technology transfer and development. Departmental approval is required.

BAEP-559.title: Investing in New Ventures
BAEP-559.description: Focus on the entrepreneurial skill set applied to new venture opportunities. Taught from the business plan reader's point of veiw; focus on selecting opportunities, structuring the relationship, adding value and realizing the value of that investment.

synonyms: Acquiring Your Own Business or Opportunity
BAEP-560.title: Acquiring Your Own Business or Opportunity
BAEP-560.description: Issues faced by the entrepreneur who wishes to acquire an enterprise; appropriateness of an enterprise, understanding funding sources and valuation methods, developing a plan for due diligence, negotiating and consummating the transaction. The acquisition process, approaches to valuation, and the roles of the various parties in negotiating and consummating and aquisition of an existing business.

BAEP-590.title: Directed Research
BAEP-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BAEP-597.title: Business Field Project in Entrepreneurship
BAEP-597.description: Individual or team projects solving real business problems for companies; situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC.

ACCT-370A.title: External Financial Reporting Issues
ACCT-370A.description: Understanding of decision-making, problem solving, and research skills as a supplement to financial accounting knowledge for accounting professionals.

ACCT-370B.title: External Financial Reporting Issues
ACCT-370B.description: Continuation of understanding of decision-making, problem solving, and research skills as a supplement to financial accounting knowledge for accounting professionals.

ACCT-371A.title: Introduction to Accounting Systems
ACCT-371A.description: Understanding of technology used to support accounting professionals in financial and managerial accounting, auditing, and taxation.

ACCT-371B.title: Introduction to Accounting Systems
ACCT-371B.description: Understanding the fundamental processes that capture the corporate data and the controls needed to assure that these processes will operate in an acceptable manner.

ACCT-372.title: Internal Reporting Issues
ACCT-372.description: Understanding of decision-making, problem solving, and research skills as a supplement to managerial accounting knowledge for accounting professionals.

ACCT-373.title: Introduction to Assurance Services
ACCT-373.description: Explores the requisite skills and knowledge needed to offer services in assurance, attestation or auditing engagements.

ACCT-374.title: Introduction to Tax Issues
ACCT-374.description: Basic tax principles, introduction to U.S. federal, state and local tax systems, income and expense definitions, property transactions, and fundamentals in individual taxation.

ACCT-410.title: Foundations of Accounting
ACCT-410.description: Non-technical presentation of accounting for users of accounting information; introduction to financial and managerial accounting. Not open to students with course credits in accounting. Not available for unit or course credit toward a degree in accounting or business administration.

ACCT-411.title: Understanding Financial Reporting
ACCT-411.description: Understanding of financial statements and insight into the implications of the disclosure requirements. Not available for credit to accounting or business majors.

ACCT-412.title: Special Financial Reporting Issues
ACCT-412.description: Analysis of contemporary financial reporting and disclosure issues. Includes topics such as accounting for stock options and income tax, off-balance sheet financing, hedging and derivatives. Not available for credit to accounting and business majors. Open to accounting majors only.

synonyms: Intermediate Financial Accounting for Non-Accounting Majors
ACCT-415.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting for Non-Accounting Majors
ACCT-415.description: In-depth study of balance sheet, income statement, and cash flow statement issued from the perspective of a user (not preparer) of corporate financial reports.

ACCT-416.title: Financial Reporting and Analysis
ACCT-416.prereq_text: 1 from (BUAD-215 or BUAD-306) and 1 from (ACCT-370B or ACCT-415)
ACCT-416.description: Examination of the role of financial statement analysis in the prediction of a firm's future financial performance.

synonyms: Advanced Financial Accounting for Non-Accounting Majors
ACCT-417.title: Advanced Financial Accounting for Non-Accounting Majors
ACCT-417.prereq_text: 1 from (BUAD-215 or BUAD-306) and 1 from (ACCT-370B or ACCT-415)
ACCT-417.description: Developing capabilities to identify, articulate and interpret financial statements reflecting complex merger and acquisition activities, with a focus on financial analysis and investment banking. Not available for degree credit to accounting majors.

ACCT-418.title: Accounting for Management Decisions
ACCT-418.description: Understanding of decision-making uses of acounting information: cost systems, planning and budgeting, and measuring and rewarding performance. Not available for credit to accounting or business majors. Open to accounting minors only.

ACCT-419.title: Understanding Accounting Information Systems
ACCT-419.description: Understanding of accounting systems focusing on how these systems are designed, selected, implemented, used, and managed. Not available for credit to accounting or business majors. Open to accounting minors only.

ACCT-470A.title: Advanced External Financial Reporting Issues
ACCT-470A.description: Developing capabilities to identify and articulate current external financial reporting problems and issues, concentrating on operating, financing and investing activities of business organizations.

ACCT-470B.title: Advanced External Financial Reporting Issues
ACCT-470B.description: Developing capabilities to identify and articulate current external financial reporting problems and issues, concentrating on operating, financing and investing activities of business organizations.

ACCT-472.title: Managerial Accounting
ACCT-472.description: Understanding of systems providing cost information useful in management decision-making and problem solving.

ACCT-473.title: Financial Statement Auditing
ACCT-473.description: Course builds on the background developed in ACCT 373, specifically the process used by external auditors to conduct financial statement audits.

ACCT-474.title: Tax Issues for Business
ACCT-474.description: Capabilities to identify and articulate tax issues related to a business entity's life: formation, investing, financing and operations, and change of form.

ACCT-476.title: Performance Measurement Issues
ACCT-476.description: Introduction to understanding how management control systems can enhance achievement of the organization's objectives and strategies.

ACCT-478.title: Accounting Systems Design
ACCT-478.description: Explores the design of accounting systems. Introduction to tools and techniques for analyzing and designing accounting systems with an emphasis on system controls and reporting.

ACCT-479.title: Accounting Systems Development
ACCT-479.description: Examines the fundamentals of accounting systems development. Introduction to the concepts of implementation and support, with emphasis on system quality assurance, evaluation and attestation.

ACCT-490.title: Directed Research
ACCT-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

synonyms: Concepts of Financial and Management Accounting
ACCT-509.title: Concepts of Financial and Management Accounting
ACCT-509.description: Introduction to the concepts of financial and managerial accounting. The course will provide coverage of key concepts needed by managers of businesses in order to communicate information important in decision-making. (Duplicates credit in GSBA 510, GSBA 518, GSBA 536.) Not open to business majors.

ACCT-537.title: Management Control Systems
ACCT-537.description: Study of systems and devices managers use to ensure that strategies are being implemented as intended and that assets are not being stolen or otherwise dissipated. Among the topics covered are planning and budgeting systems, responsibility centers, performance measures and evaluations, incentives, and the roles of controllers and internal auditors.

ACCT-546.title: Assurance Services
ACCT-546.description: Concepts and principles governing independent professional services that provide assurance on the reliability and relevance of information, including financial statement information. Topics include demand and supply issues for these services, basic principles of evidence, risk assessment and testing.

synonyms: Enterprise Systems: Design, Implementation, Security and Audit
ACCT-548.title: Enterprise Systems: Design, Implementation, Security and Audit
ACCT-548.description: Exploration of a number of areas including the role systems play in organizations, the technology that supports these systems and issues relating to technology risk, system/application security and system review/audit.

ACCT-549.title: Advanced Enterprise Systems and Technologies
ACCT-549.description: Design, control and development of advanced enterprise systems, using reengineering, focusing on accounting and financial systems, using a wide range of emerging existing technologies. Recommended preparation: GSBA 530 or ACCT 547

ACCT-550T.title: Tax Research and Practice
ACCT-550T.description: Tax law research methods; interpreting statutes, cases, and rulings; communicating research results; administration and professional responsibilities of tax practice. Recommended preparation: introductory tax course.

ACCT-563T.title: Federal Estate and Gift Taxes
ACCT-563T.description: Taxation of decedents' estates and lifetime gifts; valuation of property subject to estate and gift taxes.

ACCT-568T.title: Taxation of Foreign Business Operations
ACCT-568T.description: Taxation of foreign income of U.S. citizens and corporations and of U.S. source income of foreign persons and corporations; planning for organization of foreign operations under the tax laws.

ACCT-569T.title: Advanced Partnership Taxation
ACCT-569T.description: Advanced tax concepts involving partnerships and limited liability companies, designed to produce a level of expertise in Subchapter K of the Internal Revenue Code.

ACCT-571T.title: Taxation of Individuals
ACCT-571T.description: Application of tax law in areas of compensation planning, investment planning, tax shelters, and current developments relating to the individual taxpayer.

ACCT-572.title: Corporate Accounting and Reporting
ACCT-572.description: A study of financial reporting and disclosure issues with an emphasis on the use of corporate financial statements and their accompanying footnotes. Not open to students with credit in equivalent subjects.

synonyms: Accounting in the Global Business Environment
ACCT-574.title: Accounting in the Global Business Environment
ACCT-574.description: Study of national and international accounting and business issues; global capital market changes; international accounting and business topics; cases and studies of specific business entities and countries.

ACCT-576T.title: Consolidations
ACCT-576T.description: Concepts and principles of taxation of companies operating as consolidated groups.

ACCT-578T.title: Advanced Corporate Taxation
ACCT-578T.description: Analysis of corporate divisions and reorganizations, carryovers, and other advanced topics in corporate taxation.

ACCT-580T.title: Accounting Methods
ACCT-580T.description: An analysis of Subchapter E and related provisions of the Internal Revenue Code and of the relationships between tax and financial accounting.

ACCT-581.title: Financial Statement Analysis
ACCT-581.description: Analysis of corporate financial reports from a decision-maker's perspective. This course is case-and-applications-oriented. Applications include credit analysis, equity valuation, and financial distress.

ACCT-583.title: Accounting for Income Taxes
ACCT-583.description: Examination of the roles of auditors, tax professionals and corporate financial personnel in preparing, analyzing and reviewing the accrual of income taxes in financial statements. Open to M.B.T., M.Acc. and M.B.A. students only.

ACCT-584.title: Family Wealth Preservation
ACCT-584.description: Analysis of transfer of property during lifetime or at death from a tax saving perspective.

synonyms: Professional Accounting: Theory, Research and Policy
ACCT-585.title: Professional Accounting: Theory, Research and Policy
ACCT-585.description: A case study approach to the integration of accounting and auditing knowledge; research, communication, and interpersonal skills developed through extensive written and presentation requirements. Recommended Preparation: ACCT 572.

ACCT-590.title: Directed Research
ACCT-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the School of Accounting. Graded CR/NC.

ACCT-597.title: Business Field Project in Accounting
ACCT-597.description: Individual or team projects solving real business problems for companies; situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC.

ACCT-605.title: Survey of Financial Reporting Research
ACCT-605.description: Survey of major topics and methods in research on financial reporting with coverage of both key research questions and frequently used methods. Departmental approval.

ACCT-611.title: Selected Topics in Accounting Research
ACCT-611.description: Advanced Seminar to address issues/topics covered in accounting research forums presented by USC and visiting faculty.

BUAD-100O.title: Off Campus Studies
BUAD-100O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution appears as a section title on the USC transcript.

BUAD-102.title: Global Leadership Seminar
BUAD-102.description: Colloquium of researchers and industry leaders discussing international business and the challenges faced by leaders in a global environment, with a specific focus on China. Graded CR/NC. Open to freshmen Business Honors students only. International travel may require additional fees.

BUAD-200.title: Economic Foundations for Business
BUAD-200.description: Course examines fundamental concepts of both microeconomics and macroeconomics as they pertain to business and financial decisions. Not available for degree credit to business majors.

BUAD-215.title: Foundations of Business Finance
BUAD-215.description: Principles and practices of modern financial management; use of financial statements; valuation of investment; asset pricing under uncertainty; elements of financial decisions.

BUAD-250A.title: Core Concepts of Accounting Information
BUAD-250A.description: Accounting information in decision-making from the perspective of users and preparers; accounting issues concerning income and cash flows.

BUAD-250B.title: Core Concepts of Accounting Information
BUAD-250B.description: Continuation of accounting information in decision making, focusing on accounting issues involving economic resources, debt, and equity capital.

BUAD-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
BUAD-300O.description: Off-campus studies course; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

BUAD-301.title: Technical Entrepreneurship
BUAD-301.description: Starting and managing a technological business: developing a viable concept, market and financial planning, product development, organizing the venture, protecting intellectual property rights.

BUAD-302.title: Communication Strategy in Business
BUAD-302.description: Theory, practice, and techniques of business communication strategy essential to external and organizational communication; group and interpersonal communication; development of skill in oral and written communication.

BUAD-302T.title: Business Communication for Accountants
BUAD-302T.description: (For Accounting majors only) Theory, practices, and techniques essential to communication by accounting professionals; interpersonal communication, wirtten and oral presentations; communication technologies; development of communication strategies for varied audiences. (Duplicates credit in BUAD 302.) Recommended preparation: WRIT 340

BUAD-304.title: Organizational Behavior
BUAD-304.description: The environments and technologies of business and industrial organizations, processes of work group development and management, and their effects on individual behavior.

synonyms: Abridged Core Concepts of Accounting Information
BUAD-305.title: Abridged Core Concepts of Accounting Information
BUAD-305.description: Uses of accounting information in decision-making; accounting issues concerning income and cash flows, economic resources and capital. Duplicates credit in BUAD 250ab. Open only to students with two transferable "Principles of Accounting" courses from a two-year or four-year institution.

BUAD-306.title: Business Finance
BUAD-306.description: Financial problems of business enterprise; function of financial manager; sources of funds; instruments, institutions, and practices of finance; problems of financial management using case studies.

BUAD-307.title: Marketing Fundamentals
BUAD-307.description: Develops a managerial viewpoint in planning and evaluating marketing decisions of the firm: products, pricing, channels, promotion, information processing, legal implications, and marketing in contemporary society.

BUAD-310.title: Applied Business Statistics
BUAD-310.description: Statistical methods for business analysis; data exploration and description; sampling distributions; estimation; hypothesis testing, simple and multiple regression; model building. Extensive computer applications.

BUAD-311.title: Operations Management
BUAD-311.description: Learn the fundamentals of operations management and acquire skills to analyze, manage and improve production processes. Topics include: project/quality/materials management and just-in-time production.

BUAD-311T.title: Operations Management for Accounting Majors
BUAD-311T.description: Learn the fundamentals of operations management and acquire skills to analyze, measure, control, and improve production processes. Open to accounting majors only.(Duplicates credit in BUAD 311.)

BUAD-350.title: Macroeconomic Analysis for Business Decisions
BUAD-350.description: Behavior of economic indicators over business fluctuations, economic growth, monetary and fiscal policy, exchange rate movements.

BUAD-351.title: Economic Analysis for Business Decisions
BUAD-351.description: Theory of the firm in the enterprise system; profits, demand, and cost analysis; market competition and resource allocation; problems of size efficiency and growth.

BUAD-390.title: Special Problems
BUAD-390.description: DO NOT PUT IN SCHEDULE. Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. ENROLLMENT BY PETITION ONLY.

BUAD-403.title: Legal Environment of Business
BUAD-403.description: Legal principles of business: litigation process, constitutional law, torts, product liability, crimes, contracts, sales and leases, intellectual property, international law, agency, employment law, and ethics.

BUAD-490.title: Directed Research
BUAD-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

BUAD-491.title: Honors Seminar
BUAD-491.description: Advanced study of a selected topic in business administration. In-depth exploration of relevant theories and methods of analysis. May be repeated for credit once.

BUAD-493.title: Dean's Seminar in Entrepreneurship
BUAD-493.description: Overview of starting and developing a new business. Discussions with successful business leaders and entrepreneurs. Not available for students admitted to the Entrepreneur Program. Senior or graduate standing in business or engineering, or department approval. Graded CR/NC.

BUAD-495.title: Practicum in Business Issues (Internship)
BUAD-495.description: Combined classroom discussion and field application of business theories and practices; part-time internship employment. Project to be jointly defined by student, employer and professor. Junior or senior standing. Graded CR/NC

BUAD-497.title: Strategic Management
BUAD-497.prereq_text: 1 from (BUAD-250b or BUAD-301 or BUAD-305) and (BUAD-304 and BUAD-306 and BUAD-307) and 1 from (BUAD-302 or BUAD-302T)
BUAD-497.description: Examination of managerial decision-making, planning, and policy under changing environments; readings, cases, exercises, simulations.

BUAD-498.title: Business Field Project (Undergraduate)
BUAD-498.description: Unpaid individual or team projects solving real business problems for client companies; situation analyses; statistical analysis; consulting practicum; oral and written presentations. Open to sophomores, juniors and seniors only.

BUAD-499.title: Special Topics
BUAD-499.description: Examination of current literature relevant to the total and changing environment in which business operates. Prerequisite: departmental approval.

synonyms: Cross-Cultural Business Communication for Non-Native Speakers
BUCO-221.title: Cross-Cultural Business Communication for Non-Native Speakers
BUCO-221.description: Written, spoken, and cultural business communication skills for non-native speakers of English. Emphasis on individualized skills development according to need. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Communication in the Working World -- Managing Diversity and Conflict
BUCO-333.title: Communication in the Working World -- Managing Diversity and Conflict
BUCO-333.description: Communication strategies to manage workplace diversity and conflict. Historical, social, legal precedents. Institutional barriers to diversity. Race, gender, sexual orientation, age, physical disabilities, culture.

synonyms: The Art of Case Analysis and Presentation
BUCO-452.title: The Art of Case Analysis and Presentation
BUCO-452.description: Develop analytical problem-solving and persuasive presentation skills to successfully analyze strategic business situations and convincingly argue your position in a competitive environment.

BUCO-485.title: Business Communication Management
BUCO-485.description: Communication environment; managing communication activities; communication through intrafirm publications; research methods; report and proposal preparation; communicating institutional policy. Prerequisite: BUAD 302.

BUCO-533.title: Managing Communication in Organizations
BUCO-533.description: Analyze, design, develop, and present theory-based communication solutions and strategies to sophisticated interpersonal, group, organizational, and environmental communication issues and problems. Recommended preparation: GSBA 523 or GSBA 542 or GSBA 502

BUCO-590.title: Directed Research
BUCO-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Business Field Project in Business Communication
BUCO-597.title: Business Field Project in Business Communication
BUCO-597.description: Individual or team projects solving real business problems for companies; situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Communication for Doctoral Students: Foundations of Academic Writing
BUCO-633.title: Communication for Doctoral Students: Foundations of Academic Writing
BUCO-633.description: Academic writing for dissertations, conference papers, and journal articles. Graded CR/NC.

FBE-391.title: Real Estate Finance and Investment
FBE-391.description: Introduction to income-producing real estate from the perspective of finance, market analysis, capital markets, development and investment. Includes focus on analytical techniques and computer applications.

synonyms: Introduction to Real Estate Finance and Development
FBE-400.title: Introduction to Real Estate Finance and Development
FBE-400.description: Case analysis examining economic and financial aspects of real estate decisions for non-business majors. Focuses on dynamics of financing, markets and the development process. Open to all majors. Not available for credit as a senior options course for business majors or for students in the real estate option.

FBE-421.title: Financial Analysis and Valuation
FBE-421.description: This course develops and uses the tools of financial analysis to evaluate the performance and assess the value of individual companies in an industry context.

FBE-427.title: Real Estate Law
FBE-427.description: Principles of law regarding real property transactions; buyer-seller, debtor-creditor, landlord-tenant relationships; environmental law and land use control; investments and syndication.

FBE-428.title: Principles of Employment Law
FBE-428.description: Comprehensive survey of employment and labor law topics arising in the contemporary American workplace.

FBE-429.title: International Business Law
FBE-429.description: Introductory course on the legal and regulatory environment of international business transactions.

FBE-431.title: Financial Policies and Corporate Control
FBE-431.description: Provide student with a solid foundation in the theory of modern corporate finance. Emphasis on determinants of corporate debt and dividend policies, allocation and value of corporate voting rights and alternative methods of security issuance and retirement.

FBE-432.title: Corporate Financial Strategy
FBE-432.description: Linkage between financial theory and policy and corporate strategy, the role of financial managers in developing corporate strategy; applications of concepts and techniques using cases.

synonyms: Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management for Developing Firms
FBE-437.title: Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management for Developing Firms
FBE-437.description: Internal financial management of developing firms. Cash flow analysis; capital budgeting; sources of financing; risk analysis; measurement of profits; and mergers and acquisitions.

FBE-440.title: Trading and Exchanges
FBE-440.description: Theories, practices, and technologies of trading at exchanges and in dealer networks. Sources of liquidity, volatility, profitability, and institutional change. Domestic and international public policy issues.

FBE-441.title: Investments
FBE-441.description: Theories and applications of investment decision making; the behavior of security prices, portfolio theory, asset pricing models, market efficiency, bond valuation and term structure, derivative securities.

synonyms: Introduction to Forecasting and Risk Analysis
FBE-443.title: Introduction to Forecasting and Risk Analysis
FBE-443.description: Introduction to econometric tools and versions of Capital Asset Pricing Models to estimate financial risk, stock market risk premia and to project economic activity.

FBE-458.title: Law and Finance
FBE-458.description: Impact of law on finance: business organizations, partnerships, corporations, companies, franchising, securities regulation, mergers, tender offers, antitrust law, negotiable instruments, credit, bankruptcy, and government regulation.

FBE-459.title: Financial Derivatives
FBE-459.description: A rigorous introduction to the pricing and corporate use of financial derivatives -- futures, options, forwards, and swaps -- on stocks, exchange rates, bonds, and commodities.

FBE-462.title: International Trade and Commercial Policy
FBE-462.description: Commercial Policies and Treaty relationships; examination of export-import problems and national policies influencing world trade and finance.

FBE-464.title: International Finance
FBE-464.description: Introduction to the international financial system: foreign currency spot, forward, futures, options markets: exchange rate determination under flexible and fixed rate regimes; foreign exchange risk and elementary hedging techniques; Eurobanking.

synonyms: Management of Real Estate Development: Feasibility Studies
FBE-466.title: Management of Real Estate Development: Feasibility Studies
FBE-466.description: By means of a significant real-world case study chosen each term, the development process is examined from the interrelated perspectives of finance, market analysis, and design and construction technology. Team-generated development proposals are proposed and presented in a consulting environment that includes industry participants.

FBE-470.title: Advanced Real Estate Analysis
FBE-470.description: Mixed lecture/case approach covering market analysis, asset valuation, ownership structure, negotiation, asset management, corporate real estate, portfolio management, and affordable housing, appraisal and advanced financial modelling.

FBE-489.title: Real Estate Capital Markets
FBE-489.description: Topics in real estate capital markets including markets for debt and equity; residential and commercial mortgages and mortgage-baked securities; REITs; institutional sources of capital.

FBE-526.title: Macroeconomic Analysis for Business
FBE-526.description: The economic environment of business: American economic and social goals and policies and their impact on business; growth, stability, and the new priorities; international forces influencing business.

synonyms: Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management for Developing Firms
FBE-527.title: Entrepreneurial Finance: Financial Management for Developing Firms
FBE-527.description: Internal financial management of developing firms. Cash flow analysis; capital budgeting; sources of financing; risk analysis; measurement of profits; and mergers and acquisitions.

FBE-529.title: Financial Analysis and Valuation
FBE-529.description: An applications-oriented course to develop the financial and accounting tools required to do financial planning, valuation and assessment of financial performance.

synonyms: Corporate Financial Policy and Corporate Control
FBE-531.title: Corporate Financial Policy and Corporate Control
FBE-531.description: Theory of modern corporate finance; determinants of corporate debt and dividend policies, allocation and value of corporate voting rights and alternative methods of security issuance and retirement.

FBE-532.title: Corporate Financial Strategy
FBE-532.description: Linkage between financial theory and policy and corporate strategy; the role of financial managers in developing corporate strategy; applications of concepts and techniques using cases.

synonyms: Applied Finance in Fixed Income Securities
FBE-535.title: Applied Finance in Fixed Income Securities
FBE-535.description: The basic principles underlying fixed income securities and how these principles apply to the practical aspects of fixed income management.

FBE-554.title: Trading and Exchanges
FBE-554.description: Theories, practices, and technologies of trading at exchanges and in dealer networks. Sources of liquidity, volatility, profitability, and institutional change. Domestic and international public policy issues.

FBE-555.title: Investment Analysis and Portfolio Management
FBE-555.description: Analysis and management of common stocks and fixed income securities; development of modern portfolio theory and the efficient market hypothesis; organization of securities markets.

FBE-557.title: Legal Environment of Business
FBE-557.description: Legal aspects and strategies of business: litigation, negligence and torts, white collar crimes, contracts, sales, Internet law, e-commerce, intellectual property, trade secrets, international law, employment, property, inheritance, consitutional law and ethics.

synonyms: Law of Corporate Finance and Management
FBE-558.title: Law of Corporate Finance and Management
FBE-558.description: Practical aspects and strategies of financing and managing businesses from incubation to going public: corporate and partnership law, LLCs, agency law, internet companies, venture capital, securities and investment law, going public, corporate finance law, mergers and acquisitions, antitrust, credit and bankruptcy.

FBE-559.title: Management of Financial Risk
FBE-559.description: Analysis of commodity, futures, and options contracts; theoretical and empirical approaches; spot and futures price relationships, speculation and hedging strategies; market efficiency.

FBE-560.title: Mergers and Acquisitions
FBE-560.description: Practical application of the critical components of M&A: deal flow strategies, preliminary negotiations, deal structures, due diligence, valuation, post-merger integration, and regulations.

FBE-563.title: Theory of International Trade
FBE-563.prereq_text: GSBA-511 and 1 from (GSBA-526 or GSBA-544 or GSBA-549)
FBE-563.description: Comparative advantage and gains from trade; factor proportions and efficiency; factor price equalization; terms of trade; tariffs, customs, unions and trade agreements.

synonyms: Economics of Urban Land Use: Feasibility Studies
FBE-565.title: Economics of Urban Land Use: Feasibility Studies
FBE-565.prereq_text: 1 from (FBE-589 or GSBA-511 or GSBA-521 or GSBA-548)
FBE-565.description: Economic, market and financial analysis related to feasibility of real estate development; theory and case analysis.

FBE-571.title: Introduction to Financial Analysis: Practicum
FBE-571.description: This course, an introductory financial analysis (tools, techniques) practicum, emphasizes practical application of asset valuation and portfolio management techniques for those with little previous experience. Duplicates credit in FBE 572 and FBE 573. Graded CR/NC.

FBE-572.title: Intermediate Financial Analysis: Practicum
FBE-572.description: This practicum emphasizes asset valuation, including applications of tools and inputs (including economics, accounting, and quantitative techniques) in asset valuation for those with prior experience. Duplicates credit in FBE 571 and FBE 573. Graded CR/NC.

FBE-573.title: Advanced Financial Analysis: Practicum
FBE-573.description: This is an advanced practicum emphasizing portfolio management skills, including applied strategies (tools, inputs) in equity and fixed-income management for those with extensive prior experience. Duplicates credit in FBE 571 and FBE 572. Graded CR/NC.

FBE-588.title: Advanced Real Estate Law
FBE-588.description: Legal aspects of real estate transactions; partnerships, syndicates, and other ownership forms. Legal aspects of land use control, zoning and environmental impact reports.

FBE-590.title: Directed Research
FBE-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

FBE-591.title: Real Estate Finance and Investment
FBE-591.description: Analysis of investment in and financing of real estate assets including projections, valuation, deal structure, contracts, portfolio and tax and entity considerations.

synonyms: Business Field Project in Finance and Business Economics
FBE-597.title: Business Field Project in Finance and Business Economics
FBE-597.description: Individual or team projects solving real business problems for companies; situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC.

FBE-599.title: Special Topics
FBE-599.description: Current developments in the field of Finance and Business Economics; topics to be selected each semester.

synonyms: Ph.D. Seminar-Empirical Research Methods in Finance
FBE-654.title: Ph.D. Seminar-Empirical Research Methods in Finance
FBE-654.description: Empirical financial research methods are introduced. Applications are discussed and critiqued. Special attention is given to new statistical methods and to identifying fruitful research programs.

FBE-655.title: Financial Economics III
FBE-655.description: Doctoral-level seminar in financial economics; concentration on the theory of corporate governance and incentives in organizations.

GSBA-500O.title: Off-Campus Studies
GSBA-500O.description: International Business track within the M.B.A. Title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

GSBA-520.title: Business Fundamentals for Non-Business Professionals
GSBA-520.description: An overview of concepts, tools and principles of business management to develop a general management point of view. Open only to non-business graduate students.

synonyms: Management and Organization of the Creative Industries
GSBA-555.title: Management and Organization of the Creative Industries
GSBA-555.description: How creative industries (motion pictures, television, publishing, radio, music, arts, games) operate and are organized. Critical discussion of pressing issues that these industries face.

synonyms: Business Development in the Networked Digital Industry
GSBA-556.title: Business Development in the Networked Digital Industry
GSBA-556.description: Business development and business models for products/services delivered through networked digital platforms (NDI), including creative industries. Convergence of telecom, IT, software, entertainment, content, and media. Open to M.B.A., M.Acc., and M.B.T. students only, including dual degrees.

GSBA-561.title: Evaluating Market Performance
GSBA-561.description: Evaluation of the firm by the market forces that affect its success; financial accounting and reporting; competitive market analysis; external communication; microeconomics; labor, customer and financial markets, statistical and decision analysis, financial and organization measures of effectiveness.

GSBA-562.title: Management of Operations
GSBA-562.description: Analysis of operations management and business functions; managerial accounting; finance; marketing; production; data processing and information systems; human resources management.

synonyms: The Economics and Marketing of a Professional Services Firm
GSBA-568.title: The Economics and Marketing of a Professional Services Firm
GSBA-568.description: Development of marketing skills required for a professional's role and responsibility to social and civic concerns, as well as role of a new consultant. Review of operational and administrative aspects within the organization.

GSBA-573.title: Managing Strategic Change and Implementation
GSBA-573.description: Management of the strategic change process for the total organization including implementing growth strategies, use of consultants, corporate governance, implementation in a multinational environment, leadership and power, use of technology, innovation, corporate cultures, executive succession, corporate relations.

GSBA-590.title: Directed Research
GSBA-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GSBA-595.title: Internship in Business
GSBA-595.description: Supervised on-the-job business experience in the areas of interest of the respective student. Graduate business students only. Graded CR/NC. Recommended preparation: completion of MBA core courses

GSBA-597.title: Business Field Project
GSBA-597.description: Individual or team projects solving real business problems for companies; situation analyses; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Regression and Generalized Linear Models for Business Applications
GSBA-604.title: Regression and Generalized Linear Models for Business Applications
GSBA-604.description: Theory and application of linear regression models; role of substantive theory in statistical model building; model specification, estimation, diagnostic checking; the general linear hypothesis.

GSBA-610.title: Seminar in Business Research
GSBA-610.description: Critical analysis of research studies in the functional areas of business; practice in formulating and conducting research; presentation of original research of publishable quality (may be repeated for credit up to 9 units).

GSBA-790.title: Research
GSBA-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MKT-405.title: Advertising and Promotion Management
MKT-405.prereq_text: 1 from (BUAD-307 or JOUR-340 or COMM-200 or COMM-302)
MKT-405.description: Role of advertising in the marketing mix: determining objectives, strategies, and plans from situation analysis through research and creative processes, media selection, and sales promotion.

synonyms: Practicum in Advertising and Promotion Design
MKT-406.title: Practicum in Advertising and Promotion Design
MKT-406.description: Provides real-life marketing experience as a member of a student managed advertising and promotions agency. Requires market research, creative design, implementation planning, and client presentation.

MKT-415.title: Sales Force Management
MKT-415.description: Studies the role of managing the selling function as part of the marketing mix; planning, implementing, and controlling sales force operations; critical issues in selecting, training, compensating and surpervising salespeople.

MKT-440.title: Marketing Analysis and Strategy
MKT-440.description: Synthesis of concepts and applications relating to the analysis of market opportunities and the development of product, promotion, distribution, and pricing strategies. Recommended during student's final semesters.

MKT-450.title: Consumer Behavior and Marketing
MKT-450.description: Examines the relationship of consumer behavior to acquisition, usage, and disposition of products and the psychological, social and cultural influences that affect these decisions.

MKT-465.title: Global Marketing Management
MKT-465.description: Product and service mix in multinational business; promotional alternatives; channel of distribution systems; pricing policies and legal barriers; multinational marketing opportunities; problems and information sources.

MKT-470.title: Marketing Research
MKT-470.description: Skills needed to conduct and apply research for marketing decision making; problem formulation, secondary data, primary research, fundamentals of analysis are covered. Recommended preparation: BUAD 310.

MKT-512.title: Marketing and Consumer Research
MKT-512.description: Marketing research concepts and techniques; developing managers' ability to critically evaluate and utilize research information in the decision making process. Recommended preparation: GSBA 524 and 528

MKT-525.title: Consumer Behavior
MKT-525.description: Theories and applications of consumer behavior in marketing; psychlogical, social, cultural, and ethnic factors influencing consumer behavior. Recommended preparation: GSBA 528

MKT-543.title: Market Demand and Sales Forecasting
MKT-543.description: New product concept testing and life cycle forecasting, pricing and advertising response forecasting, consumer purchase intentions, judgmental marketing decision models, time series and regression analysis, computer methods. Recommended preparation: GSBA 524 and 528.

MKT-555.title: Marketing Channels
MKT-555.description: Examination of strategic decision making in marketing channels with emphasis on the structure and management of channels. Intensity of distribution, vertical integration, how roles in the channel are formulated, types of intermediaries, and multiple channels of distribution.

MKT-560.title: Marketing Strategy and Policy
MKT-560.description: Integrated approach to the use of marketing tools and concepts in the formulation and execution of a marketing plan. Recommended preparation: GSBA 528.

MKT-565.title: Global Marketing
MKT-565.description: Variations in markets and trade patterns around the globe; product development and adaptation, pricing, promotion, and distribution issues across national cultures and international markets. Recommended preparation: GSBA 528

MKT-590.title: Directed Research
MKT-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MKT-597.title: Business Field Project in Marketing
MKT-597.description: Individual or team projects solving real business problems for companies; situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC.

MKT-599.title: Special Topics
MKT-599.description: Examination of current literature and emerging and timely topics in marketing, social marketing, consumerism, macro-marketing, marketing of individuals, organizations, and ideas. Recommended preparation: GSBA 509 or GSBA 528

synonyms: Marketing Models in Consumer and Business-to-Business Markets
MKT-613.title: Marketing Models in Consumer and Business-to-Business Markets
MKT-613.description: Modeling research on marketing with a focus on channel structure, franchising and sales force compensation, innovation and diffusion, inter-store competition, sales promotions, and market segmentation. Open to students in the doctoral program in business administration only.

IOM-401.title: Business Information Systems -- Spreadsheet Applications
IOM-401.description: Provides an applied understanding of how spreadsheets are used to analyze business information. Create real world software application for use in accounting, finance, marketing and operations.

IOM-402.title: Business Information Systems -- Database Applications
IOM-402.description: Provides an applied understanding of how work group databases are used to analyze business information. Create real world software applications that are used in accounting, finance, marketing and operations.

IOM-428.title: Data Warehousing and Data Mining
IOM-428.description: Introduction to data-warehousing, multidimensional database, on-line analytical processing, and survey of data mining methods that extract useful information from data warehouses: e.g., decision tree. Business applications emphasized.

IOM-431.title: Business Information Systems
IOM-431.description: Fundamentals of computer networks, protocols, TCP/IP and the Internet; introduction to electronic commerce, Web application development (CGI scripting, Java, and JavaScript); discussion of security issues.

synonyms: Business Information Systems Analysis and Design
IOM-433.title: Business Information Systems Analysis and Design
IOM-433.description: Information analysis and the logical specification of business systems, including logical design, physical design, and implementation; computer exercises and case studies.

IOM-435.title: Business Database Systems
IOM-435.description: Computer-based management of data including data structures, conceptual data modeling, logical data modeling, structured query language (SQL), and physical optimization of high performance databases.

IOM-455.title: Project Management
IOM-455.description: Topics related to project management in a variety of industries such as real estate projects, new product launch, plant location, etc.

IOM-483.title: Operations Consulting
IOM-483.description: Study of concepts and techniques for improving operations, formulation and implementation of operations strategy, and development of frameworks for process design, selection and performance evaluation.

IOM-499.title: Special Topics
IOM-499.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in information systems, operations management, and statistics.

synonyms: Applied Time Series Analysis for Forecasting
IOM-522.title: Applied Time Series Analysis for Forecasting
IOM-522.description: Survey of forecasting and time series methods. Models for stationary and nonstationary time series; ARIMA model identification, estimation, and forecast development. Seasonal and dynamic models. Recommended preparation: GSBA 524

synonyms: Data Warehousing, Business Intelligence, and Data Mining
IOM-528.title: Data Warehousing, Business Intelligence, and Data Mining
IOM-528.description: Introduction to data-warehousing, multidimensional database, on-line analytical processing, and survey of business intelligence applications that extract useful information from data-warehouses: e.g., decision tree. Business applications emphasized.

IOM-547.title: Designing Spreadsheet-Based Business Models
IOM-547.description: Application of decision analysis, simulation and optimization techniques to managerial problems. Students learn how to create and present useful spreadsheet models to analyze practical business models. Recommended preparation: completion of first-year M.B.A. courses.

IOM-551.title: Managing Global E-Business
IOM-551.description: Global e-business practices; e-business value propositions and business models; managing e-business processes and transformation; e-business technology infrastructure evaluation. Cases, readings, technology briefs, and speakers. Open to IBEAR students only.

IOM-580.title: Project Management
IOM-580.description: Applications of systems theory and concepts, matrix organizational structures, PERT/CPM project modeling, and management information systems to the management of complex and critical projects. Recommended preparation: GSBA 534

IOM-584.title: Global Operations Management
IOM-584.description: Students gain exposure to the spectrum of issues which are critical to the globalization of operations and basic tradeoffs associated with global operations management decisions. Open to graduate students in business and accounting only.

IOM-590.title: Directed Research
IOM-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Business Field Project in Information and Operations Management
IOM-597.title: Business Field Project in Information and Operations Management
IOM-597.description: Individual or team projects solving real business problems for companies; situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC.

IOM-599.title: Special Topics
IOM-599.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in operations management, information systems, and decision support systems.

IOM-606.title: Bayesian Data Analysis
IOM-606.description: Principles of Bayesian inference, subjective probability, posterior inference via Markov chain Monte Carlo, applications to latent variable models. Hierarchical models and shrinkage estimation. Model averaging.

IOM-670.title: Current Research in Operations Management
IOM-670.description: Critique of the current research-based literature in operations management to include scheduling, forecasting, MRP, technology planning, inventory management, and facilities location and layout.

synonyms: Social and Ethical Issues in Business
MOR-421.title: Social and Ethical Issues in Business
MOR-421.description: The free-enterprise system from the perspective of modern corporations and their critics; business ethics in relation to personal/external values.

MOR-431.title: Interpersonal Competence and Development
MOR-431.description: An exploration of the nature of relationships at work; focus on analytical skills and self-assertion necessary to have effective, rewarding relationships. Laboratory simulations.

synonyms: The Art of Case Analysis and Presentation
MOR-452.title: The Art of Case Analysis and Presentation
MOR-452.description: Develop analytical problem-solving and persuasive presentation skills to successfully analyze strategic business situations and convincingly argue your position in a competitive environment.

MOR-461.title: Design of Effective Organizations
MOR-461.description: Designing management systems and practices that lead to organizational excellence; techniques for organizational change.

MOR-462.title: Management Consulting
MOR-462.description: Role of professional consultants; data gathering methods; consulting approaches from strategy, finance, operations, information systems, marketing, and human resources; action planning; ethical and career issues.

MOR-463.title: Organization Change and Development
MOR-463.description: Theories and methods of introducing change in organizations. Techniques for analyzing organizations, developing change programs, and implementing changes. Ethical and career issues of change management. Recommended preparation: BUAD 304

MOR-465.title: Advanced Methods in Strategy Analysis
MOR-465.description: Theories and methods for analyzing and developing strategy. Fundamental tools for strategic planning. Advanced methods for analyzing industries and competitors, and determining the scope of the firm. Recommended preparation: BUAD 497

MOR-469.title: Negotiation and Persuasion
MOR-469.description: Theories, strategies, and ethics underlying negotiation and persuasion in contemporary organizations and societies. Emphasizes the knowledge and skills needed for effective negotiation and persuasion.

MOR-471.title: Human Resource Management
MOR-471.description: Management of the human resource function for organizational performance. Recommended preparation: BUAD 304.

MOR-473.title: Designing and Leading Teams
MOR-473.description: Theories and practices for developing and leading teams. Skills for creating team structures and facilitating team processes. Knowledge for diagnosing team problems and devising solutions. Recommended preparation: BUAD 304

MOR-492.title: Global Strategy
MOR-492.description: Examination of corporate strategy practices in an international context. Effects of cultures, political systems, markets, and economic systems on developing effective global strategies.

MOR-548.title: Competitive Advantage through People
MOR-548.description: How firms develop employee talent as source of competitive advantage. Strategic implications of contemporary practices in recruitment, work systems, training, compensation, and employee relations. Speakers and cases.

MOR-551.title: Performance Management and Motivation
MOR-551.description: New approaches to performance motivation at executive and worker levels, including pay/incentive systems, job design, employee involvement, leadership behavior, and self-managed teams. Cases, project and speakers.

MOR-555.title: Designing High Performance Organizations
MOR-555.description: Latest organization design knowledge, including Internet-enabled firms, alliances, joint ventures and team-based organizations, provided through cases and research from USC's Center for Effective Organizations. Speakers and project.

MOR-562.title: Strategic Choice and Valuation Analysis
MOR-562.description: Advanced strategic planning using tools of scenario development and activity valuation for assessing market entry, expansion and business portfolio configuration. Exercises, cases and project.

MOR-565.title: Alliances and Cooperative Strategy
MOR-565.description: Essential issues and problems of cooperative strategy. Recognize and evaluate collaborative opportunities to develop and assess an overall cooperative strategy. Readings, cases and group project. Open to graduate business students only.

MOR-567.title: Interpersonal Influence and Power
MOR-567.description: Emphasizes legitimate and effective use of power to resolve conflicts and mobilize action through understanding the talent and self-interest of people involved in decision-making. Readings and cases.

MOR-569.title: Negotiation and Deal-Making
MOR-569.description: Strategies and dynamics of deal-making; practical skills necessary to win in range of business transactions conducted in domestic and international settings. Cases, role-playing, films and simulations.

MOR-579.title: The Business of Sports Entertainment
MOR-579.description: Business practices and issues in different sports markets; including growth opportunities; and innovative marketing strategies for attracting and retaining fans and corporate sponsors. Industry speakers.

MOR-590.title: Directed Research
MOR-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Business Field Project in Management and Organization
MOR-597.title: Business Field Project in Management and Organization
MOR-597.description: Individual or team projects solving real business problems for companies; situation analyses; research proposal composition; field research techniques; statistical analysis; oral and written presentations. Graded CR/NC.

MOR-599.title: Special Topics
MOR-599.description: Selected topics reflecting current trends and recent developments in management and policy sciences.

MOR-602.title: Organization Theory
MOR-602.description: Ph.D. level survey course on organization theory with focus on the history and development of research on organizations.

MOR-603.title: Seminar in Strategic Management
MOR-603.description: Survey of strategic management. Topics include historical overview of strategic management, research methods used, current theory, and empirical research on the developing paradigms.

CHEM-050.title: General Chemistry Tutorial
CHEM-050.description: Weekly tutorial for selected students in CHEM 105aL. Strong emphasis on chemical mathematics and key concepts in general chemistry. Topics parallel lectures in CHEM 105aL. Not available for degree credit. Graded CR/NC. Discussion, 2 hours.

CHEM-105A.title: General Chemistry
CHEM-105A.description: Fundamental principles and laws of chemistry; laboratory work emphasizes quantitative procedures. Prerequisite to all more advanced courses in chemistry. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory and discussion, 4 hours. Quiz, 1 hour.

CHEM-105B.title: General Chemistry
CHEM-105B.description: Fundamental principles and laws of chemistry; laboratory work emphasizes quantitative procedures. Prerequisite to all more advanced courses in chemistry. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory and discussion, 4 hours. Quiz, 1 hour. Prerequisite: one year of high school chemistry; CHEM-105aLg or 115aLg.

CHEM-115B.title: Advanced General Chemistry
CHEM-115B.description: Equivalent to 105agL-bL, but taught at a higher level for exceptionally well-prepared students. Admission to course by departmental approval only. Lecture, 3 hours; lab and discussion, 4 hours; quiz, 1 hour. Prereq: 1 year high school chemistry and mathematics through pre-calculus.

synonyms: Chemistry in the Environment, Energy and Society
CHEM-201.title: Chemistry in the Environment, Energy and Society
CHEM-201.description: A range of issues where chemistry impacts society will be explored. Topics such as global warming, pollution, energy utilization and genetic engineering will be covered.

CHEM-300.title: Analytical Chemistry
CHEM-300.description: Theory and practice in chemical analysis, emphasizing instrumental techniques; error analysis, fractional distillation, extraction; chromatograhpy; visible, ultraviolet, and infrared spectroscopy; introductions to electrochemistry and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Lecture, 2 hours; Laboratory and Discussion.

CHEM-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
CHEM-300O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

CHEM-322A.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM-322A.description: Chemistry of the carbon compounds of the aliphatic and aromatic series; laboratory preparation of typical compounds of both series. Lecture, jointly with 325aL and 325bL, 3 hours; laboratory and discussion, 4 hours. For premedical and predental students, and some categories of biology majors and engineers.

CHEM-322B.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM-322B.description: Chemistry of the carbon compounds of the aliphatic and aromatic series; laboratory preparation of typical compounds of both series. Lecture, 3 hours jointly with CHEM 325abL; laboratory and discussion, 4 hours. For premedical and predental students, and some categories of biology majors and engineers.

CHEM-325B.title: Organic Chemistry
CHEM-325B.description: Required of majors in chemistry. Lecture, 3 hours a week with 322abL; laboratory and discussion, 7 hours.

CHEM-332.title: Physical Chemical Measurements
CHEM-332.description: Experimental study of topics discussed in 430ab; adsorption, magnetic susceptibility; electron spin resonance, kinetics, equilibria, molecular spectra and structure, viscosity, dielectric properties. Discussion, 1 hour; laboratory, 9 hours.

synonyms: Advanced Laboratory Techniques in Organic and Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM-423.title: Advanced Laboratory Techniques in Organic and Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM-423.description: Advanced synthetic, analytical, and physical measurement techniques in organic and inorganic chemistry. Emphasis on laboratory work with discussion of theoretical background. Lecture, 2 hours; discussion, 1 hour; laboratory, 8 hours.

CHEM-430B.title: Physical Chemistry
CHEM-430B.description: Kinetic theory; equations of state; thermodynamics; phase equilibria; chemical equilibrium; nuclear chemistry, wave mechanics; spectroscopy; statistical thermodynamics; kinetics; electrochemistry; surface and colloid chemistry. Lecture, 3 hours; discussion, 1 hour.

CHEM-453.title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM-453.prereq_text: 1 from (CHEM-105B or CHEM-115B) and 1 from (CHEM-322B or CHEM-325B)
CHEM-453.description: Atomic structure, theory of bonding, molecular structure, metallic state, coordination compounds, transition and nontransition metals, magnetic and optical properties, crystal field theory, mechanism of reactions.

CHEM-490.title: Directed Research
CHEM-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

synonyms: Synthesis, Reactivity and Mechanism in Inorganic and Organometallic Chemistry
CHEM-516.title: Synthesis, Reactivity and Mechanism in Inorganic and Organometallic Chemistry
CHEM-516.description: A reactivity framework for inorganic and organometallic chemistry; synthesis, reaction mechanisms, and energetics; homogeneous catalysis.

synonyms: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: An Introduction for Chemists
CHEM-519.title: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: An Introduction for Chemists
CHEM-519.description: Amino acids and peptides; protein structure and function; enzyme kinetics; structure, analysis and synthesis of nucleic acids; chemical biology of DNA and RNA; biotechnology.

CHEM-527.title: Synthetic Organic Chemistry
CHEM-527.description: A survey of representative groups of widely used synthetic organic reactions; emphasis on scope, limitations, and stereochemical consequences.

CHEM-535.title: Introduction to Molecular Spectroscopy
CHEM-535.description: Theoretical and experimental methods of molecular spectroscopy and applications to chemistry. Rotational, vibrational, electronic, electron and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopies.

CHEM-536.title: Molecular Dynamics
CHEM-536.description: Potential energy surfaces, reaction dynamics, scattering theories, classical trajectories, statistical theories, molecular energy transfer, photodissociation dynamics, gas-surface interactions, experimental results, beam and laser techniques.

CHEM-540.title: Introduction to Statistical Mechanics
CHEM-540.description: Study of macroscopic systems from molecular viewpoint using statistical mechanics: ensembles, fluctuations, gases, gas-solid interfaces, crystals, polymers, critical phenomena, non-equilibrium systems.

CHEM-575.title: Modern Trends in Physical Chemistry
CHEM-575.description: Emerging research areas in physical and theoretical chemistry through a thorough discussion of seminal research articles and presentations of current research topics. Recommended preparation: some research experience and familiarity with literature search.

CHEM-588B.title: X-ray Crystallography
CHEM-588B.description: Application of diffraction techniques to problems of current chemical and biological interest.

CHEM-590.title: Directed Research
CHEM-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM-594A.title: Master's Thesis
CHEM-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM-594B.title: Master's Thesis
CHEM-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
CHEM-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Chemical Applications of Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy
CHEM-625.title: Chemical Applications of Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy
CHEM-625.description: Elementary theory of magnetic resonance spectroscopy, methods of spectral analysis, treatment of Fourier transform methods and time dependent phenomena; recent applications in organic chemistry.

CHEM-790.title: Research
CHEM-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CHEM-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CHEM-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CHEM-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CHEM-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CHEM-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CHEM-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CHEM-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CNTV-100O.title: Off Campus Studies
CNTV-100O.description: Coursework taken off campus. Section title indicates the name of the course taken at the host institution.

CNTV-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
CNTV-300O.description: Off-campus studies course; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

CNTV-490.title: Directed Research
CNTV-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

CNTV-589.title: Graduate Film Seminar
CNTV-589.description: Detailed investigation and discussion of various aspects of film.

CNTV-590.title: Directed Research
CNTV-590.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

CNTV-594B.title: Master's Thesis
CNTV-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CNTV-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
CNTV-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Introduction to 3-D Computer and Character Animation
CTAN-302.title: Introduction to 3-D Computer and Character Animation
CTAN-302.description: The fundamental principles of working in 3-D computer software with an emphasis on animation, performance, lip-syncing, timing and execution. Open to junior animation majors only.

CTAN-330.title: Animation Fundamentals
CTAN-330.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of animation, covering such topics as timing, anticipation, reaction, overlapping action, and metamorphosis.

CTAN-336.title: Ideation and Pre-Production
CTAN-336.description: Emphasis of lateral thinking working across boundaries to find underlying principles in terms of ideation: the act of becoming an agent of ideas. Open to junior animation majors only.

CTAN-432.title: The World of Visual Effects
