CTAN-432.description: Introduction to the expanding field of visual effects; topics include magic lanterns shows, stop-motion fantasies and animation combination films employing the latest digital technologies.

CTAN-436.title: Writing for Animation
CTAN-436.description: Workshop exploring concept and structure of long and short form animated films through practical writing exercises.

CTAN-443.title: 3-D Animation and Character Design
CTAN-443.description: Principles of 3-D animation and character design combining lectures, aesthetic concepts and techniques demonstrating the use of 3-D animation software and puppet animation.

CTAN-448.title: Introduction to Film Graphics--Animation
CTAN-448.description: Practical course in concepts, media, and techniques related to the graphic film; symbology, composition, kinestasis, animation, typography, color, and materials. Survey; lecture; production.

CTAN-450A.title: Animation Theory and Techniques
CTAN-450A.description: Explores the aestheics and techniques of animation, ranging from traditional character to contemporary experimental and computer animation genres, through lectures, exercises and projects.

CTAN-450B.title: Animation Theory and Techniques
CTAN-450B.description: Explores the aesthetics and techniques of animation, ranging from traditional character to contemporary experimental and computer animation genres, through lectures, exercises and projects.

CTAN-450C.title: Animation Theory and Techniques
CTAN-450C.description: Explores the aesthetics and techniques of animation, ranging from traditional character to contemporary experimental and computer animation genres, through lectures, exercises and projects.

CTAN-452.title: Introduction to 3-D Computer Animation
CTAN-452.description: Lecture and laboratory in computer animation: geometric modeling, motion specification, lighting, texture mapping, rendering, compositing, production techniques, systems for computer-synthesized animation.

CTAN-462.title: Visual Effects
CTAN-462.description: Survey of contemporary concepts and approaches to production in the current state of film and video effects work. Digital and traditional methodologies will be covered, with a concentration on digital exercises illustrating modern techniques.

CTAN-463.title: Creative Workflow in Visual Effects
CTAN-463.description: Spherical panoramic photography, 3-D digital environment techniques and a range of visual effects work while providing the stage for the student's storytelling.

CTAN-501.title: Interactive Animation
CTAN-501.description: This course introduces basic interactive and non-linear approaches to animation through a series of lectures and exercises, culminating in a group project. Recommended preparation: Photoshop/Director (software)

CTAN-502A.title: Virtual Reality and Stereoscopic Animation
CTAN-502A.description: An in-depth exploration of aesthetics and techniques involved in the conceptualization, design and production of immersive virtual environments and stereoscopic animation.

CTAN-522.title: Animation Department Seminar
CTAN-522.description: A weekly seminar required of all MFA Animation students. This course includes guest speakers, faculty and student presentations followed by lively and critical discussion.

CTAN-523.title: Principles of Digital Animationn
CTAN-523.description: Principles of 2-D and 3-D animation creation and integration culminating in a 30 second animated digital film based upon a popular science theme. Recommended preparation: basic computer knowledge.

synonyms: Contemporary Topics in Animation and Digital Arts
CTAN-524.title: Contemporary Topics in Animation and Digital Arts
CTAN-524.description: Topics exploring the evolution of the brain, development of art, technology, science and culture. How this correlates to the evolution of animation-digital media.

CTAN-547.title: Animation Production I
CTAN-547.description: Practicum in film, video and computer animation emphasizing the production process through individual projects. Open only to MFA Animation students.

CTAN-549.title: Animation Production III
CTAN-549.description: Crew constituted advanced practicum in film, video, and computer animation. Open only to MFA Animation students.

CTAN-563.title: Advanced Computer Animation
CTAN-563.description: Investigation of advanced computer techniques related to character representation and various types of algorithmically defined animation produced on either film or videotape.

CTAN-577B.title: Fundamentals of Animation
CTAN-577B.description: The exploration of the techniques of the art of character animation with an emphasis on discipline, performance and personality observation, specializing in classical Hollywood animation. Open only to MFA Animation students.

CTAN-579.title: Expanded Animation
CTAN-579.description: A survey of animation across media; applications to live action film, the fine arts, architecture; linkages with modern art, postmodern theory and social history. Open only to M.F.A. Animation students.

CTAN-591.title: Animation Pre-Thesis Seminar
CTAN-591.description: A pre-production seminar, where students complete the research, development, script and storyboards for their thesis projects to be executed in CTAN 594ab. Open to M.F.A. Animation students only.

CTAN-593.title: Directed Studies in Animation
CTAN-593.description: Individual exploration in the areas of contemporary technology, animation techniques or experimental film through internships, residencies or directed studies.

CTAN-594B.title: Master's Thesis
CTAN-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CTAN-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
CTAN-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CTAN-599.title: Special Topics
CTAN-599.description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

CTCS-190.title: Introduction to Cinema
CTCS-190.description: Gateway to majors and minors in cinema-television. Technique, aesthetics, criticism, and social implications of cinema. Lectures accompanied by screenings of appropriate films.

CTCS-191.title: Introduction to Television and Video
CTCS-191.description: Exploration of the economic, technological, aesthetic, and ideological characteristics of the televisual medium; study of historical development of television and video including analysis of key works; introduction to TV/Video theory and criticism.

synonyms: Race, Class, and Gender in American Film
CTCS-192.title: Race, Class, and Gender in American Film
CTCS-192.description: Analyzes issues of race, class and gender in contemporary American culture as represented in the cinema.

synonyms: History of the International Cinema II
CTCS-201.title: History of the International Cinema II
CTCS-201.description: The development of international cinema from World War II to the present. Lectures, screenings, and discussions.

CTCS-392.title: History of the American Film, 1925-1950
CTCS-392.description: Screenings of American film classics and their relationship to society. Lectures and discussions.

CTCS-394.title: History of the American Film, 1977-Present
CTCS-394.description: Cinematic and extra-cinematic determinants of Postmodernist Hollywood studio and independent genres, styles, and the star-phenomenon and their relationship to American history and culture.

CTCS-402.title: Practicum in Film/Television Criticism
CTCS-402.description: Exercise in writing film and television criticism using new and classic films and television programs.

CTCS-404.title: Television Criticism and Theory
CTCS-404.description: The evaluation of television programs and their reception from various theoretical perspectives which may include cultural studies, race and ethnic studies, psychoanalysis, gender and queer studies, and semiotics.

CTCS-411.title: Film, Television and Cultural Studies
CTCS-411.description: Detailed examination of film/television from the perspectives and insights of Cultural Studies; focus on the production and reception of cultural texts, practices, and communities.

CTCS-412.title: Gender, Sexuality and Media
CTCS-412.description: Examines how gender and sexuality are figured in cinema and television with an emphasis on the development of feminist media theory.

CTCS-464.title: Film and/or Television Genres
CTCS-464.description: Rigorous examination of film genres: history, aesthetics, cultural context, social significance, and critical methodologies.

CTCS-466.title: Theatrical Film Symposium
CTCS-466.description: Lectures and readings on creative problems in the motion picture industry; current films; interviews with visiting producers, directors, writers, performers.

CTCS-467.title: Television Symposium
CTCS-467.description: Lectures and readings on creative problems in the television industry; study of current and historical trends, interviews with producers, directors, writers and performers.

CTCS-469.title: Film and/or Television Style Analysis
CTCS-469.description: Intensive study of the style of an auteur, studio, film or television making mode in terms of thematic and formal properties and their influences upon the art of film. Cinema majors only.

CTCS-473.title: Film Theories
CTCS-473.description: Influential ideas and theoretical approaches that have shaped the making and study of film. Students are encouraged to take this course their junior year.

CTCS-494.title: Senior Seminar
CTCS-494.description: Rotating topics involving detailed study of the historical, cultural and aesthetic analysis of film, television, and new media technologies. Open only to majors in the School of Cinema-Television.

CTCS-495.title: Honors Seminar
CTCS-495.description: Advanced work in the historical, cultural and aesthetic analysis of film, television, and new media technologies. Open only to students in CTCS Honors program.

synonyms: History of Global Cinema Before World War II
CTCS-501.title: History of Global Cinema Before World War II
CTCS-501.description: Historical survey of global cinema from its beginnings until the advent of World War II.

synonyms: Survey History of the United States Sound Film
CTCS-503.title: Survey History of the United States Sound Film
CTCS-503.description: Survey history of the United States film from 1927 to the present, with emphasis upon film as art form, economic institution, technology, and cultural product.

CTCS-504.title: Survey of Television History
CTCS-504.description: An exploration of the historical, cultural, business, creative, and technological aspects of television.

synonyms: Case Studies in National and/or Regional Media
CTCS-510.title: Case Studies in National and/or Regional Media
CTCS-510.description: Seminar on media's impact in defining nation and/or region in specific cultural contexts. Also addresses issues of exile, diaspora, transnationalism and globalism. Departmental approval required.

CTCS-517.title: Introductory Concepts in Cultural Studies
CTCS-517.description: Introduction to central concepts, key theories, and/or leading figures in cultural studies, particularly as they relate to issues of popular culture and visual media.

CTCS-587.title: Seminar in Television Theory
CTCS-587.description: Detailed investigation and discussion of various aspects of television, including genre, textual analysis, production and distribution systems and audience studies.

CTCS-677.title: Cultural Theory
CTCS-677.description: Seminar in theoretical approaches to cultural studies; focus on interdisciplinary research of media and audiences, covering a range of methods and theoretical frameworks; concentration varies.

synonyms: Seminar in Genre and/or Narrative Theory
CTCS-679.title: Seminar in Genre and/or Narrative Theory
CTCS-679.description: Seminar in theoretical issues concerning genre and/or narrative as they pertain to media, literature, other cultural forms. Areas of focus vary from semester to semester. Departmental approval required.

CTCS-790.title: Research
CTCS-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

CTCS-791.title: Historical and Critical Research Methods
CTCS-791.description: Methods and procedures for historical and critical research in the visual media. Required tutorial with Ph.D. student's dissertation committee chair, designed to assist initial work on the dissertation.

CTCS-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTCS-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CTCS-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CTPR-241.title: Fundamentals of Cinema Technique
CTPR-241.description: Introduction to cinema production techniques and equipment, including producing, directing, camera, lighting, and editing. Open to Cinema-Television majors only.

CTPR-242.title: Fundamentals of Cinematic Sound
CTPR-242.description: Introduction to sound design, recording, editing, mixing, and finishing. Lectures, demonstrations, and exercises. Open to production majors only.

CTPR-280.title: Structure of the Moving Image
CTPR-280.description: Basic theory and application of the concepts of time, space, composition, movement, light and color in motion picture production. Open to production majors only.

synonyms: Originating and Developing Ideas for Film
CTPR-288.title: Originating and Developing Ideas for Film
CTPR-288.description: Exercises in observation, imaginative association, visualization, etc., that deepen the creative process, leading to ideas, stories, characters and images for narrative, documentary and experimental films. Open to Cinema-Television majors only.

CTPR-290.title: Cinematic Communication
CTPR-290.description: Introduction to filmmaking as related to cinematic expression, aesthetics, criticism, and ethics. Individual film projects. Open to Cinema-Television majors only.

CTPR-310.title: Intermediate Film Production
CTPR-310.prereq_text: (CTPR-241 and CTPR-242 and CTPR-290 and CTWR-413)
CTPR-310.description: Basic principles of visual and audio communication; idea development using image, movement, pace, the spoken word and other sounds; action and sound relationships; individual projects. Recommended preparation: CTPR 280

CTPR-319.title: Directing for Writers: Fundamentals
CTPR-319.description: A workshop in which students will direct original scene material in a stage environment on class time. Director's role and responsibilities, the process of translating the written word into image and action; basics of camera, working with actors and staging; working with and in various crew roles in a production team; editing dialogue scenes. Open to B.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only. Recommended preparation: CTPR 241, CTPR 290, CTPR 318

CTPR-327.title: Motion Picture Camera
CTPR-327.description: Use of motion picture camera equipment; principles of black-and-white and color cinematography. Individual projects.

CTPR-335.title: Motion Picture Editing
CTPR-335.description: Theory, techniques, and practices in picture editing; use of standard editing equipment; individual projects.

CTPR-371.title: Directing for Television
CTPR-371.description: Preparation of director's preproduction blockout; study of direction for live, tape, and film production, for both dramatic and informational television.

CTPR-376.title: Intermediate Cinematography
CTPR-376.prereq_text: (CTPR-241 and CTPR-242 and CTPR-290 and CTWR-413)
CTPR-376.description: Intermediate cinematography workshop; practical problems and assignments. Recommended preparation: CTPR 280.

CTPR-382.title: Advanced Multi-Camera Television Comedy Pilot
CTPR-382.description: A hands-on course which allows students to experience all aspects of multi-camera television production by creating a pilot episode of a situation comedy. Recommended preparation: experience working a "Trojanvision"

CTPR-385.title: Colloquium: Motion Picture Production Techniques
CTPR-385.description: Basic procedures and techniques applicable to production of all types of films; demonstration by production of a short film from conception to completion.

synonyms: Art and Industry of the Theatrical Film
CTPR-386.title: Art and Industry of the Theatrical Film
CTPR-386.description: Detailed analysis of one theatrical film from conception through critical reception to develop an understanding of motion pictures as art, craft, and industry.

CTPR-409.title: Practicum in Television Production
CTPR-409.description: Television production laboratory course for students with a major production commitment with Trojan Vision. Requires station management and Chair of Production approval.

synonyms: The Movie Business: From Story Concept to Exhibition
CTPR-410.title: The Movie Business: From Story Concept to Exhibition
CTPR-410.description: Examination of the industry from story ideas, through script development, production and exhibition; evaluation of roles played by writers, agents, studio executives, marketing and publicity.

CTPR-421.title: Intermediate Motion Picture Editing
CTPR-421.description: Intermediate motion picture editing workshop; practical problems and assignments encompassing film, video and non-linear editing techniques. Intermediate editing class for undergraduates. Open to CNTV production majors only.

CTPR-422.title: Makeup for Motion Pictures
CTPR-422.description: Lecture-laboratory in makeup relating it to mood of the story and emulsion of the camera stock.

synonyms: Introduction to Special Effects in Cinema
CTPR-423.title: Introduction to Special Effects in Cinema
CTPR-423.description: Introductory workshop in the aesthetics and practices of special effects, embracing both the classical and contemporary modes.

CTPR-424.title: Practicum in Cinematography
CTPR-424.description: Camera and lighting workshop in color. In-class exercises working in professional film crew positions that rotate each week. Class starts with 35mm still photography and moves into motion picture in 16mm and digital formats.

CTPR-425.title: Production Planning
CTPR-425.description: Theory, discussion, and practical application of production planning during preproduction and production of a film.

CTPR-426.title: The Production Experience
CTPR-426.description: To provide students with basic working knowledge of both the skills of the motion picture set and production operations through classroom lectures and hands-on experience.

CTPR-454.title: Acting for Film and Television
CTPR-454.description: Intensive examination of skills and techniques necessary for successful performances in film and television. Practical application through in-class exercises and assigned projects.

CTPR-455.title: Introduction to Production Design
CTPR-455.description: Structure of the filmic art department, fundamentals and application of design principles to film and television, including script breakdown, design concepts and storyboarding.

CTPR-456.title: Introduction to Art Direction
CTPR-456.description: Introduction to computer drafting, set design, rendering and model-making for students with diverse abilities. Guest lecturers, group discussions and hands-on workshop.

CTPR-460.title: Film Business Procedures and Distribution
CTPR-460.description: Financing, budgeting, management as applied to films; problems of distribution, including merchandising, cataloging, evaluation, and film library management.

CTPR-461.title: TV Station Management
CTPR-461.description: Station organization and management of locally produced programs. Topics include program development, financing and distribution, network relations and program acquisition issues.

synonyms: Practicum in On-Screen Direction of Actors
CTPR-470.title: Practicum in On-Screen Direction of Actors
CTPR-470.description: Concentration on the basic skills in working with actors from a director's point of view.

CTPR-473.title: Directing the Composer
CTPR-473.description: Acquaints aspiring filmmakers (who have no musical background) with the fundamental concepts of film music from theoretical, creative, and pragmatic standpoints.

CTPR-474.title: Television Documentary Production
CTPR-474.description: Production of short community-based documentaries for telecast. Collaborative research, writing, producing, directing, shooting, and editing. Emphasizes personal story telling. Class study of major documentaries.

CTPR-475.title: Directing: Mise-en-Scene
CTPR-475.description: Through a semester-long collaboration, directors and actors learn how to work and communicate with each other while shooting two scenes on camera per director.

CTPR-480.title: Production Workshop I
CTPR-480.description: Intermediate practical work in film production; creative use of camera, sound, editing, and production planning. Open to Cinema-Television majors only.

CTPR-486.title: Single Camera Television Dramatic Series
CTPR-486.description: Collaborative production and post-production of an original episodic drama, shot on original sets on stage and on location. Recommended preparation: CTPR 479.

CTPR-495.title: Internship in Cinema/Television
CTPR-495.description: On-the-job film, television, or interactive industry experience in the areas of interest of the individual student. Open only to upper division undergraduate and graduate students. Requires departmental approval.

synonyms: The Film Industry: Career Challenges and Choices for Women
CTPR-496.title: The Film Industry: Career Challenges and Choices for Women
CTPR-496.description: Discusses womens' roles in the entertainment industry and career opportunities available for women in the business, corporate, and creative sectors.

CTPR-497.title: Music Video Production
CTPR-497.description: Writing the concept, budgeting, shooting, editing and directing a music video. Also covered: getting the job, dealing with the band, working with the record company.

CTPR-499.title: Special Topics
CTPR-499.description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema and/or television; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

CTPR-506.title: Visual Expression
CTPR-506.description: Definition, analysis, and structure of the visual components that make film an expressive medium; theory and practical application; individual projects and lecture/demonstration.

CTPR-507.title: Production I
CTPR-507.description: A practical exploration of the fundamental technical and aesthetic principles of motion picture production. Involves individual and group projects. Open to graduate cinema-television majors only.

CTPR-508.title: Production II
CTPR-508.description: Practicum in group production, emphasizing the collaborative process and the expressive use of sound and image. Open to graduate students only.

CTPR-510.title: Concepts of Cinematic Production
CTPR-510.description: Overview of the process of making media. Introduces fundamental thinking typical of each craft. Presents realities of careers and ethical issues in media.

CTPR-523.title: Introduction to Multiple-Camera Production
CTPR-523.description: How to direct comedy or dramatic scenes, using multiple camera techniques. Students also serve as crew members, learning lighting, mixing, studio controls, and stage management.

CTPR-531.title: Planning the Production
CTPR-531.description: A preproduction workshop in which students complete the research and planning of an intermediate project to be executed in 546L.

CTPR-532.title: Intermediate Directing
CTPR-532.description: Practical experience in staging dramatic narrative scenes, emphasizing directing actors, rehearsal techniques and camera blocking.

CTPR-533.title: Directing Techniques
CTPR-533.description: Practicum in more complex directing issues concentrating both on performance and exploration of shaping scenes visually through blocking of action and placement of camera.

CTPR-535.title: Intermediate Editing
CTPR-535.description: Editorial construction of sequences to analyze the interrelationships of the various film elements, both visual and aural.

CTPR-536.title: Editing for Scriptwriters
CTPR-536.description: Principles, techniques, practice, and theories of editorial construction of film and TV scenes and sequences. Open to M.F.A. screenwriting majors only.

CTPR-537.title: Intermediate Cinematography
CTPR-537.description: Close study through practical exercises of the technical and aesthetic principles of cinematography.

CTPR-543.title: Editing the Advanced Project
CTPR-543.description: Utilitarian seminar focused on editing advanced projects. Open to CNTV Production students only.

CTPR-546.title: Production III, Fiction
CTPR-546.description: An intensive workshop experience in which students, crewing in their area of specialization, complete the shooting and postproduction of projects up to thirty minutes in length. Qualifying courses: for directors, CTPR 532, and for cinematographers, CTPR 537.

CTPR-547.title: Production III, Documentary
CTPR-547.description: Intensive workshop; students shoot and finish documentary projects up to about 25 minutes. (Duplicates credit in former CTPR 546L.) Qualifying courses: for directors, CTPR 531 and crewing on either CTPR 546L or CTPR 547L.

CTPR-551.title: Planning the Advanced Production
CTPR-551.description: An advanced preproduction workshop in which students complete the planning of an advanced project to be executed in CTPR 586ab or CTPR 581ab, CTPR 583 or CTPR 584.

CTPR-552.title: Advanced Directing
CTPR-552.description: An advanced production class in directing. Encounters with experienced directors, and individual student production of a digital short.

CTPR-553.title: Developing the Advanced Project
CTPR-553.description: Script workshop for advanced projects. Covers key screenplay elements, including protagonist and objective, conflict, obstacles, premise and opening, main tension, emotional throughline, etc. (Duplicates credit in former CTPR 551.)

CTPR-554.title: Advanced Sound
CTPR-554.description: Study of the technical and aesthetic elements of sound design at the professional level. Intended for those contemplating a career in the field of audio.

CTPR-556.title: Advanced Editing
CTPR-556.description: Advanced editorial theory and practice intended for those specializing in film and electronic editing.

CTPR-557.title: Advanced Cinematography
CTPR-557.description: Advanced camera and lighting techniques for those considering a professional career in cinematography.

CTPR-558.title: Advanced Producing
CTPR-558.description: Defines and examines the role of the Executive/Feature Producer through the preproduction, production and post production phases.

CTPR-561.title: Publicity for Cinema and Television
CTPR-561.description: Analysis and preparation of advertising and publicity campaigns for entertainment films and television.

CTPR-562.title: Seminar in Motion Picture Business
CTPR-562.description: Problems of studio operation, production, distribution, exhibition, or legal procedures relating to the motion picture.

CTPR-563.title: The Business of Representation
CTPR-563.description: Various roles an agent, manager, attorney and publicist play in representing talent, producers and writers. Taught by professionals who are at the forefront of the entertainment industry.

synonyms: Developing and Selling Your Film or TV Projects
CTPR-566.title: Developing and Selling Your Film or TV Projects
CTPR-566.description: Developing, pitching, and selling your feature motion picture and TV projects. Open to undergraduate senior and third-year graduate cinema majors only.

CTPR-573.title: Producing the Advanced Project
CTPR-573.description: Basic skills of production planning as applied to students' advanced project scripts. Covers all steps from breakdown to delivery. Departmental approval. (Duplicates credit in former CTPR 551.)

CTPR-575.title: Directing for Scriptwriters
CTPR-575.description: Qractical experience in directing for screen; with special attention to framing, staging and use of camera. Group projects in video or film. Open to M.F.A. screenwriting majors only.

CTPR-581A.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR-581A.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Open to production students only. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 and CTPR 573 (for directors); CTPR 573 (for producers); CTPR 537 (for cinematographers), CTPR 535 (for editors), CTPR 546L or CTPR 547L as production sound person (for sound). Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR-581B.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR-581B.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Open to Production students only. Graded IP.

CTPR-581C.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR-581C.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Open to Production students only. Graded IP.

CTPR-581Z.title: Individual Production Workshop
CTPR-581Z.description: Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live-action or animated) and sound. Open to Production majors only. Graded IP.

CTPR-582A.title: Advanced Production Seminar
CTPR-582A.description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Open to Production students only. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 and CTPR 573 (for directors); CTPR 573 (for producers); CTPR 537 (for cinematographers); CTPR 535 (for editors); and CTPR 546L or CTPR 547L as production sound person (for sound). Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR-582B.title: Advanced Production Seminar
CTPR-582B.description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Open to Production students only.

CTPR-582Z.title: Advanced Production Seminar
CTPR-582Z.description: Advanced individual film or video projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, without benefit of university equipment or resources. Open to Production students only.

CTPR-583.title: Graduate Television Production
CTPR-583.description: Advanced television group production workshop for students who want to produce an advanced multi-camera project. Open to Production majors only. Prerequisites: directing and production positions: CTPR 532, CTPR 552, and CTPR 546L or CTPR 545; other positions: CTPR 546L or CTPR 545.

CTPR-586A.title: Production IV
CTPR-586A.description: Advanced group production workshop for students who have successfully completed Production III. Prerequisite: for directing position: CTPR 532, CTPR 546L, CTPR 551; non-directing positions: CTPR 546L and related intermediate seminar. seminar

CTPR-586B.title: Production IV
CTPR-586B.description: Advanced group production workshop for students who have successfully completed Production III.

CTPR-587A.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR-587A.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs. Open to production majors only. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 and CTPR 573 (for directors); CTPR 573 (for producers); CTPR 537 (for cinematographers); CTPR 535 (for editors); CTPR 546L or CTPR 547L as production sound person (for sound). Graded IP/Letter.

CTPR-587B.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR-587B.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs. Open to Production majors only.

CTPR-587C.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR-587C.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs. Open to production majors only.

CTPR-587Z.title: Group Production Workshop
CTPR-587Z.description: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live-action or animated) and sound. Minimum enrollment: director and producer. Open to Production majors only.

CTPR-599.title: Special Topics
CTPR-599.description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

CTIN-309.title: Introduction to Interactive Entertainment
CTIN-309.description: Critical vocabulary and historical perspective to analyze and understand experiences with interactive entertainment; students imagine and articulate their own ideas.

synonyms: Design and Technology for Mobile Experiences
CTIN-405.title: Design and Technology for Mobile Experiences
CTIN-405.description: Critical and pragmatic insights into designing mobile experiences and technology. Design groups will develop a mobile project using principles from readings and class discussions.

CTIN-406.title: Sound Design for Games
CTIN-406.description: Introduction to the techniques, terminology, and implementation of sounds in games, including establishing a sense of place and concepts of realistic sound.

CTIN-458.title: Business and Management of Games
CTIN-458.description: Overview of current business models in games and interactive media, methods for pitching and getting products funded; copyright an intellectual property.

CTIN-459.title: Game Industry Workshop
CTIN-459.description: Exploration of industry-related game play research questions. Student teams will develop concepts and materials to solve a research problem posed by an industry partner. Recommended preparation: CTIN 489.

CTIN-463.title: Anatomy of a Game
CTIN-463.description: Examine two game products from concept to delivery; introduce students to each of the professional disciplines involved in making digital games. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488

CTIN-482.title: Designing Online Multiplayer Game Environments
CTIN-482.description: Grouped into teams, students will study and design an original multiplayer game environment suitable for online usage.

CTIN-483.title: Programming for Interactivity
CTIN-483.description: Introduction to creative and technical aspects of new interactive media technology; computer games; digital video and sound; interactive Flash animations. Students design and produce projects.

CTIN-484.title: Intermediate Game Development
CTIN-484.description: Advanced topics in game programming and implementation such as using game engines, creating digital prototypes, player controls and level design.

CTIN-488.title: Game Design Workshop
CTIN-488.description: Theory and evaluation of interactive game experiences and principles of game design utilizing the leading software approaches and related technologies. Recommended preparation: CTIN 309, CTIN 483

CTIN-489.title: Intermediate Game Design Workshop
CTIN-489.description: A follow-up to the introductory game design class, this course will introduce more advanced concepts in game design and game theories, including ideation, digital prototyping and level design.

CTIN-491A.title: Advanced Game Project
CTIN-491A.description: Students work in teams to produce a functional digital game suitable for distribution via the web and/or submission into independent games festivals. Recommended preparation: CTIN 483, CTIN 488, CTIN 484, CTIN 489.

CTIN-491B.title: Advanced Game Project
CTIN-491B.description: Students work in teams to produce a functional digital game suitable for distribution via the web and/or submission into independent games festivals.

CTIN-492.title: Experimental Game Topics
CTIN-492.description: Development of a game around a custom-made physical interface; various technologies and techniques involved in software/hardware integration; peripheral design.

CTIN-501.title: Database Cinema
CTIN-501.description: Provide students with a 'vocabulary' of conceptual and artistic means to create computer based interactive works.

CTIN-511.title: Interactive Media Seminar
CTIN-511.description: Seminars on latest trends in interactive media content, technology, tools, business and culture. Graded CR/NC.

CTIN-542.title: Interactive Design and Production
CTIN-542.description: Interactive design, production, prototyping and testing of projects developed in CTIN 532. Open to Interactive Media MFA students only.

CTIN-544.title: Experiments in Interactivity II
CTIN-544.description: Experimental studio course in application of technology to interactive experience. Open to Interactive Media MFA students only.

CTIN-548.title: Preparing the Interactive Project
CTIN-548.description: An advanced production workshop in which students design and prepare for the production of their advanced project. Open to Interactive Media MFA students only.

CTIN-555B.title: Advanced Interactive Project
CTIN-555B.description: A two-semester sequence in which students produce and test an advanced interactive project. Open to Interactive Media MFA students only.

CTIN-558.title: Business of Interactive Media
CTIN-558.description: In-depth investigation of publication, distribution, business and legal aspects of the interactive entertainment business.

CTIN-584.title: Graduate Interactive Group Project
CTIN-584.description: Students work in small, interdisciplinary teams on focused interactive projects which approach professional levels of creative, intellectual and aesthetic performance.

CTIN-590.title: Directed Research
CTIN-590.description: Research project leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

CTWR-106B.title: Screenwriting Fundamentals
CTWR-106B.description: B: Exercises in dramatic writing: theme, plot, character, dialogue and images. Integration of these elements into scenes and sequences. Open to B.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only.

CTWR-206B.title: Writing the Screenplay
CTWR-206B.description: Creation of feature-length theatrical or documentary screenplay based on treatment developed in CTWR 206a.

CTWR-215.title: Practicum in Writing Short Films
CTWR-215.description: Developing stories less than feature length; writing screen plays from them; understanding what length each story demands; creating idiosyngratic forms and styles. Open to B.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only.

CTWR-306.title: Advanced Screenwriting: Alternative Narrative
CTWR-306.description: Develop and write an original feature-length screenplay utilizing a non-linear narrative story structure that examines the creative use of time, perspective, and point of view to enhance both character and story. Open to B.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only. (Duplicates credit in former CTWR 306b.)

CTWR-315.title: Filmwriting
CTWR-315.description: The basics of screenwriting: theme, story structure, characterization, format, dialogue, and scene description. A character profile, short treatment, and first thirty pages of the screenplay are written. Lectures, screenings, and in-class readings. Not available for degree credit to CNTV majors.

synonyms: Character Development and Storytelling for Games
CTWR-410.title: Character Development and Storytelling for Games
CTWR-410.description: An exploration of characters and story worlds as they relate to gaming with an emphasis on emotionally rich environments in interactive enetertainment. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488

CTWR-412.title: Introduction to Screenwriting
CTWR-412.description: Introduction to the formal elements of writing the short film.

CTWR-413.title: Writing the Short Script I
CTWR-413.description: Preparation of scripts for short films: form, structure, planning.

CTWR-414.title: The Screenplay
CTWR-414.description: Students study story structure and develop several story outlines, and a short script for possible 480 production. They will also write a detailed, 15-25 page treatment for a feature film.

CTWR-415A.title: Advanced Writing
CTWR-415A.description: Principles of the two-hour story for film and television, creating theme, character, and structure that combine into a feature-length story.

CTWR-415B.title: Advanced Writing
CTWR-415B.description: Creating a feature-length script for film or television, using the craft of the screenwriter to convey mood, energy, character, structure, and intent.

CTWR-416.title: Motion Picture Script Analysis
CTWR-416.description: Evaluation of completed scripts prior to their production; evaluation of existing classic scripts.

CTWR-418B.title: Senior Thesis
CTWR-418B.description: b: Completion and revision of Senior Thesis project and introduction to motion picture industry procedures and practices through interaction with industry representatives. Open to B.F.A. Writing for Screen and Televsion students only.

CTWR-421.title: Writing the Hour-Long Dramatic Series
CTWR-421.prereq_text: 1 from (CTWR-206B or CTWR-414 or CTWR-514A or CTWR-529)
CTWR-421.description: Writing an episode of an existing dramatic television series within the hour-long format with an emphasis on conception, pitching, characterization and structure.

CTWR-434.title: Comedy Writing Genres
CTWR-434.prereq_text: 1 from (CTWR-206B or CTWR-414 or CTWR-514A or CTWR-529)
CTWR-434.description: Exploration into filmic comedy; writing by committee; developing comedic timing; using humor as a style of filmmaking.

synonyms: Writing for Film and Television Genres
CTWR-435.title: Writing for Film and Television Genres
CTWR-435.prereq_text: 1 from (CTWR-206B or CTWR-414 or CTWR-514B or CTWR-514 or CTWR-529)
CTWR-435.description: Preparation of proposals and scripts for different types of film or television programming: emphasis on conception, structure, characterization and format.

CTWR-437.title: Writing the Situation Comedy Pilot
CTWR-437.description: Essentials of television comedy with in-depth study of ideas, character, and venues. Students will write an original story outline, treatment and polish.

synonyms: Writing the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
CTWR-439.title: Writing the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
CTWR-439.description: An advanced workshop in which students create an original dramatic series, including a first script and a summary of characters and storylines.

synonyms: Writing Workshop in Creativity and Imagination
CTWR-441.title: Writing Workshop in Creativity and Imagination
CTWR-441.description: Students will explore a variety of problem solving techniques to strengthen their creative work, and apply these techniques to individual writing projects.

CTWR-453.title: Advanced Feature Rewriting
CTWR-453.description: An advanced workshop in which a feature length screenplay will be rewritten using a specific methodology that focuses on a macro to micro approach to revision.

CTWR-499.title: Special Topics
CTWR-499.description: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema and/or television; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

CTWR-514B.title: Basic Dramatic Screenwriting
CTWR-514B.description: Dramaturgy for the fiction and nonfiction work. Techniques for creating the original or adapted theatrical length script. b: Development of an outline and feature length, original script. Open to graduate screenwriting (CNTV) and dramatic writing (Theatre) students only.

CTWR-515B.title: Practicum in Screenwriting
CTWR-515B.description: Comprehensive re-writing of second and third drafts of a feature screenplay leading to a polished and professional piece.

CTWR-515C.title: Practicum in Screenwriting
CTWR-515C.description: Supervised preparation of rewrite for the master's writing project, a feature length screenplay. At least three meetings during the term are required.

CTWR-516.title: Advanced Motion Picture Script Analysis
CTWR-516.description: Detailed evaluation of completed scripts prior to their production; evaluation of existing classic scripts.

CTWR-518.title: Introduction to Interactive Writing
CTWR-518.description: A series of exercises written and discussed for interactive experiences.

CTWR-520.title: Advanced Scene Writing Workshop
CTWR-520.description: Intensive workshop oriented specifically to writing and re-writing the most effective and telling dramatic scenes to heighten audience participation and greater story impact.

CTWR-528.title: Screenwriting Fundamentals
CTWR-528.description: Introduction to the principles of screenwriting with special emphasis on story, characterization and dramatization.

CTWR-529.title: Intermediate Screenwriting
CTWR-529.description: Emphasizes structural elements crucial to the feature film. Techniques for creating an original or adapted theatrical-length script.

CTWR-533A.title: Writing the Feature Script
CTWR-533A.description: Advanced screenwriting workshop. a: Development of characters and story to complete a treatment and first draft of a feature length script. Recommended preparation: CTWR 516.

CTWR-533B.title: Writing the Feature Script
CTWR-533B.description: Advanced screenwriting workshop. b: Rewriting the first draft into a second draft through advanced work-shopping of script. A third draft polish is the final assignment.

CTWR-553.title: Advanced Screenwriting
CTWR-553.description: Advanced feature screenwriting, emphasizing the rewrite of a first draft script.

synonyms: Practicum in Directing Actors for Film
CTWR-572.title: Practicum in Directing Actors for Film
CTWR-572.description: Seminar in directing actors for film; emphasis on demonstration and laboratory exercises, script analysis, and study and character motivations.

synonyms: Advanced Seminar in Directing Actors for Film
CTWR-574.title: Advanced Seminar in Directing Actors for Film
CTWR-574.description: Emphasis on detailed script analysis and character motivation. Individual projects.

CMPP-541.title: Producing Workshop
CMPP-541.description: Practical experience in motion picture production as it relates to the producer. Open to MPPP students only. Duplicates credit in CTPR 481abL.

CMPP-560.title: Script Development
CMPP-560.description: From idea and story to finished shooting script. Open to MPPP students only.

CMPP-564.title: Producing Business Procedures
CMPP-564.description: Seminars on various management and entrepreneurial techniques, including exhibition. Open to MPPP students only.

CMPP-568.title: Producing for Television
CMPP-568.description: Discussions of the creative and financial aspects of television producing. Open to MPPP students only.

CMPP-569.title: Seminar on Non-Mainstream Producing
CMPP-569.description: Discussions on non-major studio producing options, including non-traditional financing and non-theatrical producing. Open to MPPP students only.

CMPP-570.title: Advanced Television
CMPP-570.description: Advanced studies of the business of television, including the economic structure of the television industry.

CMPP-589B.title: Graduate Film Business Seminar
CMPP-589B.description: Economic structure and history of the film industry, including entertainment law and studio management. Open to MPPP students only.

CMPP-591.title: Producing Practicum
CMPP-591.description: Producing workshop encompassing all aspects of producing, including script development, budgeting, casting, and actual production.

CMPP-592.title: Individual Project Seminar
CMPP-592.description: Directed Research project and seminars in related topics. Open to MPPP students only.

EALC-100O.title: Off-Campus Studies
EALC-100O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

EALC-102.title: Language, Art and Culture: Calligraphy
EALC-102.description: This course introduces students to the origin of the basic components of Chinese scripts and the basic principles and styles of calligraphy.

EALC-104.title: Chinese I
EALC-104.description: The sound system of modern Chinese; aural comprehension, oral expression, basic patterns, and writing system.

EALC-106.title: Chinese II
EALC-106.description: Dialogue practice and conversation; readings of simple stories and essays; comparison of Chinese and English grammar; writing of paragraphs.

EALC-108.title: Reading and Writing Chinese
EALC-108.description: The basics of reading and writing modern Chinese; intensive reading and writing of paragraphs, essays and stories; extensive reading of beginner-level authentic materials.

synonyms: East Asian Humanities: The Great Tradition
EALC-110.title: East Asian Humanities: The Great Tradition
EALC-110.description: Introduction to the major humanities traditions of China, Japan, and Korea through an examination of representative works drawn from literature, aesthetics, philosophy, religion, and historical writing.

EALC-115.title: Korean I
EALC-115.description: Aural comprehension and oral practice; the writing system; grammar drill, sentence patterns. Lecture, 5 hours; additional hours for drill and laboratory.

EALC-117.title: Korean II
EALC-117.description: Continuation of 115. Progressive drill in dialogue, reading, and writing. Lecture, 5 hours; additional hours for drill and laboratory.

EALC-120.title: Japanese I
EALC-120.description: Basic Japanese conversation practice, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing Hiragana and Katakana (Japanese alphabetical systems).

EALC-122.title: Japanese II
EALC-122.description: Continuation of EALC 120. Basic Japanese conversation practice, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing Hiragana and Katakana and basic kanji.

synonyms: Introduction to Contemporary East Asian Cinema
EALC-125.title: Introduction to Contemporary East Asian Cinema
EALC-125.description: An introduction to and overview of the contemporary cinemas of East Asia: China (Hong Kong, the People's Republic, and Taiwan), Japan, and Korea.

EALC-130.title: East Asian Ethical Thought
EALC-130.description: Introduction to the history of Chinese, Japanese and Korean ethical thought; perspectives on human nature, historical writing, and aesthetic implications. Conducted in English.

EALC-200O.title: Off-Campus Studies
EALC-200O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

EALC-204.title: Chinese III
EALC-204.description: Conversational practice: reading of stories and essays; writing of short essays.

EALC-206.title: Chinese IV
EALC-206.description: Continuation of 204, with emphasis on reading and writing, frequent interaction with native speakers.

EALC-215.title: Korean III
EALC-215.description: Drill to increase proficiency in dialogue, reading, and writing; intermediate level readings.

EALC-217.title: Korean IV
EALC-217.description: Advanced level reading of modern Korean and exercises in written composition.

EALC-220.title: Japanese III
EALC-220.description: Continuation of EALC 122. Conversation practice, basic to intermediate grammar, and building proficiency of reading and writing Hiragana and Katakana with additional kanji.

EALC-222.title: Japanese IV
EALC-222.description: Continuation of EALC 220. More sophisticated grammar and voacabulary for natural conversation. Enhancing fundamental reading and writing skills, expanding the knowledge of kanji.

EALC-304.title: Advanced Modern Chinese I
EALC-304.description: Reading selections from different styles of modern Chinese writings, analysis of stylistic techniques and syntactic structure, composition, and translation.

EALC-306.title: Advanced Modern Chinese II
EALC-306.description: Continuation of 304; composition exercises in different styles of writing.

EALC-317.title: Advanced Korean II
EALC-317.description: Continuation of EALC 315, with emphasis on the use of Chinese characters, translation, and composition exercises.

EALC-320.title: Advanced Japanese I
EALC-320.description: Strengthen intermediate Japanese language proficiency. Oral/aural communication skills as well as reading and writing skills. Promote an understanding of the present-day Japanese culture.

EALC-322.title: Advanced Japanese II
EALC-322.description: Continuation of EALC 320. Improve and strengthen abilities to speak, listen, read and write, coping with more involved materials and situation.

EALC-340.title: Japanese Civilization
EALC-340.description: Survey of the main characteristics and development of art, literature, philosophy, religion, political and social institutions through different periods. Conducted in English.

EALC-354.title: Modern Chinese Literature in Translation
EALC-354.description: Readings in modern Chinese poetry, fiction, and drama since 1919.

EALC-355.title: Studies in Chinese Thought
EALC-355.description: Chinese thought, particularly as formulated in the three great traditions: Confucianism, Taoism, Buddhism.

EALC-383.title: Later Chinese Art
EALC-383.description: A survey of Chinese painting from 900 to the present, emphasizing the role of painting within the context of Chinese intellectual history.

EALC-390.title: Special Problems
EALC-390.description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

EALC-400.title: Classical Chinese I
EALC-400.description: Introduction to the classical styles, selections from classical style writings, contrastive analysis of modern and classical Chinese, translation and writing practice.

EALC-407.title: Newspaper and Documentary Chinese
EALC-407.description: Reading selections from newspaper articles and modern documents, analysis of structural patterns, and writing practice.

EALC-424.title: Advanced Readings in Japanese II
EALC-424.description: Continuation of EALC 422. Students continue to improve their Japanese language competence in the course of acquiring Japanese pragmatic skills and cultural knowledge.

EALC-440B.title: Japanese for Academic Research
EALC-440B.description: Continuation of EALC 440a. Further develop skills for academic research conducted in Japanese. Topics include literature, history, and social and cultural issues.

EALC-452.title: Chinese Fiction
EALC-452.description: Development of Chinese fiction and readings from English translations of major Chinese novels such as the Dream of the Red Chamber, All Men Are Brothers, and others. Conducted in English.

EALC-490.title: Directed Research
EALC-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

EALC-531.title: Proseminar in Chinese Cultural History
EALC-531.description: Intensive readings in English concerning interpretive issues in the study of Chinese cultural history.

EALC-543.title: Seminar: Japanese Literature
EALC-543.description: Readings in original texts in the works of selected major writers; lectures dealing with intellectual and cultural backgrounds of the periods and the authors.

synonyms: Topics and Issues in East Asian Linguistics
EALC-561.title: Topics and Issues in East Asian Linguistics
EALC-561.description: Descriptive and theoretical analyses of the grammers of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean; emphasis on comparative studies of these languages and English.

EALC-588A.title: Directed Readings
EALC-588A.description: Assigned readings according to individual needs.

EALC-588B.title: Directed Readings
EALC-588B.description: Assigned readings according to individual needs.

EALC-590.title: Directed Research
EALC-590.description: Research leading tothe Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied tothe degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EALC-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EALC-594B.title: Master's Thesis
EALC-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EALC-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
EALC-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EALC-603.title: Professional Development II: Publication
EALC-603.description: Preparation of book and article manuscripts for publication and placement in presses and journals; revising dissertations for publication; preparing papers for conferences. Students produce an article manuscript ready for submission to a journal. Open to graduate students only. Graded CR/NC. Major Field Exam must be passed prior to taking this course.

EALC-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EALC-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

EALC-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EALC-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

EALC-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EALC-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CLAS-150.title: The Greeks and the West
CLAS-150.description: A historical and cultural survey of ancient Greece, 100-300 BCE. Emphasis will be on the reading and interpretation of literary texts, with extensive use of visual matter.

CLAS-151.title: Civilization of Rome
CLAS-151.description: Studies of Roman civilization through the major literary works of ancient Rome. All reading in translation.

CLAS-212.title: Archaeology: Interpreting the Past
CLAS-212.description: Methods and techniques employed in modern archaeological research, including the tools and principles of allied scientific fields and the impact of analytical and technological advances.

CLAS-280.title: Classical Mythology
CLAS-280.description: Origin, development, and transmission of mythology in Greek and Latin literature, with parallels from other traditions.

CLAS-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
CLAS-300O.description: Off-campus coursework; title of course taken at other insititution appears as a section title.

synonyms: Diversity and the Classical Western Tradition
CLAS-320.title: Diversity and the Classical Western Tradition
CLAS-320.description: Political, ethical, and ideological aspects of classical Western Attitudes towards human diversity. Relationship between classical tradition and contemporary discussions of diversity and unity.

CLAS-337.title: Ancient Drama
CLAS-337.description: Tragedies and comedies of the ancient world; later influences.

CLAS-360.title: Classical Arabic Literature in Translation
CLAS-360.description: Introduction to Classical Arabic literature and culture of the period 500 to 1500 AD. Focus on continuity of ancient traditions in Arabic. In English translation.

synonyms: Alexander the Great: Leadership, Personality and World Conquest
CLAS-375.title: Alexander the Great: Leadership, Personality and World Conquest
CLAS-375.description: Ancient sources on Alexander's life, personality and conquests. Modern evaluations of his achievements as a prototype for autocracy and empire-building from antiquity to today.

CLAS-465.title: Archaeology and Society
CLAS-465.description: The interaction of archaeology and contemporary societies through political and moral claims; archaeologists' role as stewards and interpreters of ancient cultures and their remains. Capstone course for the Interdisciplinary Archaeology major. Recommended preparation: background in archaeology, classics, or related field

CLAS-490.title: Directed Research
CLAS-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CLAS-495.title: Honors Research
CLAS-495.description: Individual research for honors in the major leading to a substantial paper or other project. Not open to graduate students.

synonyms: Seminar in Theoretical Approaches to Roman Culture and Literature
CLAS-565.title: Seminar in Theoretical Approaches to Roman Culture and Literature
CLAS-565.description: Introduction to the study of Roman culture and theories useful for modeling Roman culture and literature.

CLAS-590.title: Directed Research
CLAS-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS-594A.title: Master's Thesis
CLAS-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CLAS-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
