GR-120.title: Greek I
GR-120.description: Essentials of classical Greek grammar and vocabulary.

GR-150.title: Greek II
GR-150.description: Essentials of classical Greek grammar and vocabulary, continued. Basic reading skills.

GR-220.title: Greek III
GR-220.description: Reading Greek literature. Introduction to reading and translation of classical Greek prose and poetry. Extensive grammar review.

GR-250O.title: Off Campus Studies
GR-250O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution appears as a section title on the USC transcript.

GR-353.title: Plato
GR-353.description: Readings from the Republic or other dialogues.

GR-450.title: Readings in Greek Literature
GR-450.description: Readings in various authors and genres of Greek literature.

LAT-120.title: Latin I
LAT-120.description: Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary.

LAT-150.title: Latin II
LAT-150.description: Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary, continued. Basic reading skills.

LAT-222.title: Latin III
LAT-222.description: Reading Latin literature. Introduction to reading and translation of classical Latin prose and poetry. Extensive grammar review.

LAT-250O.title: Off-campus Studies
LAT-250O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at other instituiton appears as a section title.

LAT-316.title: Roman Comedy
LAT-316.description: Selected plays of Plautus and Terence.

LAT-450.title: Readings in Latin Literature
LAT-450.description: Readings in various authors and genres of latin literature.

CMGT-502.title: Strategic Corporate Communication
CMGT-502.description: Roles, responsibilities and requirements of communication functions within corporations; design and implementation of communication plans; strategic message production for internal and external audiences. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 502.)

CMGT-510.title: Communication, Values, Attitudes and Behavior
CMGT-510.description: Theory and research on value and attitude formation and change; consequences for communication and behavior. Duplicates credit in former COMM 510.

CMGT-520.title: Social Roles of Communication Media
CMGT-520.description: How mass media shape public images of groups, channel political power, promote consumption of goods. Social and political theories as tools in evaluating media impact. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 520.)

CMGT-534.title: Introduction to Online Communities
CMGT-534.description: History, technologies and theories of online communities; their uses for organizations; social networking; identity and privacy; participation; collaboration; advocacy and collective action: games and entertainment.

CMGT-535.title: Virtual Groups and Organizations
CMGT-535.description: How electronic networks affect interpersonal and organizational communication; types of interactive media; issues related to cyberspace and virtual community; collaborative teams; business on global networks. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 535.)

CMGT-540.title: Uses of Communication Research
CMGT-540.description: Applications of both data and interpretation in communications management. Topics include: audience ratings, surveys, experimental tests of programs and campaigns, formative evaluation, secondary data sources. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 540.)

CMGT-541.title: Integrated Communication Strategies
CMGT-541.description: Communication strategies for product marketing and advertising; communication's role in developing domestic and international marketplaces; practical applications of persuasion theory. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 541.)

CMGT-549.title: Case Studies in Digital Entertainment
CMGT-549.description: Explores foundation of U.S. media policy in the digital age; students prepare White Papers on an urgent issue of contemporary digital media and entertainment policy. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 549.)

CMGT-566.title: Communication Law and New Technologies
CMGT-566.description: Development of law in newer technologies. Cases include cable television, low power television, direct broadcast satellites, teletext, video cassettes, telephone, data networks, computer regulation. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 566.)

CMGT-570.title: Economics of the Communication Industries
CMGT-570.description: The economic forces that determine the structure and outputs of communication and media industries, including newspapers, broadcasting, cable, and telecommunications. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 570.)

CMGT-576.title: Communication Strategies for Conflict Management
CMGT-576.description: Communication strategies for effective negotiation, mediation and facilitation of disputes; structures for public interventions; emergence of online dispute resolution systems. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 576.)

CMGT-583.title: Social Marketing and Entertainment Education
CMGT-583.description: Theoretical foundations of social marketing and entertainment education; uses of dramatic serials, telenovelas and animation to promote human rights; program design, evaluation. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 583.)

CMGT-584.title: Communication and the Multicultural Marketplace
CMGT-584.description: Popular culture and marketing communication; race, gender, sexual orientation and consumer culture; consumption patterns and identity, loyalty and self-actualization; cultural marketing campaigns and socio-political conflict.

CMGT-590.title: Directed Research
CMGT-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the school. Graded CR/NC.

CMGT-591.title: Communication Internship
CMGT-591.description: Field experience in applying communication principles to settings in organizations, campaigns, or other contexts; analysis and assessment of issues and problems. Open to Communication Management, accelerated B.A., Communication/M.A., Communication Management, and M.A., Global Communication students only. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 591.)

CMGT-597.title: Communication Research Practicum
CMGT-597.description: Students design and produce an original project appropriate for their emphasis area within the Master of Communication degree; oral defense of project. Open to Master of Communication Management students only. (Duplicates credit in former COMM 597.)

COMM-141.title: Applied Debate
COMM-141.description: Fundamentals of debate and critical thinking; participate in classroom and public on-campus audience debates; engage in experiential learning in community settings.

COMM-200.title: Communication as a Social Science
COMM-200.description: Social scientific inquiry into human communication; core theories of message production and reception in interpersonal, group and organizational contexts.

COMM-201.title: Communication as a Liberal Art
COMM-201.description: Humanistic approaches to inquiry in communication; qualitative research techniques; core theories of message production and reception in social, political, and mediated contexts.

COMM-202.title: Introduction to Communication Technology
COMM-202.description: Survey of the cultural, social, political, and economic impacts of new communication technologies, including written language, the printing press, the telephone, television, and cyberspace.

synonyms: Introduction to Mass Communication Theory and Research
COMM-203.title: Introduction to Mass Communication Theory and Research
COMM-203.description: Survey of mass communication research; history, content, effects, theories, and policy implications of various media.

COMM-204.title: Public Speaking
COMM-204.description: Principles and practices of effective oral communication; analysis of the speaking-listening process; selection and organization of speech materials; use of new presentation technologies.

COMM-205.title: Summer Communication Practicum
COMM-205.description: Students address communication issues in a field setting. They will evaluate communication practices using interview methodology. Projects are jointly evaluated by internship supervisor and professor. Sophomore standing. Open to communication majors only. Graded CR/NC. Recommended preparation: sophomore standing

COMM-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
COMM-300O.description: Off-campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as section title.

COMM-301.title: Empirical Research in Communication
COMM-301.description: Experimental and survey methods for communication study; basic statistical concepts, procedures, and tests.

COMM-302.title: Persuasion
COMM-302.description: Theories and research in social influence; strategies and tactics of persuasive communications in such settings as politics, public relations, advertising, business.

synonyms: Learning from Case Studies in Communication
COMM-303.title: Learning from Case Studies in Communication
COMM-303.description: Case study approaches to communication research; reliability, validity, generalizability, and ethics in qualitative social research; cases in communication policy and practices.

COMM-304.title: Interpersonal Communication
COMM-304.description: Analysis of face-to-face interaction; role of communication in the development, maintenance and destruction of relationships; communication processes in managing interpersonal conflict.

synonyms: The Communication Revolution, Entertainment, and the Arts
COMM-306.title: The Communication Revolution, Entertainment, and the Arts
COMM-306.description: Explorations of the effect of digital technology on the entertainment business. Relationships among technology, economy, popular culture, entertainment and art.

COMM-308.title: Communication and Conflict
COMM-308.description: Nature and functions of communication in human conflict; development of communication skills for managing conflict productively in interpersonal, organizational and intercultural contexts.

COMM-310.title: Media and Society
COMM-310.description: Interplay between media and society, including family and children's socialization, inter-group relations and community, pornography and violence, gender and race, media ethics, conduct of politics.

COMM-320.title: Small Group and Team Communication
COMM-320.description: Group process theories relevant to communicative behavior in small group/team settings, including information exchange, decision making, leadership, and meetings; student team projects testing theoretic propositions.

COMM-321.title: Communication in the Virtual Group
COMM-321.description: Communication processes in global computer networks; formation, maintenance, and decline of virtual groups; privacy and access; introduction to computer networks for communication students and researchers.

COMM-322.title: Argumentation and Advocacy
COMM-322.description: Basic argumentation theory including analysis. Research and evidence, case construction, refutation; discursive and visual argument; diverse fields of advocacy including law, politics, organizations, interpersonal relations.

COMM-324.title: Intercultural Communication
COMM-324.description: Cultural variables and social psychological processes that influence intercultural interaction; relationship between communication and culture in diverse settings including business, medicine, and education.

COMM-340.title: The Cultures of New Media
COMM-340.description: Cultural implications of computer-mediated communication and related media. Ideological responses to media innovation; debates over artificial intelligence, virtual communities, and virtual reality. Recommended preparation: COMM 240

synonyms: Social and Economic Implications of Communication Technologies
COMM-345.title: Social and Economic Implications of Communication Technologies
COMM-345.description: Social and economic impacts of information and communication technologies; social factors that shape technological change; issues include access, privacy, freedom of expression, productivity, democratic control.

COMM-360.title: The Rhetoric of Los Angeles
COMM-360.description: Representations of Los Angeles communicated in diverse media; the city as rhetorical text; analysis of cultural identities, art, architecture, and representations in popular culture.

synonyms: Comparative Media: United States and the United Kingdom
COMM-364.title: Comparative Media: United States and the United Kingdom
COMM-364.description: Cross-national approaches to the study of US and UK media; focuses on news and entertainment media products; examines content, industries, technologies and audiences.

COMM-365.title: The Rhetoric of London
COMM-365.description: Examines the modern city as a communicative text with London as the case study; taught as a part of the Spring Semester in London Program.

synonyms: The Rhetoric of Ideas: Ideology and Propaganda
COMM-370.title: The Rhetoric of Ideas: Ideology and Propaganda
COMM-370.description: Techniques of propaganda in public discourse; communication strategies through which ideas become ideologies; case studies in wartime and corporate propaganda, imperialism, and cultural colonialism.

synonyms: Censorship and the Law: From the Press to Cyberspace
COMM-371.title: Censorship and the Law: From the Press to Cyberspace
COMM-371.description: The study of current and historical battles over the limits of free expression from press and public parks to television, movies, music and cyberspace.

COMM-375.title: Business and Professional Communication
COMM-375.description: Oral and written communication skills demanded in the workplace including informative and persuasive speeches; interviewing; team communication; and training material preparation. Recommended preparation: COMM 204

COMM-380.title: Forensics Laboratory
COMM-380.description: Directed individual research studies of contemporary problems. Supervised laboratory experience. Open only to members of the University debate squad.

synonyms: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
COMM-382.title: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
COMM-382.description: An inside look at the symbiotic relationship of sports and the media -- from the interdependence of sports and media, to the coverage of sports in newspapers, magazines, radio and television. The economic and ethical issues involved, the conflicts of interest, the history and current status of sports coverage in American media today.

COMM-384.title: Interpreting Popular Culture
COMM-384.description: Popular culture as an indicator of cultural values, a producer and reflection of cultural meaning, and a means of communication; theory and case studies.

COMM-385.title: Survey of Organizational Communication
COMM-385.description: The role of information, persuasion, and meanings in organizations. Topics include organizational culture, leadership, decision-making, networks, power, diversity and the global workplace.

COMM-395.title: Gender, Media and Communication
COMM-395.description: Issues of gender in communication, including: media representations of femininity and masculinity; and gender's role in communication at the interpersonal, public, and cultural levels.

COMM-411.title: Communication Criticism
COMM-411.description: Methods and functions of criticism in forms of public communication; historical-contextual, textual, and interpretive procedures; diverse theoretical approaches including formalism, dramatism, genre, and ideology.

COMM-421.title: Legal Communication
COMM-421.description: Analytical and communicative aspects of judicial argument; philosophy and techniques of jury trials, cross examination, and appellate advocacy; research, preparation, and presentation of case briefs.

COMM-430.title: Global Entertainment
COMM-430.description: Survey of economic, political, and cultural dimensions of the global entertainment marketplace; focuses on the international production and distribution of media products and services.

COMM-432.title: American Media and Entertainment Industries
COMM-432.description: Examines the history, technology, regulations, and business practices of American broadcast and entertainment industries.

synonyms: Gender in Media Industries and Products
COMM-465.title: Gender in Media Industries and Products
COMM-465.description: Examination of the effect of gender stratification in media industries upon the cultural products they create, especially gender and gender/race role portrayals.

synonyms: People of Color and the News Media
COMM-466.title: People of Color and the News Media
COMM-466.description: Reporting and portrayal of people of color in the United States; impact of racial diversity on media, employment and access, and development of media for individuals and communities of color. Open to non-majors.

COMM-467.title: Gender and the News Media
COMM-467.description: Gender and news media evolving images of women and men in print and electronic media. Impact of gender in content and style of news, television and cinema. Open to non-majors.

COMM-480.title: Nonverbal Communication
COMM-480.description: Theory and research; examination of the influence of environmental factors, physical behavior, and vocal cues on human behavior.

synonyms: Human and Technological Systems in Organizations
COMM-486.title: Human and Technological Systems in Organizations
COMM-486.description: How communication and information technologies are linked to organizational control, design, cultures; technology and competitive advantage; ethics and policy issues; technology-mediated work. Recommended preparation: COMM 385

COMM-490.title: Directed Research
COMM-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Available to juniors and seniors only.

COMM-494.title: Research Practicum
COMM-494.description: Students gain research experience in the design, implementation, analysis, and reporting of communication research. Students serve as research assistants to faculty members. Not available for graduate credit.

COMM-495.title: Honors Seminar
COMM-495.description: Advanced study of issues in communication; recent developments in communication and rhetorical theories. Open only to students in COMM honors program; recommended for seniors. Recommended preparation: COMM 301L.

COMM-496.title: Honors Internship
COMM-496.description: Field experience in applying communication principles to settings in organizations, campaigns, law, or other contexts; analysis and assessment of issues and problems experienced. Not available for graduate credit. Open only to COMM Honors students or seniors with a 3.0 GPA. Departmental approval.

COMM-497.title: Honors Thesis
COMM-497.description: Writing of the honors thesis. Not available for graduate credit.

synonyms: Ethical Issues in Entertainment and Communication
COMM-498.title: Ethical Issues in Entertainment and Communication
COMM-498.description: Examines social and political controversies over conflicting ethical standards for communication in a variety of media: mass-media, communication technology, and entertainment. Recommended preparation: COMM 200, COMM 201

COMM-504.title: Seminar in Interpersonal Communication
COMM-504.description: Theories of communication behavior in relatively unstructured, face-to-face situations; examination of decoder-encoder, message, channel, and situational variables. Not available to M.A. in Communication Management majors.

COMM-511.title: Seminar in Contemporary Rhetorical Theory
COMM-511.description: Theories of rhetoric from the eighteenth century to the present; emphasis on Perelman, Burke, Habermas, Grassi, and Booth. Not open to M.A. in Communication Management majors.

COMM-516.title: Seminar: Feminist Theory and Communication
COMM-516.description: Implications of feminist theory for communication; topics include epistemology, critique of science/technology, women and language, feminist approaches to media and film, women and the workplace. Not open to M.A. in Communication Management majors.

COMM-518.title: American Public Address
COMM-518.description: History and criticism of major American speakers and speeches with reference to the social, political, and intellectual background of their times. Not open to M.A. in Communication Management majors.

synonyms: Humanistic and Social Scientific Approaches to Human Communication II
COMM-526.title: Humanistic and Social Scientific Approaches to Human Communication II
COMM-526.description: Overview of humanistic and social scientific approaches to the study of communication; emphasis on macro and micro social scientific, symbolic, and structural perspectives. Not open to M.A. in Communication Management majors,

COMM-552.title: Research Methods in Communication II
COMM-552.description: Developing expertise in field research, and experimental, quasi-experimental, and correlational methods in communication research. Taught in Computer Lab. Not open to M.A. in Communication Management majors.

synonyms: Regression and Multivariate Communication Research III
COMM-554.title: Regression and Multivariate Communication Research III
COMM-554.description: Advanced analysis of variance, regression models, path analysis, MANOVA, discriminant analysis. Taught in Computer Lab. Not open to M.A. in Communication Management majors.

COMM-556.title: Advanced Communication Research IV
COMM-556.description: Structural equation modeling, LISREL and log linear. Taught in computer lab. Not open to M.A. in Communication Management majors.

COMM-580.title: Media and Politics
COMM-580.description: Mass media in American political life, including political reporting, election campaigns, non-electoral politics, and the media as a political issue.

COMM-582.title: International Communication: National Development
COMM-582.description: Roles of media institutions and communications behavior in national development including political, economic, and social spheres; Western and non-Western conceptions of development processes.

COMM-590.title: Directed Research
COMM-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the school. Graded CR/NC.

COMM-594A.title: Master's Thesis
COMM-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM-594B.title: Master's Thesis
COMM-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
COMM-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM-598.title: Practicum in Global Communication Research
COMM-598.description: Development and assessment of research into global communication; selection of appropriate research methodologies; and production of scholarly research. Open to M.A. in Global Communication students only.

COMM-602.title: Seminar in Persuasion
COMM-602.description: Classical and contemporary theories of persuasion, attitude formation and change; impact of cognition, affect and emotions; cultural and group influences; message strategies and framing.

COMM-620.title: Studies in Communication Theory
COMM-620.description: Current problems in communication theory and research; advanced, specialized interest areas of individual faculty on the frontiers of knowledge.

COMM-662.title: Video Games Research
COMM-662.description: History and content, motivation and selection, reception and reaction processes, and effects of video games; students conduct original research into video game usage and effects. Not open to Master of Communication Management students.

COMM-675.title: Independent Study
COMM-675.description: A supervised course tailored to specific student interests. The professor and student develop a syllabus that permits exploration of advanced or specialized topics. Graded CR/NC.

COMM-694.title: Preliminary Research Paper
COMM-694.description: Independent research designed to demonstrate the student's ability to conceptualize, conduct, and present scholarly research. Parallel to COMM 794. Graded CR/NC.

COMM-790.title: Research
COMM-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

COMM-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

COMM-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COMM-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

JOUR-090.title: Internships in the Media
JOUR-090.description: Intensive experience in the news and other media. Minimum time requirement; enables students to acquire skills and knowledge that cannot be gained in the classroom. Graded CR/NC. Open to journalism majors only. Not available for degree credit.

synonyms: History of News in Modern America
JOUR-201.title: History of News in Modern America
JOUR-201.description: Understanding news today. A survey of how news is gathered, weighed, and disseminated and how historical events have shaped news in the 20th century.

JOUR-204.title: Newswriting: Online
JOUR-204.description: Introduction to online newswriting with emphasis on context and relationship of topics to the story. Social responsibility and ethical framework for online journalists. Typing ability required.

synonyms: Basics of Broadcast Newsroom Production for Non-Majors Only
JOUR-210.title: Basics of Broadcast Newsroom Production for Non-Majors Only
JOUR-210.description: Introduction to broadcast newsroom production; preparation and treatment of form and content; procedures, problems, ethics, and practice in planning and producing a nightly newscast. Open to non-Journalism majors only. Not available for credit to Journalism majors. Graded CR/NC.

JOUR-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
JOUR-300O.description: Off-campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

JOUR-302.title: Reporting: Print
JOUR-302.description: Introduction to basic reporting techniques, public records reporting and beginning investigative journalism. Social responsibility and ethical framework for print journalists.

JOUR-303.title: Reporting: Broadcast
JOUR-303.description: Introduction to field reporting, audio and visual media. Social responsibility and ethical framework for broadcast journalists.

JOUR-309.title: Introduction to Online Media
JOUR-309.description: Convergence journalism and online skill sets. Blogs and Web content production. Social responsibility and ethical framework in digital information technology.

JOUR-310.title: Investigative Reporting
JOUR-310.description: Reportorial and analytical skills and techniques required for portraying and evaluating contemporary newsworthy events; lectures, discussions.

JOUR-340.title: Introduction to Advertising
JOUR-340.description: History and development of advertising; basic advertising campaigns showing relationships of marketing, creative, print and electronic media.

JOUR-343.title: Advertising Design and Production
JOUR-343.description: Production of advertising materials; emphasis on the creation and design of advertising elements.

JOUR-350.title: Principles of Public Relations
JOUR-350.description: Theories, processes, and techniques involved in planning and implementing programs designed to influence public opinion and behavior through socially responsible performance and mutually satisfactory communication.

JOUR-351A.title: Public Relations Media
JOUR-351A.description: Research, design, production, and writing public relations media; includes news releases, features, pamphlets, brochures, financial statements, management reports, scripts, scenarios, and publicity.

JOUR-351B.title: Public Relations Media
JOUR-351B.description: Research, design, production, and writing public relations media; includes news releases, features, pamphlets, brochures, financial statements, management reports, scripts, scenarios, and publicity.

synonyms: Censorship and the Law: From the Press to Cyberspace
JOUR-371.title: Censorship and the Law: From the Press to Cyberspace
JOUR-371.description: The study of current and historical battles over the limits of free expression from press and public parks to television, movies, music and cyberspace.

synonyms: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
JOUR-380.title: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
JOUR-380.description: An inside look at the symbiotic relationship of sports and the media -- from the interdependence of sports and media, to the coverage of sports in newspapers, magazines, radio and television. The economic and ethical issues involved, the conflicts of interest, the history and current status of sports coverage in American media today.

JOUR-400.title: Interpretive Writing
JOUR-400.description: Weekly assignments in the shorter forms of newspaper and magazine writing: essays, reviews, editorials, opinion-page articles, profiles; analyses of major 20th century journalists.

JOUR-402.title: Advanced Television Reporting
JOUR-402.description: Role of the broadcast journalism reporter; similarities and differences between print and electronic media; application of audio-video equipment; analysis and practical experience.

JOUR-403.title: Television News Production
JOUR-403.description: Production of television news programs; preparation and treatment of form and content; procedures, problems, and practice in planning and producing broadcast news materials.

JOUR-405.title: Non-Fiction Television
JOUR-405.description: Presentation and selection in non-fiction television programs including documentaries, electronic magazines and news series; ethical problems, field research, reporting, interviewing, pre-production.

JOUR-406.title: Advanced Broadcasting Production
JOUR-406.description: Advanced analysis, methods, and techniques of radio and television production; preparation and treatment of complex form and content; procedures, problem-solving, and practice.

JOUR-407.title: Newsradio
JOUR-407.description: Production of radio news: research, reporting, writing, preparation and treatment of form and content: procedures, problems and practice in producing radio news programs.

JOUR-420.title: Advanced Photojournalism
JOUR-420.description: Emphasis on advanced photojournalism techniques for complex photo storytelling; focus on style, content, design, expression and ethics.

JOUR-425.title: Advanced Radio News Production
JOUR-425.description: Production of public radio news: producing real-time newscasts for Annenberg Radio News. Newsgathering, assigning stories, anchoring, interviewing, working with reporters, editing and producing live programming.

JOUR-430.title: Writing the Film Review
JOUR-430.description: Techniques of writing the film review; preparation and treatment of form and content; problems, responsibilities and ethics of film reviewing.

JOUR-431.title: Feature Writing
JOUR-431.description: Techniques of writing newspaper feature stories, including the profile, the light feature, the news feature, the in-depth story; the art of narrative writing.

JOUR-435.title: Writing Magazine Non-Fiction
JOUR-435.description: A seminar in "how to" interview, research, write -- and place -- professional-quality articles for a full range of magazines/newspapers including women's, sports, ethnic, local and national.

JOUR-441.title: Sports Reporting
JOUR-441.description: News and feature coverage of sporting events, including social and economic factors influencing sports in America.

JOUR-446.title: Entertainment Reporting
JOUR-446.description: Techniques of reporting and writing about the entertainment business, economics and finances. Analysis of the skills and background needed for reporters specializing in this area of the news.

JOUR-450.title: Advanced Public Relations
JOUR-450.description: Application of principles and methods to intensive analysis of public relations problems, decision-making, programming, and evaluation in simulated staff and agency organization.

JOUR-451.title: Promotional Public Relations
JOUR-451.description: Principles and practices of public relations as a basic component in the promotion and marketing of goods and services; regulatory considerations; consumerism.

JOUR-454.title: Sports Public Relations
JOUR-454.description: Introduction to the field of sports information and promotion, including lectures, media assignments, role-playing, and presentations by sports professionals. Junior standing.

synonyms: The Role of Celebrity in Public Relations
JOUR-457.title: The Role of Celebrity in Public Relations
JOUR-457.description: Understanding of the history and application of celebrity in public relations, focusing on the entertainment industry and the notoriety attached to politics and the media.

JOUR-462.title: Law of Mass Communication
JOUR-462.description: Press law; government controls on the news media; legal responsibilities of the journalist.

synonyms: People of Color and the News Media
JOUR-466.title: People of Color and the News Media
JOUR-466.description: Reporting and portrayal of people of color in the United States; impact of racial diversity on media, employment and access, and development of media for individuals and communities of color. Open to non-majors.

JOUR-467.title: Gender and the News Media
JOUR-467.description: Gender and news media evolving images of women and men in print and electronic media. Impact of gender in content and style of news, television and cinema. Open to non-majors.

JOUR-470.title: Community Journalism
JOUR-470.description: Analyses of ethnic and community issues in community journalism. Students work with local youth to write, edit and design school newspapers and other media.

JOUR-474.title: Interviewing and Profile Writing
JOUR-474.description: Techniques of, and intensive application in researching and writing interviews and profiles for newspaper and magazines.

JOUR-475.title: Publications Design and Technology
JOUR-475.description: Art, typography, and other graphic elements in publication design; traditional, contemporary, and advanced production methods, processes, and equipment; representative examples; practice in design.

JOUR-490.title: Directed Research
JOUR-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

JOUR-498.title: Honors Seminar
JOUR-498.description: Intensive study of a subject of contemporary relevance or of professional importance to journalists. Students must be admitted to honors program.

JOUR-500.title: Media and Society
JOUR-500.description: Analysis of major theories on the role of communication media and society with special emphasis on the role and responsibility of the news media.

JOUR-502.title: Production: Print, Broadcast, Online
JOUR-502.description: Basic broadcast studio and field production, copyediting and newspaper production, database creation and management, online production. Social responsibility and ethical framework involving new media production.

JOUR-503.title: Reporting: Print, Broadcast, Online
JOUR-503.description: Basic print reporting techniques, broadcast field reporting, computer assisted reporting and statistics. Social responsibility and ethical framework for new media journalists.

JOUR-504.title: Public Relations Research and Evaluation
JOUR-504.description: Covers the use of primary psychographic and demographic research, pre- and post-campaign testing, and other highly quantifiable research techniques in program development and evaluation.

JOUR-505.title: American Media History Seminar
JOUR-505.description: Seminar surveying the history of the news media in the United States, and their sociopolitical impact, with emphasis on the 20th century.

synonyms: Legal, Ethical and Social Foundations of Public Relations
JOUR-510.title: Legal, Ethical and Social Foundations of Public Relations
JOUR-510.description: Explores the origins, effects of, and processes for adhering to the complex network of legal, ethical and social responsibilities of the contemporary PR practitioner.

JOUR-512.title: Advanced Interpretive Writing
JOUR-512.description: Analysis and writing of editorials, essays, Op-Ed page articles, profiles, and other shorter forms of journalism, combined with study of historic practitioners of those forms.

JOUR-517.title: Advanced Investigative Reporting
JOUR-517.description: Advanced reportorial and analytical skills and techniques required for evaluating newsworthy events. Group research and publication of stories on important current topics.

JOUR-519.title: Advanced Magazine Writing
JOUR-519.description: Reporting and preparation of articles for publication; analysis of magazine non-fiction markets; research and writing, techniques, and analysis of magazine markets.

JOUR-530.title: Strategic Public Relations Management
JOUR-530.description: An analytical, case study-based approach to strategic campaign planning, management and execution, with heavy emphasis on problem solving and the role of research.

JOUR-534.title: Case Studies in Public Relations
JOUR-534.description: Analysis of landmark and contemporary public relations cases; evaluation of current literature, programs, and professional personnel; identification of emerging issues.

JOUR-536.title: Public Relations Media Strategies
JOUR-536.description: Creation and execution of strategic public relations media plans based on organizational goals, audience analysis, and media characteristics.

JOUR-540.title: International Journalism Seminar I
JOUR-540.description: Historical perspective of foreign correspondence; examination of the working conditions, problems and consequences of reporting from abroad.

JOUR-556.title: Online Journalism Seminar
JOUR-556.description: Writing and reporting for the Internet and other technology platforms; computer-assisted reporting; multimedia storytelling.

JOUR-560.title: Seminar in Mass Communication Law
JOUR-560.description: Analysis of major elements of mass communication law, legal issues in contemporary mass communication, and the impact of legal trends on professional journalists.

JOUR-568.title: Critical Thinking and Crisis Management
JOUR-568.description: Introduction to the concept of critical thinking and its practical application to a variety of public relations challenges and opportunities; emphasis on formulating and evaluating problems from multiple perspectives.

synonyms: The Image of the Journalist in Popular Culture Seminar
JOUR-576.title: The Image of the Journalist in Popular Culture Seminar
JOUR-576.description: Study and analysis of the conflicting images of the journalist in popular culture and its impact on the public's perception of the media and newsgatherers.

JOUR-590.title: Directed Research
JOUR-590.description: Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

JOUR-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
JOUR-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

JOUR-599.title: Special Topics
JOUR-599.description: Seminar in selected topics in Journalism.

synonyms: Advocacy in Public Diplomacy: Argumentation and Debate
PUBD-509.title: Advocacy in Public Diplomacy: Argumentation and Debate
PUBD-509.description: A skills and theory based approach to the criticism and development of public diplomacy campaigns. Emphasizes the instruction of advocacy skills to assess the utility of specific campaigns.

PUBD-512.title: Cultural Diplomacy
PUBD-512.description: Provides overview of formal cultural diplomacy and concentrates on ways in which non-governmental entities communicate across international boundaries and the effects of those interchanges.

PUBD-516.title: International Broadcasting
PUBD-516.description: History, context and practice of global international broadcasting strategies; technological and financial parameters that shape future international broadcasting strategies; use of radio, television, and internet.

PUBD-596.title: Practicum in Public Diplomacy Research
PUBD-596.description: Development and production of original research-based project in the area of public diplomacy. Graded CR/NC.

PUBD-599.title: Special Topics
PUBD-599.description: Special topics in the area of public diplomacy.

synonyms: Origins of Western Literature and Culture
COLT-150.title: Origins of Western Literature and Culture
COLT-150.description: Survey of literary and other cultural texts from antiquity through the Renaissance with emphasis on changing conceptions of community and the individual. Not available for major credit.

COLT-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
COLT-300O.description: Off-campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

synonyms: Lyric Interactions: Poetry, Self and Society
COLT-330.title: Lyric Interactions: Poetry, Self and Society
COLT-330.description: Lyric poetry as communicative interaction between individuals and groups in premodern to modern societies, with interdisciplinary approaches from communication theory, cultural history and social psychology.

COLT-351.title: Modern and Contemporary Drama
COLT-351.description: Comparative study of major modern dramatic trends, subgenres, and techniques, through representative works from Strindberg to the Theatre of the Grotesque and the Absurd.

COLT-360.title: Classical Arabic Literature in Translation
COLT-360.description: Introduction to Classical Arabic literature and culture of the period 500 to 1500 AD. Focus on continuity of ancient traditions in Arabic. In English translation.

synonyms: Women Writers in Europe and America
COLT-374.title: Women Writers in Europe and America
COLT-374.description: Introduction to works of major women writers from the Middle Ages to the 20th century in their literary, social, and cultural contexts.

synonyms: Senior Seminar on a Comparative Literary Topic
COLT-401.title: Senior Seminar on a Comparative Literary Topic
COLT-401.description: Study of a selected topic employing a comparative perspective on literature.

COLT-426.title: Utopias
COLT-426.description: Examination of selected utopias in their historical context as "no places" whose projections of alternate cultures always comment on their own.

COLT-490.title: Directed Research
COLT-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

COLT-495.title: Senior Honors Thesis
COLT-495.description: Writing of an honors thesis under individual faculty supervision.

COLT-499.title: Special Topics
COLT-499.description: Intensive study of selected author or authors in the context of a major literary tradition.

COLT-590.title: Directed Research
COLT-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Topics in Literary Criticism and Theory
COLT-602.title: Topics in Literary Criticism and Theory
COLT-602.description: Intensive study of a theoretical tradition or citical movement, or of an individual topic or thinker, in literary criticism or theory. Duplicates credit in COLT 581.

COLT-603.title: Professional Development II: Publication
COLT-603.description: Preparation of book and article manuscripts for publication and placement in presses and journals; revising dissertations for publication; preparing papers for conferences. Students produce an article manuscript ready for submission to a journal. Open to graduate students only. Graded CR/NC. Major Field Exam must be passed prior to taking this course.

COLT-680.title: Seminar in Literature and Philosophy
COLT-680.description: Emphasis on questions raised when literature confronts philosophical discourses: aesthetics, philosophy of law, ethics, philosophy of language, political philosophy, and others.

COLT-790.title: Research
COLT-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

COLT-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COLT-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

COLT-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COLT-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

COLT-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COLT-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

COLT-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COLT-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

COLT-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
COLT-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

SLL-100O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

SLL-120.title: Beginning Russian I
SLL-120.description: Introduction to the Russian language with emphasis on basic conversational skills, major points of grammar and reading.

SLL-199.title: Chess and Critical Thinking
SLL-199.description: Analysis of significant chess games, reflecting societal attitudes towards science, competition, art, gender, psychology, politics, and technology. Graded CR/NC.

SLL-220.title: Intermediate Russian I
SLL-220.description: Development of thematic conversational skills with emphasis on extended dialogue. Review of basic morphology with special attention to verbs of motion. Reading of authentic material is emphasized.

SLL-250.title: Intermediate Russian II
SLL-250.description: Continuation of SLL 220. Development of proficieny in conversation skills, reading, and writing.

SLL-270A.title: Russian for Native Speakers
SLL-270A.description: For native Russian speakers who cannot read or write Russian. Emphasis on essentials of grammar, vocabulary, and orthography, and the reading and writing of simple texts in Russian.

SLL-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
SLL-300O.description: Off-campus studies course; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

SLL-320.title: Advanced Russian I
SLL-320.description: Advanced conversation topics based on literature, the press, films, and broadcast. Advanced syntax.

SLL-330.title: Russian Thought and Civilization
SLL-330.description: Russian cultural identity from its beginnings until today. The Eastern Orthodox tradition, its traumatic confrontation with Western culture, and their continuous interaction.

SLL-465.title: Seminar in Russian Studies
SLL-465.description: Readings and discussion in Russian of current topics in Russian culture, politics and society. Content varies each time offered.

SLL-490.title: Directed Research
SLL-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

SLL-500.title: Topics in Advanced Russian
SLL-500.description: Study of Russian required for graduate work and professional activities.

SLL-555.title: Soviet Literature I (1917-1953)
SLL-555.description: Survey of the major writers and literary schools of Soviet literature in the crucial period from the Revolution to the death of Stalin.

SLL-557.title: Soviet Literature II (1953-present)
SLL-557.description: De-Stalinization of Soviet culture, the reappropriation of Russia's literary past, and new directions in contemporary literature.

SLL-585.title: 20th Century Russian Literary Criticism
SLL-585.description: Relationship between practical and theoretical literary criticism: formalism and structuralism, sociological school, and Bakhtin; theoretical approaches applied to specific literary texts.

SLL-590.title: Directed Research
SLL-590.description: Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SLL-594A.title: Master's Thesis
SLL-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SLL-594B.title: Master's Thesis
SLL-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SLL-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
SLL-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SLL-650.title: Seminar in Russian Literature
SLL-650.description: Detailed study of single literary period, movement, or genre; two or more selected authors; specific school of literary criticism. May be repeated, with departmental permission, if content of the seminar is different. Recommended preparation: one year of graduate study.

SLL-790.title: Research
SLL-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SLL-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC

SLL-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation

SLL-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
SLL-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC

WRIT-095.title: Writing Tutorial
WRIT-095.description: Individualized instruction in writing to support instruction in WRIT 130 or WRIT 140. Graded CR/NC. Not available for degree credit. Concurrent enrollment in WRIT 130 or 140.

WRIT-120.title: Introduction to College Writing
WRIT-120.description: Intensive instruction and practice in the writing process. Focuses upon the formal conventions and conceptual expectations of college writing, with emphasis upon the grammatical, stylistic, and rhetorical techniques required in successful writing. Graded CR/NC. Limited to and required of students who score below specified level on the USC Writing Examination.

synonyms: Introduction to College Writing in a Second Language
WRIT-121.title: Introduction to College Writing in a Second Language
WRIT-121.description: Intensive instruction and practice in the writing process for non-native speakers of English. Focuses on the formal and conceptual conventions of college writing, with emphasis upon the grammatical, stylistic, and rhetorical techniques required in successful writing. Graded CR/NC. Limited to and required of students who score below specified level on the USC Writing Examination.

WRIT-130.title: Analytical Writing
WRIT-130.description: Focuses on analytical and argumentative writing skills requisite to academic and professional writing. Emphasizes logical analysis of texts and other data, effective use of evidence, ethical argumentation, and stylistic and grammatical fluency. Enrollment limited to specified groups of students. Students must achieve a satisfactory score on the verbal portion of the SAT, the USC Writing Examination, or credit for WRIT 120 or 121 before enrolling in WRIT 130.

WRIT-140.title: Writing and Critical Reasoning
WRIT-140.description: Focuses on analytical and argumentative writing skills requisite to academic and professional writing. Emphasizes logical analysis of texts and other data, effective use of evidence, ethical argumentation, and stylistic and grammatical fluency. Requires concurrent enrollment with an affiliated General Education course in the Social Issues category. Students must achieve a satisfactory score on the verbal portion of the SAT, the USC Writing Examination, or credit for WRIT 120 or 121 before enrolling in WRIT 140.

WRIT-340.title: Advanced Writing
WRIT-340.description: Instruction in writing for various audiences on topics related to a student's professional or disciplinary interests, with some emphasis on issues of broad public concern.

DENT-221.title: Introduction to Dentistry
DENT-221.description: History and current role of dental science in the health services field; review of research; overview of dental procedures with laboratory experience and practice observation.

DENT-700.title: First Year Advanced Dentistry
DENT-700.description: FOR REGISTRATION AND FEE PURPOSES ONLY.

DENT-800.title: Second Year Advanced Dentistry
DENT-800.description: FOR REGISTRATION AND FEE PURPOSES ONLY.

DENT-850.title: Advanced Dentistry Third Year
DENT-850.description: For registration and fee purposes only.

CBY-561.title: Molecular Genetics
CBY-561.description: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic molecular genetics: DNA and RNA structure and function; biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, RNA processing, translation, and regulation of gene expression. CNB 561, MICB 561, MPTX 561, PATH 561, PHBI 561, PSCI 561

CBY-574.title: Statistical Methods in Bioexperimentation
CBY-574.description: Experimental design and analysis as applied to all levels of biologic organization; hypothesis construction; probablility; univariate and multivariate analysis; basic epidemiology.

CBY-576.title: Biochemical Aspects of Periodontal Disease
CBY-576.description: Cell and molecular biology of oral tissues in disease; emphasis on molecular oral pathology. (Duplicates credit in former CBY 575b.)

CBY-585.title: Systematic Research Writing
CBY-585.description: Enhancement of critical research thinking by fulfilling anticipated conceptual components of the journal article; perfection of writing skills by correcting inter- and intrasentence flaws.

CBY-586.title: Scientific Writing Practicum
CBY-586.description: Development of writing skill while completing a discipline-required project (proposal, dissertation, journal article). Seminar and tutorial format. Not available for graduate credit.

synonyms: Cell and Molecular Biology of Craniofacial Tissues
CBY-587.title: Cell and Molecular Biology of Craniofacial Tissues
CBY-587.description: Contemporary cell and molecular biology as applied to the development, structure, and function of craniofacial tissues.

CBY-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
