THTR-100O.title: Off-Campus Studies
THTR-100O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution appears as a section title.

THTR-101.title: Introduction to Acting
THTR-101.description: Study of genres, terminology, and discipliines of acting; fundamental techniques necessary for performance; scene study from contemporary plays.

THTR-120B.title: Acting I
THTR-120B.description: Basic principles and techniques of acting through theatre games and improvisation. Introduction to contemporary texts, basic characterization and cold reading techniques. Open to BFA acting majors only.

THTR-122.title: Improvisation and Theatre Games
THTR-122.description: Individual and group exercises to free the actor physically and emotionally and to stimulate creativity, imagination, and self-expression.

THTR-124A.title: Character Acting
THTR-124A.description: Concentration of imaginative processes which develop the individual characteristics of a dramatic role.

THTR-130.title: Introduction to Theatrical Production
THTR-130.description: Introduction to the non-performance areas of theatrical production (administrative, design, and technical fields) through hands-on participation in USC productions.

THTR-140B.title: Voice I
THTR-140B.description: Physiological mechanism of voice: breath control, phonation, resonance, articulation of language for the stage; expressive use of stress, intonation and rhythm.

THTR-181A.title: Modern Dance
THTR-181A.description: a: Techniques of modern dance; elements of dance composition.

THTR-183A.title: Ballet
THTR-183A.description: a: Beginning techniques of classical ballet consisting of basic barre and center work; basic body and arm positions, port de bras, allegro and elementary adagio.

THTR-183B.title: Ballet
THTR-183B.description: Intermediate techniques of classical ballet with intermediate barre, adagio, allegro combinations and pirouettes; development of a working knowledge of ballet terminology.

THTR-183C.title: Ballet
THTR-183C.description: Advanced techniques of classical ballet; emphasis on clarity and precision with execution of movement. Study of beats, tours, advanced adagio and allegro, grand combinations, pointe-work.

THTR-184A.title: Jazz Dance
THTR-184A.description: Beginning techniques and practice of jazz dance.

THTR-184B.title: Jazz Dance
THTR-184B.description: Continuing study in the techniques of jazz dance.

THTR-184C.title: Jazz Dance
THTR-184C.description: Advanced techniques of jazz dance: advanced warm-up, rhythmic and isolation exercises, turns and advanced jazz sequences or combinations.

THTR-188A.title: International Style Ballroom Dance
THTR-188A.description: Representative ballroom dances: waltz, slow foxtrot, tango, and quickstep. a: Beginning. Graded CR/NC.

THTR-188B.title: International Style Ballroom Dance
THTR-188B.description: Representative ballroom dances: waltz, slow foxtrot, tango, and quickstep. b: Intermediate.

THTR-189A.title: Tap Dance
THTR-189A.description: Basic tap rhythms developed into elementary dances with progression of time steps and other combinations of sound.

THTR-189B.title: Tap Dance
THTR-189B.description: b: Continuing study of tap dancing including more complicated rhythmic patterns and combinations; polishing technique; combinations to varied music and introduction to advanced steps and combinations.

synonyms: Theory and Practice of World Theatre I
THTR-210.title: Theory and Practice of World Theatre I
THTR-210.description: A multicultural and transnational examination of the history, theory, and practice of theatre from its origins to the age of Shakespeare and Zeami. (Duplicates credit in former THTR 310.) Recommended preparation: THTR 125.

THTR-215B.title: Movement II
THTR-215B.description: Training of the actor's body with focus on mask work for the development of precision, strength and expressiveness.

THTR-216.title: Movement for Actors
THTR-216.description: Training and practice in the coordination of the physical apparatus of the actor utilizing various movement techniques through improvisation.

THTR-220B.title: Intermediate Acting I
THTR-220B.description: Continuing development of imagination leading to an increased range of dramatic expression through the formalized text of William Shakespeare. Open to BFA acting majors only.

THTR-222.title: Stage Make-up
THTR-222.description: Principles of stage make-up materials and skills allowing the actors to enhance their features and techniques for moderate and extreme aging, injuries, and character roles.

THTR-230.title: Communicating Theatrical Design Concepts
THTR-230.description: The visualization and communication of design ideas through free-hand and mechanical drawing: orthographics, isometrics, perspective, shades and shadows, plans, sections and elevations.

THTR-231B.title: Costume Construction
THTR-231B.description: Historical survey, theory and practice in construction of costume, emphasis on period and style.

THTR-232.title: Stage Lighting
THTR-232.description: Theory and practice of theatrical lighting design including electricity, radiant energy, refraction, reflection, absorption, chromatic variation, and electronic controls.

THTR-240B.title: Voice II
THTR-240B.description: Development of the voice using material which explores the techniques of Shakespeare and his contemporaries.

THTR-252A.title: Intermediate Acting I
THTR-252A.description: a: Polishing the actor's skills through analysis and class performance of scenes from plays.

THTR-252B.title: Intermediate Acting I
THTR-252B.description: Polishing the actor's skills through analysis and class performance of scenes from plays. Continuation of 252a.

THTR-282.title: Activities for Professional Preparation: Dance
THTR-282.description: Fundamental movements and composition in modern and aerobic dance; study of popular social dance forms; teaching and evaluation methodologies; course and class planning.

THTR-285.title: Elements of Dance Production
THTR-285.description: Theoretical aspects of creativity, choreography, accompaniment, dance notation, and production; application in individual and group composition. Lecture, 2 hours; performance laboratory, 6 hours.

THTR-295.title: Theatre in America
THTR-295.description: Current state of American theatre, through a study of acting, playwriting, criticism, stage design, lighting, dramatic styles.

THTR-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
THTR-300O.description: Coursework taken off campus; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

THTR-302.title: Shakespeare in His World
THTR-302.description: The plays and theatre of Shakespeare, the influences on his work and his contemporary world. Recommended preparation: THTR 201, THTR 310, THTR 311

THTR-305A.title: Directing
THTR-305A.description: Examination of basic directorial principles. Pre-production analysis and rehearsal procedures; relationship of the director to actor; integration of technical aspects of production.

THTR-305B.title: Directing
THTR-305B.description: Examination of basic directorial principles. Pre-production analysis and rehearsal procedures; relationship of the director to actor; integration of technical aspects of production.

synonyms: Theory and Practice of World Theatre II
THTR-311.title: Theory and Practice of World Theatre II
THTR-311.description: A multicultural and transnational examination of the history, theory, and practice of theatre from the Renaissance to the 19th century. Recommended preparation: THTR 201, THTR 310

THTR-314.title: Advanced Topics in Modern Drama
THTR-314.description: 20th century realism and the avant-garde. Recommended preparation: THTR 201, THTR 310, THTR 311

THTR-315B.title: Physical Theatre I
THTR-315B.description: Actor training anchored by rigorous physical movements. Activities include comedy, clowning, juggling, and mask work. Open to BFA acting majors only.

THTR-316.title: Advanced Movement for Actors
THTR-316.description: Advanced physical training and practice for the BA actor utilizing various movement techniques through improvisation.

THTR-320B.title: Intermediate Acting II
THTR-320B.description: Further development of range and breadth of performance skills with emphasis on texts of heightened language and style. Open to BFA acting majors only.

THTR-332.title: Lighting Design I
THTR-332.description: Historical styles, methods and dramatic analysis in lighting design as applied in contemporary practice.

THTR-340B.title: Intermediate Voice
THTR-340B.description: Extended development of vocal freedom and range, acquisition of articulate speech. Enhancement of vocal power and resonance, techniques for performing with a dialect. Open to BFA acting majors only.

THTR-341.title: Voice for the Non-Theatre Major
THTR-341.description: Designed for the non-theatre major focusing on the range, color, texture, and projection of the human voice in a variety of situations. Not available for credit to theatre majors.

THTR-342A.title: Basic Voice
THTR-342A.description: a: Examination of the individual voice centering on resonance, tone, flexibility, and support through dramatic selections for transmitting meaning and emotion of character.

THTR-342B.title: Basic Voice
THTR-342B.description: Examination of the individual voice centering on resonance, tone, flexibility, and support through dramatic selections for transmitting meaning and emotion of character. Continuation of 342a.

THTR-343.title: Musical Theatre Audition
THTR-343.description: Designed to give students confidence and integrity for auditions in musical theatre. Choosing appropriate material and preparation for the audition and performance. Audition required.

THTR-352A.title: Intermediate Acting II
THTR-352A.description: a: Building and sustaining character in drama.

THTR-352B.title: Intermediate Acting II
THTR-352B.description: Continuation of world drama. Class performance and critique.

THTR-354.title: Acting Shakespeare
THTR-354.description: Basic approach to the acting and analysis of the highly formalized texts of William Shakespeare. Recommended preparation: THTR 252b.

THTR-365.title: Playwriting I
THTR-365.description: Essential elements of playwriting through weekly assignments, students' initiative, occasional productions of scenes, and extensive classroom analysis.

THTR-366.title: Playwriting II
THTR-366.description: Continuation of the work begun in 365.

THTR-380.title: Historical Approaches to Dance
THTR-380.description: Roles of dance in pre- technological societies; development of classic and romantic ballet from medieval, baroque, and renaissance periods to contemporary forms.

THTR-390.title: Special Problems
THTR-390.description: Supervised, individual studies. No more than one registration permitted. Enrollment by petition only.

THTR-395.title: Drama as Human Relations
THTR-395.description: A focus on American ethnic and multicultural diversity from the perspectives of gender, race, and myth as revealed in plays, film, and other performance media.

THTR-396.title: God, Drama and Entertainment
THTR-396.description: An exploration of money, power, sex, and love in relation to secular and spirtual values represented by contemporary theatre media.

THTR-397.title: Theatre Practicum
THTR-397.description: Substantive participation in a production sponsored by the School and supervised by the faculty.

synonyms: Drawing and Rendering for the Theater
THTR-407B.title: Drawing and Rendering for the Theater
THTR-407B.description: Drawing and rendering techniques appropriate for theater designers. Drawing and drawing theory.

THTR-408A.title: Dialects
THTR-408A.description: The study of standard American stage dialect using the international phonetic alphabet.

THTR-408B.title: Dialects
THTR-408B.description: The study of accents and regional dialects.

THTR-415B.title: Physical Theatre II
THTR-415B.description: Advanced physical acting focusing on principles of verbal/non-verbal improvisation and communication. Elements of textual analysis, including development of character mask and of the ensemble. Open to BFA acting majors only.

THTR-420B.title: Advanced Acting
THTR-420B.description: Contemporary material from plays and screenplays with an emphasis on individual challenges and problems. Open to BFA acting majors only.

THTR-430.title: Stage Management II
THTR-430.description: Application of stage management procedures required in the professional theatre.

THTR-432B.title: Scene Design II
THTR-432B.description: Continuation of THTR 330. Evolution of scene design through analysis of script, environmental factors, and styles.

THTR-433B.title: Costume Design II
THTR-433B.description: Evolution of costume design through analysis of script, environmental factors, and styles.

THTR-434B.title: Lighting Design II
THTR-434B.description: Continuation of THTR 332. Evolution of lighting design through analysis of script, environmental factors, and styles.

THTR-435.title: Advanced Theatrical Drafting
THTR-435.description: Drafting style and complex graphic communication. Emphasis on creating professional plates, developing an individual style and graphic problem solving.

THTR-437.title: Scene Painting
THTR-437.description: Techniques, materials, and equipment of the scenic artist including both historic and modern methods. Recommended preparation: paint and drawing experience

THTR-438.title: Technical Theatre
THTR-438.description: Theory and practice of technical theatre. Emphasis is on technical problem solving and graphic solutions to technical theatre.

THTR-439.title: Stage Properties
THTR-439.description: Organization, management, and construction of properties for the theatre.

THTR-440B.title: Advanced Voice
THTR-440B.description: Continuation of exercises related to the individual student for the stage. Open to BFA students only.

THTR-441.title: Advanced Sound Design
THTR-441.description: Advanced exploration of theatrical sound design theory and related technology; creative uses of music, sound effects, and audio equipment in modern theaters.

THTR-452B.title: Advanced Acting
THTR-452B.description: Intensive investigation and performance of audition techniques. Scene study skills developed including cold readings, first readings, rehearsal procedure, performance process, camera/taping.

THTR-458.title: Visiting Artist Workshop
THTR-458.description: A workshop course taught by the visiting artist holding the George Burns chair. Course topics will be determined by the instructor.

THTR-471.title: Senior Showcase
THTR-471.description: Designed to provide the graduating students with an opportunity to select, prepare and perform for agents, directors and producers in film, television and theatre. Audition required. Open to theatre majors only.

synonyms: Acting on Camera: The Collaborative Process
THTR-475.title: Acting on Camera: The Collaborative Process
THTR-475.description: In this course acting students will learn to develop on-camera acting skills and to collaborate with student directors and cinematographers from the School of Cinematic Arts. Recommended preparation: a 300-level acting course.

THTR-476.title: African American Theatre
THTR-476.description: Issues of race and social class of African Americans in the United States as it examines stage works written by and/or about African Americans.

THTR-478B.title: Theatre for Youth
THTR-478B.description: Continuation of (a), bringing developed pieces into production for regional K-12.

THTR-479.title: Solo Performance
THTR-479.description: A writing-performance workshop in which students write, develop, and rehearse original, autobiographical and character monologues and perform them at the end of the semester.

THTR-480.title: Performance for Camera
THTR-480.description: Structured to address the dynamics of acting in relation to film/television. Refining the students' understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film. Audition required.

THTR-482.title: Choreography for Television
THTR-482.description: Creative choreography of theatrical dance for television. Emphasis on rhythmic analysis, versatility, composition, notation techniques, stylizing, and composition.

THTR-483.title: Dance Performance
THTR-483.description: Preparation, rehearsal, and performance of experimental choreography in main stage repertory.

THTR-484.title: Acting in Television Commercials
THTR-484.description: An on-camera, workshop-style introduction to techniques, perspectives and theories unique to performing in television commercials. Recommended preparation: a 300-level acting or voice class

THTR-485.title: Advanced Solo Performance
THTR-485.description: An advanced writing and performance workshop. Students will write and rehearse an extended personal monologue to be presented at the end of the semester.

THTR-488.title: Theatre in the Community
THTR-488.description: Research and actively develop the theory of theatre as a moving political, social, economic and spiritual force of change within the local community.

THTR-489.title: Theatre Internship
THTR-489.description: Practical experience in the entertainment industry.

THTR-490.title: Directed Research
THTR-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

THTR-492.title: Producing Theatre
THTR-492.description: Analysis of all procedures involved in producing theatre (commercial or non-profit) including legal and business guidelines and contracts.

THTR-493B.title: Periods and Styles
THTR-493B.description: A survey of the influence of historical and cultural events on the evaluation of theatrical styles. Restoration to 20th century.

THTR-494.title: Raising Money for the Arts
THTR-494.description: Overview of fundraising techniques for non-profit theatre including grantsmanship, board development, direct mail soliciting, and money raising activities and events.

THTR-497.title: Advanced Theatre Practicum
THTR-497.description: Intensive participation in a production sponsored by the school and supervised by the faculty, to increase and develop artistic growth.

THTR-499.title: Special Topics
THTR-499.description: Studies in selected areas of theatre art. Intensive practice in role and script interpretation and its psychological relationship to the audience.

synonyms: Seminar in History of the Theatre
THTR-513.title: Seminar in History of the Theatre
THTR-513.description: Bibliography, historical evolution, patterns, and techniques of the theatre from primitive to modern times.

THTR-515B.title: Advanced Movement
THTR-515B.description: Advanced exercises in movement for the use of the body in relation to the stage.

THTR-520B.title: Advanced Acting
THTR-520B.description: Advanced training in acting skills; emphasis upon individual needs.

THTR-525.title: Seminar in Contemporary Theatre
THTR-525.description: Analysis of trends, problems, and the work of major figures in the contemporary theatre.

THTR-529B.title: Textual Studies for Performance
THTR-529B.description: Close textual reading of dramatic texts as a fundamental tool for rehearsal and performance.

THTR-540B.title: Advanced Voice Diction
THTR-540B.description: Individual work in improving the actor's vocal range.

THTR-567B.title: Studies in Playwriting
THTR-567B.description: Continued extensive examination of playwriting, dramaturgy, development, and readings of work toward the completion of professionally promising plays.

THTR-590.title: Directed Research
THTR-590.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

THTR-593.title: M.F.A. Project
THTR-593.description: Credit awarded upon completion of project. Graded CR/NC.

THTR-595B.title: Graduate Playwrights' Workshop
THTR-595B.description: Continued development of thesis plays in a simulated professional development workshop process utilizing dramaturgy and involvement of student actors/directors. Culminates in staged readings.

THTR-597.title: Theatre Practicum
THTR-597.description: Substantive participation in productions sponsored by the school and supervised by the faculty.

GEOL-105.title: Planet Earth
GEOL-105.description: Geologic structure and evolution of planet earth. Principles of plate tectonics, rocks and minerals, processes of mountain building, continent and ocean formation, earthquakes, volcanism, development of landforms by running water and glaciers. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day or two-day field trip required.

GEOL-107.title: Oceanography
GEOL-107.description: Physical, chemical, and geological character of the oceans and ocean basins. Origin of the oceans. Ocean processes and agents. Economic value of the oceans. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day field trip required. Not available for major credit to earth or geological sciences majors.

GEOL-108.title: Crises of a Planet
GEOL-108.description: Impact of civilization on planet earth, and impact of earth's natural evolution on society: earthquakes, volcanism, landslides, floods, global warming, acid rain, groundwater depletion and pollution; mineral and fossil fuel depletion, formation of the ozone hole. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day or overnight field trip.

GEOL-130.title: The Nature of Scientific Inquiry
GEOL-130.description: Examination of the scientific process: what constitutes science; evolution of ideas about the nature of space, time, matter, and complexity; paradigm shifts in the biological and earth sciences. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. Not available for major credit to earth or geological sciences majors.

GEOL-150.title: Climate Change
GEOL-150.description: Climate systems from the beginning of earth history to the present; tools and techniques used to reconstruct prehistoric climate records; effects of climate variations on development of life forms on earth. Not available for major credit to earth or geological sciences majors.

GEOL-240.title: Earthquakes
GEOL-240.description: Causes of earthquakes and nature of large faults; earthquake hazard and risk; world's great earthquakes; understanding the Richter scale. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours; one field trip required. Not available for major credit to earth and geological sciences majors.

GEOL-290.title: Special Laboratory
GEOL-290.description: Laboratory component for GEOL 105Lg, 107Lxg, 108Lg, 125Lxg, 130Lxg, 150Lxg, or 240Lxg for students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

GEOL-305.title: Introduction to Engineering Geology
GEOL-305.description: Principles of geology with emphasis on stratigraphy, structural geology, and degradational processes; basic geologic considerations in civil engineering practice; introduction to mineralogy and petrology. Field trip required. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 3 hours. Not available for major credit to geological science majors.

GEOL-316.title: Petrologic Systems
GEOL-316.description: Formation and identification of igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks; interpretation of tectonic and environmental settings based on rock type and chemistry. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 6 hours; required field trips. (Duplicates credit in former GEOL 215abL.)

GEOL-440.title: Geophysics and Geoengineering
GEOL-440.description: Plate tectonics, magnetic and gravity fields, earthquakes, seismic waves, reflection and regraction seismics, heat transport, mantle convection, deep Earth structure, data analysis. Includes field trip.

GEOL-470.title: Environmental Hydrogeology
GEOL-470.description: Concepts in hydrogeology and their application to environmental problems. Topics include groundwater chemistry and hydrology, contaminants and their behavior. Guest lectures on regulations and remediation techniques. Recommended Preparation: 460L.

GEOL-483.title: Geobiology and Astrobiology
GEOL-483.description: Relationships between microbiota and the earth environment including the hydrosphere, lithosphere and atmosphere, with consideration of the potential for life on other planets.

GEOL-490.title: Directed Research
GEOL-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

GEOL-494.title: Senior Thesis
GEOL-494.description: Writing of a thesis under individual faculty supervision. Not available for graduate credit.

GEOL-499.title: Special Topics
GEOL-499.description: Special topics in the earth sciences. Field trip required when appropriate to the topic. Departmental approval required.

GEOL-511.title: Depositional Systems
GEOL-511.description: Analysis of depositional systems, including conceptual methods of lithostratigraphy, biostratigraphy, chronostratigraphy, and paleoecology; description of major depositional environments. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

GEOL-534.title: Mechanics of Lithospheric Deformation
GEOL-534.description: The mechanical description of deformational processes at both crustal and lithospheric scales, and the interpretation of geological and geophysical data in terms of these processes.

GEOL-535.title: Microstructures and Deformation Mechanisms
GEOL-535.description: Examination of deformation mechanisms and resulting microstructures in rocks; chemical and textural equilibrium; physical and chemical processes during fluid flow; porphyroblast-matrix relationships; interpretation of kinematic indicators. Laboratory.

GEOL-552.title: Advanced Seismology
GEOL-552.description: Advanced methods of theoretical seismology for studying the generation of seismic waves from natural and artificial sources and the propagation through realistic earth models.

GEOL-555.title: Paleoceanography
GEOL-555.description: Mesozoic and Cenozoic paleoceanography; analytical approaches applied to water mass history, paleocirculation, paleoproductivity, nutrient cycling, and paleotemperature reconstruction. Lecture, readings, and research project. Recommended preparation: GEOL 412 or GEOL 512 and GEOL 460L.

GEOL-556.title: Active Tectonics
GEOL-556.description: Aspects of deformation and associated seismicity at active plate margins around the world. Includes review of plate tectonics, seismology, geodesy, paleomagnetism, geodynamics, Quaternary dating techniques, tectonic geomorphology, paleoseismology, and seismic hazard assessment. Two weekend field trips required. Recommended preparation: GEOL 530, GEOL 531

GEOL-590.title: Directed Research
GEOL-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GEOL-601.title: Seminar in Sedimentary Geology
GEOL-601.description: Analysis and discussion of current topics in sedimentary geology; topics will be chosen by students and faculty to focus on areas of recent advances.

GEOL-609.title: Seminar in Earthquake Physics
GEOL-609.description: Current research on the physics governing earthquakes and faults, including results from continuum and fracture mechanics, statistical physics, lab experiments, and seismological observations.

GEOL-790.title: Research
GEOL-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EASC-150.title: East Asian Societies
EASC-150.description: Main patterns of change in modern China, Japan, and Korea; historical framework and the insights of geography, economics, political science, and other disciplines.

EASC-590.title: Directed Research
EASC-590.description: Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EASC-594A.title: Master's Thesis
EASC-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

EASC-594B.title: Master's Thesis
EASC-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

EASC-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
EASC-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ECON-203.title: Principles of Microeconomics
ECON-203.description: Behavior of firms and consumers, functions of the price system, competition and monopoly, labor markets, poverty, government regulation, international trade, and the environment.

ECON-205.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECON-205.description: Unemployment, inflation and output determination and links. Effects of government taxation and spending on growth, investment, saving, consumption, and trade.

ECON-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
ECON-300O.description: Off-campus studies course; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

ECON-303.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory
ECON-303.description: Decision making by business firms, consumer preferences and behavior, uncertainty, competition, monopoly, labor and resource markets, efficient resource allocation, externalities, and government policy.

ECON-305.title: Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory
ECON-305.prereq_text: (ECON-203 and ECON-205) and 1 from (MATH-118 or MATH-125)
ECON-305.description: The determinants of aggregate income, employment, and inflation; economic fluctuations; fiscal and monetary policy; financial markets; the national debt.

ECON-317.title: Introduction to Statistics for Economists
ECON-317.description: Introduction to statistical methods appropriate for analyzing economic data: probability theory, random variables and probability distributions, sampling, estimation, statistical inference.

ECON-330.title: The Political Economy of Institutions
ECON-330.description: Social functions served by the rules, laws, regulations, and customs that constrain human activity. Processes whereby such institutions adapt, or fail to adapt, to changing circumstances.

ECON-344.title: Economic Development of Sub-Saharan Africa
ECON-344.description: Contemporary economic problems of sub-Saharan economies: policies and endowments. Focus on issues of poverty, agriculture, health, macroeconomy and political economy.

ECON-357.title: Money, Credit, and Banking
ECON-357.description: The money, bond, stock, and other financial markets; portfolio choice; determinants of asset prices and interest rates; inflation; interactions between financial markets and government policies.

ECON-360.title: Public Finance
ECON-360.description: Role of the government; income and corporate taxation; direct versus indirect taxation; optimal tax structure; public goods; public sector pricing; public debt and macroeconomic stability.

ECON-366.title: Urban Economics
ECON-366.description: Urban trends and problems, including changing urban form and function, urban public finance, housing, renewal, poverty, race, transportation, and the environment.

ECON-404.title: Games and Economics
ECON-404.description: Analysis of strategic economic interactions. Topics include bargaining, insurance, patents, voting, environment depletion, strategic trade, learning, reputation, strikes, corporate takeovers, and the provision of public goods.

ECON-414.title: Introduction to Econometrics
ECON-414.description: Application of statistical methods to economic data: estimating economic relationships using regression analysis, testing hypotheses involving economic behavior, forecasting economic variables.

ECON-451.title: The Politics of International Trade
ECON-451.description: Economic approaches and political processes are used to explain observed international trade policy choices. Topics covered include globalization, regionalism, labor standards, the environment and sanctions. Recommended preparation: ECON 450, IR 330

ECON-452.title: International Finance
ECON-452.description: Consequences of trade deficits; theories of capital and currency markets, exchange rate regimes, and international monetary coordination.

ECON-457.title: Financial Markets
ECON-457.description: General equilibrium analysis of economics with financial markets; decision making under uncertainty; methods of risk reduction; portfolio theory and valuation of securities; efficiency of security markets.

synonyms: Economics of Labor Markets and Human Capital
ECON-471.title: Economics of Labor Markets and Human Capital
ECON-471.description: A human capital interpretation of labor demand and supply; wage determination, differentials, and discrimination; job turnover and occupational mobility; unions and collective bargaining.

ECON-472.title: Economics of Medical Care
ECON-472.description: Health as an investment in human capital; analysis of the demand for and supply of health services and manpower; health insurance; cost-effectiveness analysis; market structures and the pricing of medical services.

ECON-487.title: Resource and Environmental Economics
ECON-487.description: Management and extraction of renewable and non-renewable natural resources; environmental externalities and regulation of air, water, and land pollution; market incentives versus direct regulation.

ECON-490.title: Directed Research
ECON-490.description: Supervised individual research. Not available for graduate credit. Requires departmental approval.

ECON-495.title: Honors Thesis
ECON-495.description: Individual research supervised by a faculty advisor. Successful completion required for departmental honors degree.

ECON-501.title: Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
ECON-501.description: Theories of aggregate economic activity; design and use of macroeconometric models; stabilization and control of inflation, unemployment, and growth.

ECON-511.title: Econometric Methods
ECON-511.description: Review of statistical methods of estimation and inference, linear regression with multicollinearity and serial correlation; multivariate regression and simultaneous equations.

ECON-523.title: Economic History and Development
ECON-523.description: Historical trends in developed and developing societies in various aspects of modernization such as human resources, capital, technology, resource allocation, income distribution, international relations.

ECON-541.title: Economic Development
ECON-541.description: Development, underdevelopment and the problems thereof; agriculture, industry, trade, population, human capital, capital formation; structural, technological, environmental and institutional changes; political economy of the state.

ECON-590.title: Directed Research
ECON-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ECON-594A.title: Master's Thesis
ECON-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

ECON-594B.title: Master's Thesis
ECON-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

ECON-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
ECON-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

ECON-599.title: Special Topics
ECON-599.description: Selected topics in economics as developed by the instructor.

ECON-600.title: Economies of Choice
ECON-600.description: This course reviews the normative and positive theories of choice drawing upon recent theoretical and empirical work in cognitive and evolutionary psychology, artificial intelligence, linguistics and economics.

ECON-603.title: Microeconomic Theory II
ECON-603.description: General equilibrium theory; existence, uniqueness, and stability; welfare economics; social choice; dynamic models and uncertainty; special topics.

ECON-604.title: Game Theory
ECON-604.description: Strategies and equilibrium concepts; dynamic and repeated games; incomplete information and learning in games.

ECON-605.title: Macroeconomic Theory II
ECON-605.description: Macroeconomic theory based on the concepts of optimal growth and intertemporal equilibrium; overlapping generations models; recent developments in macroeconomic theory.

ECON-615.title: Applied Econometrics
ECON-615.description: Use of quantitative models to describe and forecast economic activity; estimation and application of such models to selected policy problems.

ECON-634.title: Political Economy of Institutions
ECON-634.description: The functions of laws, rules, customs, conventions, and other restrictions on economic and social activity. Theories of institutional evolution.

ECON-641.title: Empirical Analysis of Economic Development
ECON-641.description: Theory and empirics of the sources of and barriers to economic development and the micro underpinnings of macroeconomic dynamics of growth, inequality, and productivity.

ECON-651.title: International Monetary Theory
ECON-651.description: Balance of payments concepts and measures; price theory and the foreign exchange market; international monetary systems; adjustment mechanisms; speculation and official intervention.

ECON-652.title: Economics of Financial Markets II
ECON-652.description: Financial market equilibrium and partial equilibrium asset pricing in discrete and continuous time; properties of equilibria with and without complete markets: theory of option prices: Black-Scholes pricing formula; term structure of interest rates; hedging strategies and managing market risk using options, futures and swaps; hedging exhange-rates risks.

ECON-673.title: Program Evaluation
ECON-673.description: This course first proposes various means of evaluating an economic program. It then applies the tools to specific problems.

ECON-690.title: Seminar in Economic Theory
ECON-690.description: Current research in economic theory presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON-691.title: Seminar in Econometrics
ECON-691.description: Current research in econometrics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON-692.title: Seminar in Economic Development
ECON-692.description: Current research in international, regional, and urban development economics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

ECON-694.title: Seminar in Dynamic Economics
ECON-694.description: Topics in dynamic economics involving business fluctuations, economic growth and development, microeconomic adjustments and market mechanisms; related quantitative and qualitative methods; empirical research involving economic change. Graded CR/NC.

ECON-790.title: Research
ECON-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ECON-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation

AME-150.title: Introduction to Computational Methods
AME-150.description: Computer programming; organization of problems for computational solution; introduction to software for computation and graphics; application to engineering problems.

AME-201.title: Statics
AME-201.description: Analysis of forces acting on particles and rigid bodies in static equilibrium; equivalent systems of forces, friction, centroids and moments of inertia; introduction to energy methods. Recommended preparation: AME 101, PHYS 151L

AME-204.title: Strength of Materials
AME-204.description: Stress, strain and deflection of mechanical elements due to tension, shear, bending, or torsion; combined loads; energy methods, statically indeterminate structures; strength-based design.

AME-261.title: Basic Flight Mechanics
AME-261.description: Performance of flight vehicles; maximum speed, rate-of-climb, range, and endurance; basic stability and control, weight, and balance; computer exercises. Recommended preparation: AME 150L

AME-291.title: Undergraduate Design Projects I
AME-291.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended for entry in local and national design competitions. Intended for lower division students or those with little prior project experience. Graded CR/NC.

AME-301.title: Dynamics
AME-301.description: 2- and 3-D kinematics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies; systems of particles and rigid bodies; coupled rigid bodies; introduction to vibrations. Recommended preparation: PHYS 151L

AME-302.title: Dynamic Systems
AME-302.description: Modeling of lumped parameter elements and systems; free and forced response of first and second order systems; design oriented approach to dynamic systems.

AME-308.title: Computer-Aided Analyses for Aero-Mechanical Design
AME-308.description: Introduction to the finite element method; practical application of computer analysis tools for structural analyses and design.

AME-309.title: Dynamics of Fluids
AME-309.description: Fluids statics; conservation of mass, momentum, and energy in integral and differential form; applications. Laminar and turbulent pipe flow; compressible flow; potential flow over bodies. Recommended preparation: AME 205 and AME 310

AME-310.title: Engineering Thermodynamics I
AME-310.description: Fundamental laws of thermodynamics applied to actual and perfect gases and vapors; energy concepts, processes, and applications. Recommended preparation: PHYS 151L, high-level programming language

AME-331.title: Heat Transfer
AME-331.description: General principles underlying heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation; steady flow and transient flow.

AME-341B.title: Mechoptronics Laboratory
AME-341B.description: A coordinated laboratory and lecture sequence on aeromechanical instrumentation and device control stressing the symbolic integration of mechanical, optical and electronic components.

AME-403.title: Stress Analysis
AME-403.description: Theories of failure, shear center, unsymmetrical bending, curved beams, torsion of non-circular sections; cylinders, rotating discs, thermal stresses, inelastic strains, energy methods.

AME-409.title: Senior Design Project
AME-409.description: Modelling, analysis, integration, layout and performance analysis of a mechanical system to meet the specified design requirements.

AME-420.title: Engineering Vibrations I
AME-420.description: Theory of free and forced vibrations with and without damping; systems of single and multiple degrees of freedom; iteration; methods; vibration isolation; instrumentation.

AME-423.title: Loudspeaker and Sound-System Design
AME-423.description: Project-based design of loudspeaker transducers, filters, and enclosures. Measurement of transfer functions, acoustical performance, distortion, Thiele-Small parameters, and power handling. Listening evaluations. Recommended preparation: EE 330

AME-436.title: Energy and Propulsion
AME-436.description: Performance and analysis of reciprocating, jet, rocket engines, and hybrid systems. Characteristics of inlets, compressors, combustors, turbines, nozzles and engine systems. Energy and environmental problems.

AME-441B.title: Senior Projects Laboratory
AME-441B.description: Individual engineering projects designed and constructed to model and test a physical principle or system.

AME-455.title: Introduction to MEMS
AME-455.description: Introduction to micro-electro-opto-mechanical systems; scaling effects on material properties, fluid flows, dynamical behavior; fabrication methods; design considerations for MEMS sensors and actuators. Recommended preparation: AME 301, AME 309 and AME 310

AME-458.title: Theory of Structures II
AME-458.prereq_text: 1 from ((CE-108 and CE-358) or (AME-150 and AME-353))
AME-458.description: Matrix algebra; stiffness method; force method; computer analysis of planar structures.

AME-459.title: Flight Mechanics
AME-459.description: Applications of basic aerodynamics to aircraft and missile performance, power and thrust, stability and control, compressibility effects.

AME-460.title: Aerodynamic Theory
AME-460.description: Basic relations describing the inviscid flow field about bodies and wings moving at subsonic and supersonic speeds.

AME-464.title: Petroleum Reservoir Engineering
AME-464.description: Properties of reservoir fluids, volumetric and material balances for gas and oil reservoirs; reservoir modeling concepts. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory 3 hours.

AME-481.title: Aircraft Design
AME-481.description: Aircraft design and analysis, design requirements and specifications; integration of structure, propulsion, control system, and aerodynamic configuration; performance analysis and prediction. Recommended Preparation: AME 205

AME-490.title: Directed Research
AME-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

AME-491.title: Undergraduate Design Projects II
AME-491.description: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended for entry in local and national design competitions. Intended for students with prior project experience. Upper division standing. Graded CR/NC.

AME-499.title: Special Topics
AME-499.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in mechanical engineering and related fields.

AME-505.title: Engineering Information Modeling
AME-505.description: Symbolic and object-oriented modeling, product and process modeling for design and manufacturing, information models for computer integrated and collaborative engineering, information modeling for life-cycle engineering.

AME-509.title: Applied Elasticity
AME-509.description: Condensed treatment dealing with engineering applications of the principles of elasticity, using the theories of elasticity, elastic stability, and plates and shells.

AME-511.title: Compressible Gas Dynamics
AME-511.description: Thermodynamics, kinetic theory, compressible flow equations, shock and expansion waves, similarity, shock-expansion techniques and linearized flow applied to bodies, characteristics, theory of boundary layers.

AME-513.title: Principles of Combustion
AME-513.description: Thermochemistry, equilibrium, chemical kinetics, flame temperature, flame velocity, flame stability, diffusion flames spray combustion, detonation. Equations of motion including reaction, heat transfer, and diffusion.

AME-515.title: Advanced Problems in Heat Conduction
AME-515.description: Review of analytical methods in heat conduction; moving boundaries melting and freezing; sources and sinks, anisotropic and composite media; numerical methods for steady and unsteady problems. Recommended preparation: AME 331, AME 526.

AME-525.title: Engineering Analysis
AME-525.description: Typical engineering problems discussed on a physical basis. Vector analysis; functions of complex variables, infinite series, residues.

AME-526.title: Engineering Analytical Methods
AME-526.description: Typical engineering problems discussed on a physical basis. Fourier series; Fourier integrals; Laplace transform; partial differential equations; Bessle function.

AME-542.title: Theory of Plates
AME-542.description: Theory of plate bending; rectangular and circular plates; anisotropic plates; energy methods; numerical methods; large deformations; sandwich plates.

AME-544.title: Computer Control of Mechanical Systems
AME-544.description: Computer control as applied to machine tools, mechanical manipulators, and other mechanical machinery; discrete time controller design; microprocessor implementation of motion and force control servos.

AME-549.title: Systems Architecting
AME-549.description: Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace, electrical, computer, and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics.

AME-550B.title: Seminar in Aerospace Engineering
AME-550B.description: Recent developments and research in aerospace engineering and related fields. Oral and written reports. Graduate standing is required. Graded CR/NC.

AME-553A.title: Digital Control Systems
AME-553A.description: Design, analysis and implementation of digital control systems using microcomputers; Z-transform methods; frequency domain and state space approach; computational aspects; sampling and quantization.

AME-561.title: Dislocation Theory and Applications
AME-561.description: Elasticity theory; types, sources, motion, interaction of dislocations; stress fields and strain energies; partial dislocations and stacking faults; principles of work-hardening.

AME-588.title: Materials Selection
AME-588.description: Materials selection in relationship to design and fabrication, economic considerations, methodology of selection, performance parameter; case studies.

AME-590.title: Directed Research
AME-590.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

AME-594B.title: Master's Thesis
AME-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

AME-599.title: Special Topics
AME-599.description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of Mechanical Engineering.

AME-690.title: Directed Research
AME-690.description: Laboratory study of specific problems by candidates for the degree of Engineer in Mechanical Engineering. Graded CR/NC.

AME-694A.title: Thesis
AME-694A.description: Required for the degree Engineer in Aerospace Engineering. Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

AME-694B.title: Thesis
AME-694B.description: Required for degree Engineer in Aerospace Engineering. Credit on acceptance of Thesis.

AME-694Z.title: Thesis
AME-694Z.description: Required for the degree Engineer in Aerospace Engineering. Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

AME-790.title: Research
AME-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ASTE-280.title: Astronautics and Space Environment I
ASTE-280.description: Solar system. Two-body problem. Orbits. Hohmann transfer. Rocket equation. Space environment and its effects on space systems. Sun. Solar wind. Geomagnetic field. Atmosphere, ionosphere, magnetosphere.

ASTE-291.title: Team Projects I
ASTE-291.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects. Intended for lower-division students or those with little prior project experience. Departmental approval.

ASTE-301B.title: Thermal and Statistical Systems
ASTE-301B.description: Thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. Kinetics of atoms, molecules, and photons. Compressible fluid dynamics.

ASTE-420.title: Spacecraft Design
ASTE-420.description: Spacecraft mission design, space environment, attitude determination and control, telecommunications, propulsion, structures and mechanisms, thermal control, power systems, launch systems and facilities. Junior or senior standing in engineering or physics.

ASTE-445.title: Molecular Gas Dynamics
ASTE-445.description: Physical description of kinetic nature of gas flows; distribution function; introduction to the Boltzmann equation; free-molecule flow; surface and molecular reflection properties; Monte-Carlo flow calulations. Recommended preparation: AME 309 or ASTE 301b

ASTE-480.title: Spacecraft Dynamics
ASTE-480.description: Two-body motion. Rigid-body motion. Attitude dynamics and maneuvers. Spacecraft stabilization: gravity gradient, reaction wheels, magnetic torques. Thruster attitude control. Senior standing.

ASTE-490.title: Directed Research
ASTE-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ASTE-491.title: Team Projects II
ASTE-491.description: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects. Intended for students with prior project experience. Departmental approval.

ASTE-501B.title: Physical Gas Dynamics
ASTE-501B.description: Kinetic concepts in gas physics; thermal non-equilibrium intermolecular potentials; transport of radiation and particles in high-temperature gas; dissociation and ionization equilibrium; energy relaxation.

ASTE-520.title: Spacecraft System Design
ASTE-520.description: System components; vehicle structure, propulsion systems, flight dynamics, thermal control, power systems, telecommunication. Interfaces and tradeoffs between these components. Testing, system reliability, and integration.

synonyms: Design of Low Cost Space Missions
ASTE-523.title: Design of Low Cost Space Missions
ASTE-523.description: Reviews all aspects of space mission design for practical approaches to reducing cost. Examines "LightSat" mission experience and potential applicability to large scale missions. Graduate standing in engineering or science. Recommended preparation: AME 501 or some experience in space engineering

ASTE-570.title: Liquid Rocket Propulsion
ASTE-570.description: Liquid-propelled rocket propulsion systems. Capillary devices for gas-free liquid acquisition in zero gravity. Ground and in-orbit operations. Propellant life predictions and spacecraft end-of-life de-orbiting strategies.

ASTE-581.title: Orbital Mechanics II
ASTE-581.description: Theory of perturbations of orbits; numerical methods in orbital mechanics; satellite dynamics; averaging methods; resonance; mission analysis.

ASTE-583.title: Space Navigation: Principles and Practice
ASTE-583.description: Statistical orbit determination: (weighted) least squares, batch and sequential (Kalman) processing, illustrative examples; online ephemeris generation: potentially hazardous asteroids, comets, satellites; launch: vehicles, payloads, staging. Graduate standing in engineering or science. Recommended preparation: ASTE 580

ASTE-584.title: Spacecraft Power Systems
ASTE-584.description: Introduction to solar arrays, batteries, nuclear power sources, mechanical energy storage. Application, theory of operation, practical considerations. Subsystem topologies and performance. Design optimization techniques. Graduate standing in engineering or science.

ASTE-590.title: Directed Research
ASTE-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the division. Graded CR/NC.

ASTE-594A.title: Master's Thesis
ASTE-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ASTE-594B.title: Master's Thesis
ASTE-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ASTE-690.title: Directed Research
ASTE-690.description: Laboratory studies of specific problems by candidates for the degree Engineer in Astronautical Engineering. Graded CR/NC.

ASTE-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the division. Graded CR/NC.

ASTE-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ASTE-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation

BME-210.title: Biomedical Computer Simulation Methods
BME-210.description: Computational methods for simulation and analysis of circulatory, respiratory, pharmacokinetic and neural models. Quadrature, differential equations, systems of linear equations, simulation languages, experimental statistics.

BME-302.title: Medical Electronics
BME-302.description: Electronic design and measurements for medical applications. Use of integrated circuits, biopotential measurements, static and dynamic calibration of physiological transducers.

BME-350.title: Biomedical Engineering Industrial Project
BME-350.description: Training in specific skills relevant to biomedical industry. Placement in summer internship following successful completion of the course. Junior standing. Recommended preparation: BME 210

synonyms: Control and Communication in the Nervous System
BME-402.title: Control and Communication in the Nervous System
BME-402.prereq_text: 1 from (BISC-110 or BISC-220) and (MATH-245 and BME-210)
BME-402.description: An introduction to the structural and functional elements common to nervous systems, with emphasis on cellular dynamics, interneuronal communication, sensory and effector systems.

BME-405.title: Senior Projects: Measurements and Instrumentation
BME-405.description: Application of instrumentation and measurement techniques to biomedical engineering projects involving measurement, replacement or augmentation of biomedical systems.

BME-412.title: Fundamentals of Craniofacial Biotechnology
BME-412.description: Biomedical engineering and technology applied to oral health professions. Dental biomaterials, CAD-CAM, digital dental technology and tissue engineering applications to craniofacial diseases, disorders and enhancements.

BME-414.title: Rehabilitation Engineering
BME-414.description: An introduction to rehabilitation technology: limb and spinal orthoses; limb prostheses; functional electrical stimulation; sensory aids. Recommended preparation: ME 201 or ME 203

synonyms: Development and Regulation of Medical Products
BME-416.title: Development and Regulation of Medical Products
BME-416.description: An introduction to the process of medical product development with emphasis on the regulations that govern the design, fabrication, and maintenance of medical products. Junior standing. Departmental approval required.

BME-489.title: Biochemical Engineering
BME-489.description: Application of chemical engineering principles to biological and biochemical processes and materials. Design of biochemical reactors and of processes for separation and purifications of biological products.

BME-490.title: Directed Research
BME-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

BME-501.title: Advanced Topics in Biomedical Systems
BME-501.description: Advanced topics in selected biomedical systems: cardiopulmonary, neuromuscular, renal and endocrine. Duplicates credit in BME 503ab.

BME-505B.title: Laboratory Projects in Biomedical Engineering
BME-505B.description: Integration of biomedical science, engineering principles and state-of-the-art technology for the study of selected physiological systems in the laboratory setting. Laboratory. (Duplicates credit in former BME 605abL.)

BME-511.title: Physiological Control Systems
BME-511.description: Application of control theory to physiological systems; static analysis of closed-loop systems; time-domain analysis of linear control system identification methods; nonlinear control.

BME-513.title: Signal and Systems Analysis
BME-513.description: Classification; representation; statistical analysis; orthogonal expansions; least-squares estimation; harmonic analysis; Fourier, Laplace, and Z transforms; the linear system; filtering; modeling and simulation; linear control theory.

BME-525.title: Advanced Biomedical Imaging
BME-525.description: Advanced scientific and engineering principles of biomedical imaging including magnetic resonance, X-ray computed tomography, single photon and positron emission tomography, magnetoencephalography and electroencephalography.

synonyms: Medical Diagnostics, Therapeutics and Informatics Applications
BME-528.title: Medical Diagnostics, Therapeutics and Informatics Applications
BME-528.description: Picture archive communication system (PACS) design and implementation; clinical PACS-based imaging informatics; telemedicine/teleradiology; image content indexing, image data mining; grid computing in large-scale imaging informatics; image-assisted diagnosis, surgery and therapy.

BME-535.title: Ultrasonic Imaging
BME-535.description: All aspects of ultrasonic imaging including ultrasound and tissue interaction, ultrasonic transducers, instrumentation, imaging methods, clinical applications, bioeffects, safety, and recent developments in the field.

BME-551.title: Introduction to Bio-MEMS and Nanotechnology
BME-551.description: Principles and biomedical applications of micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) and nanotechnology, including microfluidics, nanowire sensors, nanomotors, quantum dots, biofuel cells and molecular imaging. Recommended preparation: Basic Biology and Electronics.

BME-552.title: Neural Implant Engineering
BME-552.description: Advanced studies of the basic neuroscience, engineering design requirements and technological issues associated with implantable neural prostheses, with paticular emphasis on retinal and cortical function.

BME-575.title: Computational Neuroengineering
BME-575.description: Introduction to computational modeling in neuroengineering, anchored in examples of brain fuction. Topics include transduction, synapses, spiking, networks, normalization, learning, Bayesian models, and Kalman filtering.

BME-590.title: Directed Research
BME-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BME-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

BME-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

BME-650.title: Biomedical Measurement and Instrumentation
BME-650.description: Design of measurement systems and biomedical instrumentation; architecture of electronic instruments used to measure physiological parameters; analysis of major process functions integrated in these instruments. Open to M.S., Medical Device and Diagnostic Engineering and biomedical engineering Ph.D students only.

BME-790.title: Research
BME-790.description: Research applicable to the doctorate. Graded CR/NC.

BME-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CHE-120.title: Introduction to Chemical Engineering
CHE-120.description: Problem-solving techniques in chemical engineering using graphics and computers. Mass and heat balances. Corequisite: MATH 125, CHEM 105agL.

CHE-350.title: Introduction to Separation Processes
CHE-350.description: Use of equilibrium phase relations and principles of material and energy balance for design, operation, and optimization of separation procedures such as distillation, absorption, etc. Recommended preparation: CHE 330

CHE-443.title: Viscous Flow
CHE-443.description: Constitutive equations and rate laws, momentum equations and kinetic theory of Newtonian and complex flows. Applications to chemical engineering systems.

CHE-444A.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
CHE-444A.description: Resolution of chemical engineering problems which require original planning, observations, and data. Field trips to chemical plants. Written and oral reports.

synonyms: Mass Transfer in Chemical Engineering Processes
CHE-446.title: Mass Transfer in Chemical Engineering Processes
CHE-446.description: Molecular and continuum approaches to diffusion and convection in fluids and multicomponent mixtures; simultaneous mass, heat, and momentum transfer; steady-state and time-dependent diffusion; Maxwell-Stefan equations.

CHE-460.title: Chemical Process Dynamics and Control
CHE-460.description: Simulation, stability and automatic control of chemical processes. Open and closed loop control schemes and introduction to optimal control theory. Computer implementation and laboratory application.

CHE-464.title: Petroleum Reservoir Engineering
CHE-464.description: Properties of reservoir fluids, volumetric and material balances for gas and oil reservoirs; reservoir modeling concepts. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory 3 hours.

CHE-476.title: Chemical Engineering Materials
CHE-476.description: Chemical and physical properties of solid materials used by chemical engineers, including polymers, metals, and ceramics. Materials design for industrial applications.

CHE-480.title: Chemical Process and Plant Design
CHE-480.description: Applications of unit operations, thermodynamics, kinetics, and economic balance; energy conservation in heat exchanger networks and in sequencing of separational devices. Safety aspects.

CHE-489.title: Biochemical Engineering
CHE-489.description: Application of chemical engineering principles to biological and biochemical processes and materials. Design of biochemical reactors and of processes for separation and purifications of biological products.

CHE-490.title: Directed Research
CHE-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CHE-491.title: Nanotechnology Research for Undergraduates
CHE-491.description: Independent research in nanotechnology. Research project selected by the student in close consultation with a research advisor.

CHE-513.title: Principles of Combustion
CHE-513.description: Thermochemistry, equilibrium, chemical kinetics, flame temperature, flame velocity, flame stability, diffusion flames spray combustion, detonation. Equations of motion including reaction, heat transfer, and diffusion.

CHE-523.title: Principles of Electrochemical Engineering
CHE-523.description: Electrochemical techniques; mass, charge, and heat transfer; electrochemical thermodynamics and electrode kinetics; electrochemical reactors; optimization; materials and corrosion; experimental modeling of industrial processes.

CHE-530.title: Thermodynamics for Chemical Engineers
CHE-530.description: Application of thermodynamics to chemical engineering systems. Recommended preparation: 430

CHE-540.title: Viscous Flow
CHE-540.description: Fluid mechanical problem of interest to chemical engineers involving laminar flows of incompressible fluids, viscous-dominated creeping flows, and motion of bubbles and drops.

CHE-542.title: Chemical Engineering Kinetics
CHE-542.description: Reaction kinetics applied to problems of engineering design and operation. Recommended preparation: 442

CHE-544.title: Heat Transmission
CHE-544.description: Principles of conduction, radiation, and convection of heat; application to chemical and related industries. Recommended preparation: 430, 445

CHE-550A.title: Seminars in Chemical Engineering
CHE-550A.description: Seminars to cover recent developments in the field of chemical engineering given by invited speakers. Master's students must register for 2 semesters; Ph.D. students must register for 4 semesters. Graded IP/CR/NC. Recommended preparation: graduate standing

CHE-550B.title: Seminars in Chemical Engineering
CHE-550B.description: Seminars to cover recent developments in the field of chemical engineering given by invited speakers. Master's students must register for 2 semesters; Ph.D. students must register for 4 semesters. Graded IP/CR/NC. Recommended preparation: graduate standing

CHE-596.title: Chemical Reactions in the Atmosphere
CHE-596.description: Chemical reactions and scavenging processes improtant in urban air pollution. Effects of solar irradiation on vehicle exhaust gases, oxides of nitrogen and sulfur.

CHE-690.description: Laboratory study of specific problems by candidates for the degree Engineer in Chemical Engineering. Graded CR/NC.

CHE-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CE-107.title: Introduction to Civil Engineering Graphics
CE-107.description: Graphic communication and drawing; use of instruments, lettering, dimensioning, and detailing of engineering drawing; free-hand sketching, drafting, and modeling.

synonyms: Introduction to Computer Methods in Civil Engineering
CE-108.title: Introduction to Computer Methods in Civil Engineering
CE-108.description: Computer programming, organization of problems for computational solution, flow charts, programming; numerical methods, analysis and solution of civil engineering problems.

CE-205.title: Statics
CE-205.description: Statics of particles and rigid bodies; equivalent force systems; distributed forces; applications to trusses, frames, machines, beams, and cables; friction; moments of inertia. Duplicates credit in CE 227 or CE 228.

synonyms: Introduction to Design of Structural Systems
CE-207.title: Introduction to Design of Structural Systems
CE-207.description: Structural materials, components and systems; gravity and lateral forces; structural performance and failures; introduction to structural plans and analysis; computer applications, case studies, design project.

CE-210.title: Introduction to Environmental Engineering Microbiology
CE-210.description: Principles of environmental microbiology; waterborne pathogens; microorganisms and air pollution; microorganisms in soil; water pollution microbiology; bioremediation and biotechnology. Recommended preparation: CE 110

CE-225.title: Mechanics of Deformable Bodies
CE-225.description: Analysis of stress and strain; axial, flexural, and torsional behavior of slender bars; elastic deflections; combined stresses; introduction to elastic stability and energy methods.

CE-325.title: Dynamics
CE-325.description: Elements of vector algebra; dynamics of particles, systems of particles and rigid bodies; kinematics; momentum relations, energy methods; vibrations; Euler's equations of motion.

CE-402.title: Computer Methods in Engineering
CE-402.description: Fundamentals of analog and digital computers; simulation of nonlinear physical systems; numerical analysis and solution of engineering problems.

CE-451.title: Water Resources Engineering
CE-451.description: Discussion of broad perspectives on control and utilization of water, quantitative hydrology, ground water, probability concept, economic study, hydraulic structures, multi-purpose water resources projects.

CE-457.title: Reinforced Concrete Design
CE-457.description: Strength and deformation of reinforced concrete; beams in flexure and shear; bond and development of bars; deflections; columns; slabs; footings; introduction to prestressed concrete.

CE-458.title: Theory of Structures II
CE-458.prereq_text: 1 from ((CE-108 and CE-358) or (AME-150 and AME-353))
CE-458.description: Matrix algebra; stiffness method; force method; computer analysis of planar structures.

CE-459.title: Introduction to Structural Dynamics
CE-459.description: Response of single and multiple degree of freedom systems to dynamic excitation; structural modeling and approximate solutions; introduction to earthquake resistant design.

CE-460.title: Construction Engineering
CE-460.description: Introduction to the construction processes; estimating and bidding, construction administration, planning and scheduling, equipment and methods, labor relations, cost control systems, and safety.

CE-462.title: Construction Methods and Equipment
CE-462.description: Current procedures in selected fields of construction; organization and planning; equipment economics; machinery.

CE-463.title: Water Chemistry and Analysis
CE-463.description: Chemistry of water purification technology and water pollution control. Chemical processes in natural and engineering aquatic environments; physical/chemical and biological characterization of water and wastewater.

CE-466.title: Design of Free-Surface Hydraulic Systems
CE-466.description: Hydrological and hydraulic design for uniform and non-uniform flows, channel transition, sedimentation controls, design discharge for tributary watersheds, flood routing, flood detention, computer aided design.

CE-467.title: Geotechnical Engineering
CE-467.description: Fundamentals of geotechnical engineering; soil classification, seepage, stress-strain behavior, shear strength, consolidation, design of retaining structures and foundations, and slope stability. Soil testing. Duplicates credit in CE 464 and CE 468.

CE-473.title: Engineering Law, Finance and Ethics
CE-473.description: An examination of the legal, financial and ethical issues regularly considered by all practicing engineers. Upper division standing.

CE-480.title: Structural Systems Design
CE-480.prereq_text: 1 from (CE-456 or CE-457 or CE-478) and (CE-358 and CE-467 and CE-473 and CE-482)
CE-480.description: Evaluate, design and analyze buildings. Organize and perform calculations for vertical loads, wind loads, and seismic loads on building projects.

CE-485.title: Wastewater Treatment Design
CE-485.description: Process kinetics, mass balance, reactor design, pretreament, clarification, chemical treatment, biological treatment (aerobic and anaerobic), disinfection, sludge treatment, nitrogen and phosphorus removal, carbon adsorption.

CE-490.title: Directed Research
CE-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CE-503.title: Microbiology for Environmental Engineers
CE-503.description: Basic microbiology of water, air, and soil. Application of microbiology to the practice of environmental pollution control.

CE-510.title: Groundwater Management
CE-510.description: Groundwater hydrology, aquifer testing technology, groundwater quality and contamination, geophysical method, well design and development, basin water balance, computer modeling, legal aspects, groundwater management system.

CE-520B.title: Ocean and Coastal Engineering
CE-520B.description: Linear and nonlinear wave theories with engineering applications; wind waves; wave spectra; wave interactions with marine structures; ship mooring, harbor resonance; sediment transport; diffusion processes. Prerequisite or corequisite: AE 510a.

CE-522.title: Groundwater Hydrologic Modeling
CE-522.description: Simulation of groundwater hydrologic processes through mathematical, analog, and physical models.

CE-523.title: Physical Processes in Environmental Engineering
CE-523.description: Environmental reactor design, coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, adsorption, solid waste management (drying, centrifugation, incineration), membrane processes, advanced water treatment; mathematical modeling of physical processes.

CE-525B.title: Engineering Analysis
CE-525B.description: Typical engineering problems discussed on a physical basis. Setup and solution of problems by means of the existing mathematical tools.

CE-529B.title: Finite Element Analysis
CE-529B.description: Basic concepts; stiffness method; variational methods; displacement method; isoparametric formulation; plane stress and strain; plates and shells; dynamics; stability; nonlinear analysis, heat transfer; computer applications.

CE-533.title: Geotechnical Earthquake Engineering
CE-533.description: This course provides a design-oriented understanding of the "state-of-the-practice" of soil mechanics and foundation engineering aspects of earthquake engineering.

CE-535B.title: Earthquake Engineering
CE-535B.description: Fundamentals of earthquake engineering; characteristics of earthquakes; seismicity; response of linear and nonlinear multidegree systems; basic concepts in earthquake-resistant design; foundation problems.

CE-538.title: Prestressed Concrete
CE-538.description: Fundamental principles of prestressing by pre- and post-tensioning; elastic and time dependent losses; stress analysis and design of prestressed and precast concrete structures.

CE-539.title: Advanced Steel Structures
CE-539.description: Design of tubular members and plate girders; design for torsional and seismic loads; general flexural theory; introduction to plastic design; connections.

CE-541B.title: Dynamics of Structures
CE-541B.description: Continuous system response; approximate methods; introduction to structural control; random vibration concepts; responses of continuous systems to random excitation; nonlinear systems (geometric theory), (approximate methods).

CE-542.title: Theory of Plates
CE-542.description: Theory of plate bending; rectangular and circular plates; anisotropic plates; energy methods; numerical methods; large deformations; sandwich plates.

CE-551.title: Computer-Aided Engineering Project
CE-551.description: Computer-aided engineering in a project environment. Responding to RFPs; conceptual design; preliminary analysis; overall and detailed analysis and design; trade-off studies; project management; project presentation.

synonyms: Managing and Financing Public Engineering Works
CE-552.title: Managing and Financing Public Engineering Works
CE-552.description: Tools for improving the efficiency and effectiveness of public engineering works, taking into account the political and policy context. Graduate standing. Recommended preparation: microeconomic theory

synonyms: Chemical and Biological Processes in Environmental Engineering
CE-553.title: Chemical and Biological Processes in Environmental Engineering
CE-553.description: Chemistry of softening, coagulation, disinfection, oxidation, corrosion control, dry and wet combustion and ion exchange; aerobic and anaerobic processes and the ecology of liquid and solid waste treatment.

synonyms: Risk and Reliability Analysis for Civil Infrastructure Systems
CE-554.title: Risk and Reliability Analysis for Civil Infrastructure Systems
CE-554.description: Elements of feasibility, reliability, and risk analysis of civil infrastructure systems, simulation, optimization, life-cycle cost, evaluation and decision making.

CE-555.title: Underwater Structures
CE-555.description: Loads on underwater structures; stress analysis of typical structural elements; buckling problems; dynamic response.

synonyms: Project Cost Estimating, Control, Planning and Scheduling
CE-556A.title: Project Cost Estimating, Control, Planning and Scheduling
CE-556A.description: Fundamental principles and practices of cost estimating, budgeting, and cost control of construction projects. Case studies and software exercises based on project data. Graduate standing in engineering, architecture, business, or urban and regional planning required.

synonyms: Project Cost Estimating, Control, Planning and Scheduling
CE-556B.title: Project Cost Estimating, Control, Planning and Scheduling
CE-556B.description: Fundamental principles and practices of cost estimating, budgeting, and cost control of construction projects. Case studies and software exercises based on project data. Graduate standing in engineering, architecture, business, or urban and regional planning required.

CE-557.title: Advanced Building Estimating
CE-557.description: Processes in compiling a bid for construction of non-residential building.

CE-558.title: International Construction and Engineering
CE-558.description: Business development and project management in international markets. Topics include marketing, planning, contracts and negotiations, procurement, logistics, personnel and financing. Construction operations in adverse environments.

CE-559.title: Strategic Planning in Construction Engineering
CE-559.description: Elements and techniques of strategic planning for construction engineering. Fundamentals of engineering as a service sector enterprise. Assessment of markets (including international issues), competitors, and technology. Aspects of overseas engineering business. Management of technology and the role of R&D. Emphasis on concepts. Recommended preparation: CE 502

synonyms: Simulation of Civil Infrastructure Systems Performance
CE-560.title: Simulation of Civil Infrastructure Systems Performance
CE-560.description: Time/space and frequency/wave number domain analysis, spectral representation of wind, earthquake and other natural loads, FEM techniques for system response simulation.

CE-561.title: Uncertainty Quantification
CE-561.description: Methods of quantifying uncertainty in civil engineering and related fields. Basic uncertainty modeling; advanced topics such as reliability analysis, Bayesian updating, random processes, random fields.

CE-565.title: Wave Propagation in Solids
CE-565.description: Elastic waves in infinite and semi-infinite regions; plates and bars; steady-state and transient scattering; dynamic stress concentration; viscoelastic and plastic bodies.

CE-583.title: Design of Transportation Facilities
CE-583.description: Planning, design, staging, construction, test, and maintenance of the public works and facilities for land, water, and air transportation.

CE-585.title: Traffic Engineering and Control
CE-585.description: Conceptual engineering geometric design, installation, and calibration of vehicular storage and traffic controls; safe flow optimization of vehicles on various thoroughfares. Recommended preparation: CE 471.

CE-589.title: Port Engineering: Planning and Operations
CE-589.description: Physical and operational characteristics of marine ports; impact analysis of modern logistics on port operation, planning and management; optimization and efficiency solutions for container terminals.

CE-590.title: Directed Research
