CE-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CE-594A.title: Master's Thesis
CE-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded Cr/NC.

CE-594B.title: Master's Thesis
CE-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

CE-633.title: Urban Transportation Planning and Management
CE-633.description: Background applications of established urban travel forecasting procedures; land use; trip-generation, trip-distribution, modal-choice, trip- assignment; evaluation; criticisms.

CE-790.title: Research
CE-790.description: Research leading to the Doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CE-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CE-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CE-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CE-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CE-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CE-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CE-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CE-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CE-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CE-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI-101.title: Fundamentals of Computer Programming
CSCI-101.description: Introduction to the design of solutions to computer solvable problems. Algorithm design, solution implementation using a high-level programming language, program correctness and verification.

CSCI-102.title: Data Structures
CSCI-102.description: Linear lists, strings, arrays, and orthogonal lists; graphs, trees, binary trees, multilinked structures, sorting techniques; dynamic storage allocation; applications.

CSCI-105.title: Object-Oriented Programming
CSCI-105.description: The principles of object-oriented programming are examined using Java. Topics include graphics, graphical user interfaces and multi-threaded programming.

CSCI-106.title: Introduction to Computer Engineering/Computer Science
CSCI-106.description: Examination of key disciplines of computing systems: architecture, operating systems, digital logic, VLSI, networks, AI, robotics, graphics, and algorithms. Includes hardware/software laboratory tours and exercises.

CSCI-110.title: Introduction to Digital Logic
CSCI-110.description: Boolean algebra; number systems; Boolean function synthesis; binary arithmetic; codes; combinational logic devices; sequential circuits; state machine design and implementation.

synonyms: Survey of Digital Games and Their Technologies
CSCI-180.title: Survey of Digital Games and Their Technologies
CSCI-180.description: Historical, technical, and critical approach to the evolution of computer and video game architectures and game design, from its beginnings to the present day.

CSCI-201.title: Principles of Software Development
CSCI-201.description: The object-oriented paradigm for programming-in-the-large (using the C++ language); UNIX tools for software development; developing window-based applications under X-windows.

CSCI-271.title: Discrete Methods in Computer Science
CSCI-271.description: Models for discrete structures; finite state automata, regular sets. Selected applications of logic and combinatorics to program correctness, algorithms and complexity, programming language semantics and databases.

CSCI-281.title: Pipelines for Games and Interactives
CSCI-281.description: Explores the aesthetic development/technical implementation necessary to achieve unique, compelling, intuitive visual design in games. Students will develop group visual game design portfolios.

CSCI-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
CSCI-300O.description: Coursework taken off campus. Title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

CSCI-303.title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
CSCI-303.description: Upper and lower bounds on sorting and order median. Deterministic and random computation, data structures, NP-completeness, cryptography, Turing machines and undecidability.

CSCI-320.title: Digital Media Basics for Multimedia
CSCI-320.description: Digital media basics for creating multimedia applications including analog and digital representation, media editing, interface construction, CD ROM and network delivery.

CSCI-357.title: Basic Organization of Computer Systems
CSCI-357.description: Organization and operation of the processor, memory and I/O of a minicomputer at the machine language level; assembly language programming; data representation and computer arithmetic.

CSCI-402.title: Operating Systems
CSCI-402.description: Basic issues in concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization scheduling, memory management, protection and access control, inter-process communication, and structured design. Laboratory experiences with Unix-like operating system. Not available for graduate credit to computer science majors.

CSCI-445.title: Introduction to Robotics
CSCI-445.description: Designing, building and programming mobile robots; sensors, effectors, basic control theory, control architectures, some advanced topics, illustrations of state-of-the-art. Teamwork; final project tested in a robot contest. Junior standing or higher.

CSCI-450.title: Introduction to Computer Networks
CSCI-450.description: Network architectures; layered protocols, network service interface; local networks; long-haul networks; internal protocols; link protocols; addressing; routing; flow control; higher level protocols.

synonyms: Introduction to System Design Using Microprocessors
CSCI-454.title: Introduction to System Design Using Microprocessors
CSCI-454.description: Operation and timing of 8/16/32-bit microprocessors; asynchronous and synchronous SRAM interface; burst and pipelined bus cycles, parallel and serial I/O, interrupt controller, DMA controller, bus protocols; hardware/simulation labs. Recommended preparation: EE 457

CSCI-455.title: Introduction to Programming Systems Design
CSCI-455.description: Intensive introduction to programming principles, discrete mathematics for computing, software design and software engineering concepts. Not available for credit to computer science majors, graduate or undergraduate.

CSCI-457x.title: Computer Systems Organization
CSCI-457x.description: Register transfer level machine organization; MIPS instruction set architecture; performance; computer arithmetic; organization and detailed implementation of non-pipelined and pipelined processors; cache and virtual memory. Not available for graduate credit to computer science majors.

CSCI-460.title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
CSCI-460.description: Concepts and algorithms underlying the understanding and construction of intelligent systems. Agents, problem solving, search, representation, reasoning, planning, communication, perception, robotics, neural networks.

CSCI-464.title: Foundations of Exotic Computation
CSCI-464.description: Introduction to new approaches to computation: quantum -- inspired by quantum mechanics; neural -- inspired by the study of the brain; and molecular -- inspired by the genome.

synonyms: Design and Construction of Large Software Systems
CSCI-477.title: Design and Construction of Large Software Systems
CSCI-477.description: Programming methodologies; intra-group and inter-group communication; software life-cycle; software economics. A large software project is a central aspect of the course.

CSCI-480.title: Computer Graphics
CSCI-480.description: Hardware for interactive graphic systems; picture representations; data structures for graphics; picture processing techniques; languages for graphics; survey of applications such as animation and simulation.

CSCI-485.title: File and Database Management
CSCI-485.description: File input/output techniques, basic methods for file organization, file managers, principles of databases, conceptual data models, and query languages.

CSCI-486.title: Serious Games Development
CSCI-486.description: Develop applications of interactive technology that extend beyond the traditional videogame market: education, health, training, policy exploration, analytics, visualization, simulation, the arts and therapy.

CSCI-490.title: Directed Research
CSCI-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CSCI-491A.title: Final Game Project
CSCI-491A.description: a: Design, iterative prototyping, and development of a 1st playable level.

CSCI-491B.title: Final Game Project
CSCI-491B.description: b: Design, iterative stage 2 prototyping and development of a refined game.

CSCI-501.title: Numerical Analysis and Computation
CSCI-501.description: Linear equations and matrices, Gauss elimination, error estimates, iteration techniques; contractive mappings, Newton's method; matrix eigenvalue problems; least-squares approximation, Newton-Cotes and Gaussian quadratures; finite difference methods. Prerequisite: linear algebra and calculus.

CSCI-502B.title: Numerical Analysis
CSCI-502B.description: Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear systems of equations; approximation theory using functional analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.

CSCI-505B.title: Applied Probability
CSCI-505B.description: Markov processes in discrete or continuous time; renewal processes; martingales; brownian motion and diffusion theory; random walks, inventory models, population growth, queuing models, shot noise.

CSCI-511.title: Personal Software Process (PSP) and Project
CSCI-511.description: Individual analysis, planning, development and maintenance of a software product or development artifact, using the principles and practices of PSP. Analysis of project's lessons learned.

CSCI-520.title: Computer Animation and Simulation
CSCI-520.description: Fundamental techniques of computer animation and simulation, knowledge and/or experience in the design, scripting, production and post-production stages of computer animation.

CSCI-522.title: Game Engine Development
CSCI-522.description: The principles of developing game engines targeted at modern PC and game console hardware.

CSCI-524.title: Networked Artificial Intelligence
CSCI-524.description: Networked game communication architectures, protocol development, architecting networked game AI clients/services. Character following, knowledge representation and reasoning, dynamic play strategies, search, learning, and planning.

synonyms: Advanced Mobile Devices and Game Consoles
CSCI-526.title: Advanced Mobile Devices and Game Consoles
CSCI-526.description: Explore the complex engineering process required to design and build a real-time graphics engine to support physical realism on mobile devices.

CSCI-529A.title: Advanced Game Projects
CSCI-529A.description: Team projects intended to address the multifaceted technical and creative challenges that are inherent to comprehensive game development.

CSCI-529B.title: Advanced Game Projects
CSCI-529B.description: This course provides students in various areas of game specialization the practice of design, iterative stage 2 prototyping and development of a refined game.

CSCI-530.title: Security Systems
CSCI-530.description: Protecting computer networks and systems using cryptography, authentication, authorization, intrusion detection and response. Includes lab to provide practical experience working with such systems.

CSCI-534.title: Affective Computing
CSCI-534.description: Overview of the theory of human emotion, techniques for recognizing and synthesizing emotional behavior, and design application.

CSCI-538.title: Human Performance Engineering
CSCI-538.description: Tools and techniques for addressing issues related to Human Performance Engineering (HPE) of computing systems.

CSCI-543.title: Software Multiagent Systems
CSCI-543.description: Investigate computational systems in which several software agents or software agents and humans interact.

CSCI-544.title: Natural Language Processing
CSCI-544.description: Examination of the issues which enable computers to employ and understand natural language; knowledge representation, memory modeling, parsing, language analysis, story understanding, and generation. Recommended preparation: CSCI 562.

CSCI-545.title: Robotics
CSCI-545.description: Fundamental skills for modeling and controlling of dynamic systems for robotic applications and graphics animations; control theory; kinematics; dynamics; sensor processing; real-time operating systems; robot labs.

CSCI-546.title: Intelligent Embedded Systems
CSCI-546.description: Survey of techniques for the design of large-scale, distributed, networked, embedded systems. Examples include sensor/actuator networks, wearable computing, distributed robotics and smart spaces.

CSCI-549.title: Nanorobotics
CSCI-549.description: Introduction to nanotechnology. Nanorobotic systems: sensing; actuation and propulsion; control; communication; power; programming and coordination of robot swarms. Nanomanipulation and nanoassembly with atomic force microscopes. Graduate standing in natural science or engineering.

CSCI-551.title: Computer Communications
CSCI-551.description: Protocol design for computer communication networks, network routing, transport protocols, internetworking.

CSCI-552.title: Logic Design and Switching Theory
CSCI-552.description: State minimization of incompletely specified sequential circuits; asynchronous sequential circuits; races; state assignments; combinatorial and sequential hazards in logic circuits.

CSCI-553.title: Computational Solution of Optimization Problems
CSCI-553.description: Computer algorithms for system optimization. Search techniques, gradient methods, parameter optimization in control systems. Optimization with constraints; linear and nonlinear programming. Random search techniques.

CSCI-554.title: Real Time Computer Systems
CSCI-554.description: Structure of real-time computer systems; analog signals and devices; scheduling, synchronization of multiprocessors; reliability, availability; serial/parallel computations; real-time operating systems and languages; design examples.

CSCI-555.title: Advanced Operating Systems
CSCI-555.description: Advanced issues in Computer Organization, Naming, Kernel Design, Protection Mechanism and Security Policies, Reliable Computing, data base OS, Secure Networks, Systems Specification, Decentralized Systems, Real Time Systems.

CSCI-556.title: Introduction to Cryptography
CSCI-556.description: Modern secret codes. Public key cryptosystems of Rivest-Shamir-Adleman, Diffie-Hellman and others. The underlying number theory and computational complexity theory.

CSCI-557.title: Computer Systems Architecture
CSCI-557.description: Comparative studies of computer system components: the CPU, memory, and I/O; analytical modeling techniques to allow comparative evaluation of architectures; parallelism and supercomputers.

CSCI-558.title: Internetwork and Distributed Systems Laboratory
CSCI-558.description: Students complete laboratory exercises in operating system and network management, distributed systems, TCP/IP, SNMP, NFS, DNS, etc. Term project required. Recommended preparation: 551, 555

CSCI-559.title: Mathematical Pattern Recognition
CSCI-559.description: Distribution free classification, discriminant functions, training algorithms; statistical classification, parametric and nonparametric techniques, potential functions; non-supervised learning.

CSCI-561.title: Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
CSCI-561.description: Foundations of symbolic intelligent systems, search, logic, knowledge representation, planning, learning. Recommended preparation: good programming and algorithm analysis skills

CSCI-565.title: Compiler Design
CSCI-565.description: Formal grammars; parsing methods and lexical analysis; code generation; local and global code optimization; and dynamic allocation.

CSCI-566.title: Neural Network Self-Organization
CSCI-566.description: Differential equations for network pattern formation. Dynamic link architecture. Simulation of brain organization processes (retinotopy, orientation columns) and face recognition by elastic matching. Recommended preparation: CSCI 564 and either MATH 225 or MATH 245.

CSCI-570.title: Analysis of Algorithms
CSCI-570.description: Explores fundamental techniques such as recursion, Fourier transform ordering, dynamic programming for efficient algorithm construction. Examples include arithmetic, algebraic, graph, pattern matching, sorting, searching algorithms.

CSCI-571.title: Web Technologies
CSCI-571.description: Advanced study of programming languages with application to the Web. Languages for client-side and server-side processing. Examples taken from: HTML, Java, JavaScript, Perl, XML and others. Recommended preparation: knowledge of at least two programming languages

synonyms: Information Retrieval and Web Search Engines
CSCI-572.title: Information Retrieval and Web Search Engines
CSCI-572.description: Examines key aspects of information retrieval as they apply to search engines; web crawling, indexing, querying and quality of results are studied.

CSCI-573.title: Advanced Artificial Intelligence
CSCI-573.description: Advanced topics in AI, covering reasoning under uncertainty, decision theory, knowledge-based and inductive learning. Recommended preparation: a previous undergraduate or graduate level course in AI

CSCI-576.title: Multimedia Systems Design
CSCI-576.description: State-of-the-art technology for networked multimedia systems such as: system design, I/O technologies, data management, data compression, networking and telecommunications. Design of real-world multimedia solution. Recommended preparation: familiarity with C or C++

CSCI-577B.title: Software Engineering
CSCI-577B.description: b: Software development, test, implemetation, and maintenance methods. CASE tools and software envirnments. Software product engineering, configuration management, quaility engineering, documentation. Application via projects.

CSCI-578.title: Software Architectures
CSCI-578.description: Study of concepts, principles and scope of software system architectures, including architectural styles, languages, connectors, middleware, dynamism, analysis, testing and domain-specific approaches.

CSCI-581.title: Logic and its Applications
CSCI-581.description: Formal systems, first order logic, truth, completeness, compactness, Godel incompleteness, recursive functions, undecidability. Selected applications, e.g., theorem proving, artificial intelligence, program verification, databases, computational complexity.

CSCI-582.title: Geometric Modeling
CSCI-582.description: Mathematical models and computer representations for three-dimensional solids; underlying topics from set theory, geometry and topology. Fundamental algorithms; applications to CAD/CAM and robotics.

CSCI-585.title: Database Systems
CSCI-585.description: Database system architecture; conceptual database models; semantic, object-oriented, logic-based, and relational databases; user and program interfaces; database system implementation; integrity, security, concurrency and recovery.

CSCI-586.title: Database Systems Interoperability
CSCI-586.description: Federated and multi-database systems, database networking, conceptual and schematic diversity, information sharing and exchange, knowledge discovery, performance issues.

CSCI-590.title: Directed Research
CSCI-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI-594A.title: Master's Thesis
CSCI-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSCI-594B.title: Master's Thesis
CSCI-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSCI-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
CSCI-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CSCI-597.title: Seminar in Computer Science Research
CSCI-597.description: Introduction of Ph.D. students to the broad range of computer science research. Two semesters registration required. Open to Computer Science doctoral students only. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI-599.title: Special Topics
CSCI-599.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.

CSCI-653.title: High Performance Computing and Simulations
CSCI-653.description: Advanced high-performance computer simulation techniques: multiscale deterministic and stochastic simulation algorithms on parallel and distributed computing platforms; immersive and interactive visualization of simulation data.

CSCI-674B.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Vision
CSCI-674B.description: Selected topics from current active research areas including image segmentation, shape analysis and object recognition, inference of 3-D shape, motion analysis, knowledge-based system, neural nets.

synonyms: Topics in Engineering Approaches to Music Cognition
CSCI-675.title: Topics in Engineering Approaches to Music Cognition
CSCI-675.description: Computational research in music cognition, including computational methods for music analysis, such as the abstracting and extracting of pitch and time structures. Computational research in expressive performance, the manipulation of parameters (e.g., tempo, loudness, articulation) to focus attention, facilitate parsing, and create emotional affect. Open to graduate engineering students only. Recommended preparation: programming experience (C++ or Java), basic signal processing and music theory.

synonyms: Topics in Computer Networks and Distributed Systems
CSCI-694A.title: Topics in Computer Networks and Distributed Systems
CSCI-694A.description: Current topics in network and distributed systems; bernal and written presentation skills, effective critiquing, and evaluation.

CSCI-790.title: Research
CSCI-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CSCI-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CSCI-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CSCI-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CSCI-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
CSCI-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

EE-101.title: Introduction to Digital Logic
EE-101.description: Boolean algebra; number systems; Boolean function synthesis; binary arithmetic; codes; combinational logic devices; sequential circuits; state machine design and implementation.

EE-106.title: Introduction to Computer Engineering/Computer Science
EE-106.description: Examination of key disciplines of computing systems: architecture, operating systems, digital logic, VLSI, networks, AI, robotics, graphics, and algorithms. Includes hardware/software laboratory tours and exercises.

EE-201.title: Introduction to Digital Circuits
EE-201.description: Digital system design and implementation using discrete ICs and FPGAs; synchronous design of datapath and control units; state machine implementation methods; timing analysis; lab experiments, logic analyzers; schematic-entry and simulation; semester-end project.

EE-202.title: Linear Circuits
EE-202.description: Lumped circuit elements; network equations; zero-input and zero-state responses; sinusoidal steady-state analysis; impedance; resonance; network functions; power concepts; transformers; Laplace transforms.

EE-241.title: Applied Linear Algebra for Engineering
EE-241.description: Introduction to the theory of matrices, vector spaces, least-squares approximation and MATLAB. Applications to communications, control and signal processing.

EE-301.title: Introduction to Linear Systems
EE-301.description: Representation and analysis of linear time-invariant systems primarily for the continuous time case. Convolution, Fourier series and transform, Laplace transform, controls and communications applications.

EE-320.title: Digital Media Basics for Multimedia
EE-320.description: Digital media basics for creating multimedia applications including analog and digital representation, media editing, interface construction, CD ROM and network delivery.

EE-326.title: Essentials of Electrical Engineering
EE-326.description: Network analysis and theorems; transient analysis; transformers; semiconductor physics and circuits; power amplifiers, modulation and demodulation, and pulse, digital, and switching circuits. Introduction to instrumentation. Not available for credit to electrical engineering majors.

EE-330.title: Electromagnetics I
EE-330.description: Basic static and dynamic electromagnetic field theory and applications; electrostatics, magnetostatics, Maxwell's equations, energy flow, plane waves incident on planar boundaries, transmission lines.

EE-338.title: Physical Electronics
EE-338.description: Semiconductor device characteristics and applications. Physical models of electronic conduction in solids, p-n junctions, bipolar and field effect transistors and other solid state devices. Not for credit to students who have taken 378L.

EE-348.title: Electronic Circuits
EE-348.description: Basic analog and digital circuit design using Bipolar Junction Transistors, Field Effect Transistors, and integrated circuits.

EE-357.title: Basic Organization of Computer Systems
EE-357.description: Organization and operation of the processor, memory and I/O of a minicomputer at the machine language level; assembly language programming; data representation and computer arithmetic.

synonyms: Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Electrical Engineering
EE-364.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Electrical Engineering
EE-364.description: Introduction to concepts of randomness and uncertainty: probability, random variables, statistics. Applications to digital communications, signal processing, automatic control, computer engineering and computer science.

EE-415.title: Introduction to MEMS
EE-415.description: Introduction to micro-electro-opto-mechanical systems; scaling effects on material properties, fluid flows, dynamical behavior; fabrication methods; design considerations for MEMS sensors and actuators. Recommended preparation: AME 301, AME 309 and AME 310

EE-422.title: Electromagnetic Systems Design
EE-422.description: Applied electromagnetics for large- and small-scale electromechanical systems. Comprehensive design project.

EE-423.title: Loudspeaker and Sound-System Design
EE-423.description: Project-based design of loudspeaker transducers, filters, and enclosures. Measurement of transfer functions, acoustical performance, distortion, Thiele-Small parameters, and power handling. Listening evaluations. Recommended preparation: EE 330

EE-434.title: Digital Signal Processing Design Laboratory
EE-434.description: Experiments and design project in digital signal processing (e.g. real-time DSP, acoustics, video) including: system specification, preliminary analysis, trade-off studies, implementation, presentation. Recommended preparation: EE 469

EE-438.title: Processing for Microelectronics
EE-438.description: Applications and electrical evaluation of selected processes used in electronic microfabrication.

EE-441.title: Applied Linear Algebra for Engineering
EE-441.description: Introduction to linear algebra and matrix theory and their underlying concepts. Applications to engineering problems.

EE-445.title: Introduction to Robotics
EE-445.description: Designing, building and programming mobile robots; sensors, effectors, basic control theory, control architectures, some advanced topics, illustrations of state-of-the-art. Teamwork; final project tested in a robot contest. Junior standing or higher.

EE-447.title: Mixed Signal Electronic Circuits
EE-447.description: Application of solid-state electronic devices to the design of linear and mixed-signal systems. Laboratory experiments and projects involving the design of electronic hardware.

EE-448.title: Communication Electronics
EE-448.description: Analysis, design, and experimental evaluation of transistor-level communication circuits and micro-systems. Transmission lines, impedance matching, noise, distortion, tuned amplifiers, mixers, oscillators, phase-locked loops.

EE-450.title: Introduction to Computer Networks
EE-450.description: Network architectures; layered protocols, network service interface; local networks; long-haul networks; internal protocols; link protocols; addressing; routing; flow control; higher level protocols.

synonyms: Introduction to System Design Using Microprocessors
EE-454.title: Introduction to System Design Using Microprocessors
EE-454.description: Operation and timing of 8/16/32-bit microprocessors; asynchronous and synchronous SRAM interface; burst and pipelined bus cycles, parallel and serial I/O, interrupt controller, DMA controller, bus protocols; hardware/simulation labs. Recommended preparation: EE 457

EE-455x.title: Introduction to Programming Systems Design
EE-455x.description: Intensive introduction to programming principles, discrete mathematics for computing, software design and software engineering concepts. Not available for credit to computer science majors, graduate or undergraduate.

EE-457.title: Computer Systems Organization
EE-457.description: Register transfer level machine organization; MIPS instruction set architecture; performance; computer arithmetic; organization and detailed implementation of non-pipelined and pipelined processors; cache and virtual memory. Not available for graduate credit to computer science majors.

EE-459.title: Embedded Systems Design Laboratory
EE-459.description: Specification, design, implementation, testing and documentation of a digital system project using embedded processors, programmable logic, analog I/O interfaces and application specific hardware.

EE-460.title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
EE-460.description: Concepts and algorithms underlying the understanding and construction of intelligent systems. Agents, problem solving, search, representation, reasoning, planning, communication, perception, robotics, neural networks.

EE-464.title: Probability Theory for Engineers
EE-464.description: Axiomatic foundations of probability, random variables, Gaussian and Poisson distributions, functions of a random variable. Gaussian random vector, functions of several random variables; sequences of random variables. Prerequisite: 301 and MATH 445.

synonyms: Probabilistic Methods in Computer Systems Modeling
EE-465.title: Probabilistic Methods in Computer Systems Modeling
EE-465.description: Review of probability; random variables; stochastic processes; Markov chains and simple queuing theory. Applications to program and algorithm analysis; computer systems performance and reliability modeling.

EE-471.title: Applied Quantum Mechanics for Engineers
EE-471.description: Introductory quantum mechanics and applications. Schrodinger equation, atomic and molecular processes, time-dependent perturbation theory. Applications to lasers, solid state demos and gaseous devices. Prerequisite: 330 or graduate standing.

EE-473.title: Lasers and Optics Laboratory
EE-473.description: Introductory design/research laboratory in lasers and optics, which typically includes fiber optics, photonics, electro-optics, optical sensors, optical communication, optical signal processing and computing.

EE-474.title: Introduction to Photonics
EE-474.description: Photonic system requirements; waveguide modes and dispersion; principles of operation of lasers, optical amplifiers, detectors and modulators; noise.

EE-476.title: Chemical Engineering Materials
EE-476.description: Chemical and physical properties of solid materials used by chemical engineers, including polymers, metals, and ceramics. Materials design for industrial applications.

EE-477.title: MOS VLSI Circuit Design
EE-477.description: Analysis and design of digital MOS VLSI circuits including area, delay and power minimization. Laboratory assignments including design, layout, extraction, simulation and automatic synthesis.

EE-478.title: Digital Electronic Circuit Design
EE-478.description: Design of digital electronic circuits. Laboratory experiments and an extensive term project using digital hardware.

EE-483.title: Introduction to Digital Signal Processing
EE-483.description: Fundamentals of Digital Signal Processing covering: discrete time linear systems, quantization, sampling, Z-transforms, Fourier transforms, FFTs and filter design.

EE-484.title: Communication System Design
EE-484.description: Design and analysis of analog and digital communication systems. System models, requirements, development, performance analysis and component selection techniques. Comprehensive system design project. Recommended preparation: EE 467

EE-490.title: Directed Research
EE-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

EE-500.title: Neural and Fuzzy Systems
EE-500.description: Neural networks and fuzzy systems, including: neuron structure and dynamics, unsupervised and supervised learning, network models and architectures, network stability and learning convergence.

EE-501.title: Solid State
EE-501.description: Atomic structure, bonding in covalent, ionic and Van der Waals crystals, Brillouin zones, lattices, diffraction, electronic states, lattice vibrations, specific heat, electrical conductivity, and magnetism.

synonyms: Solid State Processing and Integrated Circuits Laboratory
EE-504.title: Solid State Processing and Integrated Circuits Laboratory
EE-504.description: Laboratory oriented with lectures keyed to practical procedures and processes. Solid-state fabrication and analysis fundamentals; basic device construction techniques. Prerequisite: BSEE

EE-515.title: High Voltage Technology
EE-515.description: High voltage engineering basic concepts; theoretical, design, and practical aspects of overvoltages, travelling-waves, insulation, and aging; breakdown mechanisms; insulation coordination.

EE-517.title: Statistics for Engineers
EE-517.description: Presents statistics with engineering emphasis. Topics include confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, estimation, regression, nonparametric tests, analysis of variance, quality control, and experimental design. Recommended preparation: EE 464 or other probability course

EE-521.title: Power Systems
EE-521.description: Transmission lines; transients in power systems; control; stability. Special topics.

EE-522.title: Immersive Audio Signal Processing
EE-522.description: Fundamentals of digital audio signal processing, room acoustics, and psychoacoustics. Algorithms for real-time implementation of immersive audio systems for integrated media applications.

EE-525.title: Power System Protection
EE-525.description: Theory of system and equipment protection, characteristics of relays, relay coordination, and system considerations.

EE-531.title: Nonlinear Optics
EE-531.description: Theory of nonlinear optical susceptibility and application to self-focusing, harmonic generation, and parametric interactions. Raman and Brillouin scattering. Coherent spectroscopy.

EE-536B.title: Mixed-Signal Integrated Circuit Design
EE-536B.description: b: Non-linear integrated circuits, data-converter architectures and implementations, comprehensive design project. (Duplicates credit in former EE 533ab.)

EE-538.title: Spread Spectrum Systems
EE-538.description: Description analysis and design of Spread Spectrum Systems in military, navigation and wireless communication applications: portable, mobile, cellular and micro-cellular (PCS), including the industry standard IS-95. Recommended preparation: EE 568.

EE-540.title: Introduction to Quantum Electronics
EE-540.description: Fundamentals of light amplification; laser amplifiers and oscillators; atomic pumping; maser and laser systems; definitions of coherence; measurements in quantum electronics.

EE-543A.title: Digital Control Systems
EE-543A.description: Design, analysis and implementation of digital control systems using microcomputers; Z-transform methods; frequency domain and state space approach; computational aspects; sampling and quantization.

EE-545.title: Robotics
EE-545.description: Fundamental skills for modeling and controlling of dynamic systems for robotic applications and graphics animations; control theory; kinematics; dynamics; sensor processing; real-time operating systems; robot labs.

EE-549.title: Queueing Theory for Performance Modeling
EE-549.description: Review of Poisson and Markov processes; Markovian and non-Markovian queueing systems; networks of queues; priority queueing; applications of the theory to computer systems and communication networks.

EE-552.title: Logic Design and Switching Theory
EE-552.description: State minimization of incompletely specified sequential circuits; asynchronous sequential circuits; races; state assignments; combinatorial and sequential hazards in logic circuits.

EE-553.title: Computational Solution of Optimization Problems
EE-553.description: Computer algorithms for system optimization. Search techniques, gradient methods, parameter optimization in control systems. Optimization with constraints; linear and nonlinear programming. Random search techniques.

EE-554.title: Real Time Computer Systems
EE-554.description: Structure of real-time computer systems; analog signals and devices; scheduling, synchronization of multiprocessors; reliability, availability; serial/parallel computations; real-time operating systems and languages; design examples.

EE-555.title: Broadband Network Architectures
EE-555.description: ATM and BISDN, switch designs, high speed local, campus and metropolitan area networks, lightwave and photonic networks, network management techniques, applications and gigabit testbeds.

EE-557.title: Computer Systems Architecture
EE-557.description: Comparative studies of computer system components: the CPU, memory, and I/O; analytical modeling techniques to allow comparative evaluation of architectures; parallelism and supercomputers.

EE-558.title: Optical Fiber Communication Systems
EE-558.description: State-of-the-art optical fiber communication system. Emphasis on optoelectronic-device and communication-systems issues necessary to provide high-speed and/or networked optical communications. Recommended preparation: EE 338; basic knowledge of optics, semiconductor, and communications concepts.

EE-559.title: Mathematical Pattern Recognition
EE-559.description: Distribution free classification, discriminant functions, training algorithms; statistical classification, parametric and nonparametric techniques, potential functions; non-supervised learning.

EE-561.title: Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
EE-561.description: Foundations of symbolic intelligent systems, search, logic, knowledge representation, planning, learning. Recommended preparation: good programming and algorithm analysis skills

EE-562A.title: Random Processes in Engineering
EE-562A.description: a: Random vectors, sequences, and functions. Linear transformations, second moment theory, spectral densities, narrowband processes, Gaussian processes, correlation detection, linear minimum mean square error estimation.

EE-562B.title: Random Processes in Engineering
EE-562B.description: b. Orthogonal or independent increment processes. Poisson processes. Nonlinear operations on random processes; power-law detectors. Markov chains and processes; the Fokker-Planck equation; level crossing problems.

EE-564.title: Communication Theory
EE-564.description: Elementary statistical design theory with applications to the design of digital communications receivers and radar receivers; signal design in digital communications.

EE-565B.title: Information Theory
EE-565B.description: Information measures; asymptotic equipartition property; source coding theorem; noiseless coding; cryptography, channel coding theorem; rate distortion theory; Gaussian channels; multiple user source and channel theory.

EE-566.title: Optical Information Processing
EE-566.description: Coherent and incoherent optical transforming, imaging and two-dimensional information processing systems; optical image processing, spatial frequency response and filtering; optical and digital holography. Prerequisite: Knowledge of Fourier transform analysis. Recommended preparation: EE 401 and EE 464.

EE-568.title: Error Correcting Codes
EE-568.description: Linear block codes. Combinatorial decoding of block codes; convolution codes; probabilistic formulation of decoding methods; decoding methods; examples.

EE-577A.title: VLSI System Design
EE-577A.description: Integrated circuit fabrication; circuit simulation; basic device physics; simple device layout: structured chip design; timing; project chip; MOS logic; system design; silicon compilers.

EE-577B.title: VLSI System Design
EE-577B.description: VLSI design project; chip level design issues: power and clock distribution, packaging, I/O; design techniques; testability; chip fabrication and test.

EE-578.title: Reflector Antennas
EE-578.description: Introduction to the analytical and numerical techniques used in the analysis and design of modern reflector antenna systems, including physical optics, asymptotic techniques, shaping and feeds.

EE-583.title: Adaptive Signal Processing
EE-583.description: Wiener filtering, linear prediction, method of steepest descent, stochastic gradient algorithms, recursive least-squares (RLS), fast RLS, RLS with systolic arrays, QRD-least squares methods, blind deconvolution.

EE-585.title: Linear System Theory
EE-585.description: Analysis of linear dynamical systems by state-space techniques; controllability, observability, stability, passivity. Application of feedback control and network synthesis.

EE-586.title: Advanced DSP Design Laboratory
EE-586.description: Real-time adaptive signal processing design projects using special purpose DSP processors. Suitable project areas include acoustics, speech, arrays, image compression and biomedical signal processing.

EE-588.title: Linear Quadratic Control
EE-588.description: Linear systems with quadratic cost, Riccati equations, observers, Kanman-Bucy filters, separation principle, discrete linear optimal control systems. Recommended preparation: 482, 562a

EE-590.title: Directed Research
EE-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EE-594A.title: Master's Thesis
EE-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EE-594B.title: Master's Thesis
EE-594B.description: For the Master's Degree. Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EE-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
EE-594Z.description: For the Master's Degree. Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

EE-599.title: Special Topics
EE-599.description: The course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of electrical engineering.

EE-607.title: Microelectromechanical Systems
EE-607.description: Exploration of the technology methods and physical principles of MEMS, and survey various MEMS of current interest.

synonyms: Advanced Topics in Automatic Speech Recognition
EE-619.title: Advanced Topics in Automatic Speech Recognition
EE-619.description: Advanced topics in automatic speech recognition, speaker recognition, spoken dialogue, coversational multimedia interfaces.

EE-642.title: Advanced Geometrical Optics
EE-642.description: First order design of optical systems; origin of aberrations and their effects on wave propagation and imaging based on geometrical and physical optics.

EE-650.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Networks
EE-650.description: Protocol modelling: flow and congestion control, dynamic routing, distributed implementation; broadcast communication media and multiple access protocols; local networks, satellite networks, terrestrial radio networks.

EE-669.title: Multimedia Data Compression
EE-669.description: Lossless compression, audio/speech coding, vector quantization, fractal compression, JPEG and JPEG-2000, video compression techniques and MPEG standards, video transmission over wired and wireless networks. Recommended preparation: EE 464

EE-674B.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Vision
EE-674B.description: Selected topics from current active research areas including image segmentation, shape analysis and object recognition, inference of 3-D shape, motion analysis, knowledge-based system, neural nets.

synonyms: Topics in Engineering Approaches to Music Cognition
EE-675.title: Topics in Engineering Approaches to Music Cognition
EE-675.description: Computational research in music cognition, including computational methods for music analysis, such as the abstracting and extracting of pitch and time structures. Computational research in expressive performance, the manipulation of parameters (e.g., tempo, loudness, articulation) to focus attention, facilitate parsing, and create emotional affect. Open to graduate engineering students only. Recommended preparation: programming experience (C++ or Java), basic signal processing and music theory.

EE-677.title: VLSI Architectures and Algorithms
EE-677.description: VLSI models; measures of area, volume and time; mapping algorithms; systolic arrays; area time tradeoffs; application to signal and image processing problems.

synonyms: Computer Aided Design of Digital Systems I
EE-680.title: Computer Aided Design of Digital Systems I
EE-680.description: Synthesis; partitioning; placement; routing of digital circuits; integrated circuit design methods; simulation at the switch, gate, register transfer and system levels. Recommended preparation: EE 577a.

EE-690.title: Directed Research
EE-690.description: Laboratory study of specific problems by candidates for the degree Engineer in Electrical Engineering. Graded CR/NC.

EE-790.title: Research
EE-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EE-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EE-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

EE-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EE-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

EE-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EE-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

EE-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EE-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

EE-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EE-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Introduction to Applied Environmental Science and Engineering
ENE-201.title: Introduction to Applied Environmental Science and Engineering
ENE-201.description: Gateway to the B.S. in Civil Engineering (Environmental Engineering), B.S., Environmental Engineering, and minor in Environmental Engineering. Pollution control and remediation for air, water and soil. Pollution remediation for developing countries.

ENE-400.title: Environmental Engineering Principles
ENE-400.prereq_text: 1 from (CHEM-105B or CHEM-115B) and MATH-226 and PHYS-152
ENE-400.description: Analysis of water, air, and land pollution, including hazardous waste, and engineering of mitigation measures. Water and wastewater treatment systems.

ENE-429.title: Air Pollution Control
ENE-429.description: Emission surveys; engineering controls of aerosols and gaseous contaminants at emission sources, disposition of contaminants. Field trips. Senior standing.

ENE-463.title: Water Chemistry and Analysis
ENE-463.description: Chemistry of water purification technology and water pollution control. Chemical processes in natural and engineering aquatic environments; physical/chemical and biological characterization of water and wastewater.

ENE-495.title: Seminars in Environmental Engineering
ENE-495.description: Hazardous waste management, biodegradation of environmental pollutants, groundwater problems, waste minimization, energy resources, and air pollution control.

ENE-502.title: Environmental and Regulatory Compliance
ENE-502.description: Federal and state environmental laws; environmental impact assessment techniques; permitting for industrial facility construction and operation. Graduate standing.

ENE-503.title: Microbiology for Environmental Engineers
ENE-503.description: Basic microbiology of water, air, and soil. Application of microbiology to the practice of environmental pollution control.

ENE-523.title: Physical Processes in Environmental Engineering
ENE-523.description: Environmental reactor design, coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, adsorption, solid waste management (drying, centrifugation, incineration), membrane processes, advanced water treatment; mathematical modeling of physical processes.

ENE-535.title: Applied Air Quality Management
ENE-535.description: Pollutant sampling; occupational, community, and personal exposures; receptor modeling; data analysis; health effects of air pollutants. Departmental approval.

synonyms: Chemical and Biological Processes in Environmental Engineering
ENE-553.title: Chemical and Biological Processes in Environmental Engineering
ENE-553.description: Chemistry of softening, coagulation, disinfection, oxidation, corrosion control, dry and wet combustion and ion exchange; aerobic and anaerobic processes and the ecology of liquid and solid waste treatment.

synonyms: Environmental Aspects of Oil and Gas Production
ENE-560.title: Environmental Aspects of Oil and Gas Production
ENE-560.description: Environmental aspects of drilling for and producing oil and gas, and the necessary safety practices. Attention is given to the urban areas.

ENE-590.title: Directed Research
ENE-590.description: . Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENE-596.title: Chemical Reactions in the Atmosphere
ENE-596.description: Chemical reactions and scavenging processes improtant in urban air pollution. Effects of solar irradiation on vehicle exhaust gases, oxides of nitrogen and sulfur.

ENE-790.title: Research
ENE-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

MASC-110.title: Materials Science
MASC-110.description: Chemical bonding and structure in crystalline, amorphous and molecular solids; tendency and mechanisms for chemical change; homogeneous and heterogeneous equilibria.

MASC-438.title: Processing for Microelectronics
MASC-438.description: Applications and electrical evaluation of selected processes used in electronic microfabrication.

MASC-471.title: Applied Quantum Mechanics for Engineers
MASC-471.description: Introductory quantum mechanics and applications. Schrodinger equation, atomic and molecular processes, time-dependent perturbation theory. Applications to lasers, solid state demos and gaseous devices. Prerequisite: 330 or graduate standing.

MASC-476.title: Chemical Engineering Materials
MASC-476.description: Chemical and physical properties of solid materials used by chemical engineers, including polymers, metals, and ceramics. Materials design for industrial applications.

MASC-501.title: Solid State
MASC-501.description: Atomic structure, bonding in covalent, ionic and Van der Waals crystals, Brillouin zones, lattices, diffraction, electronic states, lattice vibrations, specific heat, electrical conductivity, and magnetism.

MASC-504.title: Diffusion and Phase Equilibria
MASC-504.description: Phase equilibria; phase diagrams; diffusion; planar defects; nucleation and growth; spinodal decomposition; phase transformation.

MASC-523.title: Principles of Electrochemical Engineering
MASC-523.description: Electrochemical techniques; mass, charge, and heat transfer; electrochemical thermodynamics and electrode kinetics; electrochemical reactors; optimization; materials and corrosion; experimental modeling of industrial processes.

MASC-561.title: Dislocation Theory and Applications
MASC-561.description: Elasticity theory; types, sources, motion, interaction of dislocations; stress fields and strain energies; partial dislocations and stacking faults; principles of work-hardening.

synonyms: Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Materials and Processes
MASC-576.title: Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Materials and Processes
MASC-576.description: Molecular dynamics method for atomistic simulations of materials processes, simulations using parallel computing, correlation functions for structural and dynamical properties plus simulation project.

MASC-583.title: Materials Selection
MASC-583.description: Materials selection in relationship to design and fabrication, economic considerations, methodology of selection, performance parameter; case studies.

MASC-590.title: Directed Research
MASC-590.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

MASC-598.title: Materials Science Seminar
MASC-598.description: Seminar in Materials Science research. To be taken only once for graduate credit only.

MASC-690.title: Directed Research
MASC-690.description: Laboratory study of specific problems by candidates for the degree Engineer in Materials Science. Graded CR/NC.

MASC-790.title: Research
MASC-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ISE-225.title: Engineering Statistics I
ISE-225.description: Sampling distributions; parameter estimation, hypothesis testing; analysis of variance; regression; nonparametric statistics.

ISE-310.title: Production I: Facilities and Logistics
ISE-310.description: Facilities layout and design: material handling and transportation; site selection and sourcing; supply chain management.

synonyms: Introduction to Operations Research: Stochastic Models
ISE-331.title: Introduction to Operations Research: Stochastic Models
ISE-331.description: Stochastic processes; Markov chains; queueing theory and queueing decision models; probabilistic inventory models. Recommended preparation: ISE 330

synonyms: Database Systems: Concepts, Design and Implementation
ISE-382.title: Database Systems: Concepts, Design and Implementation
ISE-382.description: Concepts in modeling data for industry applications. Designing and implementing robust databases. Querying databases to extract business intelligence; Global Enterprise Resource Planning with databases.

ISE-460.title: Engineering Economy
ISE-460.description: Utilizing principles of economic analysis for choice of engineering alternatives and engineering systems. Pre-tax and after-tax economy studies. Upper division standing.

ISE-470.title: Human/Computer Interface Design
ISE-470.description: Essentials of human factors and computer interface for the design, development, implementation, and evaluation of integrated media systems.

ISE-490.title: Directed Research
ISE-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ISE-495A.title: Senior Design Project
ISE-495A.description: a: Preparation and development of the senior project proposal. Not available for graduate credit. Senior standing in industrial and systems engineering. Open only to industrial and systems engineering students.

ISE-495B.title: Senior Design Project
ISE-495B.description: Group work on an industrial engineering design problem in an organization. Not available for graduate credit. Senior standing in industrial and systems engineering.

ISE-499.title: Special Topics
ISE-499.description: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in industrial and systems engineering and related fields.

ISE-513.title: Inventory Systems
ISE-513.description: Deterministic and stochastic demand systems with static/dynamic models. Practice in inventory management, computerized procedures, materials requirements planning, just-in-time production, Kanban systems.

ISE-515.title: Engineering Project Management
ISE-515.description: Applying industrial and systems engineering skills to problems drawn from industry, while working in teams of 3-4 students. Teach project management skills and provide direct experience in managing and executing a group project.

ISE-517.title: Modern Enterprise Systems
ISE-517.description: Study of various aspects of integrated manufacturing and service enterprises including management, design and production functions, interfaces and related resources and information systems. Recommended preparation: manufacturing processes, probability, statistics, computer programming.

ISE-525.title: Design of Experiments
ISE-525.description: Planning data collection to investigate relationships between product/process design choices (materials, temperatures, etc.) and performance, empirical modeling to predict performance, identification of the best design choices. Recommended preparation: ISE 225

ISE-527.title: Quality Management for Engineers
ISE-527.description: Principles of quality management, quality philosophies and frameworks, quality leadership and strategic planning, process management, and performance measurements.

ISE-532.title: Network Flows
ISE-532.description: Tree, path, flow problems, formulation and solution techniques. Methods for minimal cost flows. Applications.

ISE-538.title: Elements of Stochastic Processes
ISE-538.description: Random variables, stochastic processes, birth-and-death processes, continuous and discrete time, Markov chains with finite and infinite number of states, renewal phenomenons, queueing systems.

ISE-541.title: Systems Engineering Theory and Practice
ISE-541.description: Integration of engineering problem solving methodologies based on systems concepts. Application to complex, large scale technical systems and problems faced by engineering managers. Case studies.

ISE-542.title: Advanced Topics in Systems Engineering
ISE-542.description: Advanced topics in integration software management and systems engineering, probabilistic foundations of decision theory, quantitative risk management, decision-based design, and safety aspects of systems engineering.

ISE-544.title: Management of Engineering Teams
ISE-544.description: Design and management of engineering teams. Group decision-making, motivation, leadership, infrastructure requirements, performance measurement, team diversity, conflict, and integration.

ISE-555.title: Invention and Technology Development
ISE-555.description: This project-oriented course elaborates on the process of engaging creative thought, tools and techniques for invention, and issues involved in bringing inventions to the production phase. Graded CR/NC.

ISE-561.title: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
ISE-561.description: Economic evaluations of engineering systems for both government and private industry; quantitative techniques for evaluating non-monetary consequences; formal treatment of risk and uncertainty.

ISE-562.title: Value and Decision Theory
ISE-562.description: Decision making under risk conditions; utility theory; sufficient statistics; conjugate prior distributions; terminal and pre-posterior analysis; Bayesian statistics versus classical statistics.

ISE-563.title: Financial Engineering
ISE-563.description: Concepts underlying the economic analysis of engineering projects; applications to call and put options; utility theory and mathematical optimizations models; and simulation. Recommended preparation ISE 220 or an equivalent course in probability.

synonyms: Topics in Engineering Approaches to Music Cognition
ISE-575.title: Topics in Engineering Approaches to Music Cognition
ISE-575.description: Computational research in music cognition, including computational methods for music analysis, such as the abstracting and extracting of pitch and time structures. Computational research in expressive performance, the manipulation of parameters (e.g., tempo, loudness, articulation) to focus attention, facilitate parsing, and create emotional affect. Open to graduate engineering students only. Recommended preparation: programming experience (C++ or Java), basic signal processing and music theory.

ISE-580.title: Advanced Concepts in Computer Simulation
ISE-580.description: Coverage of various stages of simulation processes using a project and case study oriented approach; an introduction to available simulation tools and modern simulation concepts.

ISE-583.title: Enterprise Wide Information Systems
ISE-583.description: The role of enterprise resource planning systems (ERPs) in an organization and the task of implementing and managing the IS function.

ISE-585.title: Strategic Management of Technology
ISE-585.description: Management skills and tools for technology intensive enterprises. Life cycle analysis of technology from planning through exploitation, obsolescence and renewal.

ISE-587.title: Risk Analysis
ISE-587.description: Concepts of risk analysis, risk in engineered systems, environmental risk, security risks; fault trees, event trees, risk simulations; risks and decision-making. Recommended preparation: MATH 108 or MATH 116

ISE-589.title: Port Engineering: Planning and Operations
ISE-589.description: Physical and operational characteristics of marine ports; impact analysis of modern logistics on port operation, planning and management; optimization and efficiency solutions for container terminals.

ISE-590.title: Directed Research
ISE-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree; maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ISE-599.title: Special Topics
ISE-599.description: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of industrial and systems engineering.

ISE-650A.title: Seminar in Industrial Engineering
ISE-650A.description: Reports on current departmental research; review of papers, proposals, and special projects; guest speakers. Required of all students enrolled in Ph.D. program. Open only to Ph.D. students. Graded CR/NC.

ISE-650B.title: Seminar in Industrial Engineering
ISE-650B.description: Reports on current departmental research; review of papers, proposals and special projects; guest speakers. Required of all students enrolled in Ph.D. program. Open only to Ph.D. students. Graded CR/NC.

ISE-650C.title: Seminar in Industrial Engineering
ISE-650C.description: Reports on current departmental research; review of papers, proposals, and special projects; guest speakers. Required of all students enrolled in Ph.D. program. Open only to Ph.D. students. Graded CR/NC.

ISE-650D.title: Seminar in Industrial Engineering
ISE-650D.description: Reports on current departmental research; review of papers, proposals, and special projects; guest speakers. Required of all students enrolled in Ph.D. program. Open only to Ph.D. students. Graded CR/NC.

ISE-690.title: Directed Research
ISE-690.description: Laboratory study of specific problems by candidates for the degree Engineer in Industrial Engineering. Graded CR/NC.

ISE-790.title: Research
ISE-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ITP-031.title: Introduction to Microsoft Excel
ITP-031.description: Spreadsheet applications on microcomputers using Microsoft Excel; fundamentals of problem solving and data anaysis using a wide variety of spreadsheet features. Not available for degree credit. Graded CR/NC.

ITP-090.title: Introduction to Adobe Photoshop
ITP-090.description: Basic concepts of colors; color calibration tools; scanning, importing and exporting images; painting, editing, fill, and type tools; using layers, masks, filters, and color correction. Not available for degree credit. Graded CR/NC.

ITP-101.title: Introduction to Information Technology
ITP-101.description: Introduction to computer hardware, operating systems, networks, programming. Survey of application software in business and industry. Computer issues in the work place and society. Not available for credit to CSCI and EE majors.

ITP-104.title: Internet Publishing Technologies
ITP-104.description: Basic Internet publishing using HTML and other Web technologies. Concepts and theory of Web publishing and production. Introduction to page layout and design.

ITP-109.title: Introduction to Java Programming
ITP-109.description: Introduction to object-oriented software design for business problems. Creation of console applications, windowed applications, and interactive Web applets.

ITP-168.title: Introduction to MATLAB
ITP-168.description: Fundamentals of MATLAB: a high-performance numeric computation and visualization environment. Overview of linear algebra and matrix manipulation; using 2-D and 3-D plotting routines; programming in MATLAB; basic numerical analysis. Not available for degree credit. (Duplicates credit in former ITP 068x). Recommended preparation: MATH 118x or MATH 125.

ITP-204.title: Fundamentals of Web Development
ITP-204.description: Programming fundamentals necessary for Web development. Scripting languages, development tools and techniques for creating interactive, dynamic Web pages.

ITP-210.title: Multimedia Applications for Windows
ITP-210.description: Focuses on creating powerful presentations with affordable multimedia hardware and software; integrates sound, video and animation into windowing environment.

ITP-215.title: 3-D Modeling, Animation, Compositing and SpecialEffects
ITP-215.description: Overview of developing a 3D animation: from modeling to rendering. Basics of surfacing, lighting, animation and modeling techniques. Advanced topics: compositing, particle systems, and character animation. Recommended preparation: knowledge of any 2D paint, drawing, or CAD program.

ITP-216.title: Web Animation and Interactivity
ITP-216.description: 2-D vector graphics for web and animation. Scripting techniques for interactivity. Action Script syntax, logic and control. Recommended preparation: basic computer knowledge

ITP-230.title: Video Game Quality Assurance
ITP-230.description: Survey game software development through quality assurance and in-depth analysis of the development cycle with a focus on bug testing systems and methodologies.

ITP-260.title: Internet Technologies
ITP-260.description: Overview of emerging technologies on the Internet including multimedia components, networking, security tools, web-based databases, and wireless systems.

ITP-280.title: Video Game Production
ITP-280.description: History of video games; overview of game genres; phases of video game development (concept, preproduction, production, post-production); roles of artists, programmers, designers, and producers.

ITP-300.title: Database Web Development
ITP-300.description: Fundamental theory and technologies for creating dynamic, database-driven Web sites; Structured Query Language. Recommended preparation: ITP 204x.

synonyms: Applications for 3-D Special Effects and Character Animation
ITP-315.title: Applications for 3-D Special Effects and Character Animation
ITP-315.description: This advanced 3D animation course explores applications of various special effects processes, focusing on the use of particle systems, texture mapping, character and facial animation, and live action compositing.

ITP-320.title: Enterprise Wide Information Systems
ITP-320.description: The role Information Systems play in an organization and the challenging task of implementing and managing the IS function are both examined in detail.

ITP-321.title: Programming Enterprise Wide Information Systems
ITP-321.description: Programming enterprise applications using ABAP/4. Topics include: ABAP/4 Development Workbench, Data Dictionary, subroutines and functions, database tables, data objects, and designing reports.

ITP-325.title: Web Security
ITP-325.description: Computer networks and inherent security issues that apply to networking. Encryption protocols, securing servers, and secure network architectures.

ITP-360.title: 3-D Industry Tools
ITP-360.description: Techniques, concepts and tools for professional 3-D animation development. Strengths/weaknesses of industry-standard middle-end and high-end animation packages; hands-on instruction, discussion, and analysis.

ITP-380.title: Video Game Programming
ITP-380.description: Underlying concepts and principles required for programming video games (topics include vectors, transformations, 3-D math, geometric primitives, matrices).

ITP-382.title: Mobile Game Programming
ITP-382.description: Programming methodologies for writing mobile game applications for handheld devices, including the following programming considerations for embedded systems: graphics, screen size, memory, programming interfaces. Recommended preparation: previous programming experience

synonyms: Database Systems: Concepts, Design and Implementation
ITP-383.title: Database Systems: Concepts, Design and Implementation
ITP-383.description: Concepts in modeling data for industry applications. Designing and implementing robust databases. Querying databases to extract business intelligence; Global Enterprise Resource Planning with databases.

ITP-391.title: Designing and Producing Video Games
ITP-391.description: Key elements for designing effective video games and the processes involved in early development; roles of producer and manager, marketing and sales, and considerations pertaining to licensing and franchises.

ITP-411.title: Interactive Multimedia Production
ITP-411.description: Interactive multimedia title development cycle. Programming a time-based authoring tool; design, develop, and deliver a multimedia title on the Web and state-of-the-art storage media.

ITP-414.title: Advanced Project Development
ITP-414.description: Advanced planning, budgeting, and production processes and techniques for new media projects; team-building and management practices for creative teams. Graded CR/NC. Junior or senior standing. Recommended preparation: a minimum 20 units from the ITP 3-D Animation minor

synonyms: Enterprise Resource Planning, Design, and Implementation
ITP-454.title: Enterprise Resource Planning, Design, and Implementation
ITP-454.description: An in-depth look at the process and requirements necessary to implement an Enterprise Resource Planning System (ERP). Students will set up a server system, implement an ERP system, then transfer and configure a database for a case company.

ITP-457.title: Network Security
ITP-457.description: Network policy and mechanism, firewalls, malicious code; intrusion detection, prevention, response; cryptographic protocols for privacy; risks of misuse, cost of prevention, and societal issues.

ITP-460.title: Web Application Project
ITP-460.description: Analysis, planning, creation and maintenance of a web application are undertaken, using principles and practices of system development methodology.

ITP-499.title: Special Topics
ITP-499.description: Recent developments in computers and data processing. Not available for credit to CSCI and EE majors.

PTE-412.title: Petroleum Reservoir Engineering
PTE-412.description: Properties of reservoir fluids, volumetric and material balances for gas and oil reservoirs; reservoir modeling concepts. Lecture, 3 hours. Not available for credit to Petroleum Engineering majors. Prerequisite: 411.

PTE-464.title: Petroleum Reservoir Engineering
PTE-464.description: Properties of reservoir fluids, volumetric and material balances for gas and oil reservoirs; reservoir modeling concepts. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory 3 hours.

PTE-490.title: Directed Research
PTE-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

synonyms: Simulation of Subsurface Flow and Transport Processes
PTE-508.title: Simulation of Subsurface Flow and Transport Processes
PTE-508.description: Formulation and numerical solution of the equations describing the underground flow of fluids through porous media. Includes mass (contaminant) transport in single and multiphase flow.

PTE-517.title: Testing of Wells and Aquifers
PTE-517.description: Principles of well testing; down hole device; aquifer tests; slug tests; DST; pressure transient modeling in homogeneous and heterogeneous systems; parameter estimation; computer aided techniques.

PTE-542.title: Carbonate Rocks
PTE-542.description: Classification; porosity development; source rocks; wettability; capillary pressure curves; compressibility; surface areas; relative permeabilities; various petrophysical properties; formation evaluation; overpressures; thin section analysis.

synonyms: Well Completion, Stimulation, and Damage Control
PTE-555.title: Well Completion, Stimulation, and Damage Control
PTE-555.description: This course reviews current practices related to well completion methods, wellbore stimulation, and damage control. Formation damage prevention and stimulation methods are emphasized.

PTE-572.title: Engineering Geostatistics
PTE-572.description: Use of geostatistical methods for exploration and development of mineral and petroleum resources, application of semivariogram, kriging, cokriging, nonlinear and parametric estimation and conditional stimulation. Graduate standing.

synonyms: Smart Completions, Oilfield Sensors and Sensor Technology
PTE-587.title: Smart Completions, Oilfield Sensors and Sensor Technology
PTE-587.description: Intelligent Wellbore completion, technology of subsurface and surface sensors, deployment and data acquisition, telemonitoring and feedback, reliability of sensors, data transmission, systems networks. Recommended preparation: prerequisites for non-majors

PTE-590.title: Directed Research
PTE-590.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PTE-690.title: Directed Research
PTE-690.description: Laboratory study of specific problems for candidates for the degree Engineer in Petroleum Engineering.

PTE-790.title: Research
PTE-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

PTE-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PTE-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

SAE-549.title: Systems Architecting
SAE-549.description: Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace, electrical, computer, and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics.

SAE-551.title: Lean Operations
SAE-551.description: Study of lean principles and practices as applied to automotive, aerospace and other industries.

SAE-574.title: Net-Centric Systems Architecting and Engineering
SAE-574.description: In-depth examination of the technical design approaches, tools, and processes to enable the benefits of net-centric operations in networked systems-of-systems.

SAE-590.title: Directed Research
SAE-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

SAE-594A.title: Master's Thesis
SAE-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SAE-594B.title: Master's Thesis
SAE-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

SAE-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
SAE-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

ENGL-261.title: English Literature to 1800
ENGL-261.description: Intensive reading of major writers to 1800.

ENGL-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
ENGL-300O.description: Overseas Studies course; title of course offered at overseas institution appears as a section title.

ENGL-303.title: Introduction to Fiction Writing
ENGL-303.description: Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing prose fiction.

ENGL-304.title: Introduction to Poetry Writing
ENGL-304.description: Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing poetry.

ENGL-375.title: Science Fiction
ENGL-375.description: Investigation of the scope and possibilities of British and American science fiction as a genre, with some attention to its historical development.

ENGL-392.title: Visual and Popular Culture
ENGL-392.description: Course in the theory and practices of "popular culture," highlighting modern and comtemporary culture, film, video and popular music, as well as narrative forms.

ENGL-400.title: Advanced Expository Writing
ENGL-400.description: Intensive practice intended to develop a high level of competence in writing expository prose.

ENGL-405.title: Fiction Writing
ENGL-405.description: A practical course in composition of prose fiction.

ENGL-406.title: Poetry Writing
ENGL-406.description: A practical course in poetry writing.

ENGL-407.title: Advanced Fiction Writing
ENGL-407.description: Prerequisite: English 405 and/or consent of instructor.

ENGL-408.title: Advanced Poetry Writing
ENGL-408.description: Prerequisite: Acceptance of manuscript by instructor.

ENGL-409.title: The English Language
ENGL-409.description: Instruction in the major grammatical systems of the English language, with particular emphasis on their relevance to language activities in the elementary classroom.

synonyms: English Literature of the Middle Ages (1100-1500)
ENGL-420.title: English Literature of the Middle Ages (1100-1500)
ENGL-420.description: Selected studies in the major figures, genres, and themes of Middle English literature to Malory, with special emphasis on Chaucer.

ENGL-421.title: English Literature of the 16th Century
ENGL-421.description: Selected studies in the non-dramatic literature of Renaissance England, with emphasis on Sidney, Spencer, and Shakespeare.

ENGL-422.title: English Literature of the 17th Century
ENGL-422.description: Selected studies of prose and poetry in the age of Bacon, Donne, Jonson, Herbert, Browne, Marvell, and Milton.

ENGL-430.title: Shakespeare
ENGL-430.description: Major history plays, comedies, and tragedies.

ENGL-441.title: American Literature, 1865 to 1920
ENGL-441.description: American poetry and prose with special attention to Twain, James, Dickinson, Henry Adams, Crane, and Dreiser.

ENGL-442.title: American Literature, 1920 to the Present
ENGL-442.description: American poetry, fiction, and drama since World War I with special attention to Eliot, Frost, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, O'Neill, Stevens, Faulkner, and Nabokov.

ENGL-449.title: Asian American Literature
ENGL-449.description: Survey of Asian American literature from the earliest time to the present; development of prose, poetry, and novel.

synonyms: Periods and Genres in American Literature
ENGL-451.title: Periods and Genres in American Literature
ENGL-451.description: A concentrated reading and criticism of the works of one period or one genre of American literature; for example, colonial literature, the American Renaissance, American poetry, American drama.

ENGL-456.title: Contemporary Poetry
ENGL-456.description: Study of poetry written in English since 1945, with special emphasis on the last two decades.

ENGL-463.title: Contemporary Drama
ENGL-463.description: Selected British, Irish and American drama from the post World War II period (1945 to the present).
