ENGL-465.title: The English Novel to 1800
ENGL-465.description: Theory and practice of fiction in works of writers such as Defoe, Richardson, Fielding, Sterne, Burney, and Smollett.

ENGL-466.title: The 19th Century English Novel
ENGL-466.description: Theory and practice of fiction in works of major writers such as Austen, Dickens, Thackeray, George Eliot, Meredith, and Hardy.

ENGL-469.title: Women in English Literature before 1800
ENGL-469.description: English poetry, plays, novels, and discursive prose by and about women from 1375 to 1800.

ENGL-471.title: Literary Genres and Film
ENGL-471.description: Literary studies in the relationship between fiction and drama and their adaptation as films.

ENGL-473.title: Literature and Society
ENGL-473.description: Theoretical and applied studies of literature in English as social activity and cultural production; its expression of, and influence upon, social values, concepts, and behavior.

ENGL-474.title: Literature, Nationality and Otherness
ENGL-474.description: English Literature written about or in the British colonies and their post-colonial nations, including African, Asian, Pacific, and American countries. Emphasis on texts by other than British and United States authors. Completion of General Education Literature requirement highly advised.

synonyms: Images of Women in Contemporary Culture
ENGL-476.title: Images of Women in Contemporary Culture
ENGL-476.description: Representations of women and gender relations in contemporary literature and mass culture, using the tools of feminist, literary and political theory.

ENGL-478.title: Sexual/Textual Diversities
ENGL-478.description: Questions of gay and lesbian identity, expression and experience in a variety of literary and cultural forms; emphasis on sexual politics, equality and difference.

ENGL-479.title: History of Literary Criticism
ENGL-479.description: Philosophies of literary criticism from Plato to the end of the nineteenth century; the relationship between literary criticism and its contemporary literature.

ENGL-490.title: Directed Research
ENGL-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ENGL-496.title: Senior Honors Thesis
ENGL-496.description: Seminar in workshop form to accompany completion of Senior Honors Thesis. Bi-weekly meetings to complete thesis according to contract.

ENGL-520.title: Renaissance English Literatures and Cultures
ENGL-520.description: Studies in poetry and patronage, the popular tradition in literature and drama, the social and sexual dynamics of comedy, historical and cultural uses of genres, among other topics.

ENGL-540.title: 19th Century British Literatures and Cultures
ENGL-540.description: Studies in the Romantics and Victorians, gender and genre, the new woman and the novel, authorship and the marketplace, science, imperialism, the crisis of narrative, and other topics.

ENGL-580.title: 19th Century American Literatures and Cultures
ENGL-580.description: Studies in canonic and non-canonic literature in the American Renaissance, cultural nationalism, the consequences of race, immigration, expansion, urbanization, science, and marketplace, and other topics.

ENGL-590.title: Directed Research
ENGL-590.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL-591.title: 20th Century American Literatures and Cultures
ENGL-591.description: Studies in rural and urban fictions, modernism, the shift from imagism and symbolism to confessional poetry, recovered writers, hemispheric traditions, literature and kindred arts, and other topics.

ENGL-595.title: Literary Studies Across Cultures
ENGL-595.description: Studies in Empire and Commonwealth literatures, post-colonialism, American hemispheric connections, African-American discourse, Asian American writers, dialects and the folk, and other topics.

ENGL-630.title: Studies in Gender
ENGL-630.description: History and ideology of gender studies, feminist theory, gay and lesbian discourse, and other studies in feminisms and masculinities in relation to literature.

ENGL-640.title: Individual Writers
ENGL-640.description: Studies of major and minor, canonic and non-canonic writers.

ENGL-650.title: Multicultural Literary Studies
ENGL-650.description: Theories of race and ethnicity, cultural imperialism, discourse of power and class, literatures of the Americas, and other topics.

synonyms: Seminar in Genre and/or Narrative Theory
ENGL-679.title: Seminar in Genre and/or Narrative Theory
ENGL-679.description: Seminar in theoretical issues concerning genre and/or narrative as they pertain to media, literature, other cultural forms. Areas of focus vary from semester to semester. Departmental approval required.

ENGL-695.title: Graduate Fiction Form and Theory
ENGL-695.description: Seminar. Studies in fiction form and function or critical theory. Open only to Creative Writing Ph.D. degree candidates.

ENGL-696.title: Graduate Poetry Writing Workshop
ENGL-696.description: Intensive practicum in advanced level poetry writing, intended to develop high level creative compositional ability. Open only to Creative Writing Ph.D. degree candidates.

ENGL-790.title: Research
ENGL-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. GRADED CR/NC.

ENGL-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ENGL-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
ENGL-794Z.description: Credit upon acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

EXSC-202.title: Principles of Nutrition and Exercise
EXSC-202.description: Fundamental knowledge of proper nutrition for optimal health performance. Concepts of weight loss, gain; understanding of cardiorespiratory functioning. Laboratory experiments; body composition evaluation, energy metabolism. Laboratory, 2 hours.

EXSC-203.title: Individualized Exercise Prescription
EXSC-203.description: Principles and theories related to exercise prescription; programs of weight-training, circuit-training, aerobics, flexibility, high and low-intensity training guidelines; safeguards and effectiveness.

EXSC-205.title: The Science of Human Performance
EXSC-205.description: The physiological and nutritional basis of human performance. Factors that facilitate and limit athletic achievement. Lectures and laboratory. Not available for major credit.

synonyms: Drugs and Ergogenic Aids in Sport and Weight Control
EXSC-250.title: Drugs and Ergogenic Aids in Sport and Weight Control
EXSC-250.prereq_text: 1 from (BISC-220 or BISC-221) and 1 from (CHEM-105B or CHEM-115B)
EXSC-250.description: The course will evaluate drugs, nutritional supplements, and ergogenic aids that are purported to enhance human athletic performance to promote weight and fat loss.

EXSC-300.title: Physiology of Exercise
EXSC-300.description: Analysis of the neuromuscular system (anatomy, development, biochemistry, physiology and mechanics). Theories and principles of neuromuscular adaptations associated with acute and chronic exercise. Lecture, 3 hour; laboratory, 3 hours.

EXSC-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
EXSC-300O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution appears as a section title.

EXSC-301.title: Functional Anatomy
EXSC-301.description: Neuromuscular mechanisms involved in performance of skilled movements; analysis of body levers, movement patterns; prevention of injury; training programs; individual experiments. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 3 hours.

synonyms: Sociopsychological Aspects of Sport and Physical Activity
EXSC-310.title: Sociopsychological Aspects of Sport and Physical Activity
EXSC-310.description: Examination of the individual in a social environment related to sport and physical activity; personality, motivation, attitude, and group behavior viewed in physical activity contexts.

EXSC-407B.title: Advanced Exercise Physiology
EXSC-407B.description: Regulation of metabolic pathways and endocrinology in acute and chronic exercise. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 3 hours.

synonyms: Advanced Prevention and Care of Athletic Injuries
EXSC-442.title: Advanced Prevention and Care of Athletic Injuries
EXSC-442.description: Athletic injury assessment; principles, techniques and effects of therapeutic modalities and rehabilitative exercises.

EXSC-490.title: Directed Research
EXSC-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

EXSC-491.title: Laboratory Experience in Exercise Science
EXSC-491.prereq_text: (EXSC-200 and EXSC-203 and EXSC-300 and EXSC-301)
EXSC-491.description: Practical laboratory experience in basic and applied exercise physiology, biochemistry, and/or biomechanics. Emphasizing development of laboratory techniques.

synonyms: Experimental Studies of Human Performance II
EXSC-580A.title: Experimental Studies of Human Performance II

synonyms: Seminar on Lipid Metabolism and Exercise
EXSC-588.title: Seminar on Lipid Metabolism and Exercise
EXSC-588.description: Metabolism and utilization of lipids and fatty acids in skeletal muscles with applications to exercise. Recommended preparation: EXSC 300L.

EXSC-590.title: Directed Research
EXSC-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

EXSC-790.title: Research
EXSC-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC

EXSC-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
EXSC-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

ENST-100.title: Introduction to Environmental Studies
ENST-100.description: Gateway to the majors and minors in environmental studies. Provides students with an overview of how government agencies and societal institutions address (or fail to address) the interrelated social and scientific aspects of environmental problems and policies.

synonyms: Introduction to Applied Environmental Science and Engineering
ENST-201.title: Introduction to Applied Environmental Science and Engineering
ENST-201.description: Gateway to the B.S. in Civil Engineering (Environmental Engineering), B.S., Environmental Engineering, and minor in Environmental Engineering. Pollution control and remediation for air, water and soil. Pollution remediation for developing countries.

ENST-260L.title: Natural Hazards
ENST-260L.description: The nature and time/space distribution of extreme geophysical or biophysical events (e.g., floods, droughts, earthquakes, epizootics), and the range of technological and social adaptations to the resulting hazard.

ENST-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
ENST-300O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution appears as a section title.

ENST-360.title: Environmental Disasters
ENST-360.description: Evaluates the causes, effects, and responses to international environmental disasters. Emphasis is on contemporary case studies in a theoretical context.

ENST-373.title: Conservation Biology
ENST-373.prereq_text: 1 from (BISC-220 or BISC-221) and 1 from (BISC-120 or BISC-121)
ENST-373.description: Biological principles underlying conservation including ecology, evolution, genetics and biogeography. Covers both marine and terrestrial environments, with special emphasis on island biology. Catalina semester only. Recommended preparation: BISC 320L; BISC 313 or BISC 325

synonyms: Directed Governmental and Political Leadership Internship
ENST-396.title: Directed Governmental and Political Leadership Internship
ENST-396.description: Intensive experience in governmental and political offices. Minimum time requirement; evaluation by office and intern report required.

ENST-400.title: Environmental Engineering Principles
ENST-400.prereq_text: 1 from (CHEM-105B or CHEM-115B) and MATH-226 and PHYS-152
ENST-400.description: Analysis of water, air, and land pollution, including hazardous waste, and engineering of mitigation measures. Water and wastewater treatment systems.

synonyms: Public Policy, Management, and Planning Practices: Internship Seminar
ENST-401.title: Public Policy, Management, and Planning Practices: Internship Seminar
ENST-401.description: Seminar to accompany required internship related to public policy, management, and planning. Application of management and organizational concepts to workplace: reflection on experiences. Graded CR/NC.

ENST-487.title: Resource and Environmental Economics
ENST-487.description: Management and extraction of renewable and non-renewable natural resources; environmental externalities and regulation of air, water, and land pollution; market incentives versus direct regulation.

ENST-490.title: Directed Research
ENST-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

ENST-495.title: Senior Seminar in Environmental Studies
ENST-495.description: Students form multidisciplinary teams and are asked to study and resolve a major environmental problem facing a particular region or target population.

FA-100O.title: Off-Campus Studies
FA-100O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

FA-101A.title: Drawing
FA-101A.description: An introduction to drawing, both skill and perception oriented, as the basic tool for all the visual arts.

FA-101B.title: Drawing
FA-101B.description: An introduction to drawing, both skill and perception oriented, as the basic tool for all the visual arts.

FA-102.title: Design Fundamentals
FA-102.description: Introduction to the basic elements and processes of visual communication and design. Instruction includes studio projects, lectures and readings. Various media used.

FA-105.title: Painting I
FA-105.description: Practical introduction to oil and acrylic pigments, painting equipment, processes and media. Also, primary experience in: color, composition, and perception through representational and abstract painting.

FA-106.title: Sculpture I
FA-106.description: Practical and theoretical introduction to sculpture as dimensional manipulation. Primary exploration of form, mass, gravity, surface, structure and associative recognition in three-dimensional art.

FA-112.title: Ceramics
FA-112.description: Practical and theoretical exploration of the nature of surface, form, volume and mass as fundamental elements of clay sculpture and the ceramic object.

FA-136.title: Modeling and Mold Making
FA-136.description: Introduction to plaster mold making using clay and wax for both ceramics and sculpture. Exploration of various casting materials. (Duplicates credit in FA 208x.)

synonyms: A Cultural Guide to Los Angeles
FA-140.title: A Cultural Guide to Los Angeles
FA-140.description: An experiential and critical survey of the cultural phenomena that make up Los Angeles: dance, music, theater, film; emphasis on visual arts. Graded CR/NC. Not available for major credit to fine arts majors.

FA-150.title: Visual Culture and Literacy I
FA-150.description: Introduction to modern and contemporary visual culture with emphasis on the major aesthetic theories and practices of the past hundred and fifty years.

FA-201A.title: Life Drawing
FA-201A.description: An introduction to the representation and depiction of the human form. emphasis on anatomical, compositional, gestural, environmental and interpretive drawing.

FA-201B.title: Life Drawing
FA-201B.description: An introduction to the representation and depiction of the human form. Emphasis on anatomical, compositional, gestural, environmental and interpretive drawing.

FA-202.title: Design II
FA-202.description: Exploration of essential elements of traditional and digital design, including color and image-text integration, editing information, typography and sequencing.

FA-203.title: Digital Tools for Design
FA-203.description: Exploration of the processes of germination, ideation and application/execution in design integrated with computer usage.

FA-205A.title: Painting II
FA-205A.description: A continuation of the practical and theoretical skills introduced in Painting I. Color as an issue in personal expression and perception; color as content, cultural and social subjects/objects, symbols, and to signify a personal language.

FA-205B.title: Painting II
FA-205B.description: A continuation of the practical and theoretical skills introduced in Painting I. Color as an issue in personal expression and perception; color as content, cultural and social subjects/objects, symbols, and to signify a personal language.

FA-206.title: Sculpture II
FA-206.description: Continued examination of the concepts of three-dimensional art; interrelation of material and image on a public, human and intimate scale.

FA-207A.title: Two-Dimensional Art Workshop
FA-207A.description: Studio practice to develop standards of judgment and appreciation of the visual arts. Not available for credit to studio majors.

FA-207B.title: Two-Dimensional Art Workshop
FA-207B.description: Continuation of 207ax. Not available for credit to studio majors.

FA-208A.title: Three-Dimensional Art Workshop
FA-208A.description: Studio practice to develop standards of judgment and appreciation of the visual arts. Not available for credit to studio majors.

FA-209A.title: Photography
FA-209A.description: Introduction to the practice of photographic image making within a fine arts context. Emphasis on the development of technical skills in relation to personal vision. Work is in black and white.

FA-209B.title: Photography
FA-209B.description: Introduction to the practice of photographic image making within a fine arts context. Emphasis on the development of technical skills in relation to personal vision. Work is in black and white.

FA-210.title: Introduction to Digital Photography
FA-210.description: An introductory course exploring the processes and practices of digital capture, imaging and printing, from web-based image posting to large-scale printing. (Duplicates credit in former FA 210a.)

FA-213.title: Clay and Glazes
FA-213.description: Provides a foundation in clay and glaze materials as they relate to making ceramic art.

synonyms: Introduction to Digital Video and Interactivity
FA-215.title: Introduction to Digital Video and Interactivity
FA-215.description: A course in digital imaging, which through studio practice and critical inquiry, explores the implications and potential of digitally-based image making. (Duplicates credit in former FA 210b.)

FA-246.title: Construction Techniques
FA-246.description: Exploration of art fabrication and the techniques and philosophies of working with a variety of materials. Recommended preparation: FA 106

FA-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
FA-300O.description: Off-campus studies; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

FA-301.title: Advanced Drawing
FA-301.description: Directed examination of personal approaches in drawing; emphasis on making visual and artistic decisions and developing an appropriate attitude towards individual expression.

FA-302.title: Design III
FA-302.description: Advanced exploration of typography and image-text integration, including collaborative projects, pre-press and proofing techniques, narrative concepts and information architecture.

FA-305.title: Advanced Painting
FA-305.description: Directed examination of aesthetic concepts; investigation into personal ideas related to the development of a creative visual language in painting.

FA-309.title: Advanced Photography
FA-309.description: Continuation of the practice of photographic image making within a fine arts context, furthering technical and conceptual abilities. Continuation of critical readings.

FA-310.title: Digital Photo Studio
FA-310.description: A technically and conceptually intensive studio in 2-D imaging/ photography.

FA-311.title: Printmaking
FA-311.description: Introductory course in various printmaking techniques; necessary skills and inherent expressive qualities of different printmaking methods are explored.

FA-312.title: Advanced Ceramics
FA-312.description: Directed examination of aesthetic concepts and investigation into personal ideas as they relate to the development of a creative visual language in ceramics.

FA-320.title: Video Studio
FA-320.description: An intensive video studio in the understanding and method of time-based, narrative and non-narrative art.

FA-330.title: Ideas in Intermedia
FA-330.description: An examination of the impact of digital media on contemporary culture, with attention to a particular, changing topic each semester.

synonyms: The Human Figure in Narrative Drawing
FA-331.title: The Human Figure in Narrative Drawing
FA-331.description: An introduction to visual storytelling in both its historical and contemporary contexts. Emphasis on aesthetic, conceptual and technical skills for figurative narration.

FA-332.title: Typography
FA-332.description: The study of visual communication through the use of letterforms from historical tradition to contemporary experimental rebellion.

FA-350.title: Art Theory and Criticism
FA-350.description: An intellectual framework for the practice of artmaking; the historical context for current ideas.

FA-401.title: Topics in Advanced Drawing
FA-401.description: Continued directed examination of personal approaches in drawing, emphasis on making visual and artistic decisions and developing an appropriate attitude towards visual expression.

FA-402.title: Advanced Design Projects
FA-402.description: Advanced information design within a flexible curriculum. Emphasis on team-oriented projects.

FA-405.title: Topics in Advanced Painting
FA-405.description: Directed painting with continued emphasis on personal choices regarding the appropriation of conceptual images and arrangement, material processes scale, number of paintings. Ongoing critical response to paintings.

FA-409.title: Topics in Advanced Photography
FA-409.description: In-depth exploration of photographic and artistic concepts as they apply to the articulation of personal work.

FA-411.title: Topics in Advanced Printmaking
FA-411.description: Directed examination of specific printmaking media in relation to personal aesthetic goals and expressive concepts.

FA-412.title: Topics in Advanced Ceramics
FA-412.description: Directed examination of aesthetic concepts and investigation into personal ideas as they relate to the development of a creative visual language in ceramics.

FA-418.title: Independent Studies in Studio Arts
FA-418.description: Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required. Recommended preparation: appropriate 300-level course work

FA-419.title: Professional Internship in the Arts
FA-419.description: An experiential/academic opportunity in a museum, gallery, community cultural center, or related facility. Lectures, seminars, written analysis, and working internship. Open to upper division Fine Arts majors.

FA-432.title: Special Projects in Design
FA-432.description: Students work on projects for outside clients, and receive instruction in professional practices, advanced design techniques, and sophisticated technology. By invitation or portfolio review only. Only open to upper division students.

FA-436.title: Art and Technology
FA-436.description: An interdisciplinary course between art and engineering that addresses creative thinking in the manipulation of media and the communication of ideas. (Duplicates credit in former FA 336.)

FA-450.title: Senior Seminar
FA-450.description: Contemporary professional issues facing the studio artist; current directions in the visual arts; forces and attitudes affecting the practicing artist in our society. Available for credit to Fine Arts majors only.

FA-499.title: Special Topics
FA-499.description: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of visual art.

FA-515.title: Visiting Artist Forum
FA-515.description: Lecture and discussion course in the professional practice of art featuring formal presentations by visiting artists.

FA-520.title: Individual Studies . . .
FA-520.description: Investigation of creative problems through various media. Course may be repeated; maximum number of units to be determined by advisor.

FA-550.title: Seminar: Contemporary Issues
FA-550.description: Study of issues relative to current directions in the visual arts; analysis and implications of forces contributing to conceptual development.

FA-560.title: Studies in Two-Dimensional Media

FREN-320.description: Film-making in France from the earliest experiments to current trends. Emphasis on the political, social, historical context of French films. Taught in English. Reading knowledge of French recommended.

FREN-330.description: Critical reading of literary texts; comprehensive analysis of difficult grammatical structures and stylistics; advanced composition. Recommended preparation: FREN 300

FREN-352.description: Study of the major intellectual, artistic and sociopolitical trends that have shaped French culture from the Revolution to the present. Conducted in French. Recommended preparation: FREN 300 or FREN 310

FREN-464.description: Selected topics such as the press, educational institutions, French cinema today, and French colonial history. Conducted in French. Recommended preparation: FREN 351 or FREN 352

FREN-472.description: Study of the major figures of the Enlightenment: Prevost, Montesquieu, Voltaire, Diderot, Rousseau, and others. Conducted in French. Recommended preparation: FREN 330

FREN-473.description: Texts selected from the works of Balzac, Stendhal, Flaubert, Zola, Hugo, Musset, and Baudelaire, illustrating the century's major literary movements. Conducted in French. Recommended preparation: FREN 330

FREN-474.description: Representative novels, plays, and essays exemplifying such movements as Modernism, Surrealism, Existentialism, the Theatre of the Absurd, and Post-modernism. Conducted in French. Recommended preparation: FREN 330

FREN-490.title: Directed Research
FREN-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

FREN-552.title: Raison et Deraison II

FREN-602.description: Seminar on reason and unreason in literature and the arts in French and Francophone cultures. Topics will vary.

SWMS-140.description: Application of philosophical theories in ethics to problems such as racial and sexual discrimination, I.Q., and social justice, rights of animals, law and morality, and privacy.

SWMS-210.title: Social Issues in Gender
SWMS-210.description: Multidisciplinary survey of gender assumptions in relation to sexuality, mental health, social and political relations, and artistic expression.

synonyms: Gender and Sexualities in American History
SWMS-245.title: Gender and Sexualities in American History
SWMS-245.description: An investigation of the nature of femininities and masculinities over the course of U.S. history; including topics like women's rights, birth control, abortion, and gay/lesbian liberation.

SWMS-300O.title: Off-Campus Studies
SWMS-300O.description: Cousreseowrk taken off campus. Title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

synonyms: Introduction to Feminist Theory and the Women's and Men's Movements
SWMS-301.title: Introduction to Feminist Theory and the Women's and Men's Movements
SWMS-301.description: Theories of feminism; historical, social and cultural perspectives of the women's movement in America, Europe, and in developing countries; men's roles in the feminist movement.

synonyms: Gender Studies and the Community: Internship
SWMS-311.title: Gender Studies and the Community: Internship
SWMS-311.description: A combination of internships in the community and an intensive seminar on the relationship of the students in the academic community with the larger urban community of which it is a part.

SWMS-316.title: Gender and Global Issues
SWMS-316.description: An examination of the role women have played in world politics focusing on issues of war and peace, the environment and the global economy.

synonyms: Culture, Gender and Politics in South Asia: Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, Nepal
SWMS-330.title: Culture, Gender and Politics in South Asia: Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, Nepal
SWMS-330.description: Examination of violence, identity, law, religion, nationalism, development, caste, kinship, gender, and the South Asian diaspora.

SWMS-336.title: Health, Gender and Ethnicity
SWMS-336.description: Cross-cultural notions of the body, health, and healing; historic and cultural variability of ideas of reproduction, birth, sexuality, mental illness, and disability.

synonyms: The Family in a Changing Society
SWMS-369.title: The Family in a Changing Society
SWMS-369.description: Changing family patterns; personality development; family unity, predicting success in marriage; the family in transition; crises such as economic changes, death, divorce; family reorganization.

synonyms: Family and Kinship in Cross-Cultural Perspective
SWMS-370.title: Family and Kinship in Cross-Cultural Perspective
SWMS-370.description: Comparative examination of family and kinship in tribal, peasant, and complex societies, emphasizing non-Western cultures, societal and normative consequences of forms and functions in family.

synonyms: Women Writers in Europe and America
SWMS-374.title: Women Writers in Europe and America
SWMS-374.description: Introduction to works of major women writers from the Middle Ages to the 20th century in their literary, social, and cultural contexts.

SWMS-381.title: Sex, Power, and Politics
SWMS-381.description: An evaluation of the ways in which different ideologies, institutions, and policies contribute to differences in political power between men and women.

SWMS-385.title: Men and Masculinity
SWMS-385.description: Interdisciplinary examination of social, personal meanings of masculinity; variety of male experience by social class, race, sexuality, and age; emerging masculinities of the future.

SWMS-395.title: Gender, Media and Communication
SWMS-395.description: Issues of gender in communication, including: media representations of femininity and masculinity; and gender's role in communication at the interpersonal, public, and cultural levels.

SWMS-410.title: Senior Seminar in Gender Studies
SWMS-410.description: Study of a selected problem, period, or theme in the study of women and men in society by integrating perspectives from cross-cultural and interdisciplinary studies.

SWMS-412.title: Gender, Sexuality and Media
SWMS-412.description: Examines how gender and sexuality are figured in cinema and television with an emphasis on the development of feminist media theory.

SWMS-415.title: Ecofeminism
SWMS-415.description: Examination of the philosophy and politics of Ecofeminism. It will critique the ideologies that link the oppression of women to the exploitation of nature. Recommended preparation: 210g or 301g.

SWMS-456.title: Women in International Development
SWMS-456.description: How various developmental theories analyze the role of women as producers and how Third World women are increasing their role in development.

synonyms: Gender in Media Industries and Products
SWMS-465.title: Gender in Media Industries and Products
SWMS-465.description: Examination of the effect of gender stratification in media industries upon the cultural products they create, especially gender and gender/race role portrayals.

SWMS-467.title: Gender and the News Media
SWMS-467.description: Gender and news media evolving images of women and men in print and electronic media. Impact of gender in content and style of news, television and cinema. Open to non-majors.

SWMS-469.title: Women in English Literature before 1800
SWMS-469.description: English poetry, plays, novels, and discursive prose by and about women from 1375 to 1800.

SWMS-478.title: Sexual/Textual Diversities
SWMS-478.description: Questions of gay and lesbian identity, expression and experience in a variety of literary and cultural forms; emphasis on sexual politics, equality and difference.

SWMS-490.title: Directed Research
SWMS-490.description: Independent research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

SWMS-499.title: Special Topics

SWMS-516.description: Implications of feminist theory for communication; topics include epistemology, critique of science/technology, women and language, feminist approaches to media and film, women and the workplace. Not open to M.A. in Communication Management majors.

SWMS-560.title: Feminist Theory
SWMS-560.description: History of feminist theory and major perspectives of current feminist theory: liberal feminism, socialist/Marxist feminism, radical feminism, psychological feminism, spiritual feminism, and ecological feminism.

SWMS-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree in cognate fields. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

Limited to freshmen and sophomores. (Duplicates credit in ARLT 101 and in former LTA 100 and in former LTA 101.)

ARLT-101.description: Critical analysis of significant works of literature, philosophy, visual arts, music and/or film; intensive reading and writing to develop knowledge of analytical techniques in the humanities. Limited to students with sophomore status or higher. Duplicates credit in ARLT-100.

GERO-340.description: How Americans' political values affect public policy. Studies of landmark legislation to explore the social contract between generations and role of governments in social welfare.

GERO-380.title: Diversity in Aging
GERO-380.description: Exploring diversity in the older population and variability in the human aging process.

GERO-414.title: Neurobiology of Aging
GERO-414.description: Age-related changes in nervous system structure and function; relationship of brain changes to changes in cognitive function and perception; Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. Lecture and discussion.

GERO-416.title: Health Issues in Adulthood
GERO-416.description: Physiological, psychological, and social health problems of adults as they are impacted by health choices throughout life.

synonyms: Social and Psychological Aspects of Death and Dying
GERO-437.title: Social and Psychological Aspects of Death and Dying
GERO-437.description: Introduction and critical survey of the current issues, concepts, and research of the social and psychological aspects of death and dying.

synonyms: Ethical Issues in Geriatric Health Care
GERO-475.title: Ethical Issues in Geriatric Health Care
GERO-475.description: Biomedical ethical issues that are encountered in working with geriatric patients. Examination of ethical theory and the application of theory to clinical settings.

GERO-481.title: Case Management for Older Adults
GERO-481.description: Overview of the concepts, characteristics, skills, and clinical issues of case management in a variety of settings serving older persons.

GERO-490.title: Directed Research
GERO-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

GERO-491.title: Practicum
GERO-491.description: Supervised experience in one or more community agencies. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-492.title: Senior Seminar
GERO-492.description: An in-depth integration of major research and professional themes in the study of human development and aging.

GERO-495.title: Practicum in Geriatric Care
GERO-495.description: Supervised experience in a geriatric health care setting which allows students to put theories and ideas into practive. Graded CR/NC. Lecture, discussion, and fieldwork.

GERO-496.title: Introduction to Clinical Geriatrics
GERO-496.description: Medical problems of older adults emphasizing common geriatric syndromes, chronic illness, and alternative approaches to primary health care of older persons and their families. Upper division standing.

GERO-497A.title: Honors Seminar
GERO-497A.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology. Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior Honors Thesis research. Standing in Gerontology Honors Program and departmental approval.

GERO-497B.title: Honors Seminar
GERO-497B.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology. Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior Honors Thesis research. Standing in Gerontology Honors Program and departmental approval.

GERO-497C.title: Honors Seminar
GERO-497C.description: Advanced study of empirical approaches in gerontology. Preparation, progress, presentation, and evaluation of Senior Honors Thesis research. Standing in Gerontology Honors Program and departmental approval.

GERO-500.title: Perspectives on Aging: An Introduction
GERO-500.description: A web based course analyzing physical, mental, and social age-related changes as well as implications of population aging trends for individuals and society.

GERO-510.title: Physiology of Development and Aging
GERO-510.description: Examination of lifespan physiology of human development, growth, and aging; major emphasis in the physiology of the later years and implications for health maintenance.

GERO-513.title: Stress, Health, and Aging
GERO-513.description: A presentation of the importance of controlling stressful interaction. Aging is accelerated by stress induced disorders of regulation such as high blood pressure and arteriosclerosis.

GERO-519.title: Biological Processes and Aging
GERO-519.description: Theories of the biology of aging and the effects of age on functional integrity of the total organism.

synonyms: Counseling Older Adults and Their Families
GERO-522.title: Counseling Older Adults and Their Families
GERO-522.description: Theory and application of assessment and intervention techniques with older adults and their families. Topics include: treatment modalities, psychopathology, ethical and legal issues, brain disorders.

GERO-540.title: Social Policy and Aging
GERO-540.description: Major legislation and programs; examination and analysis of policy-making and political processes affecting development and implementation of programs for older persons.

synonyms: Administration and System Management in Programs for Older Adults
GERO-550.title: Administration and System Management in Programs for Older Adults
GERO-550.description: Application of theories of administration and system management to public and volunteer programs and services for older adults including residential institutions and community programs.

GERO-555.title: Integrating Gerontology: A Multidisciplinary Approach
GERO-555.description: Aging (commonalities and distinctions) as addressed by biologists, psychologists, and sociologists. Topics include research perspectives, normative agings, functional decline and disability, and aging and society.

synonyms: Complementary Medicine for Health and Longevity
GERO-560.title: Complementary Medicine for Health and Longevity
GERO-560.description: Alternative healing practices and complementary medicine including Eastern medicine, herbal therapies, vitamin and dietary supplements for general health and specific diseases in aging. Open to graduate students or undergraduate students with senior standing for undergraduate credit. Recommended preparation: GERO 500

GERO-585.title: The Aging Family
GERO-585.description: Family processes and structure in families with aged persons will be reviewed, including marital and family therapy and intervention strategies.

GERO-589.title: Professional Issues in Gerontology
GERO-589.description: An introduction to the concepts, attitudes, values, knowledge, skills, and ethical issues upon which professional practice in gerontology is based.

GERO-590.title: Directed Research
GERO-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-591Z.title: Field Practicum
GERO-591Z.description: Supervised experiential learning in one or more organizations that serve older adults; includes a regularly scheduled seminar. Graded IP/CR/NC.

GERO-592.title: Multidisciplinary Research Seminar in Aging
GERO-592.description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on current research in Gerontology including physiology, neurobiology, health and medicine, psychology, sociology and public policy. Topics will change each semester.

GERO-594A.title: Master's Thesis
GERO-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-594B.title: Master's Thesis
GERO-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
GERO-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-790.title: Research
GERO-790.description: Research leading up to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied toward the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

GERO-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
GERO-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Foundations in Health Education and Promotion
PM-501.title: Foundations in Health Education and Promotion
PM-501.description: Overview and application of behavioral theories to the field of health education and promotion. Examines the determinants of health behaviro and strategies for change at the individual, group and community level.

synonyms: Health Service Delivery in the U.S.
PM-508.title: Health Service Delivery in the U.S.
PM-508.description: Historical development of the American health care system; determinants of health care utilization; role of health care providers; health policy; public health services; and health care finance.

PM-509.title: Comparative Health Care Systems
PM-509.description: Macro-level analysis of the structure and delivery of health care services around the world, including an examination and comparison of health system performance.

PM-510.title: Principles of Biostatistics
PM-510.description: Concepts of biostatistics; appropriate uses and common misuses of health statistics; practice in the application of statistical procedures; introduction to statistical software including EXCEL, SPSS, nQuery. Laboratory.

PM-511A.title: Data Analysis
PM-511A.description: Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

PM-511B.title: Data Analysis
PM-511B.description: Exploratory data analysis, detection of outliers, fitting data with linear and nonlinear regression models, computer packages including S-PLUS and SPSS.

PM-512.title: Principles of Epidemiology
PM-512.description: Terminology/uses of epidemiology and demography; sources/uses of population data; types of epidemiologic studies; risk assessment; common sources of bias in population studies; principles of screening. Recommended preparation: algebra

PM-513.title: Experimental Designs
PM-513.description: Statistical methods for analysis of various experimental designs. Parametric analysis of variance (ANOVA), repeated measures methods, crossover designs, non-parametric ANOVA.

PM-516A.title: Statistical Problem Solving
PM-516A.description: An overview of the tools used by statisticians for solving statistical problems. Graded CR/NC.

PM-516B.title: Statistical Problem Solving
PM-516B.description: An overview of the tools used by statisticians for solving statistical problems. Graded CR/NC.

PM-517B.title: Research Methods in Cancer Epidemiology
PM-517B.description: Overview of epidemiological research in cancer. Selected cancer sites will be covered to highlight study design and conduct, exposure assessment, data analysis and interpretation.

PM-518A.title: Statistical Methods for Epidemiological Studies
PM-518A.description: Principles and methods used in epidemiology for comparing disease frequencies between groups. Restricted to the analysis of binary outcome variables. Prerequisite: PM 512.

PM-519.title: Introduction to Human Nutrition
PM-519.description: Dietary role of carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, vitamins, and minerals in metabolism; nutritional assessment; nutritional deficiencies. Focus on the role of nutrition in the prevention and treatment of chronic disease. Recommended preparation: PM 530

PM-523.title: Design of Clinical Studies
PM-523.description: Design, conduct, and interpretation of results of clinical trials; emphasis on structure, size, duration of a trial, and the impact of ethical and practical considerations. Prereq: PM 511L & 513.

PM-524A.title: Practicum in Health Behavior
PM-524A.description: Practical experience in a variety of field settings to gain a certain type of skill such as curriculum development, media production, and patient education. Practicum in prevention. Recommended preparation PM-500.

PM-524B.title: Practicum in Health Behavior
PM-524B.description: Practical experience in a variety of field settings to gain a certain type of skill such as curriculum development, media production, and patient education. Practicum in compliance.

PM-524C.title: Practicum in Health Behavior
PM-524C.description: Practical experience in a variety of field settings to gain a certain type of skill such as curriculum development, media production, and patient education. Practicum in Health Behavior topics.

PM-526.title: Communications in Public Health
PM-526.description: Application of communication theories and methods to community health problems. Includes background assessment, program design, evaluation, social marketing, media advocacy, review of major health campaigns. Recommended preparation: PM 500

synonyms: The Epidemiology of Infectious Disease and Injury
PM-527.title: The Epidemiology of Infectious Disease and Injury
PM-527.description: Survey of natural history of infectious disease, methods of disease control and outbreak investigation, and an overview of the epidemiology of injury.

PM-528.title: Program Design and Evaluation
PM-528.description: Core concepts, methods and values of public health program planning and evaluation, including community needs assessment, writing objectives, designing health promotion programs, process and outcome evaluation. Recommended preparation: PM 500

PM-529.title: Environmental Health: An Epidemiological Approach
PM-529.description: An overview of environmental health, identifying issues in assessing effects of exposure on health and potential interventions for reducing adverse health risks.

PM-530.title: Biological Basis of Disease
PM-530.description: With a physiological overview, dfferentiates genetic and environmental disease; emphasis on the relationships between lifestyle, behavior, and health.

PM-531.title: Research Methods in Nutrition
PM-531.description: In-depth discussion of nutrition research including nutrition assessment, measurement of dietary intake, study design, statistical issues, critical appraisal, and translation into practice. Open to M.P.H. nutrition track students only.

PM-534.title: Statistical Genetics
PM-534.description: Familial aggregation, segregation analysis, linkage analysis, association, regressive models, gene-environment interactions, genetic heterogeneity and linkage disequilibrium.

PM-540.title: Maternal and Child Nutrition
PM-540.description: Physiological basis for good nutrition during pregnancy and childhood through adolescence. Design, implementation and evaluation of public health nutrition programs serving women and children. Recommended preparation: PM 530.

PM-542.title: Social Network Analysis
PM-542.description: Theory, methods and procedures of network analysis with emphasis on applications to public health programs.

synonyms: Intervention Approaches for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
PM-562.title: Intervention Approaches for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
PM-562.description: Approaches for modifying health behavior in varioius settings and within diverse populations. Emphasis on practical considerations necessary to design and implement interventions with demonstrated effectiveness.

synonyms: Emerging Trends in Global Health: A Public Health Seminar
PM-565.title: Emerging Trends in Global Health: A Public Health Seminar
PM-565.description: Current public health issues and research topics relating to 21st century challenges and threats. Lessons learned and best practices to strengthen public health systems and enhance public health readiness and preparedness.

synonyms: Public Health in China: A System and Country in Transition
PM-566.title: Public Health in China: A System and Country in Transition
PM-566.description: Scientific, political, economic, social, and historical influences affecting Chinese public health policy and practice. Recommended preparation: PM 512.

synonyms: Applied Statistical Methods in Human Genetics
PM-570.title: Applied Statistical Methods in Human Genetics
PM-570.description: An introductory course in the statistical methods used in the analysis of human genetic data.

PM-571.title: Applied Logistic Regression
PM-571.prereq_text: (PM-510 and PM-512) and 1 from (PM-511A or PM-518A)
PM-571.description: An introduction to the logistic regression model, emphasizing practical data analysis techniques.

PM-573.title: Systems Physiology and Disease II
PM-573.description: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on neuroscience, immunology, metabolism, endocrine, reproduction, GI and liver. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences. Open to graduate students in biomedical science only. Recommended preparation: undergraduate degree in a biological science.

PM-580.title: Foundations of Child Health
PM-580.description: Overview of issues related to infant, child, and adolescent health, including special health considerations at different points in the developmental cycle, health care systems and policies, and health disparities.

PM-585.title: Child Health Policy
PM-585.description: History of child health and social welfare programs during the past century. Issues examining health status and health service delivery, the role of health care financing, and health policy.

PM-590.title: Directed Research
PM-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PM-593.title: Public Health Practicum
PM-593.description: Field placement in a community agency, such as a county hospital department or community-based organization. Open to MPH candidates only. Graded CR/NC. Recommended preparation: completion of all coursework.

PM-594A.title: Master's Thesis
PM-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM-594B.title: Master's Thesis
PM-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
PM-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM-599.title: Special Topics
PM-599.description: Special topics relevant to the study of selected issues and areas of health behavior research or other aspects of preventive medicine.

synonyms: Basic Theory and Strategies in Prevention
PM-601.title: Basic Theory and Strategies in Prevention
PM-601.description: Psychosocial basis of health-hazardous lifestyle behaviors and preventive strategies. Recommended preparation PM-500, PM 515

PM-604.title: Health Behavior Research Methods
PM-604.description: Health research/evaluation philosophies, approaches and development of skills for development and critique of health behavior research projects/studies. Recommended preparation PM-511.

PM-610.title: Seminar in Biostatistics and Epidemiology
PM-610.description: Special topics of current interest to provide background for research in biostatistics and epidemiology. Based largely on student dissertation research. Graded CR/NC.

PM-690A.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM-690A.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the field of Health Behavior. Recommended preparation PM 604.

PM-690B.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM-690B.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the field of Health Behavior.

PM-690C.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM-690C.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the field of Health Behavior.

PM-690D.title: Directed Research in Health Behavior
PM-690D.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the field of Health Behavior.

PM-690Z.title: Directed Research In Health Behavior
PM-690Z.description: Independent research at an advanced level on a problem in the field of health behavior.

PM-756.title: Research Seminar in Health Behavior
PM-756.description: Short seminar presentations and discussions on issues accompanying the development of the field of health behavior and implementation of research in this field.

PM-790.title: Research
PM-790.description: Research applicable to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PM-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PM-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PM-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PM-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PM-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

HEBR-100O.title: Off-Campus Studies
HEBR-100O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

HEBR-150O.title: Off-Campus Studies
HEBR-150O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

HEBR-315.title: Biblical Hebrew Literature (Hebrew IV)
HEBR-315.description: Introduction to biblical Hebrew style through reading of selected biblical texts; examination of linguistic and literary aspects.

synonyms: Honors in Multimedia Scholarship: The Languages of New Media I
IML-101.title: Honors in Multimedia Scholarship: The Languages of New Media I
IML-101.description: An introduction to the history, theory, and languages of new media. Open to students in the Honors Program in Multimedia Scholarship only. Recommended preparation: CTCS 191 or CSCI 102L

synonyms: Honors in Multimedia Scholarship: The Languages of New Media II
IML-104.title: Honors in Multimedia Scholarship: The Languages of New Media II
IML-104.description: An introduction to the expressive range of screen languages in their cultural, historical, and technological contexts. Open to students in the Honors Program in Multimedia Scholarship only.

synonyms: Honors in Multimedia Scholarship: Methods in Scholarly Multimedia
IML-346.title: Honors in Multimedia Scholarship: Methods in Scholarly Multimedia
IML-346.description: Emphasizing student multimedia authorship, this course explores the impact of multimedia on disciplinary conventions. Concurrent with upper division course with research component in student's major/minor. Open to students in the Honors Program in Multimedia Scholarship only.

synonyms: Honors in Multimedia Scholarship: Multimedia Honors Thesis Project II
IML-444.title: Honors in Multimedia Scholarship: Multimedia Honors Thesis Project II
IML-444.description: Production of Multimedia Honors thesis. Open to students in the Honors Program in Multimedia Scholarship only.

IML-490.title: Directed Research
IML-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

INDS-100.title: Topical and Multidisciplinary Seminars
INDS-100.description: Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.

INDS-101.title: Directed Research and Tutorials
INDS-101.description: Research and Study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.

INDS-102.title: Field Study
INDS-102.description: In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.

INDS-300.title: Topical and Multidisciplinary Seminars
INDS-300.description: Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.

INDS-301.title: Directed Research and Tutorials
INDS-301.description: Research and study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.

INDS-302.title: Field Study
INDS-302.description: In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.

INDS-400.title: Topical and Multidisciplinary Seminars
INDS-400.description: Small group investigation from an interdisciplinary perspective.

INDS-401.title: Directed Research and Tutorials
INDS-401.description: Research and study with LAS Faculty Associates and other faculty.

INDS-402.title: Field Study
INDS-402.description: In-service experience in a variety of off-campus institutions under the supervision of an LAS Faculty Associate.

INDS-494.title: Senior Thesis
INDS-494.description: Writing the IDM senior thesis under the supervision of a faculty guidance committee.

IR-212.title: Historical Approaches to International Relations
IR-212.description: Introduction to historical research methods, emphasizing historical texts and modes of discourse. Recommended preparation: IR 210.

IR-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
IR-300O.description: Off-campus studies; title of course offered at off-campus instittion appears as a section title.

synonyms: International Relations of the Great Powers in the Late 19th and 20th Centuries
IR-302.title: International Relations of the Great Powers in the Late 19th and 20th Centuries
IR-302.description: Introductory analysis of the interactions of the great powers during the period; initial focus on Europe, with expansion to include global relations.

IR-303.title: Leadership and Diplomacy
IR-303.description: The role of leaders, diplomatic leadership and creativity in statecraft, providing a deep understanding of the theoretical and practical dimensions of diplomacy.

IR-305.title: Managing New Global Challenges
IR-305.description: Examines the strategies for managing global issues in the post Cold War period. Explores ways that international institutions, national governments and non-state actors work separately and together to provide order and control over complex international issues areas. Issues that will receive attention could include financial and monetary relations, trade and foreign investment, preservation of the environment, the spread of weapons of mass destruction, population and migration, terrorism and ethnic strife.

IR-316.title: Gender and Global Issues
IR-316.description: An examination of the role women have played in world politics focusing on issues of war and peace, the environment and the global economy.

IR-318.title: Conflict Resolution and Peace Research
IR-318.description: Processes of conflict, violence, change, integration, stability, and peace in world society, analyzed primarily through the literature of the peace research movement.

synonyms: Rich and Poor States in the World Political Economy
IR-325.title: Rich and Poor States in the World Political Economy
IR-325.description: Dynamic inequality in relations between rich and poor; contending views on causes; legacies of imperialism; ameliorative strategies of poor states; responses of richer states.

IR-344.title: Developing Countries in World Politics
IR-344.description: Origin, concepts, realities, and ideals of the non-aligned movement, focusing on the United States' role in the developing world.

synonyms: Foreign Policy of Eastern Europe and the Balkans
IR-346.title: Foreign Policy of Eastern Europe and the Balkans
IR-346.description: Analysis of contemporary foreign policy issues in East-Central Europe, including inter- and intra-state conflict, peacekeeping, NATO and EU enlargement, cross-border minorities and refugees.

synonyms: International Relations of the Pacific Rim
IR-360.title: International Relations of the Pacific Rim
IR-360.description: Political, economic, military, and territorial issues in East Asia and the Pacific and the role of the United States, Russia, China, and Japan.

IR-367.title: Africa in International Affairs
IR-367.description: General overview of main historical, political, and economic issues as they affect Africa, focusing on nationalism, development, and superpower competition in Africa.

synonyms: French Foreign Policy: 1945 to the Present
IR-368.title: French Foreign Policy: 1945 to the Present
IR-368.description: Introduction to historical, thematic perspectives of French foreign policy since 1945 including review of external and internal constraints influencing foreign policy.

IR-381.title: Introduction to International Security
IR-381.description: Alternative conceptions of security; evolution of nuclear strategy; efforts to control the development and spread of nuclear and conventional weapons; current security issues.

IR-383.title: Third World Negotiations
IR-383.description: Origins, intensity, management and/or resolution of regional conflicts in developing countries and the role and intervention of great powers.

IR-384.title: Introduction to Asian Security Affairs
IR-384.description: Introduction to key security trends in Asia-Pacific, emphasizing strategic competition between U.S., Russia, and China; regional military capabilities; rise of neutrality politics.

IR-404.title: International Policy Task Force
IR-404.description: Addresses unfinished question of public policy. Provides experience in interviewing and field research, oral presentation and collective discussion and deliberation. Open to juniors and seniors only.

IR-405.title: International Negotiation
IR-405.description: A practical course designed to improve negotiation skills. A set of ideas for diagnosing any negotiation problem, international or local, and identifying alternative strategies and the risks of each. International case histories and face-to-face bargaining exercises. Original research to develop a strategy for an actual negotiation underway today. Recommended preparation: 2 IR courses

IR-408.title: Global Democratization
IR-408.description: Exploration of the global experience with democracy. Meaning of the term "democracy," explanations of the rise and fall of democracy, its current trends and future challenges.

IR-430.title: The Politics of International Trade
IR-430.description: Economic approaches and political processes are used to explain observed international trade policy choices. Topics covered include globalization, regionalism, labor standards, the environment and sanctions. Recommended preparation: ECON 450, IR 330

IR-443.title: Formulation of U.S. Foreign Policy
IR-443.description: Critical discussion of alternative approaches explaining the formulation and implementation of U.S. foreign policy: domestic politics, organizational processes, group dynamics, individual personality and perception.

synonyms: Contemporary Issues in United States-Latin America Relations
IR-465.title: Contemporary Issues in United States-Latin America Relations
IR-465.description: Examines major issues in the relationship between the United States and the countries of Latin America and the Caribbean, including trade and financial questions, security, immigration, the environment, narcotics, etc. Major bilateral relations (especially with Mexico, Brazil, and the Caribbean Basin countries) are emphasized, as are regional and multilateral relationships.

IR-468.title: European Integration
IR-468.description: Research on the European Union's role in European international relations; internal EU developments since 1985 as an actor in the world economy.

synonyms: War and Diplomacy: The U.S. in World Affairs
IR-483.title: War and Diplomacy: The U.S. in World Affairs
IR-483.description: Perspective on recent American foreign policy: a case study of conflicting literature on the origins, development and legacy of the Cold War.

IR-490.title: Directed Research
IR-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

IR-491.title: Field Study
IR-491.description: Local, national, and international internships. Not available for graduate credit.

IR-499.title: Special Topics
IR-499.description: Selected topics in various special areas within international relations, which may vary from semester to semester or within semesters.

IR-501.title: International Relations Theory: Advanced
IR-501.description: Examines the specialized nomenclature of international relations and the varied interpretations of basic concepts of international theory; conceptual analysis and criticism.

IR-503.title: Theories of Diplomacy
IR-503.description: Investigation of international relations through the lens of diplomatic theories, considering the limits and potential of diplomacy and how thinking about diplomacy has evolved.

IR-509.title: Culture, Gender and Global Society
IR-509.description: Cultural and gendered responses to economic globalization; topics include culture and security, identity politics, clashes of and accommodations among civilizations, modernity, post-modernity and world society.

synonyms: Social Science and Historical Research Methods: Introduction to Research Design
IR-513.title: Social Science and Historical Research Methods: Introduction to Research Design
IR-513.description: Introduction to problems in philosophy of science, epistemology, historical and historiographical inquiry, leading to development of elementary research design capabilities.

IR-515.title: Qualitative Research Design
IR-515.description: A practical seminar in which to develop a dissertation proposal. Covers causal inference and comparative case study designs; single-case designs; selecting cases; interviewing; combining quantitative and qualitative methods. Recommended preparation: IR 513, one course in statistics, and enough substantive study to identify a likely dissertation subject.

synonyms: Migration and Diaspora in International Politics
IR-526.title: Migration and Diaspora in International Politics
IR-526.description: Examines issues of migration, the relationship between citizen and state, economic factors triggering emigration/immigration, transnationalism, and explores the phenomenon of diasporas.

synonyms: International Political Economy of the Pacific Rim
IR-551.title: International Political Economy of the Pacific Rim
IR-551.description: Political economy of the Pacific Rim; trade investment and development strategies. The role of Japan's increasing economic power and that of the changing U.S.-Japan relations and implications for the Pacific Rim region.

IR-590.title: Directed Research
IR-590.description: Research leading to the Master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

IR-591.title: Field Study
IR-591.description: Study of contemporary institutions in selected regions of the world. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

IR-594A.title: Master's Thesis
IR-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

IR-594B.title: Master's Thesis
IR-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

IR-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
IR-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

IR-599.title: Special Topics
IR-599.description: Subjects specifically relevant to an international relations field, sometimes conducted as intensive short-courses.

IR-790.title: Research
IR-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

IR-791.title: Advanced Studies
IR-791.description: Subjects specifically relevant to an international relations field; conducted for Ph.D. students, sometimes conducted as intensive short courses.

IR-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IR-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

IR-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IR-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

IR-794C.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IR-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

IR-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
IR-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR.NC.

HIST-102.title: Medieval Civilization
HIST-102.description: Development of European civilization from the third through fourteenth centuries, with particular attention given to intellectual and religious elements.

HIST-103.title: The Emergence of Modern Europe
HIST-103.description: Political, intellectual, and cultural developments in Europe, 1300-1815. Renaissance and Reformation; absolute monarchy, scientific changes, and Enlightenment; French Revolution and Napoleon.

synonyms: Chinese Lives: An Introduction to Chinese History
HIST-106.title: Chinese Lives: An Introduction to Chinese History
HIST-106.description: Study of the lives of selected individuals who have helped to shape Chinese politics and culture.

HIST-107.title: Japanese History
HIST-107.description: Japan from the earliest times to the present; social, cultural, and political dimensions.

synonyms: Selected Themes and Topics in History
HIST-195.title: Selected Themes and Topics in History
HIST-195.description: Study of special historical themes and topics through readings, lectures, discussions, and supervised writings.

HIST-200.title: The American Experience
HIST-200.description: Patterns of American development from Colonial times to the present.

HIST-271.title: Early Native American Stories
HIST-271.description: An exploration of the history of Native America peoples and the ways they understood and explained the changes in their lives from 1492 to 1840.

synonyms: Native History and Historians: Mexico and Peru to 1615
HIST-272.title: Native History and Historians: Mexico and Peru to 1615
HIST-272.description: Introduction to Pre-Columbian Mesoamerica and the Andes, the causes and consequences of the Spanish conquest, and the establishment of colonial societies and economies.

HIST-280.title: The Modern Middle East
HIST-280.description: The interplay of local, regional, and international forces and broad themes in the history of the Middle East from 1500 to the present.

HIST-300.title: Approaches to History
HIST-300.description: Approaches to history; intellectual and personal dimensions of the historian's work. Required of all history majors.

HIST-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
HIST-300O.description: Off-campus studies; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

synonyms: North American Indians in American Public Life
HIST-317.title: North American Indians in American Public Life
HIST-317.description: Role of American Indians in American public life from colonial times to the present; native American forms of government; relations between tribes and the U.S.

HIST-318.title: Early American Indian History
HIST-318.description: Relations of European settlers with native Americans from the 16th into the early 19th centuries; cultural contacts, trade and eventual conflicts.

synonyms: Madness and Society in the Modern Age
HIST-329.title: Madness and Society in the Modern Age
HIST-329.description: The shifting place of insanity and "the mad" in Europe and the United States from the French Revolution to the anti-psychiatry movement.

HIST-331.title: The British Empire: 1588-1834
HIST-331.description: Emergence of the British Empire, emphasizing colonies in the Americas; the development of imperial economy, imperial wars, slavery and abolitionism.

synonyms: British Empire from the Mid-19th Century
HIST-332.title: British Empire from the Mid-19th Century
HIST-332.description: Political and economic development of the British Empire since Victoria; rise of the British Commonwealth.

HIST-337.title: Japan Since 1945
HIST-337.description: Survey of the impact of World War II, American occupation, and rapid economic growth on Japan's politics, society, economy, and culture; Japan as a post-modern nation.

synonyms: Work, Leisure, and Violence in Industrializing America
HIST-343.title: Work, Leisure, and Violence in Industrializing America
HIST-343.description: Rise of industrial America from eighteenth to twentieth centuries: changing work ethics, rise of factories, women workers, mass leisure, consumer culture, urban and industrial violence.

HIST-351.title: The American Revolution
HIST-351.description: Origins, course and consequences of the American Revolution; the post-war establishment of the Constitution.

HIST-360.title: 19th Century U.S. History
HIST-360.description: The social, political, and economic history of the United States from the formation of the Constitution to 1900.

HIST-365.title: The Second World War
HIST-365.description: Comparative analysis of the Second World War as a major transforming event of the Twentieth Century. Its causes, conduct, and consequences for humanity.

HIST-372.title: Modern Latin America
HIST-372.description: Exploration of major themes and events in Latin American history from independence to the present. Upper division standing.

HIST-373.title: History of the Mexican American
HIST-373.description: Racial and cultural background of Mexico; immigration and conquest; the Mexican in California and the southwest; the rise of contemporary Mexican-American consciousness.

HIST-378.title: Introduction to Asian American History
HIST-378.description: Comparative examination of the social, economic, and political experiences of Asian immigrants and their descendants in the U.S., 1840s-present.

HIST-380.title: American Popular Culture
HIST-380.description: Rise of popular culture (sports, amusment parks, movies, and televsion) and its significance in American society from mid 19th century to the present.

HIST-403.title: Carolingian Europe
HIST-403.description: Political, religious, and intellectual culture of England and the Continent in the 11th and 12th centuries.

HIST-404.title: Seminar in Korean History
HIST-404.description: Exploration of issues and sources in Korean history; work on an individual research paper through an incremental process.

synonyms: The Age of Humanism and Reformation
HIST-410.title: The Age of Humanism and Reformation
HIST-410.description: The thought, art, politics, and religion of western Europe in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries; emphasis on the contribution of Christian humanism.

synonyms: The Era of the First World War
HIST-425.title: The Era of the First World War
HIST-425.description: The background, causes, course, and aftermath of the First World War, with attention to the events in the United Kingdom and continental Europe.

HIST-438.title: Seminar in Pre-Modern Japanese History
HIST-438.description: A readings and research seminar dealing with one topic in the history of Japan before 1550. Topics will change each time the course is offered. Recommended preparation: a course in Japanese history

HIST-440.title: Early Modern World History
HIST-440.description: Comparative patterns of historical change around the world, from ca. 1500 to ca. 1800.

HIST-455.title: Advanced Topics in African-American History
HIST-455.description: Exploration of African-American history through primary and secondary sources employing a colloquium format with an emphasis on shared responsibility for comprehensive discussion and analysis. Upper division or graduate standing.

HIST-457.title: The American West
HIST-457.description: The nation's westward movement from Colonial times to the present, with emphasis on the frontier's effect on American life and insitutions.

synonyms: The Spanish Inquisition in the Early Modern Hispanic World
HIST-470.title: The Spanish Inquisition in the Early Modern Hispanic World
HIST-470.description: The Spanish Inquisition in Spain and Colonial Latin America, major theories and interpretations. Junior or senior standing recommended.

HIST-484.title: The United States, 1919-1939
HIST-484.description: Postwar reaction and the Twenties; the Great Depression and the New Deal; diplomacy between the wars.

HIST-487.title: The United States since 1939
HIST-487.description: A survey of the accelerating changes that transformed the nation's domestic life and revolutionized America's role in world affairs.

HIST-490.title: Directed Research
HIST-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

HIST-492.title: Honors Thesis
HIST-492.description: Writing of the honors thesis; for students in the History Honors Program.

HIST-493.title: Quantitative Historical Analysis
HIST-493.description: Reading and doing quantitative research with historical data. Course covers research designs, statistical analysis, and software packages appropriate for the use of historians.

HIST-498.title: Seminar on Selected Historical Topics
HIST-498.description: Advanced study in historical analysis and writing on selected topics and themes. Seminar enrollment limited to 15 students. Recommended preparation: HIST 300

synonyms: Studies in Modern European History: Europe's 20th Century
HIST-515.title: Studies in Modern European History: Europe's 20th Century
HIST-515.description: Readings in the history and historiography of Europe in the 20th century.

HIST-565.title: Studies in American International History
HIST-565.description: Readings and analyses of American policies, roles and principles in their interaction with the peoples and nations of the world.

synonyms: Historical Scholarship on Post-1860 United States
HIST-571.title: Historical Scholarship on Post-1860 United States
HIST-571.description: Graduate level introduction to influential scholarly research in the fields of late 19th and 20th century United States history.

HIST-590.title: Directed Research
HIST-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

HIST-594A.title: Master's Thesis
HIST-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

HIST-594B.title: Master's Thesis
HIST-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC

HIST-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
HIST-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Seminar on Women's and Family History
HIST-650.title: Seminar on Women's and Family History
HIST-650.description: Readings, discussions and directed research on women's and family histories.

synonyms: Seminar in 19th Century United States History
HIST-675.title: Seminar in 19th Century United States History
HIST-675.description: Research in historical problems of the Antebellum, Civil War, and Post-Civil War periods.

HIST-790.title: Research
