HIST-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

JS-100.title: Jewish History
JS-100.description: Major ideas, personalities, and movements in Jewish history from antiquity to the present in light of the interaction of the Jews with the general culture.

JS-300O.title: Off-campus Studies
JS-300O.description: Off-campus studies course; title of course offered at off-campus institution appears as a section title.

synonyms: Scripture and Polemic in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam
JS-361.title: Scripture and Polemic in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam
JS-361.description: Origins of Scriptures and their polemical environments in earliest Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Scripture as polemic and legitimation, and cross-religious/cross-cultural interpretation and argument based on scriptural themes.

JS-382.title: Judaism as an American Religion
JS-382.description: The development of American expressions of Judaism as part of the American religious context, from the perspective of the social scientific study of religion.

JS-490.title: Directed Research
JS-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

JS-504.title: Modern Hebrew Literature
JS-504.description: Reading of unvocalized texts primarily from modern Hebrew literature. A survey of the development of modern Hebrew literature, with an emphasis on short story and poetry. Knowledge of Hebrew required.

JS-590.title: Directed Research
JS-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Introduction to Liberal Studies: Methods of Knowing
LBST-500.title: Introduction to Liberal Studies: Methods of Knowing
LBST-500.description: Introduction to research methods in the social sciences, humanities, and natural sciences; then methods for applied interdisciplinary research.

synonyms: Controversies in Science, Medicine and Ethics
LBST-572.title: Controversies in Science, Medicine and Ethics
LBST-572.description: Focus on how scientific developments drive ethical issues in medicine. Exploration of ethical dimensions of issues such as stem cells, genetic engineering and reproductive technology.

LAW-200.title: Law and Society
LAW-200.description: Sources and structure of law; history of Bill of Rights emphasizing effect on criminal justice system; limits of law in solving problems in American society. Not available for major credit.

synonyms: Law and Politics: Electing a President
LAW-201.title: Law and Politics: Electing a President
LAW-201.description: Examination of the rules and realities of American politics, and the role politics plays in American life and culture. Not available for major credit to law students.

LAW-403.title: Mental Health Law
LAW-403.description: Issues at the intersection of law and psychology, both civil--e.g. civil commitment--and criminal-e.g. the insanity defense. Emphasis on ethical issues.

LAW-404.title: The Psychology of Wrongful Convictions
LAW-404.description: Examination of the psychological factors that cause failures in the criminal justice system, leading to the conviction of innocent people. Recommended preparation: PSYC 100

synonyms: Civil and Political Rights and Liberties
LAW-444.title: Civil and Political Rights and Liberties
LAW-444.description: An examination of debates and controversies surrounding the nature and scope of civil rights and civil liberties. Recommended preparation: POSC 340 or POSC 440

LAW-500O.title: Overseas Studies
LAW-500O.description: Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution appears as a section title.

LAW-504.title: Criminal Law
LAW-504.description: The crime problem and the legislative response to it through substantive criminal law; administration of criminal justice through police, prosecutorial, sentencing, and penological discretion.

LAW-505.title: Legal Profession
LAW-505.description: Functions of the lawyer in modern society; history and organization of the legal profession; the adversary system; equal access to justice; other problems of ethics and professional responsibility.

LAW-507.title: Property
LAW-507.description: The idea of property as understood through economic and philosophical ceoncepts. Rights in land, water, and other natural resources. Forms of shared ownership (e.g., landlord and tenant), and a survey of mechanisms for controlling land use.

LAW-508.title: Constitutional Law I
LAW-508.description: The function of the American Constitution: allocation of authority among branches of the national government; division of authority between the nation and the state; limitations of government control of the individual. The process of constitutional interpretation and the role of the United States Supreme Court.

LAW-511B.title: Legal Writing
LAW-511B.description: Two-semester course focusing on developing analytic and communication skills. Lawyers will analyze legal principles and incisively apply them to facts. Graded CR/D/F.

synonyms: Legal Research, Writing, and Advocacy II
LAW-516.title: Legal Research, Writing, and Advocacy II
LAW-516.description: Continuation of LAW 515. Development of legal research, writing, and advocacy skills. Emphasis on persuasive legal writing, including appellate briefs, and researching statutory and administrative law. Participation in a moot court program. Registration restricted to Law students.

LAW-521.title: Topics in American Law
LAW-521.description: This course will provide LL.M. and M.C.L. students with a survey of various topics in American law including criminal law, evidence, family law, constitutional law, torts, wills and trusts, administrative law and property law. Open to LL.M. and M.C.L. students only.

LAW-600.title: Taxation
LAW-600.description: Federal tax statutes, technical issues and social problems involved in tax planning, tax litigation, and reform of the tax laws.

LAW-602.title: Criminal Procedure
LAW-602.description: Criminal procedure in the courts, and the regulation of law enforcement by the courts through rules of evidence and interpretation of the Bill of Rights.

LAW-603.title: Business Organizations
LAW-603.description: Organization of economic activity especially the modern corporation as institutions of social power. The roles of managers, owners, and regulatory agencies in shaping processes of decision making.

LAW-606.title: Land-Use Controls
LAW-606.description: The regulation of land development through planning, zoning, subdivision controls, and private devices. Mechanisms for coordinating regional development and financing new urban infrastructure.

LAW-607.title: Gifts, Wills, and Trusts
LAW-607.description: Gratuitous transfer of wealth, especially the transmission of wealth from one generation to the next as a settlement of family affairs. Comparative analysis of the legal mechanisms of gifts, wills, and trusts. Introduction to problems of fiduciary administration.

LAW-608.title: Evidence
LAW-608.description: The purpose and character of trial. Problems of adversary presentation and the nature of proof. The basis for admission and exclusion of evidence in judicial proceedings.

LAW-620.title: Mortgage Law
LAW-620.description: Deals with the rights and remedies of mortgage lenders and borrowers after the mortgage loan has gone into default. Recommended preparation: LAW 605.

LAW-623.title: Family Law
LAW-623.description: Creating, regulating and dissolving family relationships. Explore moral and power relations among men, women, children, and the State. Develop skills to help clients in families.

LAW-625.title: Remedies
LAW-625.description: Comparison of the remedial goals of contracts, torts, and property and the impact of procedural devices in law and equity. Damages, injunctions, specific performance and restitution. Remedial theory and transactional application.

LAW-626.title: International Arbitration
LAW-626.description: Steps in the arbitration process, attorney's functions in the process, relation of arbitration to national courts, policy issues, issues involved when governments are parties to international commercial disputes. Open to Law students only.

LAW-629.title: Real Estate Finance
LAW-629.description: A survey of the major types of financing used for real estate and the basic techniques used to make real estate investment and financing decisions. Open to law students only.

LAW-630.title: Mediation Clinic
LAW-630.description: Students receive the training required to become professional mediators for civil cases in the L.A. County Superior Court, and mediate these cases.

LAW-638.title: Topics in Alternative Dispute Resolution
LAW-638.description: Examines selected topics in negotiation, mediation, or alternative dispute resolution. May be repeated with permission of the instructor as topics vary. Graded CR/D/F/. Enrollment restricted to law students.

LAW-641.title: Commercial Law
LAW-641.description: Commercial transactions involving secured financing (other than land). Government regulation of such sales and borrowing through Article 9 of the Uniform Consumer Commercial Code and other recent legislation.

LAW-642.title: Secured Transactions
LAW-642.description: This is a course on Chattel paper and secured transactions involving personal property under Article 9 of the Uniform Commerical Code and some related bodies of law.

LAW-649.title: Insurance
LAW-649.description: The pooling of risks and distributing of losses. Actuarial foundation and contract problems of insurance.

LAW-650.title: Entertainment Law
LAW-650.description: An examination of how the courts are handling selected, "cutting edge" topics in entertainment law. The topics will include the scope of and limitations on the right of publicity; fair use and parody defenses to copyright infringement; future technology clauses in rights contracts; and copyright and defamation issues arising in the online world. Previous entertainment law courses recommended, but not required.

LAW-651.title: Entertainment Law Practicum
LAW-651.description: Supervised internship for students enrolled in LAW 650. Graded CR/D/F.

LAW-655.title: Environmental Law
LAW-655.description: Focus on environmental law policy and practice. This course is a combination of regulatory and private law, with a special emphasis on disputes and regulations involving contamination in soil, water and air.

LAW-658.title: Mergers and Acquisitions
LAW-658.description: Problems of integrating the corporate, securities, tax, business, antitrust, accounting and contractual aspects of corporate mergers and aquisitions.

LAW-662.title: Public International Law
LAW-662.description: Principles of international law involving relations among governments. The function of international tribunals and organizations.

LAW-669.title: Moot Court Supervision
LAW-669.description: Evaluation and supervision of the preparation of briefs and oral arguments in the Hale Moot Court honors competition. Graded CR/69/65.

LAW-670.title: Advanced Moot Court Oral Arguments
LAW-670.description: Preparation of oral arguments in approved moot court competitions, such as national and state prize rounds, (other than Hale Moot Court Program). Graded CR/69/65. Open only to law students.

LAW-671.title: Advanced Moot Court Briefs
LAW-671.description: Preparation of briefs in approved moot court competitions, such as national and state prize rounds (other than Hale Moot Court Program).

synonyms: Review of Law and Social Justice Staff
LAW-678B.title: Review of Law and Social Justice Staff
LAW-678B.description: Writing, source-checking, and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social Justice. For second year students serving as staff members on the Review. Open to law students only. Graded CR/D/F.

synonyms: Review of Law and Social Justice Writing
LAW-679B.title: Review of Law and Social Justice Writing
LAW-679B.description: Writing, source-checking, and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social Justice. For second year students serving as staff members on the Review. Open to law students only. Graded IP to Numerical.

synonyms: Review of Law and Social Justice Editing
LAW-680B.title: Review of Law and Social Justice Editing
LAW-680B.description: Supervision of research and writing, and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Review of Law and Social Justice. For officers of the Review. Open to law students only. Graded IP to CR/D/F.

LAW-682.title: Jessup Moot Court Oral Arguments
LAW-682.description: Students prepare oral arguments on the issues in a problem that is the basis for the Jessup International Moot Court Competition. Participation is by faculty selection only. Graded CR/D/F.

LAW-703B.title: Children's Legal Issues
LAW-703B.description: Students will work on cases in the following areas: 1) dependent and neglected children: All children who are wards of the court must have legal counsel. 2) Children with AIDS: Legal implications of such issues as health care and custody. 3) Guardianships or other temporary arrangements for children whose parents are terminally ill or are otherwise unable to care for them. Graded CR/69/65.

LAW-709.title: Contract Drafting and Negotiation
LAW-709.description: Contract drafting and negotiating will teach students the mechanics of drafting and negotiating sophisticated contracts from a variety of legal disciplines including entertainment law, real estate law and general corporate law.

LAW-713.title: International Human Rights
LAW-713.description: This course will address the international law and institutions which have developed since World War II for the protection of human rights.

LAW-717.title: Estate Planning
LAW-717.description: Legal and tax considerations important to the lawyer advising his or her client on the transmission of wealth from one generation to the next.

LAW-718.title: Sports Law
LAW-718.description: Sports law is a blend of contract, labor, antitrust, agency, tax, intellectual property, tort, civil rights and constitutional law.

LAW-719.title: Corporate Finance
LAW-719.description: Legal and economic aspects of corporate finance including capital structure, policy, mergers, takeovers, and freeze-outs; analysis of policy relating to present law and possible reforms.

LAW-720.title: Topics in Corporate Law
LAW-720.description: Executive malfeasance, shareholder rights, securities class actions, asset securitizations, hedge fund regulation and corporate social responsibility from a theoretical and corporate finance framework. Open only to Law students.

LAW-727.title: Partnerships and Limited Liability Companies
LAW-727.description: This course deals with the formation, features and functions of general partnerships, limited partnerships and limited liability companies. It will also focus on business planning, recognizing business and legal objectives and selecting the appropriate entity to accomplish these objectives.

LAW-733.title: Corporate Reorganization
LAW-733.description: Reorganization of failing corporations under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy act. Claims, protective committee, plans, tax considerations.

LAW-735.title: Employer Legal Advice Clinic
LAW-735.description: Provides legal advice to clients in the area of employment law. Open to law students only. Graded CR/69/65.

LAW-751.title: Sexual Orientation and the Law
LAW-751.description: Explores the ways in which American law has responded to the diversity that exists within human sexual orientation.

LAW-758.title: Identity Categories
LAW-758.description: Drawing on feminist legal theory, critical race theory, and lesbian/gay/bisexual and queer theory, this seminar will explore the treatment of identity categories in United States law.

LAW-760B.title: Interdisciplinary Law Journal Staff
LAW-760B.description: Source-checking and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Interdisciplinary Law Journal. For third year students serving as staff members on the Journal.

LAW-761B.title: Interdisciplinary Law Journal Writing
LAW-761B.description: Writing of an article for the Interdisciplinary Law Journal. For second year students serving as staff members on the Journal.

LAW-762B.title: Interdisciplinary Law Journal Editing
LAW-762B.description: Supervision and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Interdisciplinary Law Journal. Graded CR/69/65.

synonyms: Federal Courts: The Federal System II
LAW-763.title: Federal Courts: The Federal System II
LAW-763.description: Problems of adjudication in the federal system. Allocation of authority between federal and state courts, and among Congress, the Executive and the Courts; choice of federal and state law; jurisdiction of federal courts and significant rules of practice.

LAW-767B.title: Law Review Staff
LAW-767B.description: Writing, source- checking, and preliminary editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review. For second year students serving as staff members on the Review.

LAW-768B.title: Law Review Writing
LAW-768B.description: Preparation of a second note of publishable quality. For third year students serving as staff members on the Review.

LAW-769B.title: Law Review Editing
LAW-769B.description: Supervision of research and writing, and final editing of articles and comments for publication in the Southern California Law Review. For officers of the Review. Graded CR/69/65.

LAW-777.title: Administrative Process
LAW-777.description: Legal principles subject to judicial control and the alternative ways in which agencies can be organized to serve their purposes.

LAW-778.title: Sales
LAW-778.description: This course will analyze the buying and selling of goods both in domestic and international transactions with a heavy focus on Article 2 of the Uniform Commercial Code.

LAW-780.title: Intellectual Property Clinic II
LAW-780.description: Continuation of LAW 771. Open to Law students only.

LAW-781.title: Clinical Internship/Externship I
LAW-781.description: A clinical internship or judicial externship allows a student to gain hands-on legal experience in legal settings. Students will be assigned to a legal services program, government agency, state or federal judges, under faculty supervision. Graded CR/NC.

LAW-789.title: Dissertation
LAW-789.description: Students should register for 2-4 units of dissertation to engage in supervised research and writing which is expected to result in a paper of publishable quality. Any regular, full-time member of the faculty (including full-time visitors) may supervise students in this course upon agreement by the faculty member and the student. Other persons who teach in the JD program may supervise dissertation only upon the approval of the Administrative Board. A 1 unit registration for dissertation will be available only where the unit is to be added to a course where a paper is already required, in recognition that the student's paper will require substantially more work than that expected of other students in the course. Students may take a total of 4 units of dissertation during their educational experience at the Law Center.

LAW-796.title: Immigration Clinic II
LAW-796.description: Continuation of LAW 776. Enrollment restricted to law students.

LAW-810.title: Patent Law
LAW-810.description: Patent laws, litigation, and the process of prosecuting the patent application. The concept of invention and ownership of rights under patents.

LAW-820.title: Pretrial Advocacy
LAW-820.description: Examines conceptual and practical aspects of interviewing, counseling, negotiation, settlement, drafting and formal advocacy in the handling of legal cases.

LAW-821.title: Trial Advocacy
LAW-821.description: Examines decicion-making by counsel in the litigation of cases. Emphasis is given to decisions involving tactics, strategies, and their implications for the functioning of legal institutions and substantive doctrine. Extensive use of simulated trial practice exercises.

LAW-827.title: Counseling the Startup Company
LAW-827.description: Role of the attorney in startup firms: business plan, employment agreements, lease, stock option plan, financing documents and distribution and strategic partnership arrangements. Enrollment restricted to law students.

LAW-839.title: Copyright
LAW-839.description: Study of federal copyright law, analysis of property rights and interests created thereunder. Manner in which these rights can be exploited in the various entertainment media.

synonyms: Topics in Criminal Law and Criminology
LAW-851.title: Topics in Criminal Law and Criminology
LAW-851.description: Selected topics in criminal law or criminology. May be repeated with permission of the instructor as topics vary.

LAW-861.title: International Law Seminar
LAW-861.description: Investigation of selected problems of international law. May be repeated with permission of the instructor as topics vary.

synonyms: Major Corporate Civil and Criminal Fraud: Lessons of Enron
LAW-867.title: Major Corporate Civil and Criminal Fraud: Lessons of Enron
LAW-867.description: Examines the causes for the business failures of the Enron Era through selected readings of law, accounting, business practices, contemporaneous evidence, investigations and indictments.

LAW-868.title: Business Enterprise Taxation
LAW-868.description: This course examines the taxation of corporations, partnerships, and limited liability companies.

LAW-870.title: Legal Writing Fellows
LAW-870.description: Assist in teaching writing and advocacy. Responsibilities include helping prepare lesson plans and draft writing assignments and sample answers; leading class exercises; and judging first-year moot court practice rounds. Graded CR/D/F.

LAW-871.title: Constitutional Law II
LAW-871.description: The First Amendment, freedom of expression (political speech, symbolic expression, obscenity, commercial speech, defamation), rights of access to the media of expression. The protection of religion and the prohibition of the establishment of religion.

synonyms: Advanced Legal Writing and Advocacy: Appellate Advocacy
LAW-872.title: Advanced Legal Writing and Advocacy: Appellate Advocacy
LAW-872.description: Students will research, write, and rewrite an appellate brief and may work on motions and oral advocacy as well. Open to Law students only.

LAW-890.title: Directed Research
LAW-890.description: Directed research may be taken only with the approval of the Administrative Board. This course is intended for substantial independent research and study that does not result in a paper of publishable quality. It includes, but is not limited to, preparation of research memoranda for faculty research projects, empirical research for such projects and supervised independent study. Directed research is to be supervised by a regular, full-time faculty member (including full-time visiting faculty). Students may take a maximum of 4 units of Directed Research during their educational experience at the Law Center.

LAW-893.title: Advanced Clinical Training
LAW-893.description: For third-year students who wish to continue their clinical training.

MATH-040.title: Basic Mathematical Skills
MATH-040.description: Intensive review of arithmetic and algebra. Graded CR/NC. (Not available for degree credit.)

MATH-100O.title: Off-Campus Studies
MATH-100O.description: Off-Campus Studies coursework; title of course taken at other institution appears as a section title.

MATH-108.title: Precalculus
MATH-108.description: Equations and inequalities; functions; graphs; polynomial and rational functions; exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric function; analytic geometry.

MATH-116.title: Mathematics for the Social Sciences
MATH-116.description: Finite mathematics with application to the social sciences; elementary set theory and logic; counting techniques; probability; statistics; matrices and systems of linear equations. Selected topics.

synonyms: Introduction to Mathematics for Business and Economics
MATH-117.title: Introduction to Mathematics for Business and Economics
MATH-117.description: Functions, graphs, polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, matrices, systems of linear equations.

MATH-118.title: Fundamental Principles of the Calculus
MATH-118.description: Derivatives; extrema. Definite integral; fundamental theorem of calculus. Extrema and definite integrals for functions of several variables. Not available for credit toward a degree in mathematics.

MATH-125.title: Calculus I
MATH-125.description: Limits; continuity, derivatives and applications; antiderivatives; the fundamental theorem of calculus; exponential and logarithmic functions.

MATH-126.title: Calculus II
MATH-126.description: A continuation of 125: trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates.

MATH-208.title: Elementary Probability and Statistics
MATH-208.description: Descriptive statistics, probability concepts, discrete and continuous random variables, mathematical expectation and variance, probability sampling, Central Limit Theorem, estimation and hypothesis testing, correlation and regression. Not available for major credit to mathematics majors. Prerequisite: 118x or 125.

MATH-218.title: Probability for Business
MATH-218.description: Basic probability, discrete and continuous distributions, expectation and variance, independence. Sampling, estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing.

synonyms: Linear Algebra and Linear Differential Equations
MATH-225.title: Linear Algebra and Linear Differential Equations
MATH-225.description: Matrices, systems of linear equations, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, systems of linear differential equations.

MATH-226.title: Calculus III
MATH-226.description: A continuation of 126; vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Green's theorem. Prerequisite: 126 or 126H.

synonyms: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering I
MATH-245.title: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering I
MATH-245.description: First-order differential equations; second-order linear differential equations; determinants and matrices; systems of linear differential equations; Laplace transforms.

MATH-370.title: Applied Algebra
MATH-370.description: Induction, Euclidean algorithm, factorization, congruence classes, Rings, RSA algorithm, Chinese remainder theorem, codes, polynomials, fundamental theorem of algebra, polynomial multiplication, Fourier transform, and other topics.

MATH-395.title: Seminar in Problem Solving
MATH-395.description: Systematic approach to solving non-standard and competition level math problems on inequalities, infinite sums and products, combinatorics, number theory, and games. Recommended preparation: MATH 126

MATH-407.title: Probability Theory
MATH-407.description: Probability spaces, discrete and continuous distributions, moments, characteristic functions, sequences of random variables, laws of large numbers, central limit theorem, special probability laws. Prerequisite: 226 or 226H.

MATH-408.title: Mathematical Statistics
MATH-408.description: Principles for testing hypotheses and estimation, small sample distributions, correlation and regression, nonparametric methods, elements of statistical decision theory. Prerequisite: 407.

MATH-410.title: Fundamental Concepts of Modern Algebra
MATH-410.description: Sets; relations; groups; homomorphisms; symmetric groups; Abelian groups; Sylow's theorems; introduction to rings and fields. Not open to students with credit in 470. Prerequisite: 225.

MATH-425A.title: Fundamental Concepts of Analysis
MATH-425A.description: The real number system, metric spaces, limits, continuity, derivatives and integrals, infinte series.

MATH-425B.title: Fundamental Concepts of Analysis
MATH-425B.description: Implicit function theorems, Jacobians, transformations, multiple integrals, line integrals.

MATH-432.title: Applied Combinatorics
MATH-432.description: Mathematical induction, counting principles, arrangements, selections, binomial coefficients, generating functions, recurrence relations, inclusion-exclusion, symmetric groups, graphs, Euler and Hamiltonian circuits, trees, graph algorithms; applications. Prerequisite: 225 or 226 or 226H or consent of instructor.

synonyms: Vector Analysis and Introduction to Differential Geometry
MATH-435.title: Vector Analysis and Introduction to Differential Geometry
MATH-435.description: Vectors, elements of vector analysis, applications to curves and surfaces, standard material of differential geometry. Prerequisite: 226 or 226H.

synonyms: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering II
MATH-445.title: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering II
MATH-445.description: Vector field theory; theorems of Gauss, Green, and Stokes; Fourier series and integrals; complex variables; linear partial differential equations; series solutions of ordinary differential equations. Prerequisite: 245.

MATH-450.title: History of Mathematics
MATH-450.description: Evolution of mathematical ideas and techniques as seen through a study of the contributions of eminent mathematicians to the formulation and solution of celebrated problems. Recommended preparation: upper division MATH course.

MATH-465.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH-465.description: Linear systems, phase plane analysis, existence and uniqueness, stability of linear and almost linear systems, Lyapunov's method, nonlinear oscillations, flows, invariant surfaces, and bifurcation.

MATH-471.title: Topics in Linear Algebra
MATH-471.description: Polynomial rings, vector spaces, linear transformations, canonical forms, inner product spaces. Recommended preparation: MATH 410.

synonyms: Introduction to Theory of Complex Variables
MATH-475.title: Introduction to Theory of Complex Variables
MATH-475.description: Limits and infinite series; line integrals; conformal mapping; single-valued functions of a complex variable; applications. Primarily for advanced students in engineering.

MATH-490.title: Directed Research
MATH-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

MATH-500.title: Graduate Colloquium
MATH-500.description: Lectures directed to mathematics graduate students by faculty of the department and by outside speakers. Problem solving workshops. Graded CR/NC.

MATH-501.title: Numerical Analysis and Computation
MATH-501.description: Linear equations and matrices, Gauss elimination, error estimates, iteration techniques; contractive mappings, Newton's method; matrix eigenvalue problems; least-squares approximation, Newton-Cotes and Gaussian quadratures; finite difference methods. Prerequisite: linear algebra and calculus.

MATH-502B.title: Numerical Analysis
MATH-502B.description: Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear systems of equations; approximation theory using functional analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.

MATH-503.title: Stochastic Calculus for Finance
MATH-503.description: Stochastic differential equations. Bellman equation. Applications to option pricing. Kolmogorov equations and derivative securities. State prices, equivalent martingale measure. Optimal stopping, American options. Exotic options.

MATH-505B.title: Applied Probability
MATH-505B.description: Markov processes in discrete or continuous time; renewal processes; martingales; brownian motion and diffusion theory; random walks, inventory models, population growth, queuing models, shot noise.

MATH-507B.title: Theory of Probability
MATH-507B.description: a: Probability spaces; distributions and characteristic functions; laws of large numbers, central limit problems; stable and infinitely divisible laws; conditional distributions. Prerequisite: 525a or 570. b: Dependence, martingales, ergodic theorems, second-order random functions, harmonic analysis, Markov processes.

MATH-508.title: Filtering Theory
MATH-508.description: Theory of random differential equations and stochastic stability; optimum linear and nonlinear filtering, with discussion of asymptotic behavior of filter.

MATH-510B.title: Algebra
MATH-510B.description: B: Commutative Algebra: Integrality, Hilbert Basis theorem, Hilbert Nullstellensatz; Modules: modules over PID's, chain conditions, tensor products; Noncommutative Rings: Jacobson radical, Artin-Wedderburn theorem, Maschke's theorem.

MATH-511A.title: Data Analysis
MATH-511A.description: Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

MATH-511B.title: Data Analysis
MATH-511B.description: Exploratory data analysis, detection of outliers, fitting data with linear and nonlinear regression models, computer packages including S-PLUS and SPSS.

MATH-520.title: Complex Analysis
MATH-520.description: Theory of analytic functions--power series and integral representations, calculus of residues, harmonic functions, normal families, approximation theorems, conformal mapping, analytical continuation.

MATH-525B.title: Real Analysis
MATH-525B.description: a: Measure and integration over abstract measure spaces, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Fubini's theorem, convergence theorems, differentiation. Prerequisite: 425ab. b: Metric spaces, contraction principle, category, Banach spaces, Riesz representation theorem, properties of Lp, Hilbert spaces, orthogonal expansions, Fourier series and transforms, convolutions. Prerequisite: 525a.

MATH-540.title: Topology
MATH-540.description: Initial and final topologies, function spaces, algebras in C(Y), homotopy, fundamental group, fiber spaces and bundles, smashes, loop spaces, groups of homotopy classes, cw- complexes. Prerequisite: 440.

MATH-541A.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
MATH-541A.description: Exponential families, sufficiency. Estimation: methods of estimation, maximum likelihood, least squares, comparison of estimators, unbiased estimation, optimality, theory, information inequality, asymptotic efficiency, confidence intervals.

MATH-542.title: Analysis of Variance and Design
MATH-542.description: Least squares estimation in the linear model, analysis of variance and covariance, F-test, multiple comparisons, multiple regression, selection of variables; introduction to experimental design. Includes laboratory. Prerequisite: MATH 225, 226 or 226H, and 208x or equivalent.

MATH-555B.title: Partial Differential Equations
MATH-555B.description: Second-order partial differential equations of elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic type; in particular, potential and wave equations.

MATH-565A.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH-565A.description: Existence, uniqueness and continuation of solutions, differential inequalities, linear systems, Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary value problems, Poincare-Bendixson theory, periodic solutions, perturbations, stability, fixed point techniques.

MATH-570B.title: Methods of Applied Mathematics
MATH-570B.description: Hilbert spaces, normal, self-adjoint and compact operators, geometric and spectral analysis of linear operators, elementary partial differential equations.

MATH-577A.title: Computational Molecular Biology Laboratory
MATH-577A.description: Practical experience in computational molecular biology applications. Mathematical and statistical software packages relevant for genomic analysis. Retrieval and analysis of genomic data from databases.

MATH-578A.title: Computational Molecular Biology
MATH-578A.description: Applications of the mathematical, statistical and computational sciences to data from molecular biology. Algorithms for genomic sequence data: sequence and map assembly and alignment, RNA secondary structure, protein structure, gene-finding, and tree construction. Recommended preparation: familiarity with the concepts of basic molecular biology as covered in BISC 320.

MATH-590.title: Directed Research
MATH-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MATH-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
MATH-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

MATH-601.title: Optimization Theory and Techniques
MATH-601.description: Necessary and sufficient conditions for existence of extrema with equality constraints; gradient methods; Ritz methods; eigenvalue problems; optimum control problems; inequality constraints; mathematical programming.

MATH-790.title: Research
MATH-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Introduction to Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
HP-200.title: Introduction to Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
HP-200.description: Introduction to strategies for promoting health and wellness. Includes self monitoring of health risk behavior, goal setting, and behavior changes.
HP-200.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-290.title: Introduction to Research Apprenticeship
HP-290.description: Individual research apprenticeship in health related fields under supervision of a departmental faculty member. Graded CR/NC. Departmental approval.
HP-290.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-300.title: Theoretical Principles of Health Behavior
HP-300.description: Overview and analysis of predictors and consequences of health-related behaviors; theoretical viewpoints and strategies for behavior change. Recommended preparation: HP 200
HP-300.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

synonyms: Biological and Behavioral Basis of Disease
HP-320.title: Biological and Behavioral Basis of Disease
HP-320.description: Examination of the major systems of the human body; disease processes and behavioral risk factors.
HP-320.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-340.title: Health Behavior Statistical Methods
HP-340.description: Intermediate statistics for health behavior studies; topics include descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression, and use of computer software in data analysis.
HP-340.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-350.title: Health Behavior Research Methods
HP-350.description: Introduction to the design, conduct and evaluation of health behavior research studies; quantitative and qualitative approaches to research and analysis. Recommended preparation: HP 340L
HP-350.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-400.title: Culture, Lifestyle, and Health
HP-400.description: Comparison of national and international differences in health status as influenced by cultural practices and lifestyles within geographic, economic and political environments.
HP-400.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

synonyms: Cultural Competence: Promoting Health in Diverse Communities
HP-401.title: Cultural Competence: Promoting Health in Diverse Communities
HP-401.description: Systematic development of specific professional skills for providing effective, culturally sensitive health services to diverse populations. Recommended preparation: ANTH 101
HP-401.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-402.title: Maternal and Child Health
HP-402.description: Health issues of women of childbearing age from pre-pregnancy through the postpartum period, and of children from their development in utero through early adolescence. Recommended preparation: PSYC 100
HP-402.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-404.title: Religion and Health
HP-404.description: Differential relationships of religiosity and spirituality with health and risk behaviors, physical and mental health outcomes, coping skills and well-being across cultures and religions.
HP-404.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

synonyms: Sexually Transmitted Diseases: A Global Public Health Priority
HP-405.title: Sexually Transmitted Diseases: A Global Public Health Priority
HP-405.description: An overview of the magnitude and impact of STDs including prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of common STDs, STD/HIV inter-relationship, global burden, trends, public health challenges, and STD/HIV prevention and control strategies and programs worldwide.
HP-405.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

synonyms: Issues in Prevention and Cessation of Drug Abuse
HP-410.title: Issues in Prevention and Cessation of Drug Abuse
HP-410.description: Examination of factors related to drug abuse behaviors; overview and assessment of drug abuse prevention and cessation programs; relapse prevention programs. Recommended preparation: HP 300
HP-410.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-412.title: Health Promotion and Prevention Policy
HP-412.description: Overview of health promotion and drug prevention policy at the local, state, and federal levels; methods for evaluating policy effectiveness and cost effectiveness.
HP-412.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-422.title: AIDS in Society
HP-422.description: Provides a broad examination of issues in HIV/AIDS, including behavioral, social, biological, clinical and ethical dimensions of the pandemic in the U.S. and elsewhere.
HP-422.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-430.title: Nutrition and Exercise Epidemiology
HP-430.description: Principals of nutritional assessment and dietary needs of special population groups; meal planning and exercise prescriptions during the lifecycle and for groups with chronic diseases.
HP-430.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

synonyms: Behavior and Education Strategies for Nutrition and Fitness
HP-431.title: Behavior and Education Strategies for Nutrition and Fitness
HP-431.description: Examination of dietary intake and exercise behaviors as they relate to health and illness; methods for measuring diet and exercise. Recommended preparation: HP 430
HP-431.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-440.title: Happiness, Well-Being, and Health
HP-440.description: Explores human strengths that promote happiness/well-being and whether they influence physical health; mind-body relationships; and strategies for promoting hope, resilience, and quality of life. Recommended preparation: HP 200, PSYC 100
HP-440.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

synonyms: Health Promotion in the Work Place
HP-441.title: Health Promotion in the Work Place
HP-441.description: Covers phases of worksite health promotion: research, design, implementation and evaluation; concerns regarding escalating medical costs and the role of health promotion in offering substitutes.
HP-441.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-490.title: Directed Research
HP-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit. Open to HP majors only. Recommended preparation: HP 350L
HP-490.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

HP-499.title: Special Topics
HP-499.description: Lecture and discussion focused on specific topics within health promotion and disease prevention. Course topic will vary from semester to semester.
HP-499.dept_name: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Studies

MED-100.title: First Year Medicine
MED-100.description: FOR REGISTRATION AND FEE PURPOSES ONLY.

MED-200.title: Second Year Medicine
MED-200.description: FOR REGISTRATION AND FEE PURPOSES ONLY.

MED-300.title: Third Year Medicine
MED-300.description: FOR REGISTRATION AND FEE PURPOSES ONLY.

MED-400.title: Fourth Year Medicine
MED-400.description: FOR REGISTRATION AND FEE PURPOSES ONLY.

MED-750.title: Special Medicine
MED-750.description: For registration and fee purposes only.

PATH-551.title: Advanced Pathology
PATH-551.description: Mechanisms of disease processes including inflammation, tissue injury and cell death, atherosclerosis, infectious diseases, diseases of the immune system, cancer, diseases of aging, and pollution. (Duplicates credit in former PATH 550bL.)

PATH-552B.title: Methods in Experimental Pathology
PATH-552B.description: Theory and practice methods useful in experimental pathology; experimental design; statistical analysis; literature analysis; laboratory and radiation safety.

PATH-561.title: Molecular Genetics
PATH-561.description: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic molecular genetics: DNA and RNA structure and function; biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, RNA processing, translation, and regulation of gene expression. CNB 561, MICB 561, MPTX 561, PATH 561, PHBI 561, PSCI 561

PATH-570A.title: Seminar in Pathology
PATH-570A.description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH-570B.title: Seminar in Pathology
PATH-570B.description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH-570C.title: Seminar in Pathology
PATH-570C.description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH-570D.title: Seminar in Pathology
PATH-570D.description: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH-573.title: Systems Physiology and Disease II
PATH-573.description: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on neuroscience, immunology, metabolism, endocrine, reproduction, GI and liver. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences. Open to graduate students in biomedical science only. Recommended preparation: undergraduate degree in a biological science.

PATH-575.title: Frontiers of Pathology
PATH-575.description: Weekly research lectures by leading investigators in the field of homeostatic response to injury such as cell death, inflammation, fibrosis and regeneration.

PATH-580.title: Cell Cycle Regulation
PATH-580.description: Recent advances in cell cycle research and discussion of potential significance for human development and health care.

PATH-590.title: Directed Research
PATH-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PATH-594A.title: Master's Thesis
PATH-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PATH-594B.title: Master's Thesis
PATH-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PATH-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
PATH-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PATH-650.title: Stem Cell Biology and Medicine
PATH-650.description: Basic principles, available embryonic and adult stem cells, principles of organogenesis and regeneration, animal models, delivery of engineered tissues to patients, promise and limitations of stem cells. Open to master's and Ph.D. students on the health sciences campus and to medical and post-doctoral fellow trainees only.

PATH-790.title: Research
PATH-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

PATH-794A.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PATH-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PATH-794B.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PATH-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PATH-794D.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PATH-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

PATH-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
PATH-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

NAUT-002A.title: Advanced Deepwater Cruising
NAUT-002A.description: Responsibilities and operations commanding an offshore sailing vessel including sailing theory and advanced techniques, advanced navigation, ships engineering, and oceanography relevant to seamanship. (a) senior skipper; (b) advanced senior skipper. Not available for degree credit.

NAUT-301A.title: Deepwater Cruising
NAUT-301A.description: An experiential approach to the sailing ship and seafaring, introducing offshore sailing theory and techniques, navigation, and basic oceanography as relevant to seamanship. (a) crew level; (b) watch captain level.

NAUT-301B.title: Deepwater Cruising
NAUT-301B.description: An experiential approach to the sailing ship and seafaring, introducing offshore sailing theory and techniques, navigation, and basic oceanography as relevant to seamanship. (a) crew level; (b) watch captain level.

NSC-137.title: Seapower and Maritime Affairs
NSC-137.description: Analysis of U.S. Navy development and campaigns; evolution of strategic, tactical, and maritime doctrines; interaction of naval affairs with national security and domestic policies. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

NSC-335.title: Navigation I
NSC-335.description: Purposes, methods, and instruments of navigation; terrestrial and celestial navigation and nautical astronomy; time diagrams; lines of position by observation of celestial bodies. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

NSC-337.title: Naval Ships Systems II (Weapons)
NSC-337.description: Systems approach to naval weapons; linear analysis of ballistics; weapons control systems configurations and dynamics. Field trips. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

NSC-454.title: Leadership and Management II
NSC-454.description: Introduction to primary duties of junior naval officers; counseling and interviewing techniques; review of basic administrative responsibilities at the division officer level. Lecture, 2 hrs; lab, 2 hrs.

MDA-100A.title: Introduction to the Health Professions
MDA-100A.description: An introduction to the health professions, through lectures, discussions, clinical experiences, and visits to health care delivery sites; relationships with other clinicians and the community. Graded CR/NC.

MDA-100B.title: Introduction to the Health Professions
MDA-100B.description: An introduction to the health professions, through lectures, discussions, clinical experience, and visits to health care delivery sites; relationships with other clinicians and the community. Graded CR/NC.

MDA-100C.title: Introduction to the Health Professions
MDA-100C.description: An introduction to the health professions, through lectures, discussions, clinical experience, and visits to health care delivery sites; relationships with other clinicians and the community. Graded CR/NC.

MDA-100D.title: Introduction to the Health Professions
MDA-100D.description: An introduction to the health professions, through lectures, discussions, clinical experience, and visits to health care delivery sites; relationships with other clinicians and the community. Graded CR/NC.

MDA-101.title: Health Professions: Prospects and Preparation
MDA-101.description: Presentations by health professionals, introduced by faculty members from relevant academic units and followed by discussion with the speakers. Not available for degree credit. Graded CR/NC. Recommended preparation: BISC 120L or BISC 220L; CHEM 105aL.

MDA-140.title: Practicum in Multimedia Authorship
MDA-140.description: Introduction to the expressive potential of multimedia as a critical and creative tool, supplementing traditional forms of academic work. Requires concurrent enrollment in a designated course. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Internship for Liberal Arts: Work and Career -- Theory and Practice
MDA-250.title: Internship for Liberal Arts: Work and Career -- Theory and Practice
MDA-250.description: Students explore different understandings of work and career in American society while testing theories in an actual work setting.

synonyms: The Art and Adventure of Leadership
MDA-365.title: The Art and Adventure of Leadership
MDA-365.description: Areas of knowledge and kinds of competencies that are fundamental to the study and practice of leadership in a variety of settings.

MDA-399B.title: Team Research Communities
MDA-399B.description: Cross-disciplinary inquiry in the liberal arts. Individual student and group projects contributing to the team's collaborative research report.

MDA-450.title: Individual Program of Study
MDA-450.description: An individual educational project approved by a faculty committee, combining directed research with internships, service learning, artistic or literary production, and/or other relevant educational activities. Open only to sophomore, junior or senior standing.

MDA-460.title: Collaborative Learning Project
MDA-460.description: A project approved by a faculty committee, requiring students to collaborate on research or an original work in the literary, plastic or performing arts. Open only to sophomore, junior or senior standing. Graded CR/NC.

MUCM-490.title: Directed Research
MUCM-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

MUCM-542.title: Choral Literature II
MUCM-542.description: Nineteenth and Twentieth Century choral works; criteria for program building.

MUCM-543.title: Seminar in Choral Music
MUCM-543.description: Advanced choral techniques; historical, analytical and performance problems.

MUCM-590.title: Directed Research
MUCM-590.description: Supervised research in preparation for the Master's recital. Graded CR/NC.

MUCM-643.title: Seminar in Choral Music II
MUCM-643.description: Continuation of MUCM-543, with concentration on the conducting problems in major choral-orchestral works.

MUCM-694.title: Treatise
MUCM-694.description: A major research paper designed to complement performance studies in choral music. Credit upon acceptance of treatise. Graded CR/NC.

MUCH-572.title: Sacred Music Administration
MUCH-572.description: Developing, maintaining and administering the music program of the church or other religious institutions. Programming, staffing, developing budgets, techniques and repertoire for the graded choir program, handbell choir and other ensembles.

MUCO-101.title: Fundamentals of Music Theory
MUCO-101.description: An introductory course in music theory required for those majors in need of remedial training, and available to the general student who wishes to develop music writing skills. Not available for credit to B.M. and B.A. music majors. Recommended preparation: ability to read music

MUCO-130B.title: Basics of Music Theory
MUCO-130B.description: Introduction to music theory for music minors; scales, intervals, principles of common practice harmony; melodic, harmonic, and structural analysis; 20th century developments. Not available for credit to BM majors.

MUCO-133B.title: Theory I
MUCO-133B.description: a: Notation, scales, intervals; introduction to counterpoint; harmonic principles of the common practice period; analysis, written work. b: Continuation of 133a; elements of form; application of analysis to performance. Concurrent registration in Aural Skills required.

MUCO-135.title: Counterpoint I
MUCO-135.description: The study of the techniques of modal counterpoint; exercises in two-, three-, and four-part writing in 16th century style.

MUCO-137B.title: Introduction to Composition
MUCO-137B.description: Beginning exercises in composition, study and class discussion of assigned scores and recordings.

MUCO-221B.title: Composition for Non-Majors
MUCO-221B.description: Introduction to the composition of concert music. Includes set exercises, free composition, study of selected compositions. Intended for qualified students not majoring in composition. Not available for degree credit to composition majors.

MUCO-233B.title: Theory II
MUCO-233B.description: a: Analysis of representative pieces from the classic and romantic periods; exercises in composition. b: Survey of 20th century developments; composition utilizing 20th century techniques.

MUCO-235.title: Counterpoint II
MUCO-235.description: Studies in tonal counterpoint; two-, three-, and four-part counterpoint in 18th century style; polyphonic variations, inventions.

MUCO-237B.title: Composition I
MUCO-237B.description: Smaller structural units, binary and ternary forms; rondo; variations.

MUCO-250.title: Songwriting I
MUCO-250.description: Development of musical and lyrical skills, composing, listening, analysis, and critiques of popular original music.

MUCO-252.title: Songwriting II: Arranging and Performing
MUCO-252.description: Continuation of Songwriting I with emphasis on development of arrangements and performance of original popular music in preparation for songwriting showcases.

MUCO-254.title: Songwriting III: Demo Production
MUCO-254.description: Music arranging and recording of original songs for demonstration purposes including mixing, editing, functions of midi and production techniques.

MUCO-300.title: Theory Review
MUCO-300.description: Review of materials covered in Theory I and II. For students whose entrance examination in music theory indicates the need for further study.

MUCO-321.title: Composition for Non-Majors II
MUCO-321.description: Individual instruction in composition for non-composition majors. Continuation of MUCO 221abx. Not open to B.M. in Composition majors. (Duplicates credit in former MUCO 421abx.)

MUCO-333.title: Aural Skills Review
MUCO-333.description: Review of the materials covered in Aural Skills I, II, III. For students whose entrance examination in aural skills indicates the need for further study.

MUCO-336B.title: Orchestration II
MUCO-336B.description: Intermediate exercises in orchestration, including scoring for chamber ensembles and orchestra; study of the history of orchestration.

MUCO-337B.title: Composition II
MUCO-337B.description: Continuation of MUCO 237; composition in larger forms.

MUCO-338.title: Elementary Orchestration
MUCO-338.description: Range, techniques, timbre, transposition of orchestral instruments; exercises in orchestration. Not available for credit to theory and composition majors. Recommended preparation: MUCO 233b

MUCO-339.title: Orchestration Review
MUCO-339.description: Review of materials covered in elementary orchestration; for students whose entrance examination in orchestration indicates a need for further study.

synonyms: Instrumental Music of Debussy and Ravel
MUCO-425.title: Instrumental Music of Debussy and Ravel
MUCO-425.prereq_text: (MUCO-336A and MUCO-338 and MUHL-331 and MUHL-332)
MUCO-425.description: Critical examination of the piano, chamber, and orchestral scores; comparison of styles, techniques and aesthetics of these "Impressionist" composers.

MUCO-435.title: Counterpoint III
MUCO-435.description: Canon and fugue; 19th and 20th century developments.

MUCO-437B.title: Composition III
MUCO-437B.description: Individual instruction in composition; preparation for senior recital. Not intended for SMPTV students.

MUCO-438.title: Arranging for Marching Band
MUCO-438.description: Fundamental concepts; instrumental capabilities; notation; color and scoring; modulation; percussion writing.

MUCO-439.title: Band Arranging
MUCO-439.description: Characteristics and use of individual instruments; writing for separate choirs; chamber and solo writing; scoring piano, organ, and orchestral music for band.

MUCO-440B.title: Composition for Films and Television
MUCO-440B.description: Planning, timing, composing, and orchestrating music for dramatic and documentary films and television programs.

MUCO-442B.title: History of Film Music Scoring
MUCO-442B.description: A comprehensive survey of the craft of composing music for motion pictures and television, combining film music history and score analysis, geared specifically to composers. Open only to students in the Advanced Studies Certificate Program in Scoring for Motion Pictures and Television and the BM in Composition (Film Scoring).

MUCO-443B.title: Film Score Analysis and Preparation
MUCO-443B.description: Applied techniques in film music analysis and preparation for scoring.

MUCO-470.title: Electro-acoustic Composition
MUCO-470.description: Electronic music for the composer: history of means and styles, aesthetic issues and practical problems, computer usages, bibliography and repertoire. Recommended preparation: MUEA 474a

MUCO-490.title: Directed Research
MUCO-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not avaliable for graduate credit.

synonyms: Introduction to the Analysis of Tonal Music
MUCO-501.title: Introduction to the Analysis of Tonal Music
MUCO-501.description: Survey of common practice period (1650-1900) approaches to phrase design, tonal organization and type-forms (binary, ternary, rondo, sonata.)

synonyms: Introduction to the Analysis of Post-Tonal Music
MUCO-502.title: Introduction to the Analysis of Post-Tonal Music
MUCO-502.description: Introductory survey of 20th/21st century approaches to the organization of pitch (serial, modal, extended tonal, etc.), rhythm, texture and form.

MUCO-521.title: Composition for Non-Majors III
MUCO-521.description: Individual instruction in composition. Not open to graduate students in composition. Prerequisite: submission of portfolio of musical compositions.

synonyms: Sketching and Scoring for Film and TV
MUCO-522B.title: Sketching and Scoring for Film and TV
MUCO-522B.description: Applying the techniques of music compositions, orchestration and conducting towards creating original dramatic scores for film and TV.

synonyms: Advanced Application of Film Music Technology
MUCO-523B.title: Advanced Application of Film Music Technology
MUCO-523B.description: Appliying advanced state of the art technologies to the art of film music, including synthesizers, samplers, digital audio workstations and hard disk recording.

MUCO-536.title: Advanced Orchestration I
MUCO-536.description: Continuation of Orchestration III with emphasis on contemporary techniques.

MUCO-537.title: Advanced Composition I
MUCO-537.description: For graduates with evidence of preparation for advanced work.

synonyms: Analytical Approaches to Post-Tonal Music from 1908-1950
MUCO-538B.title: Analytical Approaches to Post-Tonal Music from 1908-1950
MUCO-538B.description: Continuation of MUCO 538a; tweleve-tone methods, just tuning systems, new approaches to rhythm, texture timbre.

synonyms: Individual Instruction in Advanced Film Music Composition
MUCO-545.title: Individual Instruction in Advanced Film Music Composition
MUCO-545.description: Private instruction in composition and conducting for film and television.

MUCO-560B.title: Music Editing for Film
MUCO-560B.description: Develop and implement state of the art techniques in joining music and film.

MUCO-590.title: Directed Research
MUCO-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
MUCO-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO-633A.title: Advanced Analysis of Tonal Music
MUCO-633A.description: Application of Schenkerian techniques to large works.

MUCO-633B.title: Advanced Analysis of Tonal Music
MUCO-633B.description: Criticisms and extensions of Schenker, semiotic approaches, theories of rhythmic structure.

MUCO-637.title: Advanced Composition II
MUCO-637.description: Continuation of MUCO 537. For students holding the M.M. degree in composition.

MUCO-790.title: Research
MUCO-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO-794A.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO-794B.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO-794C.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO-794D.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

MUCO-794Z.title: Doctoral Dissertation
MUCO-794Z.description: Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Music and Movement: The Orff Approach
MUED-440A.title: Music and Movement: The Orff Approach
MUED-440A.description: Orff Schulwerk techniques in rhythmic and melodic training through speech, singing, body percussion, playing Orff instruments, improvisation, and elemental movement. Certification available.

MUED-443.title: Teaching Vocal Jazz
MUED-443.description: Strategies for teaching the principles of vocal jazz; historical perspective, repertoire, recordings, improvisation, scat, accompaniment, amplification, rehearsing, teaching sequences. No prior jazz experience necessary.

MUED-474.title: Directed Teaching: Public School Music
MUED-474.description: Observation and teaching under the guidance of a university supervisor and a directing teacher. Admission by Committee on Personnel and Credentials.

synonyms: Music for the Elementary Classroom Teacher
MUED-479.title: Music for the Elementary Classroom Teacher
MUED-479.description: The nature and structure of music, its processes, and its notational symbols. Not available for credit to music majors. Recommended preparation: MUED 330

synonyms: Philosophical and Psychological Foundations of Music Education
MUED-503.title: Philosophical and Psychological Foundations of Music Education
MUED-503.description: Implications of psychology of music and aesthetic theory for music teaching and learning.

MUED-505.title: Teaching and Learning Music
MUED-505.description: Studies of the latest resources concerning the teaching and learning of music so that musicians can function more effectively as both teachers and performers.

MUED-520.title: Early Childhood Music
MUED-520.description: An overview of significant developmental issues, current research, and appropriate practices for children from birth through age eight. Professor-guided practicum teaching.

MUED-524.title: Teaching and Conducting Instrumental Ensembles
MUED-524.description: Study of the methods and materials needed to rehearse an instrumental ensemble in K-12 settings. Includes conducting and rehearsal techniques, literature selection, score analysis.

MUED-526.title: Teaching General/Choral Music for Instrumentalists
MUED-526.description: Study of psychomotor and cognitive learning in K-12 classes. Vocal/choral music in classroom settings; techniques and repertoire for use in K-12 choirs.

MUED-534.title: Teaching and Conducting Choral Ensembles
MUED-534.description: Comprehensive consideration of the choral music program in grades K-12. Topics include: development and care of the voice, audition and rehearsal techniques, conducting, lesson planning.

MUED-536.title: Teaching Instrumental Music for Vocalists
MUED-536.description: An introduction to the pedagogical and acoustical aspects for woodwind, brass, string and percussion instruments. Includes hands-on performance, class discussion and practical application.

synonyms: Motivation and Discipline in the Music Classroom
MUED-540.title: Motivation and Discipline in the Music Classroom
MUED-540.description: An examination of the current research into learning theories and motivation with emphasis on the application of these theories to the music classroom.

MUED-549.title: Directed Teaching: Public School Music
MUED-549.description: Observation and teaching under the guidance of a university supervisor and a directing teacher.

MUED-552.title: Music Education Courseware Development
MUED-552.description: Development of music education courseware using current technology. Two lecture hours per week. Prerequisite: MUED-452.

MUED-590.title: Directed Research
MUED-590.description: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MUED-592.title: Final Project
MUED-592.description: Required for the Master of Music Education degree. Credit upon acceptance. Prerequisite: 500. Graded CR/NC.

MUED-594A.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MUED-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MUED-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
MUED-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MUED-604.title: Preparing School Music Teachers
MUED-604.description: Analysis of best practices in teacher training; faculty, curriculum, schedule, materials, methods, and supervision of directed teaching. Prerequisite: three years of teaching music in public schools or two years of college teaching.

MUED-790.title: Research
MUED-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

synonyms: Advanced Research Methods in Music Education
MUED-793.title: Advanced Research Methods in Music Education
MUED-793.description: Continuation of MUED 792. Research design, sampling, data collection and analysis. Final report.

MPGU-120A.title: Beginning Pop/Rock Guitar
MPGU-120A.description: Introduction to the performance technique of pop/rock guitar as well as music theory fundamentals, exploring repertoire by artists such as The Beatles and Dave Matthews.

MPGU-120B.title: Beginning Pop/Rock Guitar
MPGU-120B.description: Introduction to the performance technique of pop/rock guitar as well as music theory fundamentals, exploring repertoire by artists such as The Beatles and Dave Matthews.

MPGU-120C.title: Beginning Pop/Rock Guitar
MPGU-120C.description: Introduction to the performance technique of pop/rock guitar as well as music theory fundamentals, exploring repertoire by artists such as the Beatles and Dave Matthews.

MPGU-120D.title: Beginning Pop/Rock Guitar
MPGU-120D.description: Introduction to the performance technique of pop/rock guitar as well as music theory fundamentals, exploring repertoire by artists such as the Beatles and Dave Matthews.

MPGU-121.title: Intensive Beginning Pop/Rock Guitar
MPGU-121.description: Introduction to the performance technique of pop/rock guitar as well as music theory fundamentals, exploring repertoire by artists such as the Beatles and Dave Matthews. (Duplicates credit in MPGU 120abcd.)

MPGU-125.title: Beginning Fingerstyle/Chord Guitar
MPGU-125.description: Basic fingerstyle guitar, learned through the study of such pieces as "Greensleeves," "Malaguena," and "Minuet" (Bach); song accompaniment patterns and music notation for the beginner.

MPGU-126.title: Easy Fingerstyle Beatles
MPGU-126.description: Techniques of classical guitar applied to the study of five to eight Beatles songs, from "Hey Jude" to "Blackbird." No guitar or music background required.

synonyms: Functional Skills for Studio Guitarists I
MPGU-159.title: Functional Skills for Studio Guitarists I
MPGU-159.description: Study of technique, theory, and aural skills as applied to guitar; fingerboard organization of melodic and chordal topics; sight reading.

MPGU-257.title: Classical Guitar Performance Class
MPGU-257.description: Technical problems; solo and ensemble literature; interpretation; professional preparation. Required of first and second year Classical Guitar majors each semester in residence.

synonyms: Functional Skills for Studio Guitarists II
MPGU-258.title: Functional Skills for Studio Guitarists II
MPGU-258.description: Melodic and chordal topics applied to the total fingerboard; successful completion required for Junior standing. Prereq: MUPF 159

MPGU-300.title: Non-Major Individual Instruction
MPGU-300.description: Intermediate and advanced instruction designed for non-music majors. Not available for credit to music majors. Recommended preparation: MPGU 101x.

MPGU-301.title: Individual Instruction
MPGU-301.description: Intermediate and advanced instruction on secondary instrument for music majors, on principal instrument for music minors and B.A. music majors. Open only to music majors and minors.

synonyms: Evolution of the Guitar in the United States
MPGU-416.title: Evolution of the Guitar in the United States
MPGU-416.description: Historical survey of styles, literature and performance practice; emphasis on playing technique and interpretation. A time-line study relating guitar to popular music and historical events.

synonyms: Advanced Topics in Classical Guitar History and Literature
MPGU-427.title: Advanced Topics in Classical Guitar History and Literature
MPGU-427.description: An in-depth study of major works for lute, vihuela and classical guitar, with emphasis on early music and the music of the 20th century. Recommended preparation: MPGU 426

MPGU-428B.title: Improvisation and Arranging for Guitar
MPGU-428B.description: Principles of improvisation and impromptu arranging; comparison and application of techniques and musical styles of the various kinds of guitars and related fretted instruments.

MPGU-457.title: Classical Guitar Performance Class
MPGU-457.description: Technical problems; solo and ensemble literature. Required of all third and fourth year classical guitar majors each semester in residence.

MPGU-490.title: Directed Research
MPGU-490.description: Individual research and readings. NOT AVAILABLE FOR GRADUATE CREDIT.

MPGU-501.title: Individual Instruction
MPGU-501.description: Secondary instruction for graduate music majors or instruction for graduate non-music majors.

MPGU-554.title: Graduate Certificate Performance
MPGU-554.description: Individual instruction and related lab participation for Graduate Certificate students.

MPGU-557.title: Advanced Classical Guitar Performance Class
MPGU-557.description: Study of advanced classical guitar solo and ensemble literature; interpretation; professional preparation, and other topics appropriate for group study. Prerequisite: bachelor's degree with music major; principle instrument, classical guitar.

MPGU-558.title: Advanced Studio Guitar Performance Class
MPGU-558.description: Study of advanced studio guitar and ensemble literature; interpretation; professional preparation, and other topics appropriate for group study. Prerequisite: bachelor's degree with music major: principle instrument, studio guitar.

MPGU-590.title: Directed Research
MPGU-590.description: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MPGU-653.title: Performance
MPGU-653.description: Individual or master class instruction for D.M.A. Performance majors.

MPGU-754.title: Artist Diploma Perfomance
MPGU-754.description: Individual instruction and related lab participation for Artist Diploma students.

MPGU-790.title: Research
MPGU-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

MUHL-232.title: Music History II
MUHL-232.description: A study of the musical styles and genres from c. 1680 to c. 1850 within their historical context. Detailed analysis of selected works.

MUHL-315.title: Music and Culture
MUHL-315.description: Gateway to the B.A. degree in music. Western and non-Western music in its socio-cultural context. Not available for credit to B.M. majors. An ability to read music highly recommended.

MUHL-332.title: Studies in Musical Culture
MUHL-332.description: Special musical repertoires, issues, and critical problems; emphasis determined by the department. Recommended preparation: MUHL 231, MUHL 232, MUHL 331, MUCO 232b, MUCO 233b.

MUHL-333.title: Music History Review
MUHL-333.description: Supervised review of the materials covered in undergraduate music history courses for students whose music history examinations indicate the need for further study.

MUHL-403.title: Introduction to Armenian Music
MUHL-403.description: Folk and church music; text, origins, genres, and general characteristics.

MUHL-490.title: Directed Research
MUHL-490.description: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

MUHL-561.title: Studies in World Music II
MUHL-561.description: The indigenous and syncretic musics of the post-Soviet political landscape, the Far East, the Middle East, and Latin America.

MUHL-570.title: Research Materials and Techniques
MUHL-570.description: Introduction to music research, information science, and technical writing. Required of all graduate students majoring in music.

MUHL-574.title: Music of the Renaissance
MUHL-574.description: Chief musical developments in Western Europe from the middle of the 14th to the end of the 16th.

MUHL-577.title: Music of the 19th Century
MUHL-577.description: Vocal and instrumental music of the Romantic era from late Beethoven through Brahms.

MUHL-578.title: Music Since 1900
MUHL-578.description: Musical developments in Europe and the Americas from 1900 to the present.

MUHL-584.title: Special Studies in Renaissance Music
MUHL-584.description: Music problems and composers of the period. Specific emphasis to be determined by the department.

synonyms: Special Studies in the Music of the Classical Period, 1730-1800
MUHL-586.title: Special Studies in the Music of the Classical Period, 1730-1800
MUHL-586.description: Music problems and composers of the period.

MUHL-588.title: Special Studies in Music Since 1900
MUHL-588.description: Music problems and composers of the period. Specific emphasis to be determined by the department.

synonyms: Seminar in Renaissance Repertories and Performance Practice
MUHL-589.title: Seminar in Renaissance Repertories and Performance Practice
MUHL-589.description: Study and discussion of Renaissance music sources and performance practice treatises.

MUHL-594A.title: Master's Thesis
MUHL-594A.description: Credit on acceoptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MUHL-594B.title: Master's Thesis
MUHL-594B.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MUHL-594Z.title: Master's Thesis
MUHL-594Z.description: Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.

MUHL-681.title: Studies in Musicology
MUHL-681.description: Close study of musical repertories and issues (particularly ones transcending period divisions), with emphasis on recent scholarship and methodologies.

MUHL-790.title: Research
MUHL-790.description: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.
